Re: Prefabricated Schools

I have Mr. Neary's Army Signals message of October 23rd wherein we are advised that the purchase of prefabricated school buildings will be recommended and are requested to secure a similar tender from Mr. Van Norman. It is noted that Mr. Buck prefers the Precision Housing Company type of prefabricated building and that a competitive tender will result in the obtaining of authority. While we are pleased to know that some progress is being made, it would appear that in making this request several points have been overlooked, namely:

(1) Precision Housing Company's buildings are not prefabricated - they are precut and without a reasonably close estimate of erection costs in each case a comparison of tenders would be of no value.

(2) The time element, if erection is to be carried out this Fall, is of the utmost importance. It is reasonable to suppose that it would take much longer to erect a precut building than a prefabricated building to a point where work could be carried on inside during the winter months. I doubt very much if Superintendent Anfield could arrange for the erection of a precut building to the point where the roof is on at the time available having in mind that he has available a minimum of skilled labour. His proposal is based on the erection of a prefabricated building and if we are to consider a precut building it will be necessary for him to revise his entire proposal.
(3) Prefabricated Structures quote $9,765.00 f.o.b. factory on a two-room school with attached teacherage including insulation for walls and ceiling, less concrete brickwork, plumbing, wiring, heating equipment and paint. Precision Housing Company previously quoted $24,480.00 f.o.b. Vancouver on a two-room school with teacherage, which price included plumbing, heating and wiring, or if without these facilities deducting $1,800.00, reference my letter of May 18th last and enclosures.

(4) Prefabricated Structures are in a position to make delivery within three weeks of receipt of an order whereas previous experience with Precision Housing Company, reference our negotiations with them for a precut building for office and medical use at Williams Lake, indicates that considerable time is required for the production of working drawings necessary as a preliminary to the setting of material. I doubt whether Precision Housing Co. could give us delivery in three weeks.

(5) You will recall that we received two tenders on the proposed two-room school at Fort Babine, one from National All-Steel Buildings and the other from Precision Housing Co., the latter in the amount of $67,000.00, which should be a fair indication of what it will cost to erect a precut building at any one of the three points in the Skeena River Agency, whereas Mr. Anfield estimates that a prefabricated building can be erected complete for $35,000.00.

In conclusion may I suggest in view of the number of prefabricated school buildings which have been constructed in B.C., most of which have now been inspected by Mr. Drey and other officials, some cognizance should be taken of the views which they have expressed with regard to the suitability of such buildings. I would recommend that this and previous submissions be used as the basis for recommending purchase of prefabricated two-room schools with teacherages at the earliest possible date and feel that any further delay will necessitate the postponement of our entire school construction program in the Skeena River Agency until next year.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
October 26, 1949.

Re: Your Army Signals or Oct. 25, 1949

I forwarded to you today, a copy of our radio message to Greenville. It is to be hoped that you will provide an accountable advance to clear up wages incurred to date on preparing these sites. This money will not be lost in any case, as whatever the Department do with regard to type of structure, the work proceeded with will be of value.

With regard to copy of your letter of October 24th, file 12-11-3-168 to the Department. I agree that unless we can get these buildings up and roofed, work cannot go beyond the concrete stage this year, as the structures will be filled with snow. It is still considered that if the Department will authorize this work to go ahead, roofs, can be put on the buildings at Hartley Bay and Greenville by Year's end. At Kincolith we should be satisfied to get the site excavated and concrete put in. It is considered that the Precision Cut Buildings are out as far as we are concerned. I have had no experience with this type of building and would hesitate to accept responsibility for any construction on a day labour basis. I am satisfied that the Pre-fab Structures are ideal for these three school, and should be used.

F. Earl Anfield
Indian Superintendent

Re: Prefabricated School - Skeena Agency

I have Colonel Neary's Army Signals Message of November 4th, wherein we are asked to confirm that Mr. Van Norman's Company are not now producing prefabricated schools and that the price of Prefabricated structures Limited building still remains at $9,785.00.

Mr. Van Norman is out of town at the moment and will be away for ten days and I hesitate to approach the Precision Housing Company, for whom he is the architect, as previous experience with them indicates that they are willing to commit themselves to the production of anything, if given sufficient time, but the preparation of plans, production drawings, etc., takes so long that a further prolonged delay would be inevitable. Apart from this, it can be stated that the Precision Housing Company do not produce prefabricated buildings; their activities are limited to the pre-cutting of materials for use in more or less standard construction. None of these pre-cut pieces are assembled at the factory and actually all that is saved is the necessity of cutting material at the site and a certain amount of waste. This method of construction could hardly be considered prefabrication. In the case of Prefabricated Structures buildings the walls are assembled in 4', 8' and 12' sections. The roof sections are built up in trusses, windows and doors are already hung in their frames and it is only a matter of fitting the sections together. This method of construction is, in my opinion, prefabrication.

I am prepared to contact Mr. Van Norman on his return to Vancouver if you so desire, but having in mind that ten days will elapse, followed by a further indefinite period before plans and production drawings can be prepared, etc., I think negotiations with Precision Housing Company would be futile at this time, unless we are to postpone school construction in the Skeena River Agency until next year.

Prefabricated Structures have confirmed their quotation of April 12th
...at and I would ask that I be advised by Army Signals as soon as the necessary Order in Council covering the purchase of three buildings from them, is secured, so that production may be put under way at once. The Company have assured us of delivery within three weeks from receipt of the order or possibly sooner.

W.S. Arnell,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Re: Kincolith, Hartley Bay and Lakelseap Schools

Immediately prior to receipt of Mr. Neary's Army Signal of September 2nd with regard to school construction at the above-mentioned points I had an opportunity of discussing these three projects with Supt. Anfield who shared our concern at the apparent lack of progress being made. Mr. Anfield, reference his letter of September 2nd attached, feels that the solution to our problem of school construction at these three points is the erection of prefabricated two-room schools similar in construction to the building which has just been erected at Metlakatla. This is the opinion which we have had for some time and as a matter of fact the only reason we have not advanced the opinion previously is that we wished to first determine what response would be received to our advertisement for tenders on the construction of standard school buildings.

You will note Mr. Anfield's comments regarding the Metlakatla school building and the approval expressed by the Provincial School Inspector. I think it is quite apparent that the prefabricated buildings are suitable structures for school use and obviously erection costs are less. A plan of Prefabricated Structures' two-classroom building with teacherage is attached and I should like to be advised by Army Signals, if possible, if in view of what we consider to be an unsatisfactory response to advertisements for standard school construction, consideration can be given to the erection of

Kuper Island Residential School.

I have been trying to assess the actual repair work to the plumbing and heating system which has been done at Kuper Island this year.

We are endeavouring to have a thorough inspection made of all heating and plumbing systems in Indian residential schools and as you are aware, work is being carried out or is being planned at Lajos, Sechelt and Alert Bay. These projects are being carried out in accordance with plans and specifications as prepared by Mr. Hargreaves after his visit last year.

I feel that we should ask the Lands and Development Services Branch to have Mr. Hargreaves do another inspection trip and would appreciate hearing from you as to whether he should visit Kuper Island and also as to what other schools require his services.

I think that in this way we can get all our schools thoroughly overhauled insofar as plumbing and heating is concerned.

Mr. Kosner will of course do similar work for the electrical repairs required.

Bernard F. Murray,
Superintendent of Education.
Memorandum:

DIRECTOR,

Prefabricated Schools - Skeena River Agency.

Please find hereunder self-explanatory correspondence from Mr. Arneil and from Mr. Anfield concerning the purchase of a tractor with hydraulic loader and bulldozer blade for the erection of the three prefabricated schools in the Skeena Agency.

You are well acquainted with this region and realize the necessity of having some motive power on the beach if we are to move the supplies up to the school site. I feel that the Welfare Vote could bear more of the cost than indicated by Mr. Arneil but possibly Colonel Jones might wish to be consulted in this regard.

The main thing is to decide whether this equipment is essential and if so to order it at once. Otherwise we will have to make other arrangements for moving the heavy materials provided up to the school sites.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Re: School Construction - Skeena River Agency

Since receipt of Mr. Neary's Army Signals message of November 18th advising us of the approval by Order-in-Council of the purchase of three prefabricated schools for erection in the Skeena River Agency we have arranged for the supply of cement, gravel, form lumber, etc., and are assured by Prefabricated Structures Ltd., that the first building will be ready for shipment November 30th.

During the course of our correspondence with you in connection with these three construction projects Supt. Anfield, reference his letter of October 3rd and enclosures attached, made a submission for the supply of power equipment for transferring materials from the beaches to the school sites, for excavating, levelling, etc., and although at that time in view of the comparatively large expenditure involved I was somewhat hesitant at recommending his proposal I have since had an opportunity of discussing the matter with him and have carefully investigated the use of the type of equipment requested for the purpose he has in mind and feel that the expenditure is warranted.

You will note that Mr. Anfield asked for a gasoline driven concrete mixer which we have already supplied and a Model "MC" tractor and a Horn-draulic loader with bulldozer blade. We have secured competitive quotations on similar equipment from Pacific Tractor and Equipment Ltd., and A.B. Wing Ltd., both of whom quote on Oliver Model HG.

Re: School Construction - Skeena River Agency

Since receipt of Mr. Neary's Army Signals message of November 18th advising us of the approval by Order-in-Council of the purchase of three prefabricated schools for erection in the Skeena River Agency we have arranged for the supply of cement, gravel, form lumber, etc., and are assured by Prefabricated Structures Ltd., that the first building will be ready for shipment November 30th.

During the course of our correspondence with you in connection with these three construction projects Supt. Anfield, reference his letter of October 3rd and enclosures attached, made a submission for the supply of power equipment for transferring materials from the beaches to the school sites, for excavating, levelling, etc., and although at that time in view of the comparatively large expenditure involved I was somewhat hesitant at recommending his proposal I have since had an opportunity of discussing the matter with him and have carefully investigated the use of the type of equipment requested for the purpose he has in mind and feel that the expenditure is warranted.

You will note that Mr. Anfield asked for a gasoline driven concrete mixer which we have already supplied and a Model "MCP" tractor and a Horn-draulic loader with bulldozer blade. We have secured competitive quotations on similar equipment from Pacific Tractor and Equipment Ltd., and A.B. Wing Ltd., both of whom quote on Oliver Model H6.
tractors. Actually there is very little difference in the cost of this machine and the John Deere, Model "N" but it is felt that the latter is more suitable for our requirements, particularly if we purchase the Model "N" tractor with bulldozer blade and belt pulley and the Hydraulic Large Standard Loader with Horn dirt bucket. It is felt that with this equipment all excavating, back-filling and levelling for the three schools can be carried out in addition to which the tractor could move gravel, cement, form lumber, building sections, etc., from a scow at the beach to the school site. The total expenditure involved amounts to something less than $4,000. It is felt that if we divide part of this cost proportionately amongst the three schools to be erected immediately and keep in mind the future use of the equipment in not only the Skeens River but the Babine Agency the expenditure is warranted and as a matter of fact failing this I think it is quite obvious we will have to provide some form of motive power to transport materials from the beaches to the respective school sites. I would suggest and recommend that the cost of the equipment be divided as follows:

Lakslap school - $1,000
Kincolith " - $1,000
Hartley Bay " - $1,000
Welfare Vote 515-13 - $969.13

I think the value of such equipment in connection with our housing program for clearing building sites, excavating, etc., is quite apparent and we can reasonably charge the amount above-mentioned to the Housing division of the Welfare Vote.

As mentioned above the first building will be ready for shipment November 30th and it is considered essential that if the supply of this equipment is approved the order be placed prior to that date for immediate delivery.

We have prepared a new requisition based on the quotation from Finning Tractor and Equipment Co. Ltd., to whose price we have added Sales Tax which presumably the Department is obliged to pay in this case.

Our school construction program for next year was recently reviewed with District School Inspector Dewar having in mind a recent suggestion from the Department that it might be possible to purchase before March 31st a number of prefabricated school buildings for erection in the new fiscal year. Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Moriestown Indian Day School
Chehalis Indian Day School
Kispiox Teacherage

Included in our Main Estimates for 1950-51 are the following three projects in the Province of British Columbia:

Moriestown - Babine Agency - two-room school/residence - $35,000.
Chehalis - New Westminster Agency - two-room school/residence - $35,000.
Kispiox - Babine Agency - teacherage - $10,000.

Whereas in other provinces we have met with considerable success in our day school building programme, such has not been the case in British Columbia. For example, at Ucluelet on the west coast of Vancouver Island, we advertised for tenders for the erection of a two-room school and attached teacher's residence and the lowest tender for standard construction was $42,612. The same school has been built by the Department in Saskatchewan for $29,000. We finally erected a Quonset school at Ucluelet.

Therefore, due to the scarcity of contractors bidding on our projects and the high prices tendered by them, our officials in British Columbia came to the decision that prefabricated schools should be erected on the reserves listed above. Their decision in this regard has been due to the satisfaction obtained from the company which erected a two-room school and teacherage at Pemberton Meadows in the New Westminster Agency and a one-room school at
Netlakatl in the Skeena River Agency. This company is Prefabricated Structures, Limited, Post Office Box 489, Vancouver, British Columbia, and I attach photographs of the Pemberton Meadows school taken by Inspector Davy.

We are now erecting three such prefabricated schools in the Skeena River Agency and our officials in British Columbia have now recommended the purchase of two more such schools and one teacherage. You will be interested in the following comments concerning our prefabricated school at Netlakatl, submitted by Mr. Indian Superintendent Anfield, under whose supervision the present three schools are being erected:

"I am satisfied that it will wear well, operate economically and that the type of construction is suitable and most adaptable for the type of country in the Skeena Agency. The school has been viewed with considerable approval by the Provincial School Inspector, Mr. J. Shell, at Prince Rupert. It is recommended that two-classroom schools of this type, with teacherages attached, be constructed at Hartley Bay, Greenville and Lincolith, with the least possible delay."

Mr. Arnall, the Indian Commissioner, feels that these buildings are quite satisfactory and points out that they can be erected at a cost considerably less than we could get through standard construction. He also points out that the erection of these schools will provide employment for the Indians as much of the work involved is ordinary labour.

The only other company in British Columbia producing schools of this type is Precision Housing Company, which produces pre-cut schools. These are much more difficult to erect with the type of semi-skilled Indian labour we will have available and are, therefore, not recommended by our field officials. We already have in mind a foreman carpenter who would supervise the erection of these prefabricated schools during the coming summer.

(b) Approval from the Minister for the purchase of a teachersage for the Kispiox Reserve at a cost of £2,765. (I attach a requisition for signature by the Minister and passing to the Departmental Purchasing Agent for this latter building).

I am writing you at the suggestion of Mr. R. F. Davey, Inspector of Education at the Indian Commissioner's Office in Vancouver.

Mr. Davey and I have discussed the possibility of my professional services being retained by your Department in the construction of small schools for Indians students, particularly at Labine Lake. We have made the suggestion that transportable units be used and have shown the Inspector sketch drawings based on this proposal. It would appear that Mr. Davey considers that the idea has some merit but before discussing the matter at greater length he wished to have it referred to you for your approval and views.

In view of the difficulty of obtaining skilled labour in the far North and the short duration of the building season, it seems logical to consider the possibility of pre-fabricating a good percentage of the buildings. This type of building would be flexible and could be added to reduced in capacity according to the population demands of the particular locality. There would also be the added advantage of being able to write-off the cost of the construction within 10 to 15 years at little cost should the policy of your Department change with respect to your Indian charges.

As regards my personal history, I would say that I am a returned man with seven and one half years service overseas in the Royal Canadian Engineers - one year of which was spent on attachment to the Department of External Affairs (Immigration) at Sackville Street, London working with Mr. Cottsworthy. I am fully qualified as an Architect and hold an American Town Planning qualification. I am at present engaged on work for the British Columbia Electric Railway Co., the City of New Westminster and the Burnaby School Board. For the latter Client, I am building a Primary School and two Junior High Schools.
I would add that I am known to the Department of Public Works at Ottawa and was recently named in an Order in Council for the Customs and Immigration Building at Douglas, B.C.

I trust that this suggestion will receive favourable consideration and that you will sanction my proceeding further with this important development.

Yours very truly,

(Kenneth J. Sandbrook)

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Morissetown Indian Day School
Chehalis Indian Day School
Kisplox Teacherage

Included in our Main Estimates for 1950-51 are the following three projects in the Province of British Columbia:

Morissetown - Babine Agency - two-room school/residence - $35,000.
Chehalis - New Westminster Agency - two-room school/residence - $35,000.
Kisplox - Babine Agency - teacherage - $10,000.

Whereas in other provinces we have met with considerable success in our day school building programs, such has not been the case in British Columbia. For example, at Ucluelet on the West Coast of Vancouver Island, we advertised for tenders for the erection of a two-room school and attached teachers' residence and the lowest tender for standard construction was $42,612. The same school has been built by the Department in Saskatchewan for $29,000. We finally erected a quonset school at Ucluelet.

Therefore, due to the scarcity of contractors bidding on our projects and the high prices tendered by them, our officials in British Columbia came to the conclusion that prefabricated schools should be erected on the reserves listed above. Their decision in this regard has been due to the satisfaction obtained from the company which erected a two-room school and teacherage at Pemberton Meadows in the New Westminster Agency and a one-room school at
Metlakatla in the Skeena River Agency. This company is Prefabricated Structures, Limited, Post Office Box 489, Vancouver, British Columbia, and I attach photographs of the Pemberton Meadows school taken by Inspector Davy.

We are now erecting three such prefabricated schools in the Skeena River Agency and our officials in British Columbia have now recommended the purchase of two more such schools and one teachersage. You will be interested in the following comments concerning our prefabricated school at Metlakatla, submitted by Mr. Indian Superintendent Anfield, under whose supervision the present three schools are being erected:

"I am satisfied that it will wear well, operate economically and that the type of construction is suitable and most adaptable for the type of country in the Skeena Agency. The school has been viewed with considerable approval by the Provincial School Inspector, Mr. J. Shell, at Prince Rupert. It is recommended that two-classroom schools of this type, with teachersages attached, be constructed at Hartley Bay, Greenville and Kincolith, with the least possible delay."

Mr. Arnell, the Indian Commissioner, feels that these buildings are quite satisfactory and points out that they can be erected at a cost considerably less than we could get through standard construction. He also points out that the erection of these schools will provide employment for the Indians as much of the work involved is ordinary labour.

The only other company in British Columbia producing schools of this type is Precision Housing Company, which produces pre-cut schools. These are much more difficult to erect with the type of semi-skilled Indian labour we will have available and are, therefore, not recommended by our field officials. We already have in mind a foreman carpenter who would supervise the erection of these prefabricated schools during the coming summer.

- Therefore

(a) Approval of the Submission to Council attached hereto covering the purchase of two prefabricated two-room schools with attached teachersages,

(b) Approval from the Minister for the purchase of a teachersage for the Kispiox Reserve at a cost of $2,764. (I attach a requisition for signature by the Minister and passing to the Departmental Purchasing Agent for this latter building).

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is necessary and funds are provided in the Education Vote, 1950-51 Estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship and Immigration, to provide two two-room Indian day schools with attached teachers' residences on the following reserves:

Norristown Reserve, Babine Indian Agency
Chahalis Reserve, New Westminster Indian Agency,
both in the Province of British Columbia;

THAT it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Norristown and Chahalis Indian Reserves;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C. 1927, provides in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest . . . .";

THAT, due to the very isolated situation of these reserves, there are no builders or contractors in the area nor are outside contractors interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

THAT a competent building company, namely Prefabricated Structures, Limited, Post Office Box 489, Vancouver, British Columbia, has agreed to undertake immediately the provision of two prefabricated two-room schools with attached teachers' residences on these reserves for the sum of $10,475.00 each, f.o.b. Vancouver, plus additional charges for freight, erection supervisor's wages, fare and expenses, estimated at approximately fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00).
THAT it is considered that the provision of these schools is of pressing emergency and within the exception provided in Section 36 above recited and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted to expend a sum not exceeding thirty thousand dollars ($30,000.00) in purchasing from Prefabricated Structures, Limited, Post Office Box 489, Vancouver, British Columbia, a two-room Indian day school with attached teachers' residence at each of the Neskonlum and Ghasalis Indian Reserves, as outlined above, for the sum of $20,475.00 f. o. b. Vancouver, for each project, or a total of $20,950.00 plus freight, erection supervisor's wages, fare and expenses, this being the only arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried to completion in order that the buildings will be available for use by August 1930.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Citizenship and Immigration.

Ottawa, March 30 - Operations of the Priorities Branch, Department of Trade and Commerce, will be terminated April 1, in view of the improved supply of building materials and labour, Rt. Hon. C.D. Howe, Minister of Trade and Commerce, announced today. Priority ratings will cease to have any effect after March 31.

To facilitate the procurement of equipment, materials and supplied by Canadian industries, and for the effective prosecution of World War II, the Priorities Branch was established in the Department of Munitions and Supply early in 1940. During the war, and for the reconversion period which followed, the Branch cooperated closely with the War Production Board and the Civilian Production Administration of the United States Government.

In 1946, a formal system of priority ratings was established to channel building materials required for the construction of housing and other projects essential to the national economy. These included military hospitals, military health and occupational centres, and other military establishments.

Primarily designed to meet the needs of veterans, the policy was broadened in March, 1949 to include civilian homes not exceeding a cost of $10,000. Ratings were assigned to individuals or their contractors where it was established that the house would be legally owned and occupied by the applicant. Included in the authorizations were the units built under the Veterans' Land Act and programs sponsored by Central Mortgage and Housing Corporation, such as Veterans' Rental Housing, Integrated Housing, N.H.A. Control Sales Price dwellings and the Inter-Service Married Quarters program for the Department of National Defence.

During operations from 1946 to date, priority ratings were granted for the construction of 105,691 homes.

Sir:-

I beg to report that I had a conversation with his Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan in Prince Albert on the 13th instant, during which several matters in connection with the operation of our Indian day schools were freely discussed. I have already reported on the situation at Montreal Lake and further reports regarding the Day Schools in that Diocese which I visited on this trip will be forwarded in due course. There are some matters of general interest which the Bishop brought to my attention and I beg to advise you of.

Previous to the present economic depression provision was made for a simple mid-day meal for the Indian children attending day schools. This is a question which I have already brought to the attention of the Department many times. I quite agree with his Lordship with regard to the good effect on the general health of the children as well as on the attendance at the school which this meal has had. I informed his Lordship that in the first instance it was not the intention of the Department to provide a regular meal at mid-day, but provision was made whereby the ingredients for a bowl of nourishing soup was provided. This privilege in some instances was abused with the result that a full meal was provided. I find that in many instances the teachers with the assistance of the Indians have been continuing to provide a warm bowl of soup. I am quite sure that the cost of this special nourishment would not in the aggregate amount to a great deal if properly controlled and would be of great benefit to our Indian children.

The Bishop also brought to my attention that he had received complaints from teachers that the Department no longer provides soap or towelling for the day schools. Where a teacher takes an interest in the cleanliness of the pupils, I understand he has provided this equipment himself. I do not feel that our teachers should be called upon to do this, as their salaries are not large, yet cleanliness should be observed in our classrooms.

There is another matter which I did not feel I had any interest in, but the Bishop suggested that our department might co-operate in bringing about and this is the question of superannuation for teachers. The Department of Education for the Province of Saskatchewan is making provision for a non-contributory scheme of superannuation for its teachers, but no provision is made in the Act for teachers in day schools of the Indian Department. These teachers are not recognized as permanent Civil Servants.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
manent Civil Servants and so no provision is made for pensions for their old age. A teacher moving from a white school to an Indian school in the Province of Saskatchewan forfeits the benefits of his superannuation for the period of service in the Indian school and during that period he is not permitted to contribute to the Teachers Superannuation Fund. It appears to me that, as our schools are now being regularly inspected by Provincial School Inspectors and our teachers capabilities are to a large extent judged by the Inspector and the fact that they hold certificates from the Province, it would not be unreasonable to permit them to contribute to the superannuation provided by the Province. Personally, I feel that the Bishop's attitude in this question is very fair and I promised him that I would bring this question to your attention/my report.

His Lordship also suggested that, if the method of appointing teachers in vogue in the public schools were adopted by the Department when engaging teachers in our Indian day schools, it would not only be an incentive for the teacher to put forth his best efforts to make the work a success, but it would make it an easy matter to release the teacher if his work were found not to be satisfactory. The trustees of our public schools engage a teacher for a certain term. If at the end of the term, the teacher's services are not considered satisfactory he is not re-engaged, and he understands that his continuance depends altogether on the success of his work and the satisfactory report of his Inspector. I feel that the Bishop's suggestion might be worthy of consideration.

Ottawa, March 9, 1935.

Sir:

I have your 300-11 of the 27th ultimo, reporting a conversation you had with His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan, concerning matters affecting the Indian day schools in his diocese.

With reference to the providing of midday meals to the children attending the day schools, an adequate quantity of biscuits is granted each school and, in addition, other supplies are furnished upon application, in so far as funds available for the purpose permit. As explained by you to His Lordship, it is not the intention of the Department to provide a regular meal at midday. If the teachers will forward a requisition, through their local agents, for the supplies required to serve soup, as favourable consideration as possible will be given to authorizing the necessary expenditure for the purchase of the supplies. The Department is well aware of the value of serving a hot lunch, consisting of soup, to the pupils at midday, but we must be guided by the funds at our disposal in deciding on the provisions that can be supplied.

Regarding the supplying of soap and towelling for the day schools, I have to say that a reasonable quantity of these articles is allowed, upon requisitions received through the local Indian agents. The difficulty to overcome is in connection with the washing and care of the towels and the danger of infection by the pupils using each other's towels. However, a reasonable quantity of towelling will be supplied upon request.

Relative to the superannuation of teachers, I would state that teachers at Indian residential schools are not employees of the Department. They are engaged by the Rev. Principal or the church authorities who are directly responsible for the management of the particular institution.

Teachers of Indian day schools are classed as temporary civil servants and, as such, do not come under the Superannuation Act for permanent employees of the Federal Government. From the information available, while some teachers give many years' service at Indian day schools, the average length of employment does not exceed four years.

W. Murison, Esq.,

exceed four years. Regarding the appointment of teachers and dispensing with their services when unsatisfactory, I would say that the Department has authority to approve or disapprove the nomination of a teacher by the church authorities and also to dispense with their services when unsatisfactory. Order in Council 22nd October, 1892.

Indian Affairs:

On a Report dated 17th of October, 1892, from the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs stating that it is advisable to make a change in the manner of carrying on those Industrial Schools in the North West that are wholly supported by the Government. The cost of these Institutions is larger, it is thought, than that for which they might be conducted, and with a view to more economical management, it is deemed advisable and necessary, to adopt some method which would relieve the pressure of present expenditure, and at the same time keep the schools to an equal standard of efficiency and usefulness.

The Minister considers that when the whole cost of an Institution is directly borne by the Government, the same economy by those in charge is not used as would be employed under other conditions; demands under the present system are frequently made for articles and supplies, whereas if the amount to be expended were to take the form more of an annual per capita grant, more effort in the way of economizing would be made.

The Minister states that the actual cost to the Government, as shown under the head of Industrial Schools, does not meet the total expenditure which the present system entails, as there is a small expense in the purchasing and inspection of goods to be added.

The accounts for the past year (1890-91) show that the per capita cost of each child at the Industrial Schools under Qu'Appelle was:

Qu'Appelle ------------ $134.67
Battleford ------------ 175.45
High River ------------ 185.55

It is thought, is higher than it would be if a revised system of economy were exercised, and that the best way to effect the desired decrease would be to place the schools under a per capita grant system similar to that now in operation at Kichener and St. Paul's under Church of England authorities, St. Boniface and Kootenay under the Roman Catholic Church authorities. The per capita system under which these schools are operated by the religious bodies has been found to work satisfactorily.

The Minister therefore recommends that the following be applied to the Industrial Schools in operation in the North West Territories.
MEMORANDUM

Mr. A.B. Williams,
Acting Deputy Superintendent General

Recently my attention was called to the attached Order in Council dated October 22nd, 1892, respecting the Government's policy in connection with expenditures relating to Indian Residential Schools.

While this Order in Council was passed a number of years ago, it is understood that no amending Orders have been issued since; therefore it is still in force.

It is realized of course that at the time this Order in Council was passed most, if not all, of the Residential Schools belonged to the different Churches or Church organizations, and that since then most of the schools have been taken over by the Government. Only a few in the North, I understand, still belong to the Churches.

The financial assistance rendered the Church-owned schools in recent years has included repairs to buildings (material and labour), purchase of laundry, lighting and farming equipment, also grants or contributions towards the salaries of night watchmen.

As this Order in Council has not been observed for many years and the fact that it has not been observed may some day be questioned, it would appear to be desirable to anticipate any possible criticism in the future by obtaining an Order in Council to meet present day conditions and dealing with the essentials, leaving the application to the discretion of The Superintendent and Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

Memorandum:

MR. WARELE

Re: Site plans of Indian Schools.

I am in receipt of your memorandum of the 30th ultimo forwarding plans of five of the Indian Reserves on which new Day Schools will be erected during the current fiscal year.

The plan you forwarded for the Pemberton Reserve was incorrect. There are several Reserves in this Agency and the school will be erected on a different Reserve from that covered by your plan. However, arrangements have been made to secure a plan of the proper Reserve and this will be forwarded to you early next week showing the lots available for a site for this school.

The other four plans have been forwarded to the respective Indian Agents and as soon as they reply the plans will be returned to your Branch.

Director.

THE NEW YORK TIMES, SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1938.

NEW SCHOOLS FOR INDIANS

Five Constructed on Canadian Reserves Last Year

To meet the educational requirements of Canada's increasing Indian population, five day schools were constructed last year at reserves at Rama, Ontario; Quebec; Christian Island, Ontario; Bloodvein, Manitoba; Kinistino, Saskatchewan; and Port Simpson, British Columbia.

With the exception of Kinistino, where a school was established for the first time, all others were built to replace buildings which had become unsuitable for their original purpose. The new schools are modern in every respect and are equipped to provide an educational program designed to meet the needs of the children in the areas to which they are established.

Progressive attempts have been made to bring the educational policy into closer conformity with the actual needs of the children, with special emphasis on manual training and vocational instruction. Residential schools are now equipped to provide worthwhile instruction in such subjects as carpentry, boat-building, tailoring, dressmaking, cooking, handloom weaving and physical culture.

Dear Dr. Fletcher:

Mr. Jackson has asked me to secure, if I can, certain figures relating to the cost of constructing public schools.

We have made provision in the estimates of this year for the construction of 20 Indian day schools and at least one residential school. It is the policy of the Department to construct schools with full basement accommodation and with equipment necessary for a worthwhile vocational or manual training programme. At most of our day schools provision is made for teacher's residence, but in the case of our schools the residence usually forms part of the main building. We have not at any time built separate teachers' cottages since I entered the Department. I am anxious to know if you could let me have figures indicating the cost in Manitoba of erecting one, two, three and four room schools with full basement accommodation in each case.

If I remember correctly, the Department prepared plans and placed these at the disposal of local trustees from time to time. Would it be possible to secure plans for one and two room schools with full basement accommodation? This Branch will be glad to pay the usual charge for such plans.

I am aware, of course, that schools in Manitoba are usually built by local trustees and that

LIGHTING RECOMMENDATION FOR STANDARD SCHOOL CLASSROOM

The standard school classroom has approximately the following dimensions:

Length 30'-32'   Width 23'-24'   Ceiling Height 12'-12'6"

The seating area in this classroom will have approximately these dimensions:

Length 20'-22'   Width 17'

The important blackboard area will be at the front of the room and will be approximately 18' long.

The lighting of this classroom should be divided into two separate sections under the following headings:

(1) General Lighting:

4 Holophane No. C-5540 ceiling type Correctalite units. Using 300 watt Medium Base 6" Light Centre clear Mazda lamps. Calculated initial illumination at desk level -- 25 to 25 foot candles average. Outlets to be located as shown in Figure 1.

(2) Blackboard Lighting:

5 Holophane No. H-790-2 Blackboard lighting units. Using two 150 watt clear Mazda lamps per unit. Calculated initial illumination 35 - 45 foot candles average. Units to be installed as shown in Figure 1. For installation details on other ceiling heights see Figure 3 and Figure 4.

The preceding recommendations are the result of a careful investigation of the problem of classroom lighting. By locating the general lighting units with reference to the seating area rather than the whole room area the wattage per square foot is actually increased in spite of the fact that, to light the whole room area, six units of equal wattage would be required instead of four. It is necessary to point out that this result cannot be obtained unless a lighting unit of suitable distribution such as Holophane No. C-5540 is used.

NOTE - 250 watt 6" L.C. and 200 watt clear Mazda lamps may be used in No. C-5540 without accessories.
The position of the outlets is very important. The four fixtures are placed over and located in relation to the seating area. Being mounted close to the ceiling, they are removed almost entirely from the line of vision of all the pupils. Especially important is the fact that there are no hanging fixtures at the front of the room. (See Fig. 2). When fixtures are located at the front of the classroom they are constantly in the line of vision of the majority of the pupils. Holophane Semi-Direct lighting units are the most efficient type of lighting equipment available for this use. They will produce:

(a) A maximum of useful illumination on the work from the current consumed.

(b) They do not depend on wall and ceiling conditions for results, thus reducing decorating costs to a minimum.

(c) Temporary depreciation due to an accumulation of dust in the fixture is very low and there can be no permanent depreciation to any Holophane glassware.

It is a safe rule that no general lighting fixtures should be hung within twelve feet of the front blackboard; in the case of indirect and semi-indirect fixtures because the light flux from the front ceiling and upper wall over the board interfere with blackboard vision; and in the case of diffusing, direct and semi-direct fixtures because the primary light sources themselves are within the undesirable angles of vision.

It has been definitely proven that proper blackboard lighting is as important as good general lighting in classrooms. Tests conducted with adults, whose eyes have matured, have shown conclusively that the time required to copy unfamiliar material from the board can be cut in half when proper lighting equipment is used.

The Holophane No. H-790-2 Blackboard lighting unit has been scientifically designed to produce uniform high intensity illumination on the blackboard. This high intensity light is obtained from a unit on the ceiling out of the line of vision of teacher and pupils so that no discomfort can be caused by brightness. The Holophane blackboard unit is the only unit for this purpose which has effectively overcome the daylight glare which sometimes makes it impossible for pupils looking toward the windows to see the board.

A comparison of the various types of classroom lighting which can be proposed is given on sheet #2 attached. A study of this chart indicates the following savings in dollars with lighting improvements through the use of the Holophane system:

1. Lower decorating costs
2. Higher illumination between painting and decorating periods
3. Lower cleaning costs
4. Higher illumination between fixture cleaning periods
5. Lower operating costs for current and lamps
6. Higher illumination at reduced wattage
7. Three to five times as much vertical illumination on the blackboard.

Dimensions on Figures 1 and 2 are for Room 25' x 32' and a ceiling height of 12'6" only. For other room sizes use data in Figures 3 and 4.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

Re - Travelling expenses on Indian Affairs Branch work, etc.

Confirming our telephone conversation of the 16th instant, I am outlining herewith a suggested procedure in connection with engineering inspections and handling of work, etc., for your Branch so that our respective officers will have a similar understanding in handling work and expenditure.

It is understood that your Branch will be shortly transferring to us, for travelling expenses, the following amounts:-

$1,500 from Agency Votes,
$1,000 from School Votes.

It is our understanding that the above funds will be utilized by this Branch as follows:-

(a) To cover actual travelling expenses of our engineering staff when engaged on work for which funds have been transferred from your Branch for the undertaking of specific projects.

(b) To cover actual travelling expenses of our engineering staff who might be giving engineering advice to your officers or agents in connection with work they are performing and which is not being undertaken by this Branch.
To cover actual travelling expenses of our engineering staff in making engineering inspections or investigations for your Branch in connection with projects which do not involve immediate work expenditure.

In cases where engineering advice or information is required from this Branch but where the Indian Agent is actually undertaking the work, we will give such information and advice as is required but the Indian Agent will be responsible for the handling of the expenditure, including paylists, payments of accounts, etc.

In cases where the size of the project justifies a transfer of funds to this Branch our Engineer will of course be responsible for the handling of funds and the accounting therefor, including preparation of paylists and the payments of wages and accounts for materials.

Occasionally, border-line cases might arise where the expenditure involved is not large enough to warrant a Treasury Board transfer but where, owing to the nature of the work, you would prefer it to be directly handled by our Engineer rather than by your Indian Agent. In such cases we would be glad if you would forward the advance cheque to his office for transmission, with appropriate instructions, to the Engineer concerned. The latter will then account for the expenditure in the usual way.

It is understood that in this fiscal year certain Schools may be constructed under the direction of your Indian Agent. In such case, we will be glad to supply plans as required and have our engineering or architectural staff make such inspections as you may desire. Our officers on such work would not certify, however, to any of the accounts covering expenditure made.

Would you kindly give the above suggestions your consideration and let me know if you think they will meet your requirements and will be satisfactory to you.

Director.
Ottawa,
May 30, 1939.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

It is my understanding that representations will be made to the Minister by the church authorities at an early date for the construction of Indian residential schools at the following points:

1. Albany (R.C.) James Bay agency, Ontario,
2. Carcross (C.E.) Yukon Territory,
3. Wabasso (C.E.) Lesser Slave Lake agency, Alberta,
4. Whitefish Lake (C.E.) " " " " ,
5. Fort Chipewyan, (R.C.) Athabasca agency, "
6. Sturgeon Lake (R.C.) Lesser Slave Lake agency, Alberta.

The Albany school, with a pupil enrolment of 80, was totally destroyed by fire on August 22, 1939. This was the only residential school on the west coast of James Bay and drew pupils from an area in which there are approximately 800 Roman Catholic Indians.

The church authorities propose that this school be rebuilt and that the new building, which they estimate will cost $100,000, be of fireproof construction throughout. They suggest that payment be made to them in a period of two years or, if this is impossible, that the payments be divided over a three year period. The new school, if constructed, would have accommodation for 100 pupils.

The Carcross (C.E.) school, with an enrolment of 40 pupils, was destroyed by fire on April 17, 1939. This was the only residential school in the Yukon Territory and served -
and served an Indian population of 1356, all of whom, with the exception of 15, are Anglicans.

It is proposed by the representatives of the Anglican church that the school at Carcross be rebuilt and that log construction with asbestos lining in the interior be used throughout. If provision is made for the construction of separate and distinct buildings for the regular classrooms and the dormitories, the estimated cost is $80,000. The pupils enrolled at the Carcross school at the time of the fire are now receiving instruction in a number of dilapidated shacks that have been repaired and made fit for temporary use, in the hope that a new building would be provided next year.

There are at present at Babascan and Whitefish Lake two comparatively small residential schools, operated by the Anglican Church. The total enrolment of these schools at this date is 65. It is my understanding that these schools were originally built by the Anglican Church without cost to the Government.

I have been assured by Dr. Westgate on a number of occasions that these schools are wholly unfit for educational purposes, as both are in an insanitary condition and constitute a great fire hazard and should not be utilized as residential schools.

There is at the present time at Fort Chipewyan a residential school with an enrolment of 40, operated by the Catholic Church in the diocese of Bishop Breymat. During the last six years His Lordship has constantly brought to the attention of the Department the claims of this district for a new school. In this connection I refer to my memorandum to you dated October 30, 1929. It is estimated by the officials of the Survey and Engineering Branch that the construction of a fireproof school at this point, capable of accommodating 100 pupils, would cost approximately $150,000.

At Sturgeon -
At Sturgeon Lake there is a church-owned residential school with an enrolment of 90 pupils. There are 353 Indians, all of whom belong to the Roman Catholic Church, in the Sturgeon Lake area. Bishop Langlois has intimated to us that this building is urgently in need of replacement. However, I have not secured figures with respect to the exact cost of a fire-proof school at Sturgeon Lake.

It is important in my judgment that these requests from the church authorities for residential schools be carefully reviewed at an early date and a decision reached in respect to the extent of our building program for the fiscal year 1940-41, while the estimates of this Branch are still under consideration.

Director.

RAH

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

In response to your request, I am sending forward herewith a memorandum, relating to the operation of Indian residential schools, prepared by the Superintendent of Welfare and Training.

Director.

RAH
Ottawa, May 31, 1940.

Memorandum:

DOCTOR MCGILL

In view of the national crisis in which we find ourselves and the desire on our part to conserve to the utmost extent possible the appropriations available for Indian education, I am of the opinion that a careful review should be undertaken of the number and condition of our residential schools and the best ways and means whereby the cost of their operation can be kept within reasonable bounds without unduly impairing the Government's investment in these institutions - an investment at this date of approximately ten million dollars ($10,000,000.00).

I should state that there has not been at our disposal at any time since I entered the Department the funds necessary to undertake the repairs required at a majority of our residential schools. The decision, therefore, to pay our per capita grants this year on the basis of 85% of the maximum pupilage allowed at each school, coupled with a reduction of the amount available for repairs, purchase of equipment, etc., may not be the best policy to pursue even in a critical period such as the present. I am suggesting, therefore, that it might be more desirable to consider the advisability of closing a number of government-owned and church-owned schools, that are at this date in a somewhat dilapidated condition and which have become acute fire hazards. Before submitting a list of these schools, however, may I refer to the condition of our residential schools, generally. I have no hesitation in stating that the faulty construction of a great many of these schools has imposed upon those responsible for their repair and operation burdens that should never have been imposed, had the original construction conformed to the usual standards of construction recognized as the minimum standards in the construction of public buildings, particularly institutions for the education of children, the hospitalization of the sick, etc. A few examples will illustrate and emphasize the thought I have in mind:

SHUBENACADIE, (R. C.) Shubenacadie, Nova Scotia.

This school, which was completed in 1929, at a cost of $153,000.00, has an enrolment at this date of 160 pupils. Dr. Robertson, in his report on the Maritime Provinces, states:

"Shubenacadie Boarding School -

"This school is beautifully located and is of brick construction, just across the river from Shubenacadie. On the inside of all the walls of
this school there is evidence of a leaking condition, due to the heavy rain and wind storms coming from the south and east. This condition is most noticeable on the east and south walls; on these walls the plaster is badly stained and constantly falling off in many places. This condition, it should be noted, has existed ever since the construction of the building and is believed by the Principal to be due to the brick being porous.

A somewhat similar condition exists at the ALERT BAY (C. E.) Residential School, Kwakwakwaht agency, British Columbia. This school was built in the year 1931 at a cost of $148,000.00.

Mr. J. C. McLean, of the Surveys and Engineering Branch, in a report on this building dated September 21, 1936, states:

"The brick work in this building, I must say, is very porous and unevenly laid, and worst of all, the mortar was mixed with very coarse sand and little cement, which makes the joints of the brick very porous and undoubtedly allows the moisture to penetrate. The work recently done on these walls has been of some benefit, although I consider the clear waterproofing used has not been heavy enough and would therefore recommend waterproofing paint of not less than three coats, on the south and east walls in particular, coupled with careful inspection of all pit-holes and open joints in brick, which should be pointed before painting, and that this be done as early as possible next year, weather permitting. In so doing I consider you may save the metal laths and plaster on the interior of these two walls. The brick throughout the whole building is very unevenly laid and forms small ledges that hold the water which when the wind is blowing will eventually seep through the walls."

The repairing of these walls - the work is only partially completed at this date - has cost us over $3,000.

BIRTLE (Presbyterian) Birtle, Manitoba

This school was built in the year 1931 at a cost of $120,000.00.

Although this is a comparatively new building, heavy expenditures have been necessary in recent years. For example we spent $1,800 on the repainting of the water line in the fiscal year 1933-40. The foundations of this school, which is said to be of fireproof construction, have sunk badly within the last two or three years, with the result that large cracks have appeared in the
in the classrooms and in the dormitories. It is exceedingly difficult to know just what action should be taken in an attempt to repair these cracks, which, I understand, have become very wide. Inspector Hamilton has suggested that the cracks be filled with a pitch mixture and that the floors themselves be covered with Battleship linoleum. However, we have never had the money at our disposal to supply this linoleum or to undertake these repairs.

CECILIA JEFFREY (Presbyterian) Kenora, Ont.

This school was built in the year 1923 at a cost of $80,045.00. The present enrolment is 145 pupils.

It has been necessary to undertake costly repairs at this school within the last year or two. The sewage disposal plant has been reconstructed, but we have not been able to undertake other repairs that appear necessary to the main building. The Secretary of the Women's Missionary Society informs me that a committee, representing their Society, visited the building recently and that the north wall appears to be buckling. She attributes this to faulty eaves troughing and to the fact that the rain has been permitted to run down the walls.

ST. GEORGE'S (Church of England) Lytton, British Columbia.

This school, with an enrolment of 160 pupils, was built in 1928, at a cost of $130,000.

When I visited British Columbia in the spring of 1938, I was informed by the Indian Commissioner for British Columbia that the roof of this school had shown a tendency to leak. He expressed surprise that a flat roof of concrete construction should show this weakness so soon after the erection of the building. He expressed the hope that the necessary repairs could be undertaken without cost to the Department. A new roof, he intimated, would prove very costly.

In the construction of this building, the baths and toilet facilities were so placed that the pupils could not make use of them without endangering their health—at least, so it was alleged by the Commissioner. The work of reconstructing these facilities was undertaken and completed at a cost of $4,330.00 in the year 1938. No action has been taken, however, in respect to the roof repairs.

In striking contrast to these schools and a number of others that might be mentioned, we have the case of the KUPER ISLAND (Roman Catholic) School, Cordova agency, British Columbia, built in 1915 at a cost of $60,000.00. The enrolment at this date is 100 pupils. I visited this school in June, 1928, and made a thorough inspection—
inspection of the buildings, grounds, etc. The Kuper Island school is, in my judgment, one of the best constructed public buildings I ever visited. The construction appeared almost perfect throughout and the repairs at this school since it was built have been almost negligible.

In addition to the repairs necessary at the above noted schools and a number of others, there has been an acute water shortage at a large number of our schools since I entered the Department. An attempt has been made during the last three years to install adequate water supply systems at the following schools:

Shingwauk, at Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario;
Gordon's, Punnichy, Touchwood agency, Sask.;
St. Philips, near Kamsack, Pelly agency, Sask.;
Grouard, Lesser Slave Lake agency, Alberta;
Joussard,
Vernilion,
Sturgeon Lake,
Wabasca,
Cariboo, Williams Lake agency, British Columbia.

Despite this fact, however, there is still a large number of schools where the water supply is wholly inadequate and there is what one might term a critical shortage of water at the Chapleau residential school, Ontario, and at the Brandon and Sandy Bay residential schools in Manitoba. At Sandy Bay the water is hauled by truck from the lake, while at Brandon the water actually used by the pupils is hauled from the Brandon City water main.

Since I entered the Department in December, 1936, the following schools have been destroyed by fire:

Alberni, British Columbia;
Ahousaht,
Albany, James Bay agency, Ontario;
Carcross, Yukon Territory;
Alert Bay (boys' building), British Columbia;
Kenora (staff residence and dormitories, Ontario.

In view of these fire losses, I am personally of the opinion that no residential school should be built in the future - either new or designed for replacement - other than those of fireproof construction throughout.

In this memorandum I should perhaps refer also to the location of a number of our schools. I have in mind such schools as Portage la Prairie, Elkhorn and Edmonton.

The ELKHORN residential school, Manitoba, was closed for a number of years during the last war and it is difficult to understand at this date why it was ever re-opened. The repair costs for this school at the time of
time of the re-opening in 1923-24 amounted to $100,026. The pupils enrolled at this school come in the main from northern Manitoba and the cost of transportation is quite substantial.

A more striking illustration though of poor location is supplied in the case of the EDMONTON residential school, Alberta (United Church). I have never been able to secure a rational explanation from anyone with respect to the establishment of this school on its present site. The Principal in charge - Mr. J. F. Woodsworth - is one of our best principals. He has never at any time in recent years succeeded in securing his full quota of pupils, despite the fact that he has been permitted for a number of years to recruit on Indian reserves along the western coast of British Columbia. This school cost more to erect than any other school in our entire system. It is my personal opinion - and the representatives of the Church agree with me - that it is going to be increasingly difficult to recruit the number of pupils necessary for the operation of this school during the years that lie immediately ahead of us.

I feel you will agree with me when I state that regardless of what our opinion may be with respect to the efficiency of the residential school as an educational unit, it will be necessary for great many years to maintain a large number of these schools throughout the Dominion. This will be necessary to provide institutional care for a large number of Indian orphan children and children neglected by their parents and indeed children from homes where conditions are such that a child, unless removed to a residential school, has little chance of surviving. In my judgment it will be necessary also to maintain these schools in an attempt to salvage our investment. Very few of these schools appear to be suitable for any purpose other than the purpose for which they are now used.

The proposal I am submitting, therefore, if carried out, would mean the closing down of a number of residential schools and the substitution therefor of up-to-date consolidated schools on the reserves at which transportation might be provided in the sense that we are providing transportation at the newly constructed consolidated school in the Cowichan agency, British Columbia. A certain proportion of the saving effected should be used to defray the cost necessary to repair and reconstruct our remaining schools and thus maintain them in a high state of efficiency.

A list of the schools to the closing of which we might give consideration is attached hereto.

Before -
Before such action is even seriously considered, however, a conference should be arranged between representatives of the Department and representatives of the Churches now engaged in the operation of the schools. I feel confident that the churches would be glad to co-operate with us in any attempts we might make to work out a more efficient system of Indian education.

I desire to refer briefly to the schools in the enclosed list.

PORTAGE LA PRAIRIE (United Church) Manitoba.

This school, with an enrolment of 35, is situated close to the city of Portage la Prairie and is at this date urgently in need of a new sewage disposal plant. The sewage, until now, has been released into the comparatively small lake, south of Portage la Prairie. The civic authorities are vigorously opposed to the release of this sewage and I am convinced that it is only a matter of time until we shall be compelled to establish our own sewage disposal plant at the institution. The cost of this work has been estimated at $2,000.

The pupils at this school are drawn in the main from Long Plains, Swan Lake and Roseau River reserves. There is a good Indian day school on the Swan Lake reserve, with a comparatively small enrolment. A two-room day school on the Long Plain reserve would be sufficient to provide the educational facilities for the children now enrolled at the Portage residential school. The comparatively few pupils that come from Roseau River might be provided for at Brandon or a small day school might be established on the Roseau River reserve.

PINE CREEK (Roman Catholic) Manitoba.

This school, which has an enrolment of 120 pupils, displayed signs of collapsing last year. Steel girders were installed in an attempt to keep the school in operation until more extensive repairs could be undertaken. It is an old building.

A thorough survey would have to be undertaken of the district, however, by a fully qualified investigator, to determine the best and the least costly ways and means of providing educational facilities for the pupils of the district.

ROUND LAKE (United Church) Saskatchewan.

This is an old, dilapidated building, originally constructed, I understand, by the Church, on the Ochapowace reserve, Crooked Lake agency, in the province -
province of Saskatchewan. This school has an enrolment of 75 pupils and is undoubtedly one of the most dilapidated and insanitary schools we have at present in operation. Conditions at this school became so insanitary that the provincial authorities felt prompted to send in a sanitary inspector, whose report is one of the most scathing documents of its kind that I have ever read. Not only is the building insanitary but the wiring is faulty and has become an acute fire hazard.

A two-room Indian day school should be established immediately on the Ochapowace reserve and the residential school should be closed at the end of the present academic year.

THUNDERCHILD (Roman Catholic) Saskatchewan.

This is an old school, in poor state of repair, on the Thunderchild reserve in the Battleford agency, Saskatchewan. The entire population of the reserve is 227, 83 of whom are listed as Catholic.

A two-room Indian day school, with basement accommodation for vocational instruction, should be established to take the place of the present residential school.

WARASCA (Church of England) Alberta. Enrolment 35.

WHITEFISH LAKE (C. E.) " Enrolment 30

STURGEON LAKE (R. C.) " Enrolment 90.

These are all old buildings, church-owned and in a poor state of repair. These schools are costly to maintain and operate from year to year.

A thorough survey of this district should be undertaken with the object of providing Indian day schools for the pupils of these districts to the utmost extent possible that Indian day schools can meet the needs of these Indians.

SACRED HEART (R. C.) Alberta Enrolment 50.

ST. CYPRIAN (C. E.) " Enrolment 50.

These schools are established on the Peigan reserve, Alberta. This reserve has an Indian population of 438, of whom 304 are Anglicans and 135 Roman Catholics.

These buildings are not old, in the sense that we usually speak of old buildings. Both were constructed about the year 1927-28. However, the design of both buildings is most unusual. They are of frame construction, comparatively narrow and each has three storeys in addition -
addition to a full basement. I have been told by men who have visited these schools that in one of the wind storms that arise from time to time in southern Alberta it is impossible to keep water in a basin on the third storey, owing to the swaying and rocking of the buildings. The utmost difficulty has been experienced in securing water at the Sacred Heart school. The experiments have proved costly and are not satisfactory at this date. A capable contractor might undertake an investigation of both these schools with the object of having them transformed into Indian day schools - the top storey removed, etc., on the understanding that transportation would be provided for the pupils. These buildings, although comparatively new, are also acute fire hazards.

**KITAMAAT**, Bella Coola agency, B. C. Enrolment 30.

**PORT SIMPSON**, Skeena agency, B. C. Enrolment 25.

Both these schools are owned by the United Church. We have at Port Simpson an up-to-date three-room Indian day school with ample accommodation for vocational instruction, and the Port Simpson residential school should be closed.

In the estimates of this year, provision is made for the establishment of a two-room Indian day school at Kitamaat. The Kitamaat residential school should also be closed.

**SQUAMISH** (Roman Catholic) Vancouver agency, B. C.

This is a church-owned school, operated by the Sisters of the Child Jesus. It has an enrolment of 60 at this date. This school is operated on the Squamish reserve, North Vancouver. The reserve has a population of 447 Indians, 357 of whom are Catholic.

I visited this school in 1928, and while it is an old, ramshackle building, it is kept spotlessly clean and in a very sanitary condition by the Sisters in charge. It is an acute fire hazard, however, and is operated in conjunction with the Indian day school, the day school being close to the main building. The land on this reserve is becoming increasingly valuable and should in the immediate future become an ideal site for better-class suburban homes.

An additional room should be added to the day school on this reserve and the residential school closed at the end of the present academic year.

**ST. PAUL'S HOSTEL**, (C. E.) Yukon. Enrolment 30.

This is not an Indian residential school in any sense; there is not at this date a single Indian pupil in attendance. The majority of the pupils, I understand, are half-breed orphan children. The amount of $7,500 paid in per capita grants to this school is not a legitimate charge against the Indian Affairs Branch.

The official charged with the responsibility of administering the Yukon territory should be
asked to investigate this institution and to report on the necessity of maintaining the institution in the sense that it has been maintained in recent years. If it is necessary for the care of half-breed children, the per capita grant should be paid by the Yukon administration and not by the Indian Affairs Branch.

It will be noted that 15 schools are involved in this suggested retrenchment program, with a total enrolment of 732 pupils and an annual per capita grant allowance of $141,755.30. In my judgment it would take at least 95 classrooms to accommodate the pupils now in attendance at these residential schools. It is difficult to submit an accurate estimate, but I should think that classroom accommodation could be provided for approximately $6,000.00 per room or a total cost of $150,000.00. In addition to this, of course provision would have to be made for the salaries of at least 25 Indian day school teachers and the funds necessary for other incidental expenses such as fuel wood, caretaking, etc.

I must express regret for having to discuss this matter at such length. I have felt very keenly, however, owing to the condition of our residential schools since I entered the Department, and my inability to keep these schools in a proper state of repair and efficiency. You will notice that my main recommendations are:

(a) That a number of our dilapidated schools that are costly to repair and operate be closed and Indian day schools substituted therefor.

(b) That part of the money saved be used to repair and bring to the highest possible state of efficiency our remaining residential schools.

It is difficult to submit an accurate estimate, but I should think that classroom accommodation could be provided for approximately $8,000.00 per room, or a total cost of $150,000.00. In addition to this, of course provision would have to be made for the salaries of at least 25 Indian day school teachers and the funds necessary for other incidental expenses such as fuel wood, caretaking, etc.

I must express regret for having to discuss this matter at such length. I have felt very keenly, however, owing to the condition of our residential schools since I entered the Department, and my inability to keep these schools in a proper state of repair and efficiency. You will notice that my main recommendations are:

(a) That a number of our dilapidated schools that are costly to repair and operate be closed and Indian day schools substituted therefor.

(b) That part of the money saved be used to repair and bring to the highest possible state of efficiency our remaining residential schools.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR,
SURVEYS AND ENGINEERING BRANCH:

I have for acknowledgment your memorandum of June 28, 1940, and also memorandum relating to the above noted subject, received by you from your Chief Engineer, Mr. Mills.

I regret that circumstances have prevented me from acknowledging receipt of this memorandum until now.

It seems to me highly desirable that sites recommended for the erection of Indian day schools should be carefully surveyed from time to time by an engineer representing your Branch. This engineer should be requested to report upon the general suitability of the site, drainage, etc., and particularly upon the availability of an adequate water supply. As you know, we have had many failures experienced the utmost difficulty in securing an adequate water supply at a number of our schools, particularly in the Prairie Provinces. There may be recommendations from time to time for the erection of schools in the outlying districts of the Dominion where it might be considered unwise to send an engineer, owing to the inaccessibility of such districts and the amount of time required to undertake the work. In the majority of cases, however, a report from the engineer would be desirable.

The inclusion of an amount in the estimates to cover the grading of school grounds and the erection of a school fence, etc., as suggested in your memorandum is in my opinion highly desirable.

Director.
