Memorandum:

MR. JACKSON,

In response to your telephone request of yesterday, I am attaching hereto a statement of the amount provided in the 1941-42 estimates for the purchase of equipment and for repairs at government and church-owned Indian residential schools.

I may explain that when I entered the Department almost 5 years ago, no provision was made by Order in Council for the expenditures necessary to purchase equipment and repair church-owned schools. The Director of the Branch, however, felt at that time that inasmuch as it was unusual for a government to spend money on the repair of buildings other than government-owned buildings, the authority of the Governor in Council should be sought for all such expenditures.

In recent years, therefore, provision has been made for these expenditures by Order in Council. This year's Order in Council makes provision for an expenditure of $21,050 as against an expenditure of $32,200 last year and $34,575 for the fiscal year 1939-40. This year's appropriation, I am disposed to think, is the lowest appropriation asked for in several years. The Orders in Council in which provision is made for these expenditures are frequently amended to meet emergencies that arise from time to time. In addition to the Order in Council, the sanction of the Minister is secured for all expenditures exceeding $500, and I should think that about 95% of these expenditures exceed this amount. At the time the approval of the Minister is sought, a memorandum is sent forward giving full particulars in respect to the repairs that are about to be undertaken or the equipment that is about to be purchased.

May I explain, if I can, in a sentence or two, how our estimates have been prepared since I entered the Department. The Welfare Division is responsible for sending out each year regular mimeographed estimate forms. In these forms provision is made for educational, welfare, medical and administrative expenditures, and the forms are sent to all Indian agents throughout the Dominion. I am attaching three of these forms for your information. When these forms, covering the expenditures already mentioned, are completed by the agents, they are sent
forward to the Inspectors, in the Prairie Provinces, and in the case of the Province of Ontario, to the Inspector for Ontario, and are scrutinized by these officials. They are returned to the Welfare Division by the Inspectors, with accompanying letters containing their comments and particularly their comments on large expenditures or expenditures that may appear to be unusual. They are then distributed by the Welfare Division to the Heads of the other Divisions.

It has been the practice to have these estimates received from our agents and inspectors carefully checked by Mr. Phelan and myself. In the case of our educational estimates, however, it should be pointed out that other requests for expenditures at schools reach us from representatives of the churches who visit the Department. The fact that such requests come in means that a careful study of all files has to be made before a decision is reached in the case of each school. I estimated that while our educational estimates were under review last year we handled over 300 files in a period of 2 or 3 weeks.

When a file covering the condition of a school and the regular estimates submitted by the agent come up for review, the question of the denomination under the auspices of which the school is operated seldom arises. The urgency of the case, coupled with the amount of money at our disposal, is the governing factor. The greatest care, therefore, should be exercised when consideration is being given to the amounts allotted to certain schools. For example, one of the most costly items at an Indian residential school is the purchase of electric batteries, which provide light, and the Diesel or gasoline engines necessary for the operation of the electrical plant. It so happens that practically all of the non-Catholic schools are established outside Indian reserves and can take advantage of the supply of electrical energy available in the district. Catholic schools, on the other hand, with one or two exceptions, have been established on Indian reserves, where no such supply of electrical energy is available. This one item must amount to thousands of dollars annually.

Government-owned schools built within the last 10 or 15 years cost anywhere from $100,000 to $250,000. These buildings are modern structures, fire-proof throughout, with steel or cement stairways, and require few repairs and little equipment for a great many years, although there are exceptions to this rule, as in the case of Sault Ste. Marie (Anglican Church) built a few years ago but without a barn. The barn was built 2 years ago at a cost of $5,000, and since that date a new water connection has been established between the school and the city of Sault Ste. Marie, at a cost of $4,200. Then there is the case of the two non-Catholic residential schools to each of which
the New England Company contributes $5,000 a year. This sum has been set apart for repairs and equipment at these schools but in the case of the Mohawk Institute has never been sufficient to keep the school equipped and in good condition. If other residential schools throughout the Dominion were allowed a similar amount, our estimates for equipment and repairs at residential schools would reach approximately $400,000 per annum. The cost of repairs at residential schools is kept low for the simple reason that the amount we allow from year to year ranges from one third to two thirds of the amount actually requested. Never since I entered the Department have we had the amount available to keep our residential schools in a proper state of repair.

I have referred to the modern schools established by the Government in recent years. Church-owned schools, on the other hand, on an overwhelming majority of them, were built years ago in the remote and outlying districts of the Dominion, where freight and labour costs are a great deal higher than similar costs are in the populated centres. There are one or two exceptions that might be noted. I have seen photos of the Anglican School built two or three years ago at Moose Factory. The school appeared to be a well-constructed frame building that would need few, if any, repairs for a number of years. In the case of a number of schools in northern Alberta and the Round Lake (United Church) School in Saskatchewan, it can be said without any attempt at exaggeration that several of these buildings have reached the last stages of dilapidation and are and have been for several years acute fire hazards. Since I entered the Department, the insanitary condition and the fire risks at the Round Lake School have been brought to the attention of the Branch by the Saskatchewan Government. In my memorandum to the Director dated May 31, 1940, a copy of which I understand was sent forward to your office, I recommended that a number of these dilapidated schools be closed. In the absence of a decision, however, to close these institutions, the officials of the Training Division have no alternative other than to provide the money necessary to keep them open and in operation. In the memorandum referred to, I expressed the opinion that we should aim at keeping our well built schools in a state of repair from year to year. If we follow the policy we are now following, in a few years practically all our schools, with the exception of the best built ones, will be in a condition of semi-dilapidation.

In speaking of church-owned schools, I may state that church-owned schools such as Port Simpson and Kitamaat (United Church) are not residential schools in the ordinary sense at all. We have recently constructed Indian day schools at these points and the United Church have a couple of hostels, in charge of matrons, who provide sleeping accommodation, food and clothing for a number of pupils in attendance at the day schools, who come in from the outlying districts. The Kitamaat school will close at the end of the present academic year. The decision to close this school, however, had not been reached when our estimates were
prepared. It is altogether likely that the small amount provided will not be needed for the purpose we had in mind.

The whole question of church-owned schools is one that might be reviewed by the Government. As the Director has pointed out on a number of occasions, it is somewhat unusual for the Government to provide equipment and repairs for institutions that are not government property. On the other hand, if we take into consideration interest on capital outlay, as in the case of Edmonton, the interest charges without depreciation would amount to approximately $10,000 annually—a sum far exceeding the average amount spent on repairs at a church-owned school in any given year. I have been told that it was the policy of the Government in the early twenties to gradually displace these church-owned schools by the erection of fully equipped fireproof buildings, and that the policy was abandoned in the early years of the depression. It has often occurred to me that if the policy of educating Indian children at residential schools is a sound one, then the Government, and not the Churches, should provide these schools. If, on the other hand, the Government is of the opinion that a number of these schools should be displaced by up-to-date Indian day schools and provision made for the transportation of the pupils to such centres, greater consideration should be given to this change of policy in the immediate future than has been given to it at any time in the past.

I have noted from the attached memorandum prepared by Mr. Phelan that we propose to spend at each of our government-owned schools an average of $888 this year for repairs and equipment and at church-owned schools, an average of $760 for repairs and equipment.

I am attaching hereto, for your information, copies of correspondence relating to the condition of the Sturgeon Lake Residential School. I pass this on as a striking illustration of the condition of a number of schools we are operating in the outlying districts.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

Re: Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School.

I had a number of interviews this fall with Rev. H. Fournier, O.M.I., the Principal of the above school, and with Dr. E. L. Little of Grande Prairie, the medical doctor at that point for the Indian Department, in connection with the Residential School.

I feel very strongly that there should be a new school building at Sturgeon Lake. The present building is 25 or 30 years old, being partially log, boarded over, and has been built in sections. In the original part, some rather poor, local lumber was used. It is a three-story building and is heated by numerous stoves. The roof leaks and pans have to be set out to catch the rain. It is really in a most deplorable condition and a very dangerous fire-trap. You will appreciate that it is impossible to heat such a building as this with stoves, unless terrific fires are kept on. Unquestionably, the building should be condemned, and I feel that the Department is taking a very grave risk in continuing to use it.

A residential school is urgently required at this point and the need will tend to increase rather than diminish. A day school would not serve the situation and would be quite inadequate. This residential school is doing exceptionally good work and should be continued.

I appreciate the need for economy at the present time, but I have no hesitation in urging that the construction of a new residential school at Sturgeon Lake should be proceeded with at once. I feel indeed that I would be negligent in my duty if I did not, in the interest of the health and safety of these Indian children, do my utmost to impress upon the Department the urgency of this situation.

Yours very truly,

(sgd.) J. H. Sissons,
M. P. for Peace River.
Ottawa, November 15, 1940.

Re: Sturgeon Lake Indian Residential School.

Dear Mr. Sissons:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of November 7th, in which you submit, for my consideration, the claims of a group of Indians for the rebuilding of a residential school at Sturgeon Lake.

The Sturgeon Lake School is a church-owned institution and is operated and administered by the Oblate Order. The Department pays an annual per capita grant at the rate of $180 and the enrolment at this date consists of 90 pupils.

Our school building program and the repairs most urgently needed at Indian day and residential schools are carefully reviewed from year to year by the officials of the Department, in co-operation with representatives of the Churches. The claims of the Sturgeon Lake Indians for a new residential school have been carefully reviewed from time to time. I regret to state, however, that it was not possible to include in the estimates of this year the sum necessary for the construction of a new building at that point.

I have just learned that last year a water system was installed by the Department at the Sturgeon Lake School, at a cost of $1,500. This year a carload of cement and the lumber necessary for the construction of a basement at the boys' wing of the building has been supplied.

It would appear that the construction of a school at Sturgeon Lake is inseparably bound up with the construction of schools at Wabasca, Whitefish Lake and Holy Angels. In view of this fact and the existing war conditions, it is not at all likely that the money necessary for the construction of these schools will be available at any time in the immediate future. An attempt will be made by the Department to keep these buildings in the best possible state of repair.

Yours sincerely,

(sgd.) T. A. Crerar.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

I am sending forward herewith a memorandum left with me by the representatives of the Churches at the conclusion of a conference which took place at my office this forenoon. The subject matter of this memorandum, you will note, is self-explanatory.

I may state that we met at 10 o'clock and discussed the desirability of turning over certain Indian residential schools for the care of physically incapacitated Japanese, very fully and in detail. The representatives of the Churches were unanimously of the opinion that schools established on Indian reserves should not under any circumstances, in their judgment, be selected for this purpose. They appeared to be convinced that the effect on the Indian population and repercussions in general would be very prejudicial to the interests of the Indian population. They were less vigorously opposed to the use of Indian residential schools established on property other than Indian reserves. Dr. Cochrane read a telegram from Dr. Dorey, who is at present attending a United Church conference at Edmonton, in which Dr. Dorey expressed the hope that the use of Indian residential schools for the care of Japanese would not be found necessary. If, however, the Government decided to use these buildings, the United Church would ask for the establishment of Indian day schools on the reserves from which the pupils now receiving instruction at Edmonton are recruited. They
would insist also on the taking over by the Government of the Youville School. All the representatives expressed a desire to have an opportunity of discussing the matter with their Bishops and their respective Missionary Societies.

In the judgment of the officials here it would be scarcely fair to take over Edmonton, which with its farm appears to be peculiarly suitable for the purpose we have in mind, without at the same time taking over the Youville School. These institutions are only a few miles apart. The representatives of the United Church are of the opinion that if the Youville School were allowed to remain open and in operation, certain pupils belonging to the United Church would inevitably tend to seek admission to this institution.

The delegates expressed a desire to have a decision from the Government at the earliest possible date.

Director.

RAH
1. In the name of the Churches we represent we would record our very genuine concern for the Indians and for the educational work developed among them over a long period of years. Nevertheless, the Churches heartily desire to cooperate with the Government in finding the solution to the present problem.

2. In considering the proposal that the Indian Residential Schools be taken over for the Japanese, we are apprehensive lest this action would create other and more serious problems than it would solve, such as:

(a) Provision for Indian children now in the schools, coming as they do from widely separated districts, especially orphans and adolescent girls;

(b) The erection of day schools to provide for these children will cost more than buildings to house the Japanese;

(c) Possible adverse reaction on the part of the Indian community;

(d) Possible adverse reaction on the part of sections of the white community.

3. We would suggest:

That the Government explore every other possible solution without having to take over the Indian Schools -- having the above problems in mind -- such a solution as taking over other institutional buildings.

4. While the Government is thus exploring other possible solutions we shall consult our respective constituencies. Should another solution not be found we should be prepared to meet again in conference.

May 26, 1942
1. In the name of the Churches we represent we would record our very genuine concern for the Indians and for the educational work developed among them over a long period of years. Nevertheless, the Churches heartily desire to cooperate with the Government in finding the solution to the present problem.

2. In considering the proposal that the Indian Residential Schools be taken over for the Japanese, we are apprehensive lest this action would create other and more serious problems than it would solve, such as:

(a) Provision for Indian children now in the schools, coming as they do from widely separated districts, especially orphans and adolescent girls;

(b) The erection of day schools to provide for these children will cost more than buildings to house the Japanese;

(c) Possible adverse reaction on the part of the Indian community;

(d) Possible adverse reaction on the part of sections of the white community.

3. We would suggest:

That the Government explore every other possible solution without having to take over the Indian Schools—having the above problems in mind—such a solution as taking over other institutional buildings.

4. While the Government is thus exploring other possible solutions we shall consult our respective constituencies. Should another solution not be found we should be prepared to meet again in conference.

My dear Colleague:

The emergent situation which has developed in connection with the evacuation of the Japanese from the British Columbia Coastal Area is such that I feel warranted in recommending to you an action which in peace times might be considered drastic but which, in view of the seriousness of the matter and the war conditions, I feel is sound and absolutely justifiable.

The proposal briefly is that the British Columbia Security Commission be given, as a war measure, the use of at least three of the larger Indian Schools to house Japanese women and children and some of the older men who are not fit for road camps and other work we can offer them.

As a war emergency, the Japanese situation has already compelled us to take possession of the Exhibition Grounds at Vancouver. The National Defence Department is taking possession of the Exhibition Grounds at Toronto. The provinces have turned over for war purposes many institutions which has involved an interruption of services and has necessitated changes in arrangements.

I think, therefore, it cannot be considered unreasonable that a number of the Indian Schools be used to assist us in meeting the evacuation problem.

Any plan which would involve the construction of entirely new buildings would not only necessitate very heavy expense but would also be unwise because such a programme would use up material and labour needed for war activity.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER.

In response to a request received from the Department of Labour for the use of a limited number of Indian residential schools for the care of a group of Japanese suffering from certain physical disabilities and a number of Japanese families, representatives of the Churches responsible with me for the operation of residential schools met in conference at my office on Tuesday May 26. There were present at this conference:

Reverend T.B.R. Westgate, D.D., and
Rev. Canon L. A. Dixon, M.A., representing the Anglican Church;

Rev. J. O. Plourde, O.M.I., representing the Oblate Order;
Rev. R. B. Cochrane, D.D., representing the United Church of Canada.

After a full discussion of the matter and after the representatives of the Churches had met in separate session, a memorandum was submitted by them to me, in which they embodied their recommendations. A copy of this memorandum is attached hereto.

On the morning of May 29 Mr. Jackson and Mr. Hoey met Father Plourde and two Reverend Sisters representing the Sisters of Charity and discussed with them the best ways and means of utilizing their residential school at Youville, Alberta, for the care of a group of Japanese. The Sisters expressed their willingness either to sell or lend to operate the school, and left the conference with the understanding that they would have a representative of the Order visit Youville
and submit their proposals in order of preference, in
the course of a few days.

In view of the urgency of the matter, a second
invitation was extended to the representatives of the
Churches to meet at your office on Wednesday June 3 at
10 A.M. There were present at this conference:

Reverend George Dorsey, D.D., and Rev. R. B. Cochrane, D.D.,
representing the United Church of Canada;

Reverend J. O. Plourde, O.M.I., Reverend J. Scannell, O.M.I.,
and Reverend P. O'Grady, O.M.I., representing the Roman
Catholic Church;

and the Reverend N. F. Burke, Rector of St. John's Church,
Elgin Street, representing the Anglican Church.

There were also present at this conference, which was
presided over by yourself,

Dr. H. W. McGill, Director of Indian Affairs, Mr. Arthur
MacNamara, Mr. Ford Pratt, Mr. R. A. Hoey and Mr.
Philip Phelan.

The use of residential schools for the care of
Japanese, the number of schools that might be available
without seriously disturbing the Indian educational structure
the auspices under which these schools might be operated if
used for the care of the Japanese, and the provision that
might be made for the education of the Indian pupils now
enrolled at these schools by the creation of day schools
were all thoroughly discussed at considerable length and in
detail. The representatives of the churches appeared
willing to place at the disposal of the Department of Labour
the following schools, with their lands and equipment and
with the members of the staffs necessary to operate them,
if it were considered desirable after further negotiations
to have the staffs now in charge left in control:

Edmonton, Youville, Elkhorn, and either
Kootenay or Cariboo.

Father Plourde intimated during the course of the discussion
that the Sisters of Charity would be prepared to operate the
Youville School for the Government as a T.B. sanitarium.
The representatives of the United Church, however, were

opposed -
opposed to the care of the Japanese suffering from tuberculosis by a religious Order or Body other than the religious Body or Denomination to which the Japanese belong. It would appear that a large number of the Japanese are either members or adherents of the United Church of Canada. The United Church representatives expressed the view, however, that they would have no objection whatever to the care of the Japanese in an institution operated by the Government with a lay staff in charge.

The meeting adjourned on the understanding that representatives of the churches would later meet with representatives of the Department of Labour, with the hope of discussing the practical steps in respect to the actual date when the schools will be taken over, the purpose for which each school appears to be best equipped, the question of staff, management, etc., and the utilization of farm machinery, live stock, equipment, etc. It was agreed that it might be advisable to invite to Ottawa one or two members of the British Columbia Security Commission for the purpose of meeting the representatives of the churches and reviewing the whole problem with them.

I am sending forward a copy of this memorandum to Mr. MacNamara.

Director.
Ottawa, June 4, 1942.

MEMORANDUM:

DEPUTY MINISTER:

A cursory survey of the Indian reserves that are likely to be affected by the transfer of four of our Indian residential schools to the Department of Labour, for the care of a group of Japanese, would indicate that it will be necessary to provide 10 Indian day schools. We have in mind two 2-room schools and eight 1-room schools - provision for living quarters for the teachers to be made at all the buildings erected. Indian Schools Used To Shelter Japanese

Large numbers of Japanese women and children in the coast areas of British Columbia are being housed in Indian residential schools, Mr. Westwood Canada, Labour Minister, told the House of Commons yesterday.

AIR MAIL

Ottawa, June 5, 1942.

Dear Doctor Simes:

It has been decided by the Government that we should place at the disposal of the Department of Labour and the British Columbia Security Commission a limited number of our residential schools for the care of a group of Japanese citizens who, it would appear, are suffering from certain physical disabilities. The schools that have been decided to place at the disposal of the Commission for this purpose are Edmonton (U.C.), Youville (R.C.), Elkhorn (C.E.), and either Cariboo or Kootenay (R.C.). The information at our disposal would lead us to believe that there are approximately 250 of this group of Japanese suffering from tuberculosis. The Government, for reasons that it is not necessary to discuss, consider it undesirable to use either Edmonton or Youville as a T.B. sanatorium. They have under consideration at the moment, however, the desirability of using the Elkhorn Residential School for this purpose.

I have been wondering if it would be possible for you to undertake an inspection of this building and submit a report on the advisability of using the institution as a sanatorium. In making this inspection you should of course keep in mind the fact that there are few, if any, buildings available for the care of these people and that it certainly is not possible, for the time being at least, to provide them with an up-to-date sanatorium. It has been suggested also that the seminary owned by the Oblate Fathers at Qu'Appelle, near the Lebret residential school, might be used as a sanatorium. Would it be convenient for you to make an inspection of this -

Ottawa, June 4, 1942.

Dear Mr. Doucet:

It was decided at a conference held yesterday at the office of the Deputy Minister, and attended by representatives of the churches responsible for the operation of Indian residential schools, that four of our schools should be placed immediately at the disposal of the Department of Labour for the care of a group of Japanese citizens suffering from certain physical disabilities.

The schools that will be used for the purpose are:

Edmonton (U. C.)
Youville (R. C.)
Elkhorn (C. E.) and either
Cariboo (R. C.) or
Kootenay (R. C.)

It was decided also at this conference that we should undertake immediately the construction of Indian day schools on the reserves affected and thus make educational facilities available for the pupils now enrolled at the four afore-mentioned residential schools.

I am sending forward a copy of the 1939-census. It would be appreciated if you could visit the Edmonton, Hobbema and Saddle Lake Agencies prior to your return to Ottawa. You should discuss with the agents in charge of these agencies the best locations that might be selected for school sites, the type of building that might be erected, etc. It is of the utmost importance that the building program should be undertaken immediately. Funds will be available from the special war appropriation. You might also discuss the matter with the Reverend J. F. Woodsworth, Principal of the Edmonton School. Mr. Phelan and I at the moment have in mind the construction of one one-room day school with teacher's residence for the Samson's Band, Hobbema Agency; one two-room school with teacher's quarters for the Saddle Lake Band, Saddle Lake Agency; a one-room school with teacher's residence for the James Seenum's Band and one one-room day school with teacher's quarters for the Wabamun Band. In the Edmonton Agency we had in mind the construction of three one-room day schools with teacher's quarters on the following Reserves: Alexander's, Alexis and Michel's. These schools will of course be operated under Roman Catholic auspices.

We are hoping that it will not be necessary for you to spend much time at the Peigan Reserve and -

Dear Mr. Doucet:

In a letter dated June 4, you were instructed to proceed to the Robbema, Edmonton and Saddle Lake Reserves, with the object of selecting sites suitable for the erection of Indian day schools.

In my radiotelegraph message dated June 5, you were instructed to cancel your trip to the Beigan reserve for the time being and proceed at once to Edmonton.

When you have completed this work, I want you to report at the Edmonton U.C. School. I may explain that when the Indian pupils are discharged from the school - as they will be in the course of a few days - the responsibility for any alterations necessary, the steps required to have the buildings occupied by a group of Japanese and the arrangements that it may be necessary to make with the church for the care of these Japanese citizens are all matters for which the British Columbia Security Commission will have to assume full responsibility. As a department, our responsibility practically ends in an official sense at least with the discharge of the pupils. The per capita grant will be allowed up until the end of the present academic year, June 30.

We are anxious, however, to do everything humanly possible to assist the British Columbia Security Commission and the Department of Labour in the task of making provision for the transfer and care of this group of Japanese. It has occurred to me, therefore, that you might act for two or three weeks and perhaps longer as liaison officer between this Department and the Department of Labour and the British Columbia Security Commission, representatives of which commission you will, no doubt, meet at the school.

In addition to certain alterations in the main building itself and in the outer buildings, the members of the Commission have in mind the erection of a large number of cottages. These cottages will be built to provide homes for groups of Japanese women and children who may not require institutional care and who are not suffering from physical disabilities. TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL:

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT due to the exigencies of war there has arisen urgent need for buildings remote from coastal areas suitable as to location and equipment to provide for the accommodation and care of persons of Japanese origin.

THAT after careful survey of such available accommodation as the country affords it appears that a number of Indian Residential Schools are most suitable for the purpose and after negotiation and discussion with those charged with the responsibility for their administration and management the following have been tentatively selected:

1. The Edmonton Indian Residential School at Edmonton in the Province of Alberta, a government owned institution operated by The United Church of Canada.

2. The Elkhorn Indian Residential School at Elkhorn in the Province of Manitoba, a government owned institution operated by The Church of England.

3. The Kootenay Indian Residential School at Cranbrook in the Province of British Columbia, a government owned institution operated by the Oblate of Mary Immaculate Order of the Roman Catholic Church.

4. The Youville Indian Residential School at St. Albert in the Province of Alberta, owned and operated by The Sisters of Charity an Order of the Roman Catholic Church.

THAT it is deemed expedient that the government owned institutions at Edmonton in the Province of Alberta, at Elkhorn in the Province of Manitoba, and at Cranbrook in the Province of British Columbia, be turned over to the Department of Labour by the Department of Mines and Resources, in consideration of which there shall be paid to the said Department of Mines and Resources from the War Measures Appropriation the sum of $
such sum to be used to provide day school accommodation to the Indian pupils in lieu of services formerly provided by the said institutions.

THAT it is deemed expedient that the properties of the Sisters of Charity at St. Albert in the Province of Alberta and

be purchased from monies provided in the War Measures Appropriation for like purposes at a price to be determined, the total cost not to exceed $50,000, all of which said properties to be used for the purpose of providing facilities and accommodation to such persons of Japanese origin as may be assigned to each such institution.

THAT tentative arrangements have been made (or are to be made) with the United Church of Canada, The Church of England, The Sisters of Charity, The Oblate Order, and , respectively, to provide for the operation of the said institutions and for the accommodation and care of persons of Japanese origin along lines similar and as far as applicable to the arrangement presently subsisting between each of them and the Department of Mines and Resources in relation to the care and education of Indians.

IT IS THEREFORE JOINTLY RECOMMENDED:

1. THAT the Minister of Labour be empowered and authorized to enter into an agreement with the Minister of Mines and Resources, in consideration of payment of the sum of $50,000 from War Measures Appropriation to be used for the erection and equipment of day schools for Indian children, to take over possession of the Indian Residential Schools at Edmonton in the Province of Alberta, at Elkhorn in the Province of Manitoba, and at Cranbrook in the Province of British Columbia, for the purpose of providing therein accommodation for such persons of Japanese origin as may be assigned thereto, and for such other purposes related to the war as may hereafter arise.

2. THAT the Minister of Labour be empowered and authorized to purchase from the Sisters of Charity the Youville Indian Residential School at St. Albert in the Province of Alberta, and

at a price to be determined but not to exceed in total the sum of $50,000 Dollars ($50,000) and that the purchase price be provided from monies voted in War Measures Appropriation.

3. THAT the British Columbia Security Commission be empowered and authorized to enter into agreement with the United Church of Canada, The Church of England, The Sisters of Charity, The Oblate Order, and any of them to provide necessary services and accommodation to such persons of Japanese origin as may be assigned to each such
institution, the cost of which services and accommodation
to be provided from monies voted in the War Measures Approp-
riation.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources

During his time in Ottawa no mention was made to him by any of the Indian Department Officials regarding transferring Tuberculosis Japanese from B.C. to the Prairie Provinces. This I think has been definitely squashed by the Provincial Department of Public Health.

Recently I received a letter from Dr. McGill to inspect and report on the suitability of Elk Horn Residential School for this purpose. This is a Manitoba, not a Saskatchewan problem if they should take over that school. As you possibly are more interested in Manitoba than Saskatchewan, it was thought advisable to drop a line and let you know what was in the offing. It is felt by the men doing Tuberculosis work in Saskatchewan, that Dr. Macleod in Vancouver is trying to pull a fast one in shipping these Japs out of the Province. If they are sick, what harm can they do as fifth columnists. No doubt they will be difficult to manage and there is a great possibility of them getting scattered throughout the Provinces, causing a great increase in Tuberculosis. In our opinion it is up to B.C. to care for them themselves.

In our opinion it was felt that the B.C. Government was dealing with the Federal Government, when it considered taking over Indian Residential Schools, and all arrangements might be made before the Provincial Government of Manitoba was aware of what was going on. This was my main reason for writing you regarding this matter, and in our opinion the Manitoba boys would certainly appreciate any action you might take to prevent these Tuberculosis Japs being moved East of the Rockies.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Doctor Westgate:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of June 16 and also a list of pupils now enrolled at the Elkhorn School, attached thereto.

I note with interest that it is your opinion that the pupils whose names appear on this list should be transferred to the Sioux Lookout School.

I regret to state that it is not possible to reach a definite decision in respect to this matter at the present time. The latest reports we have received from the Department of Labour indicate that it is just possible, as the result of an acute labour shortage in the East, particularly in the province of Ontario, that a very large group, if not all, of the individuals of Japanese origin may be placed in work camps and that the Japanese so placed will be prepared to look after the old and physically incapacitated relatives. If such is the case, our residential schools will not be required for the care of Japanese and it will not be necessary to disturb in any way the present enrolment at these institutions. In view of all the circumstances, I am disposed to think that you should inform the Principal of the Elkhorn School that no steps should be taken in the meantime to transfer these pupils to the reserves or to the Sioux Lookout School; in other words, that the school should be operated in the same sense that it would have been operated if the proposal for the care of the Japanese had not been submitted to us for consideration.

Dear Dr. McGill:

Thank you for your letter of June 10th. We are naturally greatly interested in the decision which has been reached regarding the use of certain of the Indian Schools for Japanese.

As you will doubtless recall, we were not given a new school building to replace the Mackay School at The Pas which was destroyed by fire in 1933.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

To Recruit Indians For Harvest

Indians will probably help harvest Saskatchewan's 1942 wheat crop.

At a meeting of the central committee for organization of farm labor help, held Tuesday afternoon at the legislative buildings, committee members were told by M. Christiansen, general superintendent of Indian affairs for the federal government, that there were 13,000 Indians in the province, many of whom could be made available to help with harvesting.

Discuss Indians

Mr. Christiansen was unable to say exactly how many of these Indians would be available; some of them would be busy on their own farms, he said. Others, he said, could be utilized in the districts adjacent to Indian reserves and in the frontier sections, and for their families could be arranged, still others would be able to assist in harvesting across the province.

The committee members also discussed the possibilities of bringing Japanese laborers into the province during harvesting time, but no definite decision was reached in this matter.

Commanding officer's representative to the war service, Lt.-Col. A. S. Redford, explained to the committee the effect the August call up of trained men would number 119 per day would have on the available farm labor situation allowing consideration of the possibility of securing postponement and release for those trainees and for men still in the depots. To secure postponement it is necessary for the men to make an application within eight days after he has received notice to report for military training.

To the Minster

The conference Tuesday agreed to write Hon. Humphrey Mitchell, minister of agriculture, asking what financial help from the federal government the province could get for accommodating and transporting harvest laborers.

At the meeting a committee was appointed to make a reconnaissance of the lake in each of the 10 zones. Hon. R. J. M. Parker, minister of mines, who is also minister of agriculture, will be chairman of the committee, consisting of Hon. R. J. McGurrin, W. E. Hodge, L. J. O'Brien, C. A. Scott, R. L. Christopher, F. B. McMurtry, and W. V. Dawson.

Members of this committee intend to visit the census and provincial offices where reserve committees will be formed, and it was agreed that the mayor of each town, including Prince Albert, Swift Current, North Battleford, Weyburn, Yorkton, and Regina, will be asked to convene the meetings in their districts.

Name Sub-Committees

Meanwhile, sub-committees are being formed in the smaller divisions of the province, through rural municipalities, school districts, and local councils. The meetings will be held between now and next Monday, at which time they will be considered by the central committee, meeting of July 27th at 10 a.m., at the legislative buildings.

Besides the zone organization, a committee to study the matter was appointed from the central body. The committee will consist of Mr. Redford, chairman, and F. W. Townley-Smith and D. S. McMurtry as publicists. It will be handled by D. B. Rogers and J. W. Fairley.

Sub-committees will be assisted in taking surveys of suitable land in each small area, by a statistical committee consisting of Dr. F. H. Oliver, D. B. Rogers and George Oliver.

Irrigation Is Giving Impetus To Farming On B.C. Indian Reserve

Once Arid Area in East Kootenay Now Producing Splendid Crops

(From Our Own Correspondent)

CRANBROOK, B.C., July 22—Twenty-five farming properties, operated by Indians on the St. Mary's Indian Reserve, on the east side of the St. Mary's river, reflect the impetus given agriculture on that section of the province. The projects built at a cost of ten to twenty thousand dollars.

Frank Bond of Cranbrook, supervised construction of the five-mile main ditch while a dozen Indians did the rest of the work. From this ditch there are nearly fifteen miles of lateral ditches which serve the twenty-five properties. The irrigation system is available for twice this number of properties and additional at operations are anticipated for the service in the course of time.

Now productive

Formerly the drainage of this section in an average year was such that a large number of acres of hay was destroyed and was not to be expected from the land. With the extra water during the past three years marked improvement has been made in the standard of living and the farming methods which are producing fine crops of good vegetables in quantity and grain crops. Production of beef cattle is becoming the chief agricultural pursuit of the area, now is possible with the aid of the new grasses.

Headgate of the system is about a mile downstream from the mission, and the main ditch serves from there to the intersection of the St. Mary's and the Kootenay at Fox Creek. The project was planned originally nine decades ago by R. L. Galbraith of Fort Steele, and more recently by Mr. Bond on main ditch. In 1923 it was re-turned and in 1928 work was begun, and in 1929 operation for three years.

An estimated hundred and fifty acres of land are now under irrigated, and the success of their work indicates that others will start similar projects when there is sufficient water available to serve five or more such properties.

Two Indians Die When Boat Upsets

Man and Woman Lost and Third Man Rescued by Fireman

Belleville, July 23—An Indian man and woman were drowned early today when their boat upset, capsizing in the Bay of Quinte.

The dead: Mrs. Gordon Maracle, 5, of Belleville, Ont., eight miles from Belleville; and Gordon Maracle, no relation, also of Shawville. Twenty-year-old Albert Maracle, whose name was not related to the other two, was rescued by Fireman Frank Post as he clung to the overturned boat.

Indians Threaten To Quit Hopfields

VANCOUVER (CP) August 27—Khakhalahtah, spokesman for the Klahoose Indians of British Columbia, said here today 500 tribesmen are ready to "lie down" on the hop fields if the government does not increase the rate of cents per pound for picked hops is raised and better living quarters are provided for the workers.

Chief Khakhalahtah said Indian hop pickers are offered 4 cents a pound by United States firms, and unless improvements are made the Indians will force the hop fields of British Columbia for those of the United States.

"They'll go down into the States and pick. Hundreds of them go away. There aren't any barriers at the border to stop their Indians," said the spokesman. But, he said, they would rather stay in Canada and pick if they are given an even worse bread for they do not wish to take advantage of a situation caused by a shortage of help.

Word Awaited On Transfer Indian School

Officials Had Planned Use Building Shelter Japanese

EVACUATION PLAN

Officials at the Indian Residential School, near St. Albert, said Friday no official word had reached them regarding the proposed taking over of the school for the housing of Japanese from vital coastal defence areas.

Officials in charge of the removal of Japanese from the coast recently stated that the evacuees would be removed by the end of the month. The Indian school near St. Albert was mentioned as being considered as summer holidays to provide temporary shelter for the evacuees.

School officials said they have not yet had word that it was planned to take over the buildings.

Won't House Japs At Indian School

Rev. J. F. Woodsworth, principal of the Indian Residential School near St. Albert, said there would be no Japanese arriving to be housed at the school.

No satisfactory arrangements could be reached between the school management and the British Columbia security commission, in charge of the evacuation of Japanese from the west coast.

It is "definite," he said, that no Japanese will be housed at the school. Word from Ottawa recently indicated several Indian schools in Alberta would be considered for the purpose of housing the Japanese. It was not known whether other Indian schools still will be used.

For example, if the husband has been guilty of cruelty and the wife has forgiven him, the wife may bring action for judicial separation on this ground. If, at a later date, however, the husband again commits cruelty, then the wife may bring an action for judicial separation, not only on the ground of the cruelty last committed, but also the cruelty which she forgave.

Adultery condoned may be revived by adultery or by cruelty or by desertion. In other words if adultery has been condoned the subsequent cruelty will revive it. Cruelty condoned may be revived by cruelty or by adultery, but not by desertion. Desertion condoned may be revived by adultery.

If there has been collusion between the parties, the plaintiff is not entitled to a decree. The term "collusion" implies impropriety; arrangement or concerted effort to improperly secure that to which neither of the colluding parties are fully entitled.

If the plaintiff has himself or herself committed some matrimonial offence the Court has a discretion to refuse to give relief notwithstanding that the defendant has committed an offence of a class for which a decree of judicial separation would normally be granted.

In an action for judicial separation the Court may make an order as to costs, alimony and custody of children.

The Court may, upon application grant either interim alimony, permanent alimony or both. Interim alimony is an allowance made to the wife for the purpose of assuring that she will be properly maintained during the course of the action. Permanent alimony is an allowance made upon the conclusion of the proceedings when the wife has been adjudged entitled to the continued support of her husband. The terms "maintenance" and "permanent alimony" mean the same thing. In addition the Court may award interim disbursements to the wife so that she will have means to carry on the proceedings. In many cases the wife may have no money and the Court can therefore order the husband to make payments to the wife so that she may be able to defend an action or take the action herself. Following the same reasoning the Court may award costs to the wife whether she is plaintiff or defendant and whether successful or not.

It must be borne in mind however, that interim alimony, permanent alimony or interim disbursements are awarded only where the wife is living separate and apart from her husband and is in some actual need of being supported and maintained. It is also necessary that a valid and subsisting marriage must be established, because if there has been no marriage the wife can have no claim for support or maintenance as a wife.

In preliminary proceedings, that is in applications for interim alimony or permanent disbursements, it is necessary only to establish a prima facie marriage. A strict proof at this stage of the proceedings is not necessary as long as a prima facie case is made out. However, before permanent alimony can be awarded strict proof of the marriage is essential.

In making an order as to custody of children the Court invariably treats the interests of the children as paramount. The Court should make such an order as is in the best interest of the children. The guilty party in an action for judicial separation is not necessarily disqualified to custody although cruelty and adultery are common grounds for denying custody. The question the Court must ask is which parent is better qualified to look after the children' physical and moral welfare. The Court may decide that neither parent is a fit and proper person and in such case, the children could be made wards of the Court, and a guardian.
BUILD SCHOOLS FOR INDIANS

Japs to Take Over Present Structures on Edmonton Reserves

EDMONTON, June 8—Federal government officials were reported today as making plans for the erection of day schools on Indian reserves in this area, in view of the possibility that last winter's take over the Indian industrial school a few miles northwest of Edmonton and the Young Men's Club at St. Albert for housing accommodation for Japanese women and children to be moved from the war defense area.

Points in the Edmonton Indian agency where day schools are expected to be located include Stony Plain reserve, Wabamun, Calahoo, and Lac Ste. Anne. The schools are to be completed by the beginning of the term next fall. Building operations are expected to begin immediately.

At the Indian industrial school, where Mr. Woodsworth is principal, an inventory of classroom equipment already is under way. The Japanese students are expected to leave for the reserves as soon as possible after June 15. There are 319 at the industrial school and 180 at the St. Albert school.

Mr. Woodsworth is likely to remain in charge of the industrial school in a supervisory capacity, his duties to cover management of the farm and business operations during the period the Japanese are there. Some members of the staff of 11 also are to remain on hand to be called for auxiliary work.

The reserve comprises 535 acres, of which 500 are under cultivation.

Officials here had no definite information regarding whether the Japanese will be moved here, but it is understood that workmen will start shortly on major structural alterations to the main buildings.

Expecting Decision by Ottawa
On Future of Indian Schools
Dominion and Church Officials Now Are Negotiating

TWO NEAR EDMONTON

Definite word from Ottawa concerning plans to take over two Indian schools in the Edmonton area for the housing of Japanese women and children from the British Columbia mainland area is expected during the next few days, it was learned Friday.

Meanwhile negotiations concerning these schools are pending. The buildings involved are the Indian Industrial school 4½ miles northeast of the city, which has 150 pupils enrolled, and the Youville school, operated at St. Albert by the Sisters of Charity, which has 160 Indians.

Some days ago, the B.C. security commission announced that plans for placing the Japanese in certain schools had been abandoned.

Inquiries here showed that so far as the two schools in this area are concerned, negotiations still are under way.

Rev. J. F. Woodworth, principal of the Indian Industrial school, said that negotiations concerning that school were still going on, and final word was awaited.

Word concerning the outcome of recommendations to take over the schools is expected here during the week-end.
Indian Schools To Be Used As Japanese Home

The Edmonton Indian Residential School will be used as a clearing house while the children are away for the summer, and their families will be temporarily housed in the school until they are placed elsewhere.

It was learned that Ottawa Labor department officials decreed use of the school for this purpose would be on a temporary basis.

The Rev. Mr. F. Wilson, principal of the school, declared that while he had no immediate word on the Ottawa decision, negotiations for use of the school, commenced some time ago, were continuing.

Officials of the Columbia Security Commission said yesterday that if present plans materialize, 3,000 or more Japanese in the Pacific coast defense area will be en route to new homes near Hope and near Edmonton within the next fortnight.

The commission expects that by the end of August the last Japanese will have been evacuated from the Pacific strip. It is planned that 300 Japanese families in leased buildings and farms near Hope, and families in an Indian residential school near Edmonton.
Expect Japanese From Coast At Indian School in 2 Weeks

Dominion Taking One School, Drops Plan to Take Second

WORD IS AWAITED

First batch of approximately 50 Japanese families being moved from the British Columbia defence area to the Indian Industrial school, 4½ miles northeast of Edmonton, may arrive within the next two weeks, it was learned Tuesday.

At the same time it was reported that the Dominion government abandoned plans to make use of the Youville Indian school at St. Albert, Rev. J. F. Woodsworth, principal of the Indian Industrial school, said he has not received definite word as to when the first group will arrive but it was reported from Vancouver that officials of the B.C. security commission stated that the movement will be under way within the next two weeks.

Mr. Woodsworth said his information was that the school would be used as a distributing depot. The Japanese would be sent out to various farms where they could be assisted, under policy of keeping the families together.

While it was first reported from Olathe that only women and children would be sent to Edmonton, it now appears that the heads of families also will go.

Mr. Woodsworth said that there was no thought of establishing Japanese colonies here but to make the people available for farm work and to keep the families together as units.

The aim will be to bring 50 families or more of Japanese residents to the depot and as these go out to farms others would be brought in until the movement was completed.

The latest report from the commission expects that by the third week of August, the last Japanese will have been moved off the Pacific strip. It is planned to house 500 Japanese families in leased buildings near Hope, B.C.

All told, 3,000 of the remaining 9,000 Japanese on the coast will be moved to Hope and to Edmonton, if present plans materialize, according to officials of the B.C. security commission.

Will Replace Industrial School System for Indians

READY IN AUTUMN

Plans in the Edmonton Indian agency were day schools to be erected include Stony Plain reserve, Nakawka reserve, and the St. Anne. The schools are to be built in time for the opening of the term next fall. Building operations are expected to commence immediately.

At the Indian industrial school where J. F. Woodsworth is principal an inventory of class-room equipment already is under way.

The Indian pupils, it was reported unofficially, are expected to leave for their reserves as soon as possible after June 15. There are 25 at the Industrial school and 10 at the St. Albert school, the latter being operated by the Sisters of Charity.

Mr. Woodsworth is likely to remain in charge of the Industrial school in a supervisory capacity, his duties also covering management of the farm and other activities. During the period the Japanese are removed some members of the staff of 11 also will be employed at the school for supervisory work.

The school comprises 36 acres, of which 500 are under cultivation. In view of the fact that numerous Japanese families are expected to be placed there, the farm operations may be extended so that as much food as possible will be raised.

Cottages Likely

Cottages are likely to be built at Stony Plain, Nakawka, and also at St. Albert to provide accommodations for the Japanese families, it was reported.

Officials had no definite information as to whether Japanese will be moved here, but it is understood that workmen will start shortly in making necessary alterations to the main buildings.
Indian Schools Secured for Japs; 6000 More to Be Moved at Once

Interval remaining before Canada's war-menaced Pacific Coast sees the last of its Japanese population will be markedly reduced.

Announcement in the House of Commons Thursday by Hon. Humble Mitchell, Minister of Labor, that 6000 Nipponese will be shifted to Indian residential schools of British Columbia, Alberta, and Manitoba, makes this fact plain.

There is an excellent chance, in view of the government declaration that the Hastings Park situation will be substantially cleared up by September. By November, the last Jap may be gone from the Vancouver area.

One of the chief problems involved is that there are 2000 babies to dispose of, children under the age of two. Mr. Mitchell indicated, however, that women and children are being especially considered in the Indian school plans.

Extra accommodation found for them will cut down the total to be carried during the next few months at the Hastings Park clearing grounds.

The minister's outline of the day after the Japanese hit-and-run raid on Dutch Harbor signalled the first increase in precautionary measures in the British Columbia coastal area.

Total of resident Japanese moved so far amounts to more than 12,000. If accommodation can be found for another 6000 in the Indian schools, more than two-thirds of British Columbia's Japanese population will have been evacuated from the coast, and British Columbia Security Commission will be close to the end of the first phase of its job.

It has been practically decided to take over the Edmonton Residential School, a school center at St. Albert, Alta., a school at Elkhorn, Man., and one in British Columbia," Mr. Mitchell said. "The education of the Indian children will not be neglected."

(There are three large Indian residential schools in the British Columbia Interior.

They are located at Kamloops, Lytton and Fraser Lake, and are conducted for the Government by Catholic and Anglican Churches.)

With the Squamish School now operating as a hospital, we have at this date three residential schools less in operation than have been in operation at any time in recent years.

No pupilage increases have been allowed at any of our residential schools since the decision to discontinue this practice was reached about 18 months ago. Prior to that decision it was the practice to allow supplementary grants at a number of residential schools for the care of orphan and neglected children. The fact that per capita grant payments are made on a 5% basis has in itself a tendency to restrict the enrolment at a number of our schools.

With the Indian school population increasing at the rate of approximately 300 pupils per annum, the question of school accommodation is one that cannot be indefinitely postponed.

We have made temporary provision for the care of the pupils at Carcross by renting a number of houses. The rent paid for this accommodation amounts to $1,140 per annum. At Alberni, temporary accommodation has been provided for the pupils in the basement playrooms of the main building; this accommodation, however, is in a semi-infected state. It means that throughout the winter season, when there is heavy rainfall in the district, pupils have no recreational rooms and no playground that can be utilized at least two or three months. It is difficult to know just what provision can be made for the pupils at File Hills. Mr. Huston, principal of the Round Lake School, who was in charge of the File Hills School for a month immediately following the destruction of the classroom...
building by fire, was definitely of the opinion that it would be impossible to conduct classes in the dormitory buildings. It would appear that there are no playrooms in the basement of the building and that the only possible space available is the dormitory space. Here, it would appear, the lighting is very poor and the beds, of course, will have to be moved night and morning. From a health standpoint, this condition should be remedied at the earliest possible date.

At Caughnawaga the pupils formerly enrolled in the Senior School are now accommodated in the basement of the Kateri School and in one room of the teacher's residence. I have before me at the present time a request from the Principal of the Caughnawaga School for an additional building, capable of accommodating a couple of classrooms, which, she informs me, is available and is located almost directly opposite the teacher's residence.

It is our intention to make provision for the pupils of the Back Settlement section of the Munsey Reserve in the basement of the Anglican Church which, I understand, can be rented for this purpose.

It is perhaps too early at this date to state in exact terms what accommodation will actually be needed on the Eskasoni and Shubenacadie Reserves, Nova Scotia, and on Lennox Island, P.E.I. Mr. Denot is at present engaged in an educational survey of these reserves and will supply us with more complete information in the course of a few weeks. It would appear, however, that regardless of any recommendations he may make, provision should be made in the 1943-44 estimates for the construction of additional school accommodation on these reserves.

The construction of Indian day or residential schools in a period as critical as the one in which we find ourselves is in my judgment a matter of government policy. I have not at my disposal the information necessary to make a definite recommendation. A great deal will depend, I should think, upon the supply of building material and the number of skilled labourers available for such work. I naturally hesitate to assume responsibility for a continuance of the policy now in force. I do feel the whole matter should be very carefully and very thoroughly reviewed at a conference called for this purpose.

R. A. Hagg,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa, August 10, 1942.

Memorandum:

DOCTOR McILL

Re: Operation of Carcross Residential School

I am sending forward herewith copy of a letter received by this Branch from the Reverend Canon L. A. Dixon, General Secretary of the Missionary Society of the Church of England in Canada.

When the Carcross Residential School was destroyed by fire on April 17, 1939, an assurance was given to the Anglican Church authorities that the school would be rebuilt just as soon as the funds necessary for this purpose could be secured, and that in the interval funds would be provided to rent two or three houses that appeared available at that time for the conduct of classes and for dormitory accommodation. These houses have recently been condemned as insanitary by the Medical Health officer of the district, who issued an order that the building be closed. Later, however, the building was re-opened with an enrolment of 20 rather than 40 pupils.

I am not at all sure that we are justified in spending at this particular time, or indeed at any time, the sum of $10,000 on the education of 20 pupils. This per capita grant does not include money paid for a night watchman or for incidental expenses such as repairs, the purchase of textbooks, etc. I am disposed to think, without knowing much about local conditions, that this money might be more profitably spent in the establishment of one or two day schools at certain centres and in the employment of a nurse, qualified to give instruction in dietetics, etc.

Mr. Phelan and I have spent the last week in carefully reviewing the requests received for the repair and general upkeep of our residential school buildings. The appropriation available in the 1943-44 estimates is sufficient to meet no more than 50% of the amounts requested. In addition to these requests, however, there are requests for new buildings, particularly from the Anglican Church, and requests from all the churches for the new buildings necessary for the promotion of vocational instruction. Therefore, unless the Government is in a position to provide the funds necessary to meet these requests, I am of the opinion that it would be sheer folly to build additional residential schools anywhere in the Dominion. The policy of the Government in respect to the construction of Indian day and residential schools has never been clearly defined at any time since I entered the Department. In this connection I should like to
refer to my memorandum to you on the operation of residential schools, dated May 31, 1940. In view of the fact that representatives of the churches have made arrangements to meet the Minister toward the end of December, with the object of discussing with him the desirability of a substantial increase in the present per capita grant allowances, it has occurred to me that the policy of the Government in respect to the building of residential schools and the operation of these schools might very well be reviewed prior to the Minister's interview with the representatives of the churches.

In respect to the request submitted by Canon Dixon, my recommendation is that a special grant be made to the Carcross school to enable this school to operate without loss during the present academic year and that this grant be made on the understanding that the school will cease to operate on the 30th of June, next. I recommend, also, that the Church be told definitely that it is not our intention to rebuild the residential school in the Yukon Territory at any time during the years immediately ahead of us.

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.
MISSIONARY SOCIETY OF THE CHURCH OF ENGLAND IN CANADA

The church House - 604 Jarvis Street,
Toronto 5, Ont.,
November 11, 1942.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I wired to you from St. John, N. B., with reference to the critical situation which had arisen in the school at Carcross. I have since received a copy of Mr. Hoey's letter of October 21st to Dr. Westgate informing him that it had been decided to reduce the pupilage in the school from 40 to 20.

In connection with the decision which has thus been made I would draw your attention to the statement in my aforementioned telegram that to reduce the numbers of children in the school would seriously increase the operating costs.

The per capita rate for the Carcross school is $250.00. With the discharge of 20 pupils this means a corresponding annual loss in income of $5000.00. While there will be some savings on items like food and clothing, the major items of expense, namely staff and overhead, will remain unchanged. Thus, whereas with a pupilage of 40 the per capita grant was sufficient to run the school, with the pupilage reduced to 20, the same per capita rate must result in heavy loss.

I write to ask, therefore, that under these special circumstances the Government will see its way to assume responsibility for this loss - or at least a considerable part of it.

Yours faithfully,

(sgd.) L. A. Dixon
MEMORANDUM:

Deputy Minister

You will find attached a memorandum dated November 16 submitted to me by Mr. Hoey and dealing with the operation of the Carcross Indian Residential School.

The facts set forth and the observation made by Mr. Hoey have a much wider application than to the question of the Carcross school itself. Mr. Hoey refers to his memorandum dealing with the general question of residential schools dated May 31, 1940. I have carefully re-read this memorandum and have discussed the matter with Mr. Hoey and Mr. Phelan.

I am in full agreement with the views held by the officials in charge of Indian education that the time has come when a definite decision should be reached regarding our policy in respect to residential schools. I hold, and have long held the opinion that the educational requirements of the vast majority of Indians could be met by day schools to the decided benefit of the Indians and to the financial advantage of the taxpayer.

As it has been pointed out very plainly by Mr. Hoey many times, both verbally and in writing, our vote for several years past has not been sufficient to keep these buildings in a proper state of repair. A steady deterioration is taking place in our physical equipment and the question must be decided whether we are to go forward in developing a residential school system or to direct our efforts in another direction.

Lately I have been disagreeably impressed by a number of police reports concerning truancy from these schools.

In Mr. Hoey's memorandum of May 31, 1940, mentioned above, you will note his recommendation that a number of dilapidated residential schools that are costly to repair and operate be closed and Indian day schools be substituted therefore. On page 9, paragraph 2, of the same report you will note the figures he gives showing that the amount saved in one year in per capita grants through the closing of certain residential schools would almost meet the cost of building Indian day schools to take care of the pupils affected.

(over)
I am in full agreement with Mr. Hoey's recommendation that a number of these residential schools be closed, and day schools substituted therefore. I would suggest that as soon as war regulations regarding building materials permit, the building of day schools and the closing of certain residential schools be proceeded with, in accordance with the plans and recommendation made by Mr. Hoey and outlined above.

Several days ago, a letter was received from Bishop Geddes of the Yukon, dealing with the Carcross school and carrying the suggestion that a system of day schools might be introduced into the Yukon.

(Signed) Harold W. McGill

INSTRUCTIONS FOR APPLYING PLASTIC ROCK NO. 225-100

Plastic Rock should be applied to a depth not greater than 1/2". If it is necessary to apply same to a greater depth, it would be advisable to put it down in two coats.

The room temperature where applied should not be under 45°Fahr. Be sure to keep contents of barrels from freezing.

CLEANING SURFACE

1. Clean all grease and loose dust from the floor before applying the bond.

2. APPLYING BOND TO WOOD FLOORS. When applying bond to wood floors, first add about half a pint of water to the gallon can. Then trowel a light coat to the surface. Allow to dry until it loses its tackiness and can be walked upon without lifting, before applying Plastic Rock. A good plan is to apply the bond the night before the job is to be done.

3. APPLYING BOND TO CONCRETE FLOORS. First moisten the floor with water. Add about one quart of water to the gallon of bond then apply with a broom or brush, allowing same to dry before applying Plastic Rock.

4. MIXING THE PLASTIC ROCK. First dry mix the rock and setting powder together. Then thoroughly mix in 3 gallons of water. The balance of the water required for the mix, namely 5 gals., should be mixed into the 5 gals. of paste. In other words, the total mix will include 5 gals. of water to the 5 gals. of the paste supplied. Now thoroughly mix the paste into the aggregate until the colour is uniform throughout. If the trowelled floor shows dark spots, you can rest assured it requires more mixing. The mixing can be done very fast with a small portable concrete mixer.

We find 5/16" iron depth strips best suited for laying the Plastic Rock for a ½" floor.

If you should find the mix a bit heavy to trowel, an extra pint or so of water may be added.

5. ROLLING THE SURFACE

A harder surface may be secured by rolling same with a water filled lawn roller while the floor is still partially set, usually in about 8 to 14 hours from the time it is laid.
