GENERAL DIRECTIONS FOR MIXING AND APPLYING
PLASTIC ROCK UNITS

NOTE: This sheet is furnished merely to illustrate the various steps necessary to follow when mixing and applying Plastic Rock Units of various sizes and grades. We also furnish specific directions for patching, waterproofing, etc. When requesting specific directions, please give all particulars such as type of base, wood, concrete, brick interior or exterior and whether used for pedestrian or heavy duty truck traffic.

1. THE UNIT: Your Plastic Rock Units come to you complete. Each ingredient is exactly in proper proportion, in its own container, all packed in one Unit. All Units contain rock, setting powder, asphalt paste and bond. Open the Unit and remove the setting powder, asphalt paste and bond. The BOND is used first.

2. BONDING: Sweep the floor clean and moisten it with water. Add a quart of water to each gallon of Bond and dump the mixture over the moistened floor. Each gallon of Bond, PLUS the quart of water, should cover 100 sq. ft. Scrub it into the surface, with a back and forth movement of the brush. Leave it rough and let it dry. Floor may be bonded the day before if desired.

MIXING

3. MIXING THE ROCK AND SETTING POWDER: The mixing should be done on a clean spot on a concrete floor or in a metal or watertight mortar box. Dump all of the rock in a pile. Sprinkle the setting powder over it. Mix the rock and powder thoroughly by turning it over at least three times while dry.

4. ADDING THE WATER: Pull the rock and powder away from the center of the pile, forming a basin, as shown in Fig. 4. Depending upon the type and size of Unit, add water as shown below:

VERY IMPORTANT: Measure the water carefully and use:

For Unit No. A-225-100 — ½" Heavy Duty, 5 gallons
For Unit No. A-225-20 — ½" Heavy Duty, 1 gallon
For Unit No. A-225-10 — ½" Heavy Duty, 2 quarts
For Unit No. A-221-100 — ¼" Light Duty, 4 gallons
For Unit No. A-221-25 — ¼" Light Duty, 1 gallon
For Unit No. A-229-200 — ⅛" Light Duty, 4 gallons
For Unit No. A-229-50 — ⅛" Light Duty, 1 gallon

(Directions continued on reverse side)
5. **WETTING THE ASPHALT PASTE:** After mixing flatten out the pile of wet rock and powder. Remove the asphalt paste from the package with trowel or shovel and smear it over the wet rock and powder as shown in Fig. 5.

Splash water over the paste, using NOT MORE than amount specified below.

For Unit No. A-225-100—1/2 gallon. For Unit No. A-221-25 — 1 pint.
For Unit No. A-225-20 — 1 pint. For Unit No. A-223-200—1/2 gallon.
For Unit No. A-225-10 — 1/2 pint. For Unit No. A-223-50 — 1 pint.
For Unit No. A-221-100—1/2 gallon.

6. **MIXING:** Now mix the wet asphalt paste and the wet rock and powder together by turning over the mass with shovels and cutting it through as shown in Fig. 6. MIXING MUST BE THOROUGH. No lumps of asphalt paste should appear in the complete mixture. It is usually necessary to turn over the entire mass about four times. Careless mixing will cause soft, sticky spots to appear in the finished floor, due to lumps of asphalt paste not being properly mixed with the aggregate.

7. **SCREEDING AND FLOATING:** If coarse Plastic Rock (No. 225) is being used, depth strips should be 3/8" thick. If fine Plastic Rock (No. 221) is being used, depth strips should be 3/16" thick. The thickness of the depth strips is very important. It regulates the uniform distribution of the mix. Strips are usually laid from 6 to 8 feet apart. The Plastic Rock mix is dumped between them distributed with a garden rake, and then levelled with a levelling board. See Fig. 7 at left. (No depth strips are needed when Plastic Rock No. 221 is used.)

The levelling board is usually 2' x 6' about 8 to 10 feet long, having a straight, smooth edge. It rests on the depth strips and the mix is leveled by riding the board back and forth across the strips with a forward motion. Fill any low spots with the mix evenly distributed across until surface is level. The levelling mix is then compacted to correct any imperfections and to fill voids. Now let the floor alone until it takes its initial set which may take several hours.

8. **FINISHING:** If a smooth finish is desired, the floor may be steel troweled, otherwise rolling traffic will roll it smooth. Cement finishers may begin troweling when their knees do not sink into the floor. FOR AN EXTRA SMOOTH FINISH, mix a small Unit of Plastic Rock No. 223 to the mortar consistency and apply as a very thin mololithic finish (about 1/4" deep). Use the James Plastic Rock surfaces. This mortar mixture merely serves to fill any small voids or rough spots in the No. 225 surfacing. A Plastic Rock No. 225 floor may thus be made as smooth as glass by expert finishers.

**PUTTING THE FLOOR INTO SERVICE**

The floor may be opened to traffic when dry or when sufficiently hard to withstand loads without marking.

**CURING AND COMPRESSING.**

A Plastic Rock floor never becomes brittle hard as compared to the hardness of concrete, brick or stone. During the first 30 days of its life, a perfect Plastic Rock floor may appear to be too soft to withstand heavy loads on steel wheels. This should cause no concern because the floor is in its "curing" stage. During this "curing" stage, the more traffic it receives the more quickly it will become thoroughly compacted. A Plastic Rock floor, under rolling traffic, automatically compacts to a density which is normal for the traffic conditions to which it is subjected.

**WHEN USING A CONCRETE MIXER:**

A standard "one bag" mixer will mix 100 sq. ft. of Plastic Rock No. 225 per batch. Pour Plastic Rock and settler powder into the mixer drum. The water is then added all at one time. Use same quantities of water as shown above and on reverse side. MIX THOROUGHLY before adding asphalt paste. Then mix 3 minutes or more after paste has been added. NEVER add asphalt paste to any DRY rock or powder.

**SPLITTING BATCHES:**

If any Unit is to be mixed in two or more batches, instead of all at one time, remove ALL the Plastic Rock aggregate from the package and turn it over several times to thoroughly mix the fine and coarse rock which may become separated in transit. The fine particles usually settle to the bottom of the package.

**SURFACES EXPOSED TO WEATHER:**

When Plastic Rock is to be exposed to weather and at the same time used for steel wheel traffic, apply a coat of Certified Emulsion No. 322. Use 1 gallon per 100 sq. ft. Scatter dry, fine sand into the coating as it is spread. Let traffic embed it into place.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER,

I am sending forward herewith a statement of total expenditures at Indian residential schools for the fiscal year 1942-43.

You will note that in addition to the general statement of expenditures, prepared by the Treasury officials, a summary has also been prepared with respect to expenditures at government-owned and church-owned schools. The total cost per pupil for the former, you will note, is $168.28. For this amount the Church, in operating the schools have supplied food, clothing, instruction. In the case of church-owned buildings, shelter is also provided by the churches. A large proportion of the cost involved in the transportation of pupils from Indian reserves to the residential schools is also borne by the church authorities.

I should like to direct your attention particularly to the last two items of the summarized statement. You will note that the cost of new buildings and repairs at government-owned schools amounted to $8.36 per pupil and that repairs and new buildings at church-owned schools amounted to $5.18. This higher figure, I may state, is due almost wholly to the expenditures necessary for the construction of a new residential school at Sturgeon Lake. These particular expenditures for the year under review amounted to $5,391.30. Plans and specifications of this building were submitted a few weeks ago to the officials of this Branch, for approval. The new building, which when completed will be semi-fireproof, appears to be very satisfactory. We were assured by the Bursar of the Diocese, who submitted the plans, that wages alone in the construction of this school during the spring and summer months exceeded $1,000 per month.

Re: Residences for Teachers at Indian Day Schools

In connection with Mr. Hoey's memorandum to you dated December 20th, last relative to the above, we are forwarding attached, duplicate blueprint copies of a design embodying accommodation as requested.

This type of bungalow residence, built of insulated frame construction, having warm air heating, electric wiring, and the indicated number of plumbing fixtures should cost in the neighborhood of $8,000, exclusive of water supply and sewage disposal facilities, which are factors peculiar to specific sites and conditions. Mr. Hoey suggests the possibility of heating the residence by a pipeless furnace, but in our opinion better distribution is afforded by the use of leaders, ducts and registers, to the various rooms.

It will be recalled that a six-roomed house designed for use as an Indian Agent's residence at Lennox Island, Prince Edward Island, was considered satisfactory as a typical Indian Agent's residence. Indian Affairs have copies of these drawings, and it is suggested that consideration be given to using the same drawings as an alternative design for teachers' residences. The cost for the alternative, under the same circumstances would also approximate $8,000.

These estimated costs would be increased on buildings located on isolated sites.

If a building as shown on the attached prints, is considered satisfactory, one print should be initialed and returned to this Service for our records, and further use.

Gentlemen:

In reply to your letter of June 14th in which you are inquiring as to the relative advantages or disadvantages of the battery charging type of electric generating plant as compared with the non-storage battery automatic type of plant, I would say that it is our opinion, borne out by experience, that for plants up to 10 Kilowatts in capacity the battery charging type of plant is the most satisfactory. Wear and tear is heavy on the automatic type because of its many starts and stops often times only carrying a very small load, e.g., one lamp. Generating machinery should be loaded with a load at least equal to one-third (1/3) of its rated capacity and is still more efficient when operated at or near its full rated capacity.

In any case batteries are required as starting batteries. These generally become a nuisance unless they are the main storage batteries. When the engine is started often and generates for only a short time the starting batteries become run down and are useless until charged. Since the main storage battery is due and receives regular attention, nuisances such as this are eliminated as long as the plant is in operating condition.

A high quality, long life battery of the iron clad type is most essential to successful operation of a storage battery type of plant, since it has greater efficiency throughout its life and provides greater economy.

If you have any special application we would be pleased to receive information in regard to it and to advise you thereon.

Yours truly,

W. J. Hickey,
Supv. Electrical Engineer.

Memorandum:

MR. HOEY,

On November 30 I gave you a draft of the Estimates for "Indian Education" for the fiscal year 1946-47. Under the heading "Structures and Parts - New Construction" there was included a request for certain day schools at a total estimated cost of $390,000.00.

On his return to the office this week from an inspection trip, Mr. Arnell brought to my attention the situation at Serpent River Reserve, located near Cutler, Ont. - Electoral District of Algoma East.

Several years ago the school was destroyed by fire and since that time it has been using a former Indian house as a school. This building has now reached a stage where it is practically impossible to repair it. There are approximately 35 children of school age there. Mr. Arnell strongly recommends that provision be made in the Appropriation for the fiscal year 1946-47 for a combined school and teacher's residence on this reserve.

This would involve an additional amount of $8,000.00. I would appreciate having your authority to include this with the other proposed new schools.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I beg to enquire whether the Department has arrived at any conclusion as to the supplying of mid-day meals at the day schools in the future.

There does not seem to be a clear cut policy in this connection and while I am aware that the payment of family allowance money should act as an extra so far as the Indians are concerned I do not think that the Department should lose sight of the fact that many of our Indian day school teachers are spending too much time in the preparation of the mid-day meal for the children when some of this responsibility might be thrown back on the parents now in receipt of family allowance money.

I think that it goes further than the actual supplying of a meal to the children going to school. I believe that if the school teacher supplied soup or a hot drink and biscuits and in addition kept a fairly close check on the contents of lunch boxes which the children are bringing to school it would give an indication to the teacher and the information could be passed on to the farming instructor and Indian Agent as to the kind of food that is being prepared in the Indian homes.

In nearly all Indian homes where children are attending school there are usually younger children not yet of age to attend. If the mother is required to prepare a reasonable lunch for the child or children going to school she must, of necessity, be doing a reasonable amount of cooking and baking which will be beneficial to the children at home.

I do not wish to have my ideas conflict with the intentions with respect to payment of family allowances but I think that we should make use of the payment of family allowances wherever possible to improve the living conditions of the children in their homes as well as the children going to school.

Many of the Indian women are quite able to prepare a good meal if they have the inclination to do so but many are quite willing to give their children almost any kind of a meal which will not give them too much trouble and let the mid-day meal at the school make up.......
mid-day meal at the school make up the difference. I am sure it is the intention that the money received through family allowances should be considered an extra only to this extent.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

For some time I have been wondering whether it would be possible to arrange to have our building programme commence earlier in the year than has been done in the past. If construction could commence, say early in May, it would be possible to have the buildings completed by September or earlier, and this is particularly important in the case of schools which open on or about September 1.

Would it be possible to make arrangements to invite tenders in March for buildings, the plans and specifications for which are complete, and award contracts immediately after April 1 when money is available in the new fiscal year's appropriation.

You have in your office copies of the Schedules (A) required by the Department of Reconstruction for our 1946-47 building programme. It was hoped that it would be possible to carry out this programme in its entirety, but we realise that certain conditions, such as the shortage of staff at Ottawa, scarcity of materials and labour, etc., may prevent the realisation of our wishes. However, as some of the plans and specifications are complete I should like to know whether tenders could be called in March for these buildings and in April or soon after for others for which the plans are perhaps not entirely completed. The buildings which are of primary importance are listed below:

Kahsami Indian Reserve, N.S.
School, teachers' residence and water system.
R.C.M.P. residence.

Shubenacadie, N.S.
Residence for Indian Agent, combined office and warehouse,
Clerk's residence.
Teachers' residence, Principal's residence.

Gardiner Agency, Ont.
Four classroom Day School.

Six Nations, Ont.
R.C.M.P. Barracks.
At the Eskasoni Reserve, as you probably know, we are proceeding as rapidly as possible with the moving of the Indians to this reserve. The agency residence, office and warehouse, Principal's residence are built. When it is possible for these buildings to be occupied the Agent will be able to give adequate supervision and direction on the reserve. However, we have a number of children of school age on the reserve and no school for them. We will be criticised if the school is not erected and ready for operation by September 1, 1946. The school cannot be operated until the teachers' residence is provided, as there is no place in which the teachers can live.

At the Sinibouacan Reserve the Indians have moved as quickly as houses could be erected for them. The school is in operation, but it is being operated by lay teachers. The men cannot move to the reserve for teaching purposes until their residence is built and the Principal's residence is also needed. The agency staff cannot give the proper supervision to the Indian population or administer the affairs of the agency until quarters are provided.

At the Caradoc Agency, Ont., owing to the condition of the Mount Elgin Residential School it is felt that it would be impracticable to spend a large sum of money to repair this building. Consequently it has been agreed with the United Church of Canada to close this school at the end of June. We have promised that we will erect and operate a four-room day school in its place. For this building, for which plans may not have been commenced, it is suggested that the plan of the St. Catherine School be used. Possibly some slight changes to suit local conditions might be required, but in the main the plan is suitable.

I realise that the time of your architectural staff has to be divided to meet the needs of all the branches of this department, and that only a certain amount of time can be spent on Indian Affairs work. It would be appreciated, however, if that time could be spent on the projects mentioned above in an effort to have them completed during 1946.
I trust that I am not leaving with you the impression that I am not interested in buying the other buildings on our programme erected in 1946. There are many places where, at the moment, I cannot see just what can be arranged so that our staffs will be housed. There is a crying need for residence for the Clerk at the Fisher River Agency, Man., at the Saddle Lake Agency, Alta., there is no place for the Clerk to live - the buildings at the Lesser Slave Lake Agency are not suitable or tenable and a new site at High Prairie, Alta., has been acquired - we have no buildings or offices for our staff at Fort St. John, B.C., and at St. Regis, Que., the Agent has had to move into Cornwall as the agency residence has been condemned for residence purposes. These are just a few of our more urgent and immediate needs, not to mention the school programme all the projects on which are required.

If there is any way in which the officials of my staff can assist or co-operate with your officials in order to facilitate our work, I shall be glad to arrange this if you will inform me what information is required or what they can do to help. I know that for the last decade the building programme has been so curtailed that we are now in the unhappy position of requiring everything at once and that you have not the staff to handle such a volume of work. I will welcome any suggestions you care to make so that we may be helpful.

I should appreciate knowing whether it is possible for your branch to take care of the projects at the locations mentioned early in the new fiscal year.

It is my understanding that a meeting will be held at the office of the Minister to discuss the subject matter of this memorandum at the earliest possible date.

M.W.

Memorandum:

MR. HOEY

Equipment for Residential Schools -
Hand Potato Peelers.

I have today had a visit from Mr. Whittle of the Hobart Manufacturing Company, who specialize in the construction of kitchen machines.

We had a thorough discussion on the use of hand potato peelers, both in civilian establishments and their projected use in our residential schools. Mr. Whittle pointed out that the Hobart Company no longer manufactures a hand potato peeler, for the following reasons:

(a) A mechanical peeler does the work of three hand peelers.

(b) A hand peeler is made with cast iron gears and is without ball bearings. This makes it a very difficult machine to operate. In fact, it would be almost impossible for children of school age to turn the handle.

(c) The Canadian Army discarded the use of such hand peelers after using them for about a year. They found that these machines did not stand up to the heavy usage which they were given and, in general, proved unsatisfactory. They adopted, eventually, the mechanical peeler.

Mr. Whittle has recently been discharged from the Canadian Army, in which he served as Chief Equipment Officer with the Royal Canadian Army Service Corps Catering Branch. Therefore, I feel that his recommendations can be taken as...
not only those of a commercial representative but of a man who has had considerable experience in the use and installation of kitchen equipment. The attached catalogue lists two small machines which would be of use in our schools:

Dear Mr. Neary:

Pursuant to our conversation yesterday, regarding Potato Peelers for use in Welfare and Training Schools, you will recall that I expressed considerable doubt as to the practicality of Hand-operated machines for this purpose. In this respect I would like to summarize briefly the reasons that have convinced me that a peeler of this type would not be practical for your purpose:

1. In my position as "Officer in Charge - Kitchen Equipment" during the war, attached to Canadian Army Headquarters, I had ample opportunity to observe the effectiveness of hand-operated peelers. I can state, without hesitation, that machines of this type are not satisfactory. They are not well made. This leads to frequent breakdowns and consequently excessive repair work and requests for parts.

2. Hand machines can be operated only by strong, healthy men. Even then considerable objection is made to operating them because the physical exertion required is excessive.

3. The hand-operated machine saves very little time.

I feel sure, Mr. Neary, that the more you investigate this question the more convinced you will be, as I am, that hand-operated machines will do little to solve your problem. Hand-operated machines are practically obsolete where hydro-electric power is available.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

I enclose Memorandum-to-Council covering the amount provided in Vote 183, 1946-47 for the purchase and maintenance of equipment, repairs and improvements to the church-owned Indian Residential Schools. As such expenditures constitute a grant, it is considered desirable to have the approval of the Governor General in Council. The amounts mentioned for the schools are exactly the same as the estimate detailed originally presented to Treasury Board, with the exception of the Braine-skin Residential School in the Province of Alberta. The amount of $1,000.00 was specifically provided for this school, but owing to the necessity for paying accounts for supplies that had been ordered previous to March 31, 1946, it was found necessary to expend at this school the amount of $1,507.57. The over-expenditure of $507.57 has been taken from the amount of $1,000.00 provided for maintenance of equipment at any or all church-owned residential schools, leaving a balance in this particular item of $492.43, which from previous experience will be sufficient.

A similar Order-in-Council was secured in the last fiscal year; see P C 41/692, dated March 1, 1946.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, SURVEYS and ENGINEERING BRANCH

Proposed One-room Day School Plan

This branch approves the plan of the one-room Indian Day School as prepared by you in April, 1939, as the basic plan for the twenty-three new one-room day schools which we intend building during the 1947-48 fiscal year.

We would like the following minor alterations made:

1. That the basement be at least 10' in height from floor to floor, allowing at least 7'4" clear height at the lowest point.

2. That the minimum window size be 3'7" x 4'.

3. That as many windows as possible be provided in the basement to give there as close to the ratio of lighting as provided in the classrooms.

4. That book shelves be provided along the wall with the windows, and running at window level height.

5. That an ample book supply cupboard be provided in one of the rear corners of the room so that the teacher can lock therein the supply of paper, pencils, etc.

Director
Ottawa, February 14, 1947.

Plan for a Two Room Indian Day School

As you are aware, we have included in our next year's estimates appropriations for the construction of three two-room Indian day schools. In order to find out how the two-room day schools recently constructed have been standing up, one of our officials visited the Maria Indian Day School at Maria, P.Q.

This school was constructed in May, 1939 under your Plan No. 741.

We would like our schools planned for construction this year modified slightly as hereunder in view of our experience with the Maria school.

1. The school should be raised to provide between 11' and 11'6" from floor to ceiling in the basement.

2. The basement windows should be at least twice their present height to provide better lighting for industrial art classes.

3. In order to accommodate the larger classes we anticipate, the classrooms should be lengthened to provide for 40 pupils. To do this it is recommended that they be lengthened to between 30' and 33', inside length.

4. A separate entrance should be provided to the teachers' residence, with a small 6' x 6' covered verandah. It is believed that this entrance should be situated to lead into the livingroom along the front wall.
5. That consideration be given to excavating below the teachers' residence in order to extend the basement space. If this is done, this space should be insulated in order to provide a dry storage space for use as a dispensary and first aid room.

The present heating arrangements have apparently proved satisfactory. However, in view of the above recommendations, it is realized that you may have to make modifications.

Director
February 27, 1947.

I have your letter of February 4th, 1947, regarding the matter of the construction of additional school accommodation in this Province during the coming fiscal year, and note that an amount of $42,500 is being requested for this purpose.

The items will be dealt with herein in the sequence in which they are listed in your letter:

1. Babine Agency Hazleton.

A two (or three) class-room school with teacher's living quarters should be provided at this point. A memorandum on the subject from Inspector Coleman, is enclosed in which considerable information on the situation at Hazelton and vicinity will be found. Of the two sites referred to, by Inspector Coleman, I should say that the 5-acre area belonging to Arthur Mowatt, as the more suitable in-as-much as it provides for present and future playground space. However, this is a point that should be looked into on the ground by Mr. R. F. Davey, Inspector of schools.

The existing set-up suggests the advisibility of a non-sectarian school operated and controlled direct by the Department. Provision might be
made to include the children from the nearby Kispiox, Glen Vowell and Hagwilget reserves, in which case, arrangement for the transportation of the pupils of these Reserves to and from the school would be necessary. From the information I have before me however, I would be inclined to leave Kispiox out of the suggested amalgamation. I consider it most important, however, that Inspector Davey look into the situation on the ground, and report his findings and recommendations before we proceed with construction.

There are no Contractors at Hazelton, or in the vicinity who could undertake construction. I understand, however, that building is more or less at a stand still in Prince Rupert, and it might be possible to get a firm from that town to undertake the work. John Currie and Son, Contractors and Builders, Prince Rupert, who built our school at Bella Bella, might be interested.

The need of a new school at Hazelton, is urgent and construction should be proceeded with if at all possible this coming fiscal year.

2. Bella Coola Agency
Kelmtu Reserve.

A new school with teacher's quarters is needed here, but I should say that the need is more urgent at Alert Bay, where there is a large day school pupilage with very inadequate accommodation. It might be well to consider using the funds provided in items 2 and 3, to assist in providing the accommodation required at Alert Bay. This is a matter that will be discussed with Inspector Davey, on his return from the North, and you will be further advised in this connection in due course.

3. Kwawkewlth Agency
Cape Mudge.

It is intended to use one of the buildings at the Port Hardy Military Camp, for the necessary
accommodation at this point, and if this is done, most of the funds allotted for Cape Mudge, could be used for the proposed construction at Alert Bay. Mr. T. Johnson, Builder and Contractor at Alert Bay, would no doubt be interested in the work at Kelinitu, Cape Mudge and Alert Bay, but likely on a daily basis only.

4. Lytton Agency.
Seabird Island Reserve.

A new school should be erected here this year. Mr. William Swan, Hatzic, B.C., would undertake the work on a daily basis. Mr. Swan is a well known and reliable contractor and builder and has done good work for us at both the Kamloops and St. Mary's Residential Schools.

5. New Westminster Agency.
Pemberton Reserve.

The proposed addition to the existing school at this point should be proceeded with. Mr. W. Swan, Hatzic, B.C. would undertake this work in conjunction with the proposed building at Seabird Island.

It would be well to have the Surveys and Engineering Branch, undertake the supervision and responsibility for the construction authorized, as this office has not the staff to undertake such work. Certainly the projects under items 1, 4, and 5 should be handled in this way and also the proposed school at Alert Bay, if the Department decides to proceed with construction of a new unit there.

A further report will be submitted following a discussion of the subject with Inspector Davey.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

In the instance of non-denominational day schools, religious teaching shall take place only as hereinafter provided.

(a) Such religious teaching shall take place only during the last half hour of the teaching day and shall be conducted by any Christian clergyman whose charge includes any portion of the reserve or by any person duly authorized by such clergyman, or by a teacher when so authorized.

(b) Where so specified in such band resolutions, religious teaching during the prescribed period may take place only on certain specified days of the week instead of on every teaching day.

(c) In any Indian day school where the average attendance of Roman Catholic children is 25 or upwards, the Minister shall, if required by a petition of parents or guardians of such number of Roman Catholic children, employ at least one certified Roman Catholic teacher in such school. In any day school where the average attendance of Protestant children is 25 or upwards, the Minister shall if required by the petition of parents or guardians of such children, employ at least one duly certified Protestant teacher.

(d) Where religious teaching is required to be carried on in any school in pursuance of the foregoing provisions and there are Roman Catholic and Protestant children attending the school and the school room accommodation does not permit of the pupils being placed in separate rooms for the purpose of religious teaching, provision shall be made by the regulations of the department whereby the time allotted for religious teaching shall be divided in such a way that the religious teaching of Roman Catholic children shall be carried on during the prescribed period of one-half of the teaching days in each month, and the religious teaching of the Protestant children shall be carried on during the prescribed period of one-half of the teaching days of each month.

(e) No separation of pupils by religious denominations shall take place during the secular school work.
(f) Where the school room accommodation permits, instead of allotting different days of the week to different denominations for the purpose of religious teaching the pupils may be separated when the hour for religious teaching arrives and placed in separate rooms.

(g) No pupils shall be permitted to be present at any religious teaching unless the parents or guardians of such pupils desire it. If the parents or guardians do not desire the attendance of pupils during such religious teaching, then such pupils shall be dismissed before the religious teaching is begun, or shall remain in another room.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

School Construction Programme -
Indian Affairs Branch.

Included in our Estimates for 1947-48 is a sum for the construction of some 43 classrooms in one, two, four and twelve-room schools. This latter school is the day school planned on the Caughnawaga Reserve and has been the subject of considerable correspondence and discussion between the Surveys and Engineering Branch and this Branch, since we first requested its construction on December 12, 1946. Under file I A 1256-24, dated March 12, 1947, we received a minute memorandum from the Director of Surveys and Engineering in which it was stated as follows:

"We propose directing every effort toward completing our work on this project as soon as possible, but with our unreasonably small staff depleted by the recent resignations of Mr. Horwood and Mr. Barnes, we are no longer prepared to estimate dates within which phases of our work will be completed."

In January the Chief Architect was given the list of buildings which we intend to build next year. On March 7 we sent him a memorandum officially confirming our building requirements. A copy of this memorandum is attached for your information.

On February 24 another memorandum was sent to the Director of the Surveys and Engineering Branch concerning
the erection of two day schools in Sault Ste. Marie Agency (as included in the above list). They were advised that our Educational Survey Officer was ready to proceed to the site of these schools with one of their officials when they were ready to survey the actual location of the buildings.

As you are doubtless aware, we have approximately 10,000 Indian children who are not receiving education of any kind. Both the Indians and the members of the Joint Parliamentary Committee, as well as many Canadian citizens, are keenly aware of this fact and we must endeavour to provide classroom accommodation at once. A conservative estimate is that a minimum of 300 classrooms is required. It is imperative that this programme be undertaken as soon as possible and without any further delays. Both the Minister and Mr. Jackson have been very co-operative in permitting the inclusion of appropriations to cover the construction of 43 classrooms this year.

However, it would appear that we will be able to construct only a small percentage of these schools, unless some immediate action is taken to remedy the situation as revealed by the Director of Surveys and Engineering in the memorandum of March 12, quoted above.

MEMORANDUM:

Re: General Observations in connection with Mechanical Services at Indian Residential Schools.

In the course of inspections carried out at various residential schools, and in consideration of field reports submitted by inspecting engineers, a number of points are repeatedly being brought to our attention. This memorandum is intended to comment on certain of the more important items with the view of placing before the Indian Affairs Branch, information which may prove to be of value in bringing the mechanical services in these buildings up to an economical and efficient level and maintaining that level.

While some of the schools vary somewhat in design and personnel, the heating plants are required to perform a service along more or less uniform lines, and with this in mind, it is felt that certain facts pertaining to the welfare of the institutions, should be reviewed.

One of the outstanding points which is continually being brought to the fore, is a lack of domestic hot water. It should be borne in mind that a certain normal wastage of this commodity is unavoidable, but nevertheless, without exception, investigations and analyses of our field engineers reports have always shown that the supply has been short; and in addition, the methods of heating water as well as the originally estimated capacities, have been well under what is considered to be normal requirements of good design.

The majority of boiler plants in the schools thus far visited and reported on, have the necessary boiler capacity to heat the amount of water needed. This capacity has not been used in many cases, to the best advantage. Many of the schools have used jacket heaters which have rapidly burnt out and have been replaced with similar equipment. Other schools have used below-the-waterline type heaters, which represents a nearer approach to the solution of the problem if such heaters are properly sized, but which up to now have been more or less ineffective. Still other schools have attempted to press their high pressure laundry boilers into this service, imposing as a consequence, a load far in excess of their capabilities.

Embracing somewhat on the foregoing paragraph, and considering any of the schools which have two steam heating boilers, it is pointed out that either boiler can carry the load except under the most severe weather conditions. This leaves one unit idle for a large part of the season and there is no good reason why this excess capacity should not be used to heat, by means of an indirect heater of the proper type, the domestic hot water.

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.
This would pay dividends in maintaining a reasonable standard of efficiency and would be much less costly than allowing a plant to approach collapse before action was taken, which always means a much greater expenditure and degree of discomfort and inconvenience, always evident when major operations are carried out. Proper cleaning implements should be provided and where necessary, memoranda outlining the purpose of the various items of boiler room equipment with advice on how to use same to the best advantage should be provided, and an attempt made to make the operating staff feel that their work is appreciated and that it forms not the least important part of the School's welfare.

Additional itemized comment could be offered but it is felt that the foregoing general remarks will bring to the attention of Indian Affairs, some of the principal points which are contributing in no small way to repeated failures and near failures in the heating, plumbing and domestic water services.

Chief Engineer.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, Regina, April 21st, 1947

Dear Mr. Hoey -

The Indian Association of Alberta wishes to enter a strong protest against the fact that day schools are not apparently being established at the following reserves of the Edmonton Agency, Paul's Band, Alexander, Alexis, Enoch's Band and the Saddle Lake Agency, the following reserves, Paddle Lake, Goodfish Lake, Beaver Lake.

We do very much appreciate the fact that a day school is under consideration at Michel's of Edmonton Agency and sincerely trust that nothing will be permitted to interfere with its completion.

We have furnished a census of the children of those reserves who would be accommodated in day schools. We have set forth our arguments at very great length but, when Mr. Doucet, (I believe) made his inspection, he seems to have disregarded our more intimate knowledge of these reserves, which I have mentioned. We are of the opinion that the members of our organization are very familiar with the conditions on those reserves. We have every respect for Mr. Doucet and his opinion but we do believe that a closer consultation with the Indians concerned would have been advisable. When matters of this sort are under consideration, there should be a Band Meeting, not merely a Council Meeting at the Agency and every Indian should be given his chance to say something.

In our meetings we have discussed this matter at great length. In a sense they - the Indians - have given the matter very serious consideration. I too as an educationist of some experience, have thought it over very carefully. I have discussed the matter with several Public School Inspectors who have made visits to Indian Residential Schools. They agree
Generally that in the cases mentioned day schools are now desirable.

One young man, for whom I have considerable respect, states it thus, "I have no idea how to raise my own children because I am not given a chance. My children spoke only English when they went to school but now they speak Cree. I live on my reserve; I can make a living for them. The white schools will not take them in because they are afraid that all the Indian children will come there. I can teach them to milk cows at home. My wife can keep a good house (She can too because I like to stay there)."

Sir, I know he is speaking the truth not only for himself but for many on his reserve.

The case for day schools on these reserves, especially Paul's Band, Enoch's Band, and Alexander is too strong to disregard further. We know that it may mean closing the Indian schools at St. Albert, and probably at Edmonton (Protestant). The Edmonton plant may very well be used as a superior school for advanced education, a matter which should be carefully considered. I mean by a superior school, one which will concentrate on advancing promising Indian children beyond Grade 6, and preparing them for something other than life at present lived on the reserves.

The school at St. Albert has many other functions already and extremely valuable functions they are.

Since the Protestant children from the Saddle Lake Agency and from the Hobbsma Agency must go to the Edmonton School, there is a strong argument for day schools on the reserves of those Agencies. If the present schools could turn out men such as those educated in the old McDougall Orphanage School, or the Industrial schools at Dunbow, Calgary and Red Deer, there might be an argument against day schools. But the present schools have failed to turn out men like the Steinhauers, Heubens Bull, the Rabbitts, the Houses, MacLean and Hunters of Morley and many others. I have yet to see the young men turned out by the present schools, except St. Paul's at Cardston, who are of the calibre of those here mentioned.

From those schools mentioned I should like to turn to the case of the Indians of the Louis Bull Reserve, Hobbsma Agency. These people have several times asked for a day school. There is not enough
room at the Ermineskin School at Hobbs. However, a number of these children are protestants and must go to Edmonton; there is a building which could be repaired and put into use on that reserve. But as all this is already set forth in our subject on Education in the Minutes and Proceedings, Nos.15 and 21, 1946, To repair and reopen this building as a day School would solve the question of room at the Ermineskin School, the hesitancy of the Protestant Indians to send their children all the way to Edmonton, and be an enormous saving in the long run to the Indian Affairs Branch. As you know there will soon be the question of a new building at the Ermineskin School.

Now to those Indians living at Pigeon Lake or Ta-me-o Beach. The school which was put in there by the Province for the white children could have accommodated the Indians there as well. We understand that there was some quibbling over payment for tuition which would not have amounted to any appreciable sum in the long run, here is a set fee in this province for children attending schools other than their own. Instead of worrying over a matter of a few cents on a daily basis, this fee could have been paid for those children. BUT, the confidence of the Indians has been weakened in the Indian Affairs Branch by the failure of the Province and the Department to get together on the matter and their dissatisfaction has been increased. Their children are receiving an inferior education - the most serious matter of all.

We recognize that a change may for some time produce few tangible results. But there is reason to doubt the tangible results now being produced.

If the Branch will act on this matter, please let the I.A.A. have some representation in any investigation. They are no getting over the fact that Indians are still afraid of speaking out before a group of officials only.

I ask your consideration of this matter and would appreciate hearing from you. We know that you can proceed without delaying the matter on account of the Committee.

I feel certain that your personal interest is with the Indians in this and that you will expedite matters without delay.

Sincerely—

Re: Two-roomed Indian Day Schools.

Reference is made to your memorandum of May 30th last in which you enquired when working drawings for the above would likely be available.

These drawings are being based on the original plans prepared in 1939 for a school at Maria, Quebec, but revisions requested by your Branch in your memorandum of February 21st, 1947, necessitated a complete set of new drawings.

Sketches were prepared and the difficulties arising from the new floor and window heights were worked out. Working drawings were begun but due to the number of projects required by the Agencies Division of your Branch and draughting requirements contingent on suggested revisions to heating plants and domestic hot water distribution systems in Indian Residential schools across the Dominion, covered by a series of inspection reports by our Mr. Hargreaves, it became necessary to defer further operations on the two-roomed school until some of that work had been disposed of.

However work on the drawings for the two-roomed school was resumed on May 30th and it is hoped that if no interruptions occur they will be available early in July.

Erected at Low Cost in Record Quick Time

There has always been a need for low cost homes suited to the requirements of the average family of modest means. Homes that can be erected easily and quickly at moderate cost, yet which provide modern accommodation, combined with individuality of design and plan arrangement. Hallidays have devoted a great deal of time and thought to the planning and designing of a group of attractive homes which can be built and financed by the man who must consider cost first,—the man who must build at the lowest possible expense.

WELL BUILT INSULATED HOMES

For several years, we have been supplying sectional homes and cottages that are erected quickly and easily at minimum cost. Many of our customers do all the work of erection without engaging paid help except to build the foundation and chimney or perhaps for the finish woodwork inside. But until we devised our Simplex System of interchangeable wall sections, such buildings were limited to one or two designs. Now, home builders may choose from many attractive designs and a wide variety of plan arrangements as shown in this booklet. Simplex homes are just the kind of homes many people want, low in cost yet well and strongly built with insulated walls, suitable for year round use.

HIGH GRADE MATERIALS

Because of the care taken in the construction of the wall sections, owners find that these Simplex homes are warm and comfortable even in severe weather, requiring only a minimum amount of fuel. Approved methods and high grade materials are used throughout. Plans have been designed by experts assuring smart appearance and well arranged interiors.

MAIN WALLS IN PREFABRICATED UNITS

Simplex homes cost little to build because we ship the materials to you in the most convenient form for quick, easy assembly. Floor joists are ready-cut, main walls are sent in prefabricated sections. We make up these wall units in our own workshops. Skilled men, using production line methods, quickly frame up walls, nail on the thick damp proof sheathing and insulation, then add the finish siding. Windows and doors are carefully fitted and hung in place. Shop construction of wall sections ensures uniformly better workmanship throughout. Because we do this difficult, time-consuming part of the work in our shop, you save time and money in the erection of your home. Once the floor joists are set in place, the assembling of main walls and gables is completed in record time. Each unit fits the next accurately and easily and is quickly bolted in place.

ROOF RAFTERS READY-CUT

Roof rafters are sent ready-cut, notched to fit, and can be erected just as fast as they can be nailed in place. Applying the roof sheathing boards requires only "handy man" ability to do a thoroughly practical job.

PARTITION FRAMING READY-CUT

All studding for inside partitions and all ceiling joists are sent ready-cut also cellar stairs if included. Floor boards come in random lengths to be cut and nailed as required; inside doors are mortised to receive the locks and inside door and window trim is supplied in ready-cut form. In short, we send materials for your home in such a way that no man possessing ordinary ability to use a hammer, a wrench and a saw, need hesitate about undertaking the bulk of the work, with only the help of family or friends.

ERCTION TIME SAVED

If you prefer to engage paid help to erect your Simplex home, the method of supplying materials in prefabricated and ready-cut units reduces the labor cost to a minimum. Because of the short time required for erection and the fact that only inexpensive "handy man" labor is required, Simplex homes are made ready for occupation at surprisingly low cost. The scarcity of skilled workers need cause no worry to the builder of a Simplex home.

Memorandum:

MR. HOEY

Port Hardy Military Camp

I have recently had an opportunity of inspecting the army buildings which Colonel Hamile has had moved to the Six Nations Reserve. They are progressing very rapidly in having these set up as school buildings and they should prove satisfactory for a period of 5 years or more.

The attached letter and report concerns the removal of buildings from the Port Hardy Military Camp to be re-erected similarly as schools in the Kwawkewlth Agency at Alert Bay.

I had an opportunity of discussing this situation with Major Mackay during his recent visit here. This project will do a great deal to alleviate the present shortage of educational facilities for the Indians in this area. In all it will provide the following buildings:

(a) A four-room school at Alert Bay with two teachers' dwellings,

(b) A teacher's residence at Campbell River,

(c) A one-room school and teacher's residence at Tournour Island,

(d) A one-room school and residence at Gilford Island,

(e) A one-room school and residence at Cape Mudge,

(f) A one-room school and residence at Village Island.

....... when
When Major Mackay's telegram arrived on Saturday, I did not hesitate to draft the telegram of approval for your signature. The reason for the immediate decision being necessary was the fact that men had to leave Vancouver on June 28 in order to begin this operation at once.

The immediate funds necessary are available under the item entitled "Cape Mudge - one-room school and residence - $8,000." included in our Main Estimates. In order that we may fully avail ourselves of this excellent opportunity of securing important classroom accommodation, I would also recommend that we consider the transfer of $5,000.00 from the $10,000.00 which is available in our Vote for the assembling of materials for the residential school at Teslin, Y.T. Major Clark estimates that $5,000.00 will be sufficient to carry out most of this work at Teslin this summer.

I would appreciate an opportunity of discussing this project with you and Miss Walton. You will note that one of the buildings will be used as a stores building for agency purposes.

[Signature]

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Re: Fort Hardy Military Camp Buildings.

With reference to your letter of June 27th and attached report addressed by Mr. C. E. Webb to Mr. T. S. Mills, outlining the uses to which these buildings could be put together with estimates of costs, you did not make any recommendations in regard to having some of these materials used for the erection of the stores building, presumably for agency purposes, at Alert Bay. Is it your wish and recommendation that we set aside $1,200.00, the estimate contained in Mr. Webb's report, for this building from the Indian Agency Vote, and can arrangements be made to handle this in the same way as the school programme is being arranged for.

We discussed at some length when you were in Ottawa the need of replacing the agency residence and office at Alert Bay, but as funds were not available this year it was decided to ask Mr. Todd to try to rent a residence if he was concerned as to the safety of his family owing to the condition of the residence. It has occurred to me that there might be materials available from this camp which could be set aside for the erection of an office building or possibly both office and residence. Will you kindly take the matter up with Mr. Webb and ascertain whether there is any likelihood of suitable materials, at least for an agency office, being available. If so please advise what sum should be set aside in the agency Vote for removal and re-erection and other costs.

M.W.

Director.

Ottawa, July 10, 1947.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, British Columbia.

Fort Hardy Military Camp

Please find attached a copy of our memorandum which was submitted by our Director to the Deputy Minister concerning the utilization of certain buildings at the above camp, for educational purposes.

We have today received notification of the Deputy Minister's concurrence in our proposals.

This means that a total sum of $26,000.00 has been set aside for use on this project.

It is hoped that this sum will be sufficient and that we may be also able to consider putting an outer covering on the buildings of either asbestos shingle, insul-brick or cedar shingles. Colonel Ramsay has finished the army buildings at Brantford with both asbestos shingle and insul-brick. Of the two, he has found the insul-brick to be more satisfactory. However, in view of the lumber situation in British Columbia, you may prefer the use of cedar shingles or cedar siding.

To date we have not received from our Survey and Engineering Branch an official letter concerning this project. However, we are proceeding on the assumption that Mr. Webb's letter to his Chief Engineer will be dealt with by them in the near future.

School Building Programmes for 1948-49

We are now in the process of formulating plans for school buildings which will be required for the next fiscal year.

Residential Schools

We hope for the erection of three residential schools,

1. Teslin, Yukon,
2. A school in Northern Manitoba,
3. A school in Northern Saskatchewan.

We have already written to you on May 31st concerning the proposed school at Teslin and have requested that your local engineer investigate our selected site.

The schools in Northern Manitoba and Saskatchewan will replace those burned down during the war.

Day Schools

We hope to erect at least the following schools:

1. 2 four-room day schools
2. 4 two-room day schools
3. 40 one-room day schools

In most instances the day schools will follow our standard plan. However, there is a possibility that certain
of the schools will be for classrooms only and not combined teacher's residence.

In all, as you can see, we are doing everything possible to overcome the great deficit in the educational facilities now being provided for our Indian children. We are under increasing pressure from both the Indians, the Indian Committee and the public generally to provide classrooms for these children. A conservative estimate is that at least four hundred additional classrooms are required to accommodate children for whom there are at present no schools. Our plans for 1948-49 should help to reduce the required number of classrooms.

However, we have not yet received the specifications for the Caughnawaga Day School. We requested the preparation of these plans in 1944.

The specifications for the two-room day school arrived on August 7th. We requested preparation of these plans on February 21, 1947.

According to information you have given us, it would seem evident that you lack the staff necessary to prepare plans for these three residential schools and at the same time continue to do the necessary major repairs required constantly at our residential schools.

We must immediately face this problem as our building program for 1948-49 must be planned now. Therefore, we are bringing this situation to your attention so that we can have your considered opinion as to the feasibility of hiring private architects to carry out a part, at least, of our next year's program.

DEPUTY MINISTER

I enclose Memorandum to Council covering the amount provided in Vote 517, 1947-48, for the purchase and maintenance of equipment, repairs and improvements to the church-owned Indian residential schools.

As such expenditures constitute a grant, it is considered desirable to have the approval of the Governor General in Council.

A similar Order in Council was secured in the last fiscal year - see P.C. 4213 of October 11th, 1946.

Some of these items are large because certain of these schools have been having difficulties during recent years in getting essential repairs carried out to their buildings. This is particularly true of those schools in the more isolated parts of the country. Workmen were not willing to go to such places during the war years. Therefore, we face an accumulation of repairs.

This is the cause of the large sums required for the four schools situated in Northern Alberta.

(a) Grouard - where $4,350. is required for repairs to the interior and exterior of the building, the pig pen and a new dough mixer.
(b) Holy Angels - where $5,700. is required for repairs to the water system and a new battery for the lighting system.

(c) Joussard - where $3,350. is required for repairs to the exterior and the root house, and a new dough mixer.

(d) Vermilion - where $5,350. is required for repairs to the roof of the barn, interior of school, a new washer and a dough mixer.

In British Columbia we have two similar instances.

(a) Cariboo - where $5,000. is required for repairs and replacements in the power house.

(b) Christie - where $10,000. is required for building a 4 mile road to the school. For over 20 years all supplies and persons landing at this isolated spot on the stormy west coast of Vancouver Island have been carried ashore on human backs. Now the school management have erected a wharf in a sheltered cove and the road is required to give the school a proper supply route for the first time since it was constructed.

Educational Facilities in the Northwest Territories

I have received your letter of September 11 and attached report from Inspector McKinnon, summarizing the educational situation at each settlement in the Northwest Territories.

There are really three aspects to the problem of providing schools which Mr. McKinnon recommends:

(a) As you are doubtless aware, the Indian Act requires that we operate a denominational school system. It is noted that Mr. McKinnon has recommended non-denominational day schools. It is felt that while church authorities are aware of the present clauses of the Indian Act dealing with this subject it will be extremely difficult to establish non-denominational schools until the Parliamentary Committee decides on the future educational clauses which it will recommend to Parliament for inclusion in our new Indian Act.

(b) The problem of having these schools erected is one that will present many difficulties. We have had a most disappointing year insofar as the construction of new day schools in the Provinces is concerned. It will be just that much more difficult to interest contractors in the construction of schools in the Northwest Territories.

MEMORANDUM:

THE DEPUTY MINISTER

I am returning herewith a Memorandum to Council dated August 18th, 1947, covering the amount provided in Vote 517, 1947-48 Estimates, for the purchase and maintenance of equipment and for repairs and improvements to church-owned Indian residential schools.

We have at this date twenty-six church-owned Indian residential schools in operation. It has been the policy and practice of the department over a long period of years to contribute to the repairs necessary at these schools, and contributions have also been made for the purchase of a limited amount of operating equipment.

The desirability of continuing this policy has been carefully reviewed, following the increase in per capita grants for which provision is made in this year's Estimates. With the cost of living steadily increasing, however, it is difficult for me to see how we can escape this responsibility. I have in mind the cost of food, clothing, fuel, etc., higher salaries to teachers and to mechanics. I am attaching for your information a statement showing the annual outlay for repairs and for the purchase of equipment at government-owned schools and church-owned schools during the last four-year period. You will note that the amount spent on the repair of church-owned schools is substantially lower than the amount spent... on our own
on our own buildings. I can appreciate fully the hesitancy of the government to spend public funds for the repair of buildings other than buildings recognized as Crown property. In this connection, it has always seemed to me that a wise step would be for the government to set apart an annual appropriation enabling us to purchase one or two schools annually from the churches who now own them over, say, a ten-year period. I should be glad to discuss this matter with you personally at your convenience.

Director
Ottawa, October 4, 1947.

October 6, 1947.

Re - Construction of Schools and Teacherages in the Mackenzie District, Northwest Territories

I have your letter of the 25th September and discussed the situation with you briefly over the telephone. We would like to see the type of portable building that is being considered. It is a little late in the season for anyone to go in and select sites just now but I do think that the Superintendent of Forest Protection and Wildlife Management, Mr. Oldham, with the assistance of the Forest and Game Officers, could make the selection of the suitable sites because they are stationed permanently in the Territories and have facilities for getting around. It would be necessary for us to give a general idea of the type of location desired and the sort of layout that is contemplated. In fact, we should have a sufficient number of plans to convey a pretty accurate idea.

At some of these places it is going to be pretty difficult to put in a basement because of permafrost. We should know this as soon as possible.

As soon as the plan has been decided upon if you will give me a list of the places where the buildings are to be erected and copies of the plans, I will ask our officers to undertake the task of choosing the site. In view of the fact that these are to be designated as "denomination" schools, do you not think we should tell the mission authorities what is contemplated.

R. A. Gibson,
Deputy Commissioner.

My dear Mr. Phelan,

Nearly all our Principals are complaining about the small amount allowed for the payment of wages of night watchmen in schools which are not fire-proof. If I am well informed, this has been reduced to $40.00 per month, and is only payable during part of the year.

They claim first of all, that it is impossible to secure any kind of a watchman for $40.00 per month. Moreover, they have to provide board and lodging for them. In the case of married men, this becomes quite a problem.

Cannot something be done by the Department to increase the amount paid yearly for these services and put them on a yearly basis because the danger of fire is almost as great in May, June and September as it is during the balance of the year. All these buildings are getting older and the danger from fire is therefore increasing. Moreover, whilst there is no heating in the summer months, the cooking and operation of the laundries go on for 365 days. The danger of fire from these sources is no doubt quite apparent.

Therefore, I hope that the Department will restore the ten months' grant and increase it in proportion to the increased cost of living.

Yours very truly,

J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.

The undersigned has the honour to report:

The reasons for these changes in allotments are as follows:

(a) When our 1947-48 Estimates were being prepared, our Surveys and Engineering Branch was supervising the construction of a 4 classroom block at the Alberni Residential School. It was anticipated by the Engineer that this work would be completed and that all the accounts would be in by the end of the fiscal year. However, due to a shortage of materials this building was not completed in time to make final payment out of our last year's appropriation. Therefore we request that a part of the amount authorized for the Lennox Island 2-room school be used instead for this purpose. We have not been able to make any satisfactory arrangements with the contractor for the construction of this latter school.

(b) An Order-in-Council has been obtained approving the granting of a contract for the construction of a 2 room school at Chenaill. However, this school will cost considerably more than estimated, due to the fact that we have included running water and electricity plus a full basement to the original plan. As the Caughnawaga plans and specifications are not even completed yet,
the Surveys and Engineering Branch have assured us that we will only be able to use a small portion of the money for this school.

(c) We were fortunate in obtaining from the Crown Assets Allocation Committee an entire army camp at Port Hardy, which is near Alert Bay. The Indian Commissioner for British Columbia had great difficulty in interesting contractors in the building of the schools which were listed in the Estimates. Therefore he recommended that the Surveys and Engineering Branch supervise the moving of some of these army huts for use as schools and teacherages at Alert Bay, Turnour Island, Gilford Island, Village Island and Campbell River.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, LANDS AND DEVELOPMENT SERVICES

Standardized two-room day school plan for use in Northwest Territories -

As agreed upon at the meetings of the Sub-committee on Education in the Northwest Territories, we have included in our estimates the sum of $40,000.00 each for two-room schools and residences at Arctic Red River, Fort Franklin, Fort Good Hope and Roche River.

Our Superintendent of Education has discussed this matter with your Inspector of Schools and they are agreed that the present two-room Indian day school plan would not provide a suitable building for use in the Northwest Territories.

Therefore, I would request that you have your architects prepare a new plan with the following modifications:

(a) In view of the permafrost conditions there should be no basement to the school.

(b) There should be a furnace-room on the same level as the school, with some storage room space provided.

(c) Other modifications could be discussed with your architects, as it is understood that in preparing the plans for the Bay River School, they have departed considerably from the previous standard four-room school.

Memorandum

Re: Sites for Indian Day Schools at Battleford, Carlton, Onion Lake and Touchwood Agencies, Sask.

With reference to your memorandum of the 24th ultimo, regarding the above, we would advise you as follows.

Following the receipt of Mr. Hoey's memorandum of August 11th last, we wrote to our Mr. C.H. Walker at Banff requesting him to assign an officer of his staff to contact Inspector Ostrander and arrange to inspect and submit a report to this office in connection with each of the proposed school sites.

Full instructions as to our requirements were transmitted to Mr. Walker and he was requested to advise us as soon as possible regarding the arrangements that he had made.

In a letter dated November 10th last, Mr. Walker explained that he had twice written to Mr. Ostrander requesting his co-operation in the matter, and that he had received no reply until in a letter dated October 26th last. Mr. Ostrander wrote:

"I am communicating with our Branch in connection with the location of day school sites, and I shall advise you when a reply has been received."

Mr. Walker states that since the receipt of Mr. Ostrander's letter referred to he has received no further communication from him, and that therefore nothing could be done from our Banff office to speed up the matter of the survey of the school sites.

Chief Engineer.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,

The copy of a letter from North American Builders Limited, which you forwarded to our Chief Architect, has been studied and in our opinion constitutes only a request to be permitted to revert to their own standards of construction rather than to follow the working drawings furnished to their Mr. Carpenter by this Division when he visited this office with you a few weeks ago.

It appears that no purpose will be served in entering into extended discussions with North American Builders Limited in attempting to have them follow structural details embodied in our drawings. However, suggestions advanced in the Company's letter of November 28th last are not indicative of sound structural practice nor were the drawings they had previously submitted structurally correct.

Nevertheless, if in the interest of the Indian Affairs' Training Programme, it is decided to build prefabricated one-roomed schools supplied by North American Builders Limited, where the services of recognized contractors can not be obtained in Western areas, the drawings from which such buildings will be erected should be amended in accordance with sketches prepared in this office, duplicate copies of which are forwarded herewith for your transmission to them.

In connection with Mr. Carpenter's comments relative to difficulties encountered in attempting to apply their prefabricated floor panels to our design, he advanced the suggestion that basement windows should be lowered in order that 6" of concrete above such windows should serve as a lintel we may say that the suggestion is quite in line with practices followed by speculative builders, but that such lintels usually fracture as soon as the adjacent floor load is applied. The detail embodied in our drawings was worked out particularly to overcome that fault. If concrete rather than a wooden beam is preferable, then the detail drawn in crayon on the accompanying blue prints is a more acceptable alternative. It permits windows being left as they are, but necessitates raising the main floor level sufficiently to permit pouring a greater depth of lintel, and which of course, must be reinforced. The sill must be dowelled to the concrete by hooked bolts placed when concrete is poured. The increase in height will necessitate the addition of two steps at the outside entrance platform.

A rigid inspection of a completed prefabricated school building should be made by a well qualified technical officer after the structure has been in use for two or three years.

Dear Mr. Neary,

I have gone over very carefully with our engineering department the plans for the Indian School given to us by Mr. Buck while in Ottawa, and there are a number of points they brought up which make it undesirable for us to prefabricate exactly as the print shows.

The prefabrication of floor sections for this type of dwelling necessitates a beam being inserted to act as a lintel over basement windows, and this is not practicable in our method of construction. I suggest that you lower the basement window height 8" and pour 6" of concrete on top of this and have the mudsill embedded in the concrete.

The specifications show gypsum board as an inside finish. This would necessitate crating each and every panel for shipping, and would add considerably to the shipping weight of the building. In addition we are unable to get a seamless plywood wall using gypsumboard.

One other feature is that in prefabrication we must avoid a large overhang in the eave and gable ends.

Another thing on the plan is that it necessitates our installing dwarf walls on the second storey bedroom, which would require to be braced to the roof and ceiling joists and would entail a large amount of field work, thus delaying the speedy erection of the building and adding considerably to extra cost.

In view of the difficulties we will encounter in trying to prefabricate exactly to the print as prepared by Mr. Buck I would ask that you have Mr. Buck send us the alternative plan which he had worked out using our blueprints as a basis. I feel that in this way we can give you what you wish and at the same time simplify our production and save considerable cost to you at the same time.

I would be pleased to hear from you at your earliest convenience in regard to the above.

Yours very truly,

NORTH AMERICAN BUILDINGS LIMITED.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR,
LANDS AND DEVELOPMENT SERVICES

Standard One-room Indian Day School
and attached teacher's residence -

The standard plan for the above school is proving satisfactory. There are a few points which have been revealed in constructing this school during the past year:

(1) In the specifications and the bill of materials it is required that 3/8 inch thick gypsum board in sheets 4 ft. x 12 ft. be used for classroom walls and ceilings. We have received reports from Indian Agents that where this gypsum board has to be transported for long distances and especially where boat transportation is used, it is too heavy and too brittle to stand the rough handling involved. Mr. Indian Agent Goodman of Norway House, who was building a school by day labour at Cross Lake, reported a loss of 40% was sustained on a shipment of gypsum board. He has asked that we substitute one inch thick Ten-test in place of gypsum board in future.

(2) In the specifications and bill of materials it is required that for the exterior wall finish either bevel or drop siding or asbestos-siding shingles be used. Here again we have had difficulty with the transporting of the Asbestos shingles. It would seem evident that manufacturers today are not producing Asbestos-shingles as carefully as they should. They arrive on the school site with the corners chipped and with many of the shingles cracked. As a result we have had requests from Agents that they be permitted to substitute Insul-brick siding as an alternative to Asbestos-shingles.

---- The
The above points are passed along to you for comment.

We would also like to have prepared by your Architects and Engineers the following further blue-prints and specifications for this school. It is suggested that they be prepared as an appendix to the original plan; to be sent out only where conditions permit of such improvements:

(a) Installation of electricity for this standard school.

(b) Installation of plumbing for this standard school.

(This to include a teacher's toilet, a teacher's shower, two toilet bowls for the girls and two toilet bowls and one urinal for the boys.)

The above request is based on the fact that certain of these schools will be located on Indian reserves in which running water and electricity are now available.

Acting Director.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, LANDS and DEVELOPMENT SERVICES

Standard one-room Indian Day School
(without teacher's residence).

In our building program for 1948-49 are included three schools which will not require an attached teacher's residence. In these schools, it is planned that the female teacher will reside with the nurses in the nursing station to be erected by the Indian Health Services. It is felt that in isolated communities, it will be to the advantage of all concerned if the teacher and the nurse can live together and thus reduce the sense of isolation which so often discourages our teachers.

Therefore we would like to have prepared a set of standard plans for a one-room school. This plan could be either based upon the blue prints for the New Credit Indian Day School (erected in 1938) or the attached modern one-room school plan. It is also requested that this plan be prepared to indicate electrical connections and running water connections.
