MEMORANDUM

Re: Standard Combined One Classroom Indian Day School with Teachers Quarters.

With reference to the memorandum of the 2nd instant regarding the above, signed by the Acting Director of Indian Affairs and your marginal request thereon dated 5/1/48, we would comment as follows:

(1) Gypsum wallboard 3/8 inch thick with filled and taped joints is specified for interior walls and ceilings as it has a smooth hard surface for painting approximately equal to that of a hardwall plaster surface. It may be that if gypsum board sheets not longer than eight feet were used, these would withstand the rough handling involved in transportation to distant points, without anything like the 40 per cent loss by damage reported by Indian Agent Goodman of Norway House where sheets up to 12 feet in length were used.

An objection to "Ten-Test" is that it is a soft material with edges and surface easily subject to damage not only in transportation but by the ordinary wear and tear of school usage. Also all joints have to be covered with wood strips or moulding to present a neat appearance which would involve a considerable amount of extra material and labour. For Ten-Test 1" thick window frames should be deepened, so that the interior window trim can be correctly applied. The extra thickness of the Ten Test plus the deeper frames will of course add to the cost, and is not required.

More durable alternative materials than Ten-Test, would be 3/6" Masonite board or ply-wood, both of which should be available.

(2) Regarding exterior walls, this Division has felt that asbestos shingle siding provided an attractive appearing and fire resisting finish, but under conditions where care in transporting and applying is not possible, damage will certainly occur.

Nevertheless since insul-brick has fire resistance, and some insulating value, we will raise no objection to its use, although in our opinion the appearance of the building will not be as good.

With reference to the matter of plans and specifications for (a) electrical and (b) plumbing installations for standard one-room day schools, insofar as equipment inside the building is concerned layouts, and equipment can be shown on a separate sheet to be used as an appendix to the typical set of drawings.

The Deputy Minister,

Re - Aluminum Building Construction.

Since my memorandum of the 19th of November, considerable information has been obtained as to the progress in Canada in the construction of aluminum buildings. This may be summarized as follows:

The Aluminum Company of Canada advise that the plans of standard departmental buildings submitted to them would not be suitable for conversion into prefabricated metal structures. They admit that certain components might be made of aluminum, but they are not in a position to undertake the design, fabrication or construction of such parts or buildings, nor is there any other company in Canada, except the Cresswell Roll Forming Company, able to do so.

Mr. M. F. Goudge of this Department recently inspected two prefabricated houses erected at Kingston; the first made by the Cresswell Company of Montreal is composed entirely of aluminum with the exception of foundations, floors and insulation. A dwelling 17' x 27' would cost £600 factory, about $2,500, but would require certain modifications, particularly as regards insulation, to suit our purpose which would add to the cost.

The second house is of English manufacture in which aluminum is used for sheathing only. The cost of this building 30' x 22' in England would be about £4,500, but this cost includes plumbing, fittings, stove, etc. This structure in its present state would not be suitable for our climate.
The Directorate of Engineering Development, Department of National Defence, is now working on the design of an aluminium army hut having the roof, floor and wall panels interchangeable, and with the main structural parts so designed that they would be suitable for structures of variable dimensions. Insulation is receiving considerable attention and a sample building is to be erected at Churchill for tests during the winter of 1948-49. A certain amount of research is being carried out by the National Research Council and the information being assembled will be available to the army.

It is believed that further studies by the Department of National Defence, the Research Council and the Crosswell Roll Forming Company, who are the only fabricants equipped for construction of this nature at present, may eventually lead to the economic use of aluminium for building construction suitable for northern latitudes. However, no immediate relief is foreseen and probably the only type of aluminium building that can be produced at reasonable cost in the Northwest Territories for years is a simple one-story army hut structure.

We will keep in close touch with research now being carried on to ensure that any practical developments are brought to your attention.

R. A. Gibson,
Director.

To use the products of these firms, it would evidently be most expedient to select one of their stock designs, and then to have made the minimum alterations required for efficient and safe construction. Cost and the amount of time involved would have to be the subject of further enquiry.

Memorandum:

MR. HOEY

As you requested, I attended the meeting in the Norlite Building this morning. There were present

Mr. R.A. Gibson who presided,
Mr. Mills,
Mr. Buck,
Mr. Sinclair,
Mr. Crombie,
Mr. Smart,
Mr. W.E. Noffke, Architect, 46 Elgin St., Ottawa.

In opening the meeting Mr. Gibson stated that Mr. Noffke had been requested to attend with a view to ascertaining if he was prepared to assist the Lands and Development Services by preparing plans and specifications for some of the buildings that the Department hopes to erect during the coming summer. Mr. Gibson referred particularly to the four proposed residential schools.

After some discussion during which Mr. Buck outlined the plans he had already prepared and those that were required, Mr. Noffke stated that he was prepared to prepare plans, specifications, etc., within a reasonable time.

It had been pointed out to Mr. Noffke that funds would be available on April 1st and would have to be spent by the end of March, 1949 and consequently it was desirable to have plans and specifications ready at the earliest possible date.

Mr. Gibson directed Mr. Mills to prepare an order in council authorizing the employment of Mr. Noffke at the rates specified by the Ontario Architects' Association.
It was further arranged that Mr. Noffke would interview Mr. Buck on Friday, February 6th, at which time Mr. Buck would outline more specifically the work that is required at once.

Subsequent to the meeting I accompanied Mr. Noffke to Mr. Buck's room where we discussed the plans required for ten or fifteen minutes. During this latter discussion Mr. Noffke pointed out the desirability of existing fire proof buildings. Mr. Buck and myself agreed that such action might be desirable but that owing to the very heavy increase in cost of lumber and the fact that lumber is available in many places and that fire proof materials would involve heavy expenditures to transport, we were not in a position to decide that funds would be available for construction of fire proof buildings at a much greater cost than frame buildings.

Mr. Noffke realized this point and following his interview with Mr. Buck on Friday, we will hear further from the latter.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

Memorandum

Re: Prefabricated Buildings

Further to our memorandum of the 20th instant, the following information is submitted which is based on a discussion held yesterday with the Ottawa representative of the Fearless Housing Company of Canada Limited.

The system used by this Company is not prefabrication in the original sense; instead the individual joists, studs, rafters, exterior and interior finish are cut to size at the mill and supplied to the owner or sponsor at the site. Each component part is accurately pre-cut to shape and size, and numbered to correspond with a master layout. By this means, the use of semi-skilled labour can be increased, while time and transportation costs are reduced.

This Company does not undertake the erection of their pre-cut buildings and advise that employment of a reliable general contractor is the usual procedure.

The Company has developed a number of efficient carefully designed small houses, several hundred of which are currently being erected in the Ottawa area. It is possible that some of their standard designs might be used where we require similar accommodation for a game warden's cabin or an agent's residence. They will also prepare designs to suit customers' requirements, but due to heavy commitments, they are reluctant to do so at the present time.

Their representative stated that they prefer not to accept orders of less than ten (10) buildings of the same design at one time, and states that they hoped to provide more varied and rapid service when supply conditions become easier.

Of the three companies investigated, this organization appears to have the most carefully studied and best designed houses, in addition to which, the cost includes concrete materials for the basement and footings, electric wiring, plumbing materials and fixtures, as well as all materials for the super-structure.

Copies of this report will be forwarded to Messrs. Smart, Meikle, LeCapelain and Henry.

Chief Engineer.

Director,

I have to refer to Department letter of the 17th instant, File No. 1-1-5 (W T), regarding the erection of day schools in the future.

I have already received blue print of a standard one-room Indian day school with attached teacher's residence, and the work of constructing one on this plan has been commenced at the Nut Lake Reserve of the Touchwood Agency. Please advise me whether that is the plan which it is proposed to follow.

It will be recalled that an effort was made to have a similar school built at the Chitek Lake Reserve of the Carlton Agency in 1947 but I was able to secure only one quotation, and the Department decided that the quotation was too high. All construction is too costly at the present time and I believe that we, in the Province of Saskatchewan, are the most unfortunate in this respect. New labour laws and regulations in this province make it necessary for the contractor to add approximately 12% to the usual labour costs. This 12% is to cover holidays with pay, over-time, and lost time resulting from our strict labour laws. Of course this results in a construction job costing more in this province, and those in management who have the decisions to make in acceptance of a tender should not forget our difficulties in this regard. If we are going to continue to erect buildings while being subjected to labour laws which are not in force in other provinces, the additional cost must be accepted as a fact and I hope that I shall not be continually reminded that a certain type of building can be erected in other provinces at less than in Saskatchewan.

With this in mind I am inclined to favour the prefabricated building because of the fact that much of the labour in a prefabricated building has been performed in other provinces at a lower cost because of more lenient labour laws. Our experience with the North American Buildings, of Winnipeg, in connection with a prefabricated house for the Farming Instructor at the Keseseekoue Reserve, of the Pelly Agency, has not been at all encouraging, but the difficulties which we have faced could be avoided to some extent in the future by being guided by experience in this first house. I certainly think that if we are to construct an appreciable number of prefabricated buildings we should have a construction foreman with some experience in the factory in Winnipeg, to supervise each prefabricated building we erect. Both time and money would be saved by this being done. It is true that a company foreman to supervise construction is sent for each job. He has instructions to perform certain work in the commencement of the erection, but he is gone from the job before those left to complete it have learned much about the difficulties they will meet.

I am also in favour of the employment of a full-time construction foreman for all building work, both new and repaired. A suitable man with full-time employment on a salary could have most of the work performed by Indians at fair wages, and be instructing them in order that they would, themselves, become more useful for the future. I have already communicated with the Department regarding the employment of Mr. Olaf Lidfors, of Meadow Lake, Saskatchewan, who would be very satisfactory for such employment. However, Mr. Lidfors will not accept it unless he is promised an annual salary and apparently that cannot be done under the present set-up.

DEPUTY MINISTER

Prefabricated one-room day schools with attached teachers' residences - Saskatchewan.

In our 1947-48 Estimates we included appropriations for the construction of five one-room Indian day schools and attached teachers' residences for the province of Saskatchewan. In spite of every effort made by Inspector Ostrander and the Indian Agents concerned, we were only able to begin the construction of one of these schools.

The one school under construction is being built by Indian labour, under the supervision of the Indian Agent, and most of the lumber is coming from a mill being operated by the Indians and owned by this branch.

Some tenders were received for the construction of these Saskatchewan schools. These and other tenders were submitted to the than Surveys and Engineering branch. Their reply read in part as follows:

"This service has no hesitation in stating that tenders for one room schools where the cost will approximate $16,000.00 are exorbitant and no contract should be awarded."

In view of the fact that these Saskatchewan tenders were all high and because we were having this identical building constructed elsewhere for prices ranging from $11,000 to $14,000, we would not further consider these bids.

Therefore, when Inspector Ostrander was approached concerning his 1948-49 building program and asked whether he
would consider prefabrication as a means of having the badly needed day schools provided for the Indian children of his province, his answer was as follows:

"All construction is too costly at the present time and I believe that we, in the Province of Saskatchewan, are the most unfortunate in this respect. New labour laws and regulations in this province make it necessary for the contractor to add approximately 12½% to the usual labour costs. This 12½% is to cover holidays with pay, over-time, and lost time resulting from our strict labour laws. Of course this results in a construction job costing more in this province, and those in the Department who have the decisions to make in acceptance of a tender should not forget our difficulties in this regard. If we are going to continue to erect buildings while being subjected to labour laws which are not in force in other provinces, the additional cost must be accepted as a fact and I hope that I shall not be continually reminded that a certain type of building can be erected in other provinces at less than in Saskatchewan. ............"

"I should emphasize that because of our Saskatchewan Labour Laws we should concentrate on prefabricated buildings, if possible, and we should have a full-time foreman to supervise their construction if a number are being ordered."

The officials of our Education Division have had several interviews with officials of the North American Builders, Limited, 711 Royal Bank Building, Winnipeg, Manitoba. This company has developed a prefabricated one-room day school with attached teacher's residence which should be quite satisfactory for our reserves on these reserves. It is based upon the standard one-room school drawings of Departmental Architects.

This company provided four prefabricated teachersages for Saskatchewan and Manitoba last year and we have found these buildings quite satisfactory. They have also done considerable work for Indian Health Services (nursing stations) and for Department of Transport (living quarters, etc.). They are now engaged on a contract for approximately one hundred housing units for the Department of National Defense.

Therefore it is requested that you approve the submission to the Departmental Purchasing Agent of requisitions
covering the purchase of prefabricated one-room schools and attached teachers' residences from the North American Builders, Limited. These requisitions will cover seven schools in Saskatchewan and probably three for Manitoba. It is understood that the Departmental Purchasing Agent will soon be receiving an estimated cost on this school from the company concerned.

Director.
Re: Plans and Specifications for Four Classroom Indian Day School.

With reference to your notation dated January 20th appearing on Mr. Hey's memorandum to you of the 17th ultimo in connection with the above, you are advised that plans for this School were developed for a specific location and while the architectural plans can be used as a standard plan for construction at various locations, the heating, plumbing and electrical designs cannot be applied unless conditions are similar to those upon which the design was based.

We propose therefore, to forward only the architectural plans for this building now and if the Indian Affairs Branch will advise us of the areas, in which schools of the four classroom type are to be erected, we will examine the heating and electrical drawings we have on file, and amend them to suit the local conditions.

Chief Engineer.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands & Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
Ottawa, February 18, 1948.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

I enclose memorandum to council in connection with transferring certain amounts in the appropriation for church-owned residential schools, as authorized in P.C. 65/4200, October 18, 1947. The following transfers are necessary,

(1) $122.91 from Grouard Residential School to Sturgeon Lake Residential School. Both these schools are operated under R.C. auspices and it was found necessary to expend at the Sturgeon Lake School the amount mentioned, over and above the amount actually provided. There is an unexpended balance at the Grouard School.

(2) $458.33 from the Fort William Residential School. Of this amount $335.83 is to be transferred to the Squamish Residential School; $72.50 to the Fort George Residential School; $50.00 to the Ermineskin Residential School. All of these schools are operated under R.C. auspices.

(3) An amount of $824.56 from the item "Maintenance of Equipment at any or all Church-Owned Residential School". This amount will not be required during the present fiscal year for the purpose mentioned. This is to be distributed as follows: Albany R.C. Residential School - $654.91; Youville R.C. Residential School - $169.65. The comparatively large amount at Albany is due partly to the fact that equipment ordered in
the fiscal year 1946-47 was not delivered until after April 1st, 1947 and consequently had to be paid from the funds provided in the current year's appropriation.

(4) $228.67 from Joussard Residential School to Thunderchild Residential School. Both these schools are conducted under R.C. auspices.

(5) $388.65 from Vermillion Residential School to St. Mary's Mission Residential School. Both these schools are conducted under R.C. auspices. There is an unexpended balance in the case of the Vermillion School and the over-expenditure at St. Mary's Mission was due to the necessity for replacing the boiler tubes.

(6) $1,128.06 from Whitefish Lake Residential School. Of this amount $128.06 is to be transferred to the Aklavik C.E. Residential School and $1,000.00 to the Moose Fort C.E. Residential School. All three of these schools are conducted under Church of England auspices, and the money provided at Whitefish Lake cannot be expended this year. The authorities of the M.B.C.C. are extremely anxious to make necessary repairs at the Moose Fort School and have urgently requested the transfer of $1,000.00 from Whitefish Lake to Moose Fort in order to provide funds for the purpose. Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, LANDS and DEVELOPMENT SERVICES BRANCH.

Two Classroom Day School with Teacher's Residence
(for Northwest Territories Type)

Reference your I.A. 1856-9.

These plans have been studied at some length
and we have the following comments to make:

(a) There are only five windows on one side of each
classroom. While we appreciate the difficulty of
placing extra windows in these classrooms, we feel
that the children farthest from the windows will have
great trouble in reading unless electricity is provided.

We understand that extra windows can not be placed
above the blackboards opposite the windows because
of the position of the folding doors between the two
classrooms. Our calculations were that the present
fenestration is only twelve and a half percent. In
most provinces a fenestration of twenty percent is
required. Therefore, we would recommend that higher
windows be provided and if at all possible extra windows.

If necessary we are prepared to dispense with the
cupboards provided in the corners of the rooms so that
extra windows can be placed there. We could have low
cupboards substituted along the rear of the room under
the blackboards or low cupboards under the windows.

(b) It is recommended that blackboard panels be provided
for the folding doors.

Director.
Ottawa, February 17, 1948.

Memorandum:

MR. HOBY

School Construction Program, 1948-49

I have read Mr. Mills' comments on our building program and I agree entirely with him as to the need for employing casual assistance, a number of men familiar with building construction, to whom could be assigned areas in which they would carry out inspections on any work for both this Division and the Agencies Division.

I understand that Mr. Ostrander has such a man in mind for Saskatchewan and that there is also such a man available in Manitoba. Now that the estimates have been tabbed, I feel that we should proceed with the hiring of such assistance. Therefore I am in agreement with Miss Walton's recommendations in this regard and am prepared to cooperate entirely with her on our joint building program.

Even where we are contemplating prefabricated schools, it is still necessary that a proper sound foundation be put under such a building. Therefore, it is most essential that we have a skilled foreman on hand even if only for a week while the cement is being poured. I feel that Mr. Mills' recommendation is a sound and feasible one and would ensure not only that our building program be carried out, but that it would be carried out in such a way that it would give us good buildings which would be little trouble to us in the years to come.

Bernard F. Henry,
Superintendent of Education.
Ottawa, March 15, 1948.

Booth Building,
OTTAWA - Ontario.

Dear Sir:

While the matter of the establishment of schools in the Northwest Territories has been under discussion and the subject of various memoranda from time to time, I wish to point out that more is involved than actually the construction of the school building itself. The school building will be placed on a lot, on ground selected for this purpose, and if the activities, in a construction sense, ended here, only part value would be received for the facilities provided.

The problem of providing education is two-fold --

(a) the actual teaching of subjects according to the school curriculum;

(b) the creation of recreational facilities.

Under (a) - Actual education - this will be provided for by the construction of the school building,

Under (b) - Recreational facilities - some attention must be given to the provision of playground facilities in the vicinity of the school property and, in fact, this should be placed on the school grounds. Particularly with the type of native population (Indian and Eskimo) met with in the Northwest Territories, and who have had, up to now, little chance for education, it is felt their interest in education will be more quickly aroused by having them become interested in the playing of games and in the use of such facilities as playground and recreational activities will provide.

Your attention is drawn to the fact that playground facilities can be added at relatively small cost while the school building is being built. There will be considerable lumber shipped to the site (more than is actually used in the actual school building itself) and this lumber will remain over after the completion of the building. This additional lumber is used during the construction period for the erection of stagings for plank-ways or passageways for movement of materials by hand-barrow or cart, and for allied construction purposes. On completion of the Project considerable of this lumber could be used in the creation of playground facilities, and the carpenter crew while at that point could obtain local unskilled labour and build these recreational facilities at relatively small expense. It would cost considerably more if the work were carried out at a later date.

Attached hereto is a suggested list of equipment which might be considered as standard for each school building to be built in the Northwest Territories. Most of the above facilities can be provided, as above noted, from construction lumber remaining on hand. There will be a few items of Sports' equipment, such as Basketball end sets, Teeter-totter apparatus, some parts of the Giant Stride apparatus, and so forth which will be required. On the whole, however, the equipment to be brought in of special manufacture, is relatively small.

(over)
Your attention is drawn to the fact that an endeavor is being made to interest persons of all ages in the schoolground equipment. For this reason the provision of sand boxes, teeter-totters, swings and ice slides have been provided particularly for the use of the younger members. There is also intended to be installed sufficient apparatus for the playing of games such as Volleyball, Football, Softball, Baseball, and so forth, which will attract the interest of the teen-age children and even grown-ups.

I have discussed this matter with Mr. W.J. Johnston, District Engineer of the Department of Public Works, Edmonton, and he assures me that much of the construction lumber could be re-used in the provision of playground facilities and that the carpenter force, when at the site, could have the installation made under the supervision of the carpenter-foreman, at a relatively small over-all cost.

It should be noted, however, that some additional expense over and above what is required for the bare establishment of a school building, will be required. This provision of recreational facilities should, therefore, be considered as part of the creation of the school project, and be included in the total cost.

I would like your comments, please, that this provision of recreational facilities is approved, if this approval is necessary.

Yours very truly,

J.W. MacKinnon
Inspector of Schools for the Northwest Territories.

Dear Sir or Madame:

We have just received your coupon and notice you are interested in purchasing a new furnace.

If you happen to have a furnace in your home now and you would wish to change it for a new furnace, then we can supply you with a furnace and casing. With this layout all you would have to do, would be to get a tinsmith to connect the new furnace casing with your warm and cold air pipes that are now installed.

It might be that you would have to add another warm air or possibly another extra cold air pipe, in order to give sufficient circulation of air through the new furnace.

Now in the next case, you may be building a new house and if you wish to have a pipe furnace, then we can supply you with a furnace and casing and it would be necessary then for you to get a tinsmith to install this furnace for you, putting in the registers and the necessary warm and cold air pipes.

Now in the next case, you might be able to use a pipeless furnace instead of a pipe furnace. This depends upon the situation of the principal rooms of your house.

If you will send us a plan of your house, marking the rooms and the size of each room, then we can tell you whether you can use a pipeless furnace. A pipeless furnace can be installed by any handy man for the reason that we give you directions how to do it.

One good point about a pipeless furnace is the fact that with it you have very, very little heat in the basement or cellar of your home and this style of furnace frequently keeps your cellar sufficiently cool so as not to make it too warm for the vegetables stored in the basement.
With a pipeless furnace, you fill your home with warm air and in this respect it is necessary for you to have a pipeless furnace of the proper size, in order that you would have no cold air drafts on the floor.

With a pipeless furnace, practically all the heat goes into your home.

We might state that a pipeless furnace can be made particularly suitable for any size house up to eight or nine rooms.

A pipeless furnace can be used in a larger house, if of square construction with a large centre hall in it.

Pipeless furnaces have been abused by people installing a furnace that is entirely too small. We might state that a pipeless furnace is the most economical style of furnace you can possibly use.

Any room you do not wish to heat, all you have to do is close the door.

We have no hesitation in recommending a pipeless furnace if we know how the rooms in your house are situated.

Under these conditions, we would advise you therefore to give us the information regarding your requirements. Then we would be pleased to make our recommendations.

Thanking you, we remain,

Yours sincerely,

STRESSED SKIN PLYWOOD BUILDINGS ON FLOATING FOUNDATIONS IN PERMAFROST AREAS.

The aim of every designer of Arctic buildings is to provide adequate and comfortable permanent shelter within as low a cost range as possible.

As transportation is one of the main cost factors in Arctic building, a lightweight, stressed skin plywood building of a permanent nature has been developed by the writer which can be assembled by a small crew in a few days and incorporates the latest scientific design features.

Marine plywood panels are glued and nailed to a stud frame and contain within a sandwich of triple insulation against radiation, conduction and convection. The panels are held together by patented connectors. All joints are covered with felt lined joint strips which make the building quite air tight. The floors are heavily insulated and according to information received from one station before Christmas, operators have been walking barefoot on the floor at an outside temperature of -42° below and a 50 mph storm.

The inside of the buildings is painted with bright fire resistant paint, chosen by psychologists to counteract the feeling of drab monotony on lonely Arctic Stations.

When the building is erected, the panels form a rigid frame. It has been found that in areas of high permafrost level such a rigid frame can advantageously be floated on a gravel bed. As practically no heat escapes through the floor, the permafrost level stays undisturbed and the buildings do not move.

As every location in the Arctic presents a different problem a careful survey of soil characteristics and permafrost levels should be undertaken before erecting any permanent structure. Special consideration must be given to the surface drainage on top of the permafrost. In many areas a certain amount of excavation with subsequent gravel fill will be necessary to insure a wide enough gravel bed on which to float the building. The lower the permafrost level, the higher the gravel bed has to be.

GEORGE JACOBSEN.

Ottawa, March 20, 1948.

Mr. Rose,

I have been awaiting word from you regarding work to be executed with funds in your 1948-49 estimates, and for which you will wish to have the cooperation of the Engineering and Construction Division of this Branch.

A news release of March 17th gives some information about your plans but we have had no definite word regarding any specific projects other than those undertaken in the fiscal year just ending, and the following:

1. New Indian Residential School, Teslin, Y.T.
2. New Indian Residential School, Lac la Ronge, Sask.
3. New Indian Residential School, Norway House, Man.
4. New Indian Residential School, Seven Islands, Que.
5. New two-room day school with teachers' quarters, Fort Norman, N.W.T.
6. New two-room day school with teachers' quarters, Roche River, N.W.T.
7. New two-room day school with teachers' quarters, Fort Franklin, N.W.T.
8. New two-room day school with teachers' quarters, Fort Good Hope, N.W.T.
9. New two-room day school with teachers' quarters, Arctic Red River, N.W.T.
In regard to the two-room schools for the Northwest Territories we have received a copy of a letter sent to you by Inspector McKinnon who has been discussing the school building programme with District Engineer Johnston of the Department of Public Works at Edmonton. Apparently, Mr. Johnston is afraid that he cannot get all the material in to complete all of these schools this year and he favours reducing the number of schools to be built in 1948 and shipping in of supplies for the balance so that the construction can be carried out in the ensuing year. We would like to discuss this with Col. Neary on Tuesday when it is expected he will be returning to the office.

In addition to the above we understand that a series of inspections will be required for existing Indian Residential Schools, and that our Architectural personnel has been contacted directly for heating and electrical designs for four-room Indian Day Schools your Branch will be responsible for at Cowessess, Saskatchewan, Kamloops, B.C. and Alert Bay, B.C.

If you will furnish me with all further information you can assemble in connection with projects where you are expecting co-operation from this Branch during the coming fiscal year, we will be in a position to consider what we can do to help you.

R. M. Gibson,
Director.
Ottawa, March 30, 1948.

Memorandum

Re: Indian Affairs - Construction Programme.

Your marginal notation dated the 6th instant on Mr. Hoey's memorandum to you of April 3rd last, requests comment on Items A, B, and C, under which headings Mr. Hoey has listed the schools on which it is desired to undertake construction operations during the 1948-49 fiscal year.

In this connection comment is furnished as follows:

A. Residential Schools

1. Indian Residential School - Teslin, Y.T. - A set of preliminary sketch plans has been furnished to our Chief Architect by Mr. Noffke, which Mr. Buck has examined, discussed, and has left with Col. Neary of the Indian Affairs Branch. The sketches have not yet been examined by Mr. Hoey. It is our Architect's opinion, that in his initial sketches, Mr. Noffke has over-reached the demands of the project. Certain features he has planned must be eliminated and several accommodational areas reduced in size. When Mr. Hoey has had the opportunity of reviewing the sketches with his officers, he will advise you of his opinions. These processes will not be permitted to interfere with the Architect's progress.

We feel that the arrangements reached between this Branch and the Works and Accommodation Directorate of National Defence, their Major Stevens and the assignment of Mr. Noffke to the architectural phases of the project completes the organization of this school.

2. Indian Residential School - Leo la Ronge, Sask. - As well as being reduced from a five building group to a four-classroom building only, we are advised by Col. Neary that this proposed school has become a matter of considerable discussion between the Province of Saskatchewan, the religious order, who will operate the school, and the Indian Affairs Branch, both as regards the area in which the school will be built and the arrangements for operation. Col. Neary has advanced the opinion that these matters will likely result in abandoning the building operations this fiscal year.

A. Residential Schools (Cont'd)

3. Indian Residential School - Norway House, Man. -
This project has been reduced for the present to providing a four-classroom building adapted to conditions at the school instead of the original five building plan visualized by the Indian Affairs Branch. Some study will be required and additions made to our typical drawings so that extensions to services can be properly made when the ultimate development is undertaken. The Indian Affairs Branch have requested that tenders be invited by advertisement in which we concur. It is suggested that supervision might be requested from the Works and Accommodation Directorate of National Defence. Major Stevens will advise Mr. Buck in this connection.

Keep this fact constantly in mind, when considering the "Hygeosan" Septic Toilet Combination—no chemicals, no mechanical or other than natural means are required to assist in the disposal of sewage wastes. Nature has provided everything, and for the benefit of those who do not understand how this can be, the following simple questions and answers will, we feel sure, clarify the situation in sufficient detail to convince the most skeptical.

1. (Q) What is a Septic Tank?

(A) A tank that is a water-tight container, so designed and arranged, and of correct capacity, to provide conditions under which sewage may decompose, or be broken down, through biological activity without putrefaction. Into this tank sewage is discharged, and because the tank is water-tight, and so arranged, the solid sewage is held in suspension, allowing the free activity of anaerobic bacteria and the circulation of gases.

2. (Q) What Takes Place in a Septic Tank?

(A) When the tank is properly designed and fabricated, the solid sewage sinks to the bottom, forming what is known as the sludge bed; here the sewage is immediately attacked by millions of bacteria, known as anaerobic bacteria, because they only live where there is no oxygen or light. These bacteria, by their rapid life functions (being born, living, and dying by the millions to the square inch per hour) break the solid sewage into its component parts of liquid and gases. The lighter sewage, or floaters, rise to the top, forming what is known as the scum; this scum seals the tank against the ravages of oxygen and light, and also provides an ideal culture ground for the bacteria.

3. (Q) Does a Septic Tank Finally Dispose of Sewage?

(A) No! The function of a septic tank is to break down the sewage into a condition fit to mingle with the soil, or be absorbed into the atmosphere by evaporation. For this reason, an area of final disposal must be provided. This can usually be accomplished, by tile drains running to a leaching pool, or tile drains without a leaching pool as illustrated. If these methods do not appear practicable for you, write us outlining your problem, and we may be able to offer you further suggestions to suit your particular requirement.

4. (Q) Will a Septic Tank Freeze?

(A) No! If properly designed and installed, and of correct capacity, when in use the Septic Tank should maintain a steady temperature of 70° F. If not in use, that is to say, if sewage is not being regularly discharged into the septic tank, the tank may freeze.

5. (Q) Will Freezing Destroy the Septic Tank?

(A) If manufactured from iron or steel welded, no! Iron or steel is impervious to moisture, therefore the material of which the tank is constructed does not absorb water and only the contents of the tank will freeze. Because of the solids in the tank the outer shell will not crack or fracture and the tank is not destroyed.

Instructions for the Installation of 'The Septic Toilet Combination'

The Septic Toilet Combination combines a septic tank, a white china bowl, a ventilating stack, and an area of final disposal, usually with field tiles in the ground to dispose of liquids, and having for its object the reception and complete disposal of the wastes from the human body. It is a complete disposal system.

Always bear in mind that the system is for the disposal of wastes from the human body—garbage, tea leaves and slops from the kitchen should not be thrown in the tank.

Bath or hand lavatory water can be run into the tank, but it is usually desirable to by-pass the tank with these liquids and run them directly into the tile bed. There is no good reason for polluting these waters with sewage. When bath or hand basin water is to be disposed of, the tile or underground disposal area should be enlarged sufficiently to take care of the additional fluids.

This combination operates on identically the same principal as the pressure of the sewage disposal system.

Follow the simple rules contained in this folder, and your Septic Toilet Combination will render you years of carefree service.

On our sales folder we illustrated method of setting tank partly under building. The illustration here shows method of setting tank in a basement entirely under building, with 3" iron pipe running through wall. Be sure to caulk drop tube well on this type. Also cement around manhole to prevent escape of gases into the basement.

Setting Tank Etc.

1. First choose a location, on the ground floor. (Septic Toilet can be installed on the second floor, but it is generally difficult to get an unobstructed direct course to the tank from the second floor.)

When you have located the place that you want the bowl to stand, be sure that you have a direct, unobstructed connection to the tank, thirteen inches in diameter.

Dig your hole for the tank if one is required, and place the tank directly below the spot you have chosen for the bowl location. Allow if possible not less than twenty inches from the bottom of the bowl to the top of the tank. However, a drop tube thirty inches long is shipped with each outfit and this will allow up to twenty-eight inches from the top of the tank to the bottom of the bowl. If a greater distance is desired, a drop tube extension will be required. See figure No. 1.

2. Now take the paper template of the bowl bottom, mark out and cut hole in floor, being sure that bowl is facing in direction you desire. The bowl is longer from front to back than it is wide. See Fig. No. 2.

3. Now slip drop tube through floor, and into tank sleeve welded into top of tank. Then take the piece of oakum provided, and caulk around the drop tube outside, but inside tank sleeve, using a screw driver or some such instrument and pack firmly. Now take a putty knife or something flat of that nature, and liberally cover the oakum, so as to make this a gas tight joint. This is important so that no gases can come up outside the drop tube below the bowl. See Fig. No. 1 and 3.

MADE IN MULTIPLES FOR LARGER INST.
4. Now the tank and drop tube are in place. Take some of the putty supplied in tin and roll between the hands into a sausage-like shape. Either lay it around the edge of the drop tube on the floor side of the opening, or turn the bowl upside down and press firmly into the orifice provided on the flange. Then place the bowl in position, facing in the right direction, and tighten down the floor screws supplied for this purpose. If the floor is of hard wood before putting the putty place the bowl in its correct position and mark the holes in the base, then removing bowl, bore some small holes at the designated spots and screw in the boltshanks before putting bowl finally in position with putty.

5. You may now proceed to run the ventilating pipe through to the roof. (See the suggestion contained on the back page of this booklet.) To commence, take the adaptor, which is the piece of pipe $3\frac{1}{2}$" at one end and 4" at the other, insert the small end into the small hole at the back of the bowl and proceed from there following the plan you have selected through to the roof. When you have cut the hole in the roof, place the universal roof safe in position, nail it down and put some of the heavy cement around the edges. After the pipe has been run through roofsafe, place some of the plastic cement around the top of the flashing where the pipe comes through. This roofoise or flashing is universal in that it does not matter what the pitch of the roof, the pipe remains vertical. You may now place the anti-down draft ventilator in position.

**DRAINS**

About twenty to thirty feet of drain tile is sufficient, using the higher figure where the ground is heavy.

The drains are composed of four inch farm drain tiles laid with weeping joints — that is the tiles are laid end to end loosely and a piece of tar paper or two placed over the top of each loose joint so that water will not enter the tile. The bottom of the joint is thus free and open, permitting the fluids to leak away into the surrounding soil.

If hard clay or clay clay dig the trench deep, and fill in with some gravel or other material of such nature to keep the trench filled with a supply of air, this will aid in the penetration into the air. At the end of the tile line dig a hole two or three feet across and two or three feet below the tile line and fill in with loose rock or open gravel, or bore some holes in a wooden barrel as illustrated. This is a safety measure to take care of any overflow from the tiles in rush periods.

Keep the tiles near to the surface, 12 to 16 inches, so that air and sunlight may assist final disposal by evaporation.

Some Useful Hints on Ventilation

Proper ventilation plays a very important part in the efficient operation of a Sewage Disposal Plant. Read the following instructions very carefully.

Fig. A—This shows the proper way to install the pipes where toilets are located at opposite sides of the building.

Fig. B—This plan is improper and should be avoided, because of the counteracting influence that one pipe has upon the other, depending upon direction the wind is blowing.

Fig. C—This plan is always in favor and when possible run the vent alongside the chimney, but make sure that the ventilator is above the top of chimney, so that the chimney does not prove an obstruction to air currents.

Fig. D—There is only one condition under which we can recommend a chimney connection, and this is where the fire is kept going the year round. Unused chimneys become dead and soggy and the air will not move.

Fig. E—Shows two styles of which Style 3 is best. Style 2 would not be recommended for cold climates unless the pipe outside be reduced to one-third the total. It is better to keep under and follow the roof to the peak.

Fig. F—Shows two plans both of which are entirely wrong and Style B cannot work either way. Any attempt to install toilets according to either of these plans can be reasonably certain that results will be disappointing. Style C, Fig. F, will give bad results on account of possibility of back drafts. Style A fails for same reason and for the additional reason that it has two right angle turns.

Fig. G—A header, as here illustrated, is used to join the vents from several bowls. From the header up the same rules apply as to single bowl toilets.

Fig. H—This shows the best plan for joining vents on a two bowl toilet. This plan should not be used to join bowls located in separate adjoining rooms. The vents from toilets in each room should always be kept separate.

Fig. I—Shows two views of an electric exhaust system. This plan of ventilation is always successful. Any plan for introducing continuous heat into the vent pipes also gives splendid results.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT due to a shortage of materials and labour during the continuance of the last world war, many replacements of equipment and services, as well as maintenance work required in connection with residential schools, operated by the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources, could not be undertaken; and

THAT in the subsequent reconstruction period, the volume of work assigned to the Engineering and Construction Division of the Lands and Development Services Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, has become too great to permit the limited architectural personnel of that Division, to carry out the necessary inspections, and furnish the reports with relevant recommendations, usually included in their duties;

THAT continuing deterioration in buildings and equipment particularly with regard to heating, plumbing, domestic water supply, and electrical installations, should not be permitted, and that under the circumstances, the required surveys and reports should be obtained from other sources;

THAT the Lands and Development Services Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources have carried out investigations, through which it has been established, that the Donald Inspection Limited, Inspection and Testing Engineers, 1161 Guy Street, Montreal, Quebec, is a highly reputed organization, with staff qualified to prepare reports, and submit recommendations of the nature required, and that they are prepared to undertake the building surveys or inspections assigned to them by the Department, and submit complete reports and recommendations, in consideration of the standard fee and expenses for such work, the total amount to be concurred in by the Department.

Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 10 June 1948

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report, dated June 2nd, 1948, from the Acting Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

That due to a shortage of materials and labour during the continuance of the last world war, many replacements of equipment and services, as well as maintenance work required in connection with residential schools, operated by the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources, could not be undertaken;

That in the subsequent reconstruction period, the volume of work assigned to the Engineering and Construction Division of the Lands and Development Services Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, has become too great to permit the limited architectural personnel of that Division to carry out the necessary inspections, and furnish the reports with relevant recommendations, usually included in their duties;

That continuing deterioration in buildings and equipment particularly with regard to heating, plumbing, domestic water supply, and electrical installations, should not be permitted, and that under the circumstances, the required surveys and reports should be obtained from other sources;

That the Lands and Development Services Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources, have carried out investigations, through which it has been established, that the Donald Inspection Limited, Inspection and Testing Engineers, 1161 Guy Street, Montreal, Quebec, is a highly reputed organization, with staff qualified to prepare reports, and submit recommendations of the nature required and that they are prepared to undertake any building surveys or inspections assigned to them by the Department, and submit complete reports and recommendations, in consideration of the standard fee and expenses for such work, the total amount to be concurred in by the Department.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Acting Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that authority be granted to enter into an arrangement with the Donald Inspection Limited of Montreal, whereby that Company will carry out inspections and submit reports with recommendations for work urgently required in those Indian Residential Schools selected by the Minister of Mines and Resources, the fees and expenses not exceeding $4,550, as outlined in a letter from the Company, dated 12th May, 1948, to be paid from funds included in the applicable appropriation of the Indian Affairs Branch 1948-49 estimates.

Memorandum:

MR. G. BICK,

Educational Plans - Western Provinces and Northwest Territories.

I understand that you have been requested to prepare a brief summary, for our Minister, of the school building program for the Western Provinces and the Northwest Territories.

In British Columbia, we have now on order or under construction 6 one-room Indian day schools and 2 two-room Indian day schools. Some of these buildings are prefabricated ones. We have also completed the conversion of army buildings into day schools in the Alert Bay Agency and classes are now being conducted in these buildings.

In Alberta, we have completed the day schools at Michel and Stony Plains, near Edmonton. Contracts have recently been let for a two-room day school at Sarcee and a one-room day school on Alexander's Reserve, near Edmonton. Air Force buildings were moved and set up on permanent foundations to provide extra classroom blocks at the St. Paul's and Blood Residential Schools near Cardston, Alberta.

In Saskatchewan, the Nut Lake and Pecuma Indian Day schools are nearing completion. A contract has recently been let for another day school on the Meewasin Lake Indian Reserve.

In Manitoba, day schools are under construction or have been completed on the following reserves: Valley River, Nelson House, Little Grand Rapids, Peguis, Fisher River, Oak River, Island Lake and Cypress Lake.

In the Northwest Territories, two-even day schools are nearing completion at Fort Norman and Moosonee River. A four-room day school is being erected at Hay River.

In addition to the above new schools, we have been able to open several temporary classrooms in rented church buildings and halls. In this way we have managed to provide educational facilities for some 300 Indian children for whom we were unable to provide educational facilities previously.

Memorandum:

The Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch

Re: Revised Plan for One-Room Indian Day School with Attached Teacherage

At the present time, we are building a number of standard one-room Indian Day Schools with attached teacher's residences according to plans, specifications, and bills of materials as prepared by your branch (your Index No. 37).

This school is proving quite satisfactory on the Reserves where accommodation is required for a fairly large number of pupils. The size of the classroom is 26 ft. 6 ins. by 22 ft., and accommodation is provided for forty pupils.

We are gradually meeting the educational requirements of Indian Reserves on which there are thirty or more Indian pupils. To the top of our priority list are now coming Reserves where some fifteen to twenty-five pupils require classroom facilities.

The standard one-room school and attached teacherage (Index No. 37) costs from $14,000.00 to $20,000.00, depending on location and transportation facilities. It is felt that a less expensive and somewhat smaller type of school would suffice for Reserves where only some fifteen to twenty-five children require education.

Therefore, we would request that plans, specifications, and a bill of materials for a low cost school be prepared. In this connection, I am forwarding to you a sketch made of a school built by the Breanett Lumber Company of Bresen, Ontario. Two such one-room schools...
were erected in Chatham Township in 1948. On the Building Committee for these projects was Inspector Barrett of the Provincial Department of Education. In the original sketch no lighting facilities were provided on the far side of the classroom opposite the "wall of windows". In the sketch we are forwarding to you please note that we have indicated two small windows above the blackboard on this side.

I would emphasize that this sketch is being forwarded to you only as an indication of our requirements. Naturally, in some instances, we will have to provide an attached teacherage along similar lines to the accommodation provided in Index No. 837.

I am advised that the Bresett Lumber Company have erected these two schools for approximately $6,000.00. Could a similar low cost school be designed for our Education Division?

To summarize, we would request that plans, specifications and bills of materials be prepared for:
(1) a low cost one-room day school,
(2) a low cost one-room day school with attached teacherage (three rooms).

Would it be possible to have this data prepared by January 10, 1949? We intend to build two of these schools at Oxford House, Norway House Agency, next summer and will have to buy the materials by January 31 to have the supplies shipped in by tractor train.

Acting Director.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, LANDS AND DEVELOPMENT SERVICES BRANCH,

Two-room Indian Day School Plans.

It would be appreciated if we could have twenty sets of the plans and specifications for the standard two-room Indian Day School and attached Teachers' Residence, as recently revised.

We have found Plan 865 to be a satisfactory building and would like to arrange for a visit by one of your officials when the first such project is completed. This school is at ALNWICK, near Peterborough, Ontario, and should be completed about the end of January.

You will recall that Plan 865 is the standard one-room school with attached teacher's residence, but with modifications to provide for electricity and running water, not normally provided in these small schools.

It is our intention to build a number of two-room Indian day schools and attached teachers' residences on reserves which are provided with lighting plants and with running water. Therefore, could a similar modification be developed to provide for the installation of electricity and running water in the two-room school? This would be preferable to having local contractors install their own lighting and plumbing plans and specifications.

Acting Director.

Please find attached two sample copies of the new bills of materials as prepared for the low cost one-room Indian day school which we intend to build on many reserves next year.

MEMORANDUM:

DIRECTOR, LANDS AND DEVELOPMENT SERVICES BRANCH

Re: Index No. 891 - Two Classroom Indian Day School (Water and Electricity)

The draft plan submitted by you for a two room Indian Day School with attached teacher's quarters on Reserves where electricity and running water can be made available, has been studied carefully by officials of our Education Division. The following observations have been made as a result of their consideration:

(1) Unexcavated part below water toilets - It is felt that these two parts might well be excavated because not only of the possibility of giving difficulty in presenting a danger from frozen pipes, but also because of the fact that this space can be utilized as dressing rooms. In fact, on one or two Reserves we may contemplate the installation of a small shower room in this space.

(2) Fenestration - The fenestration in the new one room school, Index No. 888, has been highly commended by both our field and education officials. Would it be possible to add a sixth window to the main bank of windows in each room and thus raise the fenestration ratio from 5:28 (below the ideal) to 6:28.

(3) Shelves - We are constantly requested for additional shelves by our teachers, and I would suggest that these be provided as follows:

(a) under the windows in the classroom
(b) a narrow shelf in the coat rooms so that children's lunches can be placed in safety above the reach of dogs, etc. This shelf should be five feet high and approximately eight inches wide.

(4) Partition between kitchen and living room. It is presumed that this partition will be thick enough to handle a four inch drain pipe.

(5) Kitchen chimney - This chimney can be eliminated, and I would ask that heavy wiring be provided so that a small electric range can be provided in the teacherage. This will be preferable from the teacher's point of view but will mean that heat will also have to be provided from the furnace for the kitchen.

(6) Glass brick - As we are anxious to keep the cost of our schools as low as possible, could we please be advised as to the necessity of placing this glass brick over the two entrance doorways. If the cost is as low as the installation of windows then we are prepared to accept this item. If it is much higher, then we would prefer windows.

You will note that the above are all relatively minor points and that, on the whole, we are very pleased with this plan. We feel that this design will provide very satisfactory classroom accommodation and comfortable teacher's living quarters. It is hoped that these can be built at a reasonable cost. Could we also be provided, when the final plans are completed, with copies of any changed specifications required over our present design and a bill of materials.

Director.

You are advised that we have received and carefully read the reports submitted by the above firm.

In general it can be stated that these reports present an outline description of the buildings and property with certain comments and general recommendations with reference to maintenance and repairs.

It is not the purpose of this memorandum to criticize these reports, but it must be pointed out that in order to make intelligent recommendations with regard to repairs and revisions in connection with mechanical and electrical services, thorough inspections will have to be carried out by men well qualified in these lines.

The reports contain repeated suggestions that by the installation of vacuum pumps, the heating systems can be made satisfactory. This statement is misleading to say the least. No reputable manufacturer would be willing to guarantee satisfactory operation of a vacuum pump without being assured that the return piping had been thoroughly checked for possible leaks and that the radiator traps were all either removed or satisfactorily repaired. Since no mention has been made in any of the reports in question that piping and accessories have been checked, it can only be assumed that the Donald Inspection Company did not consider it their obligation to make a thorough analysis in this connection.

While the boiler sizes have been given in several instances, no attempt was made to provide the very necessary information with regard to piping connections. Generally it can be stated with definite assurance that the reports merely point out the various conditions requiring specialized investigation and attention, and as previously mentioned, there is a complete lack of essential data.

In summary, it can be taken for granted from the reports that large sums of money will be required in order to bring the mechanical and electrical services up to a reasonable point of efficiency.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,
Lands and Development Services Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.
This is not surprising as many of the buildings are from 20 to 60 years old and there is evidence that only nominal attention to maintenance has been given in the past.

It is our understanding that the Indian Affairs Branch are considering closing down some of the older schools. With this in mind, it is suggested that they be requested to provide this Division with a list of the schools intended to be kept in operation, with requests for the necessary inspections and recommendations.

With such information, it would then be possible to make the necessary arrangements to have the surveys carried out.

Chief Engineer

The Director,
Indian Affairs Branch

THE PIPELESS FURNACE

Many people object to the use of the pipeless furnace. They say, for instance, that the floors are always cold.

There is a reason for this and the reason is that the person who purchased the furnace happened to buy one that was too small to heat the house. If the furnace had been a size larger it would have filled the house with warm air and when a house is filled with warm air it is heated and no objection can be found.

The installers of furnaces invariably find fault with the pipeless furnace for the reason that any handyman can install a pipeless furnace without any difficulty and therefore it lessens the work and the original cost of the furnace.

With the pipeless furnace all the heat generated in the furnace itself passes directly into the home and practically no heat is left in the basement, or very little.

This is a good point because vegetables in the basement are not softened and sometimes dried up with the heat in the basement as when a pipe furnace is used.

With the pipeless furnace you have no warm or cold air pipes filling up the basement of your house and making it more or less inconvenient for other uses.

We find that many installers of furnaces will not install a furnace that they are not handling themselves. The reason for this is no doubt very evident to you.

In a six or seven roomed house, or even a larger house, a pipeless furnace can be used to great advantage both with regard to cost of installation and also to the distribution of heat throughout the home.

We advise you to buy your furnace NOW. Don't wait until September or October to place your order.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR,

RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL BUILDING PROGRAMME.

While feeling that our Indian day school construction programme is progressing satisfactorily, I am rather concerned over the many proposals being made for the erection of residential schools. As I have advised you previously, it is my feeling as an expert that the present cost of building, equipping and operating residential schools is such that I recommend only the building of residential schools in those areas in which we are definitely assured of the impossibility of educating Indian children in day schools.

In the past, one denomination in particular has assumed the attitude that day schools should only be built in areas in which there were not enough Indian children to warrant the building of a residential school. I feel that this is the wrong attitude and that therefore we should proceed with caution in meeting recommendations advanced for the building of certain residential schools. At the same time we will have to make it clear that residential schools will only be built when there is no hope of operating day schools. I feel that my main concern as Superintendent of Education is to provide educational facilities for as many Indian children as possible. This cannot be done by the building of residential schools wherever they may be. It is now clear that a residential school of 150 pupils will cost at least $40,000 to build and equip fully. The per capita grant which will have to be paid to the denomination operating this school will be at least $250 higher, depending on its location. In any year of operation it will cost the Department at least $40,000. In other words, for the sum required to build and
equip one residential school, we can build and equip at least twenty-five one-room day schools and teacherages. For the cost of operating one residential school for a year, we can operate at least fifteen day schools. To summarize, therefore, we can educate, in equivalent day schools, approximately 750 children as compared with 150 children educated in a residential school.

It is not my intention at this time to present to you a long list of the pros and cons of educating Indian children in residential schools. Your long experience in Indian affairs and your many contacts with denominational authorities have provided you with all the various arguments in this regard. I fully appreciate the fact that residential schools can provide a broader curriculum than day schools because of their facilities for vocational education. However, I do feel that we should proceed with great caution in examining every residential school project request and therefore I present to you now a review of the main demands made by the various denominations:

CHURCH OF ENGLAND:

(1) Carcross Residential School:
The request here is that the school now being operated in temporary quarters be replaced with a modern building. In Appendix A I attach my recommendation for procedure in this particular case.

(2) Lac la Ronge Residential School:
The request here is for a dormitory block to be operated in conjunction with a provincial day school under the control of the provincial Department of Education. In Appendix B I attach my recommendation in this connection.

(3) The Pas:
In this instance the church is considering the closing of the Elkhorn Residential School in central Manitoba and requesting the rebuilding of the former Maskay Residential School at The Pas. This school was closed many years ago as the result of fire and the children were moved to Elkhorn. In Appendix C you will find my recommendations in this regard.
(4) Onion Lake

This school is presently housed in the former Anglican Theological College in Prince Albert and there is no urgency in the consideration of this request.

We are already proceeding at the present time with the other project requested by this Church, namely the building of a dormitory block at Wabasso.

UNITED CHURCH OF CANADA

(5) Norway House

This request is for the rebuilding of the former school destroyed by fire in 1946. In Appendix D attached you will find my report and recommendation on this situation.

In addition to this project, we also have under consideration the closing of the File Hills Residential School and the replacing of it by day schools as we did at Mount Elgin. There is also a situation at the Round Lake Residential School requiring further study.

ROMAN CATHOLIC Church

6. Teslin, Yukon.

This request has been fully investigated by our Educational Survey Officer and by our Inspector of Schools for British Columbia. Originally there were requests for two residential schools, one at Fort St. John, British Columbia, and the other at Teslin, Yukon. We are agreed that the one school at Teslin will satisfy the requirements of those children who need residential school education. The building of this school should begin this summer.

7. Hay Lakes, Alberta.

This request is for a residential school and is a result of an educational survey made by a Provincial School Inspector. The building of this school should begin this summer.
8. **Thunderchild, Delmas, Saskatchewan.**

This request is for the rebuilding of the former school destroyed by fire in 1946. In Appendix B attached, you will find my report and recommendation concerning this school.

9. **Island Lake, Manitoba.**

This request is for a new school in an area now served by day schools. This situation will have to be handled with care as the United Church have been prominent in missionary activities in this area for many years. I feel that their pressing for a school at Norway House (see No. 5) is a result of the activities of R.C. missionaries in this area. In Appendix F you will find my report and recommendation.

10. **Nelson House, Manitoba.**

This request is for a new school to serve the R.C. Indians of Nelson House and South Indian Lake. Our preliminary survey indicates no need for this school and we are now proceeding with the building of a new day school at Nelson House for R.C. pupils. A day school was built last year for the U.C. pupils.

11. **Armstrong, Ontario.**

All other requests for R.C. residential schools have been submitted by the various Bishops of the diocese concerned through the local Oblate Indian Welfare and Training Commission. This request is from the Jesuits engaged in missionary activities in Western Ontario. In Appendix G you will find my report and recommendation.

12. **Albany, Ontario.**

This request is for building a school previously destroyed by fire and now housed in a building which the Bishop asserts he wants for a hospital. In Appendix H you will find my report and recommendation.

..... (13)
13. **Abitibi Agency** (in or near Amos, P.Q.)

This request is for a new school. There has been a previous report and you will find my recommendations in Appendix I, attached.

14. **Seven Islands Residential School**, P.Q.

This request has been under consideration for some time and surveys have been made by the Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies for Quebec, the Supervisor of Vocational Training and our Educational Survey Officer. A memorandum has been sent to the Lands and Development Services Branch for the preparation of plans for a school to educate 100 residential school pupils and 60 day school pupils. A sum has been included in our estimates for its construction and the project now awaits the completion of the necessary plans.

In addition to these projects there have also been representations for the rebuilding of the following R.C. Schools:

15. **Cariboo Residential School**, Williams Lake, B.C.

This is an old and dangerous building. You will find my recommendation in Appendix J attached.

16. **Ermensekine Residential School**, (Hobbs Agency, Alberta)

This also is a frame building which now presents a serious fire hazard. You will find my recommendations in Appendix K attached.

There have been a few other requests but these have mainly been already satisfied by the erection of day schools in the last two years.

While it is relatively easy to decide on the need for, the positioning of, and other matters relating to the building of a day school, it is not possible to have one official make such decisions concerning a residential school. Often we place an unfair responsibility on our field officials in requesting recommendations from them concerning representations received for the building of such schools. I therefore feel that in order to fairly assess the
educational needs of the Indians concerned, educational survey committees should be formed as fast finding bodies to present a report to the Department on each request for a residential school. The costs of such committees would be small and would be amply justified in view of the large expenditures of public funds involved in the building of the many residential schools requested.

I feel that we must always keep in mind the fact that the erection of a residential school is but an initial item in contributing to the high cost of educating an Indian child in one of these schools. The present per capita rate is high and will probably continue to be so. In erecting one of these schools, we are therefore committing the Canadian taxpayer to an outlay of public funds over a period of 30 or 40 years to come. Due to the present Vote distribution, it is difficult to ascertain exactly the cost of educating an Indian child at a residential school as compared with educating an Indian child at a day school. However, I have detailed one of my officials to obtain such information so that we will have exact figures to present to you in the near future.

Bernard F. Henry,
Superintendent of Education.
