MEMORANDUM

DIRECTOR LANDS AND DEVELOPMENT SERVICES BRANCH

Indian Education Building Projects 1949-50

Our 1949-50 Estimates have recently been finalized, and I am now in a position to provide you with information concerning our Education votes. As you are aware, the building of schools is still occupying high priority in the policies of this Branch. We have had considerable correspondence with you this winter concerning specific projects, and I attach for your information the various items submitted by our Education Division.

Residential Schools:

(1) Seven Islands - We have already corresponded with you concerning this project and would ask that this be given top priority as soon as the Tealin plans are finalized.

(2) Norway House Residential School - The size of this building has yet to be determined, but we will submit our proposals to you immediately a decision is reached.

(3) Thunderchild Residential School - An Educational Survey Committee is expected to visit the reserves of the Battleford Agency in order to determine our educational requirements. Our recommendations will be submitted at a later date.

(4) Lac La Ronge - This project is still the subject of correspondence between this office and the Bishop of Saskatchewan and the Provincial Department of Education. It is expected that a dormitory block somewhat similar to that now under erection at Wabasca will be required.
(5) Hay Lakes - This project has been the subject of previous correspondence and meetings.

(6) Sabacon (C.E.) - This project is now under erection and we have included an amount for its completion.

(7) Alert Bay classroom block - It is Mr. Indian Commissioner Arnell's intention to submit plans for the erection of a classroom block at this school similar to the day school block erected recently from surplus Army buildings from Fort Ardy. You can anticipate a request for cooperation in this project when we hear further from Mr. Arnell.

(8) Alberni Residential School - We are in correspondence with Mr. Indian Commissioner Arnell concerning educational requirements at this school and will submit a separate memorandum on this project.

(9) Cariboo Residential School - A memorandum was sent recently concerning our plans for this school and little action can be taken until your heating engineer has reported on our proposals. We would ask that his visit to this school be given priority.

(10) Teslin Residential School - It is anticipated that tenders will soon be called for the construction of this building.

Day Schools:

In accordance with our previous agreement, we are proceeding with the building of one and two-room schools under Branch arrangements. This is placing a great burden on the Education Division, and I find that these officials are spending too much time in carrying out a day school building program and not sufficient time on other educational matters which should receive their attention. It is a source of some concern to me to find trained educators occupied almost exclusively in a construction program and in correspondence over contracts, progress payments, etc., rates, orders for bills of materials, etc. The responsibility of building these schools was taken over at a time when there was a shortage of staff in your Engineering and Construction Division. It was thought that this shortage was a temporary situation but such has not proven to be the case.
For the past two years all one and two-room day schools have been built, therefore, by our Education Division whose staff has remained the same and whose normal correspondence has increased greatly as a result of the new schools thus opened.

The projects listed below are those for which we will require technical and other assistance.

(1) Whitefish Bay - We have asked that this school be built entirely by your branch and presume that tenders will be called in the near future.

(2) The Pas - It may be necessary to request visits from one of your engineers during the construction of this two-room school. We found that this arrangement worked satisfactorily last year at Lake St. Martin and at Barree.

(3) File Hills - We anticipate that a request will be made for a supervisory visit from an engineer during the course of erection of this school.

(4) British Columbia two-room schools -
   (a) Fort Babine
   (b) Cape Mudge
   (c) Hartley Bay
   (d) Laxalasp
   (e) Kincolith

The demand in British Columbia is definitely on the erection of day schools, and you will note that our building program here is a large one. It is anticipated that we will have to request supervisory visits from an engineer for the above projects. We are in correspondence with Indian Commissioner Arnell concerning these two-room schools, and a memorandum will be sent to you soon listing our requirements.

(5) In addition to the above projects we will be requesting a sum in the Supplementary Estimates for a two-room school at Thunderchild in the Battleford agency in Saskatchewan. We will require supervisory visits from an engineer at this project also. We will advise you when this matter has been settled.

Director.

PAINTING STEELOX BUILDINGS

Cleaning - Clean surface of grease and other foreign matter. Remove grease or oil with naptha or turpentine. Do not paint unless dry.

PAINTGRIP surface should not be treated with any acids, alkalis or other treatments sometimes used on galvanized surfaces. It is already prepared for painting. Additional treatment is harmful.

Proper Weather - Paint only when surface is dry. Temperature must be above 50° F. during and for 6 hours after painting.

Priming Coat - Any paint is suitable that will meet the National Bureau of Standards Post Office Specification. Essentially this is as follows:

A durable air drying, oil varnish base, iron oxide zinc chromate metal primer is the most suitable primer. Desired pigment formula is 2/3 Spanish Oxide (84% Fe₂O₃) and 1/3 by weight C.P. zinc yellow. It shall dry to touch within 2 hours and form a firm film in 6 hours. It shall dry suitable for recoating in 18 hours. Vehicle shall be water-resistant, tough, very adherent, and hard drying, composed of suitable drying oils, hard gum varnish, drier and thinner. (Alternate Specification is Federal TT-P-64L).

DESCRIPTION:
Asbestos-Bonded Pipe has the same riveted construction as galvanized corrugated metal pipe. However, during the galvanizing process, a thin layer of asbestos felt is pressed into the molten zinc (galvanizing). This layer is impregnated with a special saturant and seal coat after which the sheets are corrugated and formed into pipe.

A bituminous pavement is applied to the lower one-fourth of the pipe to a thickness of at least \( \frac{1}{8} \) inch over the crest of the corrugations. The pipe may then be given a full coating of the same bituminous material.

USES
Wherever utmost durability is required and wherever the soil or contents of the pipe are highly corrosive to galvanized metal. Also economical for normal conditions where long life is a factor. This may be for highway, railway or industrial drainage, levee openings, subdrains, storm and sanitary sewers, ocean outfalls, siphons, etc.

ADVANTAGES OF CORRUGATED METAL PIPE

STRENGTH. Flexibility and reasonable care in installation enable corrugated metal pipe to resist crushing, cracking and dislocating under high fills, impact and vibration of heavy loads, poor foundations, shifting soils, undermining and frost action.

EASY, SPEEDY INSTALLATION. Light weight, long sections, fewer joints and simple couplings make for quick, economical installation. Detours are kept at a minimum, and the pipe can be put in in any weather. Only a few small tools are needed.

DURABILITY. ARMCO Ingot Iron Culverts have been serving for more than a third of a century (since 1906). They outlast the road, but can often be salvaged and re-used.

ACCEPTANCE:
Corrugated metal pipe is used for the highest type of engineering construction—by the railroads under main line tracks—under superhighways and low cost roads; for sanitary sewers under main paved streets; under levees and dams.

DESCRIPTION:

The thick pavement in the bottom, applied at the fabricating plants, consists of a special bituminous material which fills the corrugations in the invert of the pipe (about the lower ¼) and covers the crest of the corrugations to a minimum depth of ½ inch. It gives protection against erosion or scour.

DESCRIPTION:
There are two types of Perforated Corrugated Pipe, Hel-Cor and riveted. Hel-Cor, with helical corrugations and folded and locked seams, is most commonly used and comes in 6, 8, 10, 12, 15, 18 and 21-inch diameters in 18 and 16 gage galvanized Ingot Iron or steel. Bituminous coatings and paved invert can be added.

Riveted Perforated Pipe comes in 8 to 30-inch diameters in 16 and 14 gage galvanized iron or steel. This type can be supplied with paved invert and asbestos-bonded coating.

Two or more rows of 5/16-inch perforations in the lower quarters are separated by an unperforated area.

Pipe comes in any lengths, usually 20-feet.

USES: SUBDRAINAGE

1. Soft spots in roadbed
2. Wet cuts and backslopes
3. Frost boils and heaving
4. Landslides and slips
5. Grade crossings
6. Yards and terminals
7. Airport runways and other areas
8. Recreational areas
9. Retaining walls
10. Infiltration galleries and well casings
11. Dams and levees
ADVANTAGES OF PERFORATED METAL PIPE

STRENGTH AND EASE OF INSTALLATION: A small crew can lay long sections of perforated pipe in a trench or on an embankment by hand. The corrugated design gives the pipe strength to resist the impact of heavy vehicles or other traffic. Long lengths with strong couplings ensure continuous service.

NO CLOGGING: Cross-section of intersecting subdrain with perforated pipe outlet. The use of graded backfill or "filter" material ranging from 1/2-inch down to fine sand keeps silt from clogging the pipe. The perforation admits very little backfill material.

EFFECTIVE DRAINAGE: View showing perforated pipe being installed on an intersecting drain on a highway ditch; end view of perforated pipe which kept water pockets in a railroad fill.

ACCEPTANCE: Principal railroads use perforated metal pipe to stabilize roadbeds for high-speed trains; highways, low-cost roads, city streets, industrial areas, airports, dams and levees, and other important uses.

LITERATURE REFERENCES:
Handbook of Culvert and Drainage Practice
Airport Drainage Manual

DESCRIPTION:
ARMCO Metal Buildings are made up either entirely of Steelex panels without the usual framework or of Steelex panels on structural framework for larger buildings.

Steelex is a steel building panel used for walls, roofs, floors, ceilings and other elements of buildings. These shop-fabricated panels are load-bearing, their strength resulting from forming the edges of steel sheets into interlocking panel flanges.

Assembly of Steelex into a building is accomplished by fitting the panel flanges together and then securing them to the foundation and to each other by means of suitable connection pieces and fastenings.

Steelex panels are usually of 18 or 20 gage, in several widths and depths to suit the structural requirements. For exterior walls they are usually 16 inches wide. Lengths are up to 18 feet. Standard Steelex frameless buildings range up to 28 feet in width, of any length and up to 14-foot eave heights.

Steelex panels are formed from ARMCO steel, with galvanized Paintgrip coating, or uncoated. All bolts, screws and fastenings are made of special hardened and coated steel.

Building Products. Steelex panels, besides comprising the basic parts of ARMCO Metal Buildings, are available separately for roof deck and floors for building construction of other types. They are also used as forms for concrete.

DESCRIPTION:
An ARMCO Bin-Type Retaining Wall is a wall composed of bins or cells bolted to columnar units at the corners, filled with earth or other material to give weight and stability.

By varying the gage (No. 16 to 10) of the stringer units which form the face and rear of the wall, a uniform bin or panel length of 10 feet is maintained, regardless of wall height. Similarly, by varying the gage (No. 16 to 12) and length (5.2 to 14.0 ft.) of the spacer units which extend from front to back of wall, single-bin construction is possible for both low and high walls.

More than thirty standard designs are available varying from 4 to 30 feet in height.

The metal parts are all heavily galvanized. For severe conditions a bituminous coating is asbestos-bonded to the metal.

USES:
1. Serve valuable right-of-way where embankment slopes encroach on private or industrial property—at grade separations, bridge wingwalls, dock areas, etc.
2. Serve as a boundary for made land
3. Provide stable slopes or save excessive fill as along the edge of a hillside road
4. Prevent encroachment of streams, lakes and other bodies of water
ADVANTAGES OF BIN-TYPE RETAINING WALLS

STRENGTH and DURABILITY. These walls have ample strength to resist the buffeting of wind waves. Placed on a slight batter or slope, they resist overturning and sliding. The stiff corner columns transmit lateral thrust to the base of the wall. With a service record of 14 years to date, these walls should equal the culvert record of nearly 40 years.

SPEEDY CONSTRUCTION. With a few shovels and wrenches a small crew quickly erects an all-metal bin-wall in any kind of weather. The heaviest unit weighs only 140 pounds. As erection progresses, the wall can be backfilled and put into immediate use. No curing is necessary.

ADAPTABILITY. An Armco Bin-Wall can be built on a curve; it can be extended, raised or lowered; and in fact can be completely disassembled for another purpose without losing its usefulness. Another advantage is the nestability of the units which conserves space in transporting and storing.

They specifically require that the glass area referred to shall be taken to mean the light size times the number of lights.

THE CLASSROOM AND ITS VISUAL TASKS

By GEORGE G. COUSINS

Lighting Engineer

The Hydro-Electric Power Commission of Ontario

For many years there has been an increasing consciousness of the importance of good seeing conditions in schools. It has been obvious that there is an increasing percentage of children wearing glasses as they progress from grade to grade (see Fig. 1). More parents are concerned about the welfare of their children. Public Officers of Health realize that defective sight retards the acquisition of knowledge, also that attempts to see under adverse conditions, whether caused by defective eyes or poor lighting, reacts to the detriment of the health of a child, as well as its progress. Teachers know by experience that on dull days the seeing conditions are so poor that there is a lack of attention and response on the pupils'. These conditions are directly related to the ability of the pupils to see mentally and distinctly the work that confronts them and in the end they result in a general retardation of the pupils' progress. There are many factors that affect the legibility of the various details that a pupil is required to see during the periods of instruction. The following is a discussion of some of these factors and the way in which they affect the pupils.

In the design of new schools provision for the best seeing conditions should be made, but there are hundreds of old schools to be lighted for the first time and old inadequate lighting replaced by modern lighting. Consequently, while those interested in schools may look forward to the advantages of modern design and equipment there will be existing schools that must remain in use for many years and every known means of improving the seeing conditions in them must be used. The requirements for good seeing are the same in both old and new schools.

THE EYES

The eyes are sensitive organs designed by Nature to operate under a wide variety of conditions. This does not mean that they operate equally well under all conditions. Nature demands perfect vision and the eyes will automatically strain themselves in an attempt to accomplish this, even under very adverse conditions. However, as the eyes are controlled by delicate muscles, they, like any other muscles, quickly become tired when forced to work under conditions that are different to the normal easy working range. Consequently, prolonged use under difficulties will exact a toll which may appear as fatigue, headaches or other disturbances to the nervous system. It is necessary to recognize this fact in order to appreciate the tasks of the eyes in the classroom.

The eye is equipped with an iris, the purpose of which is to regulate the amount of light that enters the eye. When the eye is exposed to a bright surface the iris adjusts the size of the pupil to a relatively small opening. If the eye is then exposed to a dark surface the iris expands. The greater the difference in brightness, the greater is the range of adjustment necessary. This naturally results in greater muscular effort and greater fatigue.
Comfortable lighting depends to a great extent upon the contrasts in brightness in the field of view. In order to see an object or detail clearly there must be a strong contrast between the object and its adjacent background. This is necessary but strong contrasts in brightness in the field of vision are also detrimental. Strong contrasts between chalk and the chalkboard or between a pencil or penmark and the writing surface is vision. On the other hand, strong contrast between bright parts of lighting fixtures and the ceiling or wall or between the sky viewed through a window and the adjacent wall or between a white paper and a dark desk top is detrimental to vision. A very bright area is a definite distraction which tends to cause the iris to contract when the work upon which the eyes are focussed may demand that the iris expand. It cannot do both at once.

DAYLIGHT

Daylight is thought of as abundant, which it is out of doors, but it is not adequate for easy seeing indoors, except for a very few feet from the windows. Therefore, it is generally not adequate for the normal working distance for most of a classroom, and, moreover, daylight is difficult to control; it can be severely glaring if not properly controlled. It is thus obvious that the control of daylight cannot be overlooked in any plan of seeing conditions for classrooms.

Fig. 3 illustrates the decrease of daylight from the window to the dark side of the room. The figures are values of daylight averaged from a large accumulation of measurements. The light vertical bars represent measurements made on clear days and the striped bars represent measurements on dull days which comprise 20% or more of the days during the school season. This graph does not apply to classrooms with clerestory windows or directive glass blocks.

It is obvious that there is a serious need of good artificial lighting in the dark side of the rooms during all of the dull days and most of the clear ones.

CLERESTORY WINDOWS AND GLASS BLOCKS

Two departures from the long established type of school have appeared during the past few years. The first is a classroom with a clerestory ceiling. Windows are placed high in the right-hand wall (as one faces the chalkboard). Conventional windows are placed in the left wall. The windows in the right wall, known as clerestory windows, are designed to admit light to what has heretofore been known as the dark side. Fig. 3 shows a room of this type. The clerestory windows being high in the wall are liable to admit sunlight into the room during some hours of the day and seasons of the year. Furthermore, there frequently will be an excessive contrast in brightness between the high part of sky, viewed through these windows, and the adjacent wall surface which will become a source of serious glare. These will necessitate window shades on these clerestory windows. When no direct sunlight is admitted and the clerestory windows are unshaded, the daylight in the otherwise dark side is appreciably improved. If typical deep window shades are drawn down to obscure the sun through these windows the daylight in the otherwise dark side increases so that in the conventional type of building, because the windows in the left wall are not so high as the conventional design and it is the upper part of the high windows that are most important for the illumination of the dark side of the room (see Fig. 15). On the other hand, if the clerestory windows are shaded with translucent material such as Scotch-holland or muslin, some of the benefit of them will be retained. The full advantage of the clerestory windows depends almost entirely upon keeping them unshaded. It is therefore obvious that they will demand more attention by the teacher in order to derive the full benefit from them.
The second type of new design is based upon the use of light-directing glass block. This particular type of block deflects light from the sky upward into the room in such a way that it reinforces the natural distribution of daylight in the far side of the room. Fig. 4 illustrates such a classroom. When the sun shines on these blocks there is an improvement in the daylight in the far side of the room, but on the shady side of a building or on a dull day the daylighting is not much better than in a reasonably modern school of conventional design. The windows are equipped with clear glass, 2 feet 6 inches in depth, below the glass blocks, so as to prevent a shadow falling. These blocks are made of the same type of glass blocks, so that they eliminate the necessity of window shades, except when unobstructed sky viewed through the clear glass may be excessively bright. In such cases, the clear glass only need be shaded.

These new designs represent important steps toward greater utilization of daylight. The graphs showing the distribution of daylight in them represent measurements made in two schools only and under two conditions of daylight. Consequently, it is logical to assume that in different schools under different daylight conditions there will be many days in which the results will be less favourable than those shown. Nevertheless, they represent distinct improvements over older conventional designs. It cannot be claimed that they eliminate the necessity of artificial lighting.

**DESK LOCATION**

The location of a pupil's desk in the classroom may be a strong factor in the pupil's progress. Pupils near the front left of a room (near windows) are favoured with short distance from the chalkboards from which the work written thereon appears large and easy to see distinctly. There is no reflected chalkboard glare to obliterate the writing on any part of the chalkboard. There is no diminution of glare due to the brightness of the sky. There is an abundance of daylight illumination for desks A, B, C. All of these factors tend to prevent eye strain and fatigue. All of these advantages do not exist in the other parts of the room. Consequently, pupils in the other sections are handicapped, some of them severely so. Because of this it cannot be expected that all of the pupils will be able to accomplish their tasks with an equal degree of ease. Fig. 5 illustrates the effect of desk locations on the legibility of work written on the chalkboard when viewed from four points of view. The positions of the pupils with the desk fronts A, B, C have been selected for the basis of comparison because they represent the most favourable combination of conditions. The legibility from point A is rated as 100 and as percentages of this from the other points. The values were measured with a visibility meter.* Those who may be handicapped by defective sight or slow mental process may find it exceedingly difficult, if not impossible, to keep up with the work of the pupils succeeding in the less favourable locations in the classroom are added to their personal handicap. Therefore, such pupils should be given the benefit of the best locations in the classroom. Normal eyes can adapt themselves to a reasonably wide range of conditions without appreciably affecting the individual. Thus, the choice of the most favourable location in the classroom would be of minor benefit to pupils with normal sight, but it would be a matter of serious need to pupils with defective sight. There have been many cases of apparent mental dullness that were caused by inability to see distinctly.

*A visibility meter is an instrument that permits actual measurements of the visibility of objects.
It is not economically practicable to eliminate completely these inequalities but the adverse effects can be minimized by relatively simple means such as properly planned artificial lighting, placing defective-sight-pupils in the favourable locations, suitable window shades, AND THE INTELLIGENT USE of them.

ARTIFICIAL LIGHTING

It is obvious from the foregoing that artificial lighting is necessary to supplement daylight in order to overcome some of the handicaps under which about half of the children in a classroom work. If artificial lighting is located on account of lighting handicaps, children tend to advance as rapidly as uninhibited ones; there will be an appreciation of the real value of artificial lighting and less tendency to regard it simply as a means of complying with a regulation as cheaply as possible. It will be a real asset instead of a liability.

For about ten years the standard of classroom lighting in Ontario has been 15 foot-candles* on desks and chalkboards of ordinary classrooms. Previous to that time it was exceedingly rare to find a classroom lighted to more than half that intensity. The adoption of that standard raised the level of many hundreds of classrooms in Ontario and has greatly benefited the thousands of pupils attending those schools. Recent studies of classroom lighting requirements have led to the adoption by the Illuminating Engineering Society of a new set of standards in which 30 foot-candles on the work (desks, chalkboards, etc.) for ordinary classrooms is stipulated, and higher for special classes. See Table I.

| Location | Foot-candles |
|----------|-------------|
| Classrooms—on desks and chalkboards | 30 |
| Work benches, including art rooms, offices, libraries, shops and laboratories | 30 |
| Study lighting, including library lighting—on desks and chalkboards | 30 |
| Drafting rooms, typewriting and sewing rooms | 50 |
| Recreational and recreational and auxiliary rooms | 30 |
| Auditoriums (not for study), cafeterias, locker rooms, washrooms, corridors containing lockers and stairways | 10 |
| Open corridors and store rooms | 5 |

*A foot-candle is the intensity of illumination produced on a surface one foot from a standard candle.
The new requirements represent a higher standard of lighting than the previous ones, and these should be the basis of lighting for all new schools. They are nonetheless desirable for old schools. However, for old schools which may be replaced in a few years its cost may be a deterrent to its use.

In planning lighting for classrooms a minimum number of outlets and fixtures will be necessary to produce a desirable approach to uniformity. The required number of footcandles will determine the wattage of the lamps to be used.

The following requirements should be met:

1. The intensity of illumination must be sufficient to enable all of the pupils to see what they should see instantly and without conscious effort.
2. There should be no noticeable shadows on desks or chalkboards.
3. There should be no glare. Even mild glare that would not be obvious is detrimental when the eyes are exposed to it for lengthy periods of time.
4. The fixtures must be so designed and constructed that they will not collect dust in excessive quantities and they must be easily cleaned.
5. There should be no strong contrasts in brightness in the normal field of view.

SELECTION OF FIXTURES

The most difficult task for the school trustees is the selection of a suitable type of lighting fixture. Far too many decisions are based upon the first cost. Low first cost must be accompanied by some compromise with visual comfort. This is illustrated by a comparison of white glass diffusing tungsten lamp fixtures and indirect fixtures. A considerable difference may be made between types of fluorescent lamp fixtures. It is a simple matter to construct efficient indirect fixtures that are free from glare. On the other hand it is practically impossible to make white glass enclosing units entirely free from mild glare, although the glare may be minimized by the use of large diameter units mounted high enough to be as far as practicable from the normal lines of vision. Indirect units provide the maximum usable light at the surfaces where it is distributed throughout the room. (See Fig. 6, groups 1 and 2.) There are no excessively bright parts exposed to view, therefore, there is nothing to interfere with comfortable vision. On the other hand with diffusing white glass units all of the usable light must pass through the glass. (See Fig. 6, group 4.) Consequently, if the glass is too small in diameter its brightness will be too high to look at without discomfort.

It is true that the indirect lighting fixtures are a little higher in cost than diffusing fixtures but if the difference in cost is spread over ten years the difference per year for a classroom would probably not be more than $5.25 or 30¢ a month for each school section. This small difference in cost represents the difference between high quality lighting and that which would be at all acceptable for classrooms. An ordinary classroom accommodates about 40 pupils. In 10 years this represents 400 pupils who can be provided with high quality lighting for an equipment cost for 10 years of about 12¢ each more than the cheapest lighting. When glareless, comfortable lighting means so much to the pupils is not this slight additional cost justified? This question must not be passed over without mention of the problem of maintenance which will be discussed later.

TUNGSTEN vs. FLUORESCENT LIGHTING

The choice between tungsten and fluorescent lighting is principally one of cost. Fluorescent lamps and fixtures possess distinctive advantages and are capable of producing lighting of the highest quality when properly applied. Fluorescent lamp fixtures are much higher in cost than tungsten lamp fixtures. Also their price range includes cheap glaring fixtures and much better ones at correspondingly higher cost.

Fluorescent lamps produce the required intensity of illumination with much less power than that required by tungsten lamps. Consequently, when the cost is spread over a period of years the fluorescent lighting may not cost any more than tungsten lighting for an equal intensity of illumination.

All fluorescent lighting is not good. Exposed bare fluorescent lamps are subject to the same objection as white glass tungsten fixtures. The high costs of bare fluorescent lamp fixtures are not consistent with the relatively low quality lighting that they produce. Enclosed lamp fixtures with louvres or diffusing glass or plastic are capable of producing the highest quality lighting that is available at this time. (See Fig. 7.)

Fluorescent lamps are particularly valuable in the application of the new lighting standards as they will produce the higher intensities with no more power consumption than that now required by tungsten lamps for the older standards. One four-lamp fluorescent fixture consuming about 200 watts is equivalent in light production to one 300 watt tungsten lamp. The heating effect on the pupils produced by fluorescent lamps is very much less than that produced by tungsten lamps of equal wattage. When used on 25 cycle circuits extra care must be taken to select fixtures which are designed so that they minimize the flicker. This involves the shielding of the lamps by suitable louvres or glass or plastic shields. Curved or wavy louvres are somewhat better than flat straight louvre surfaces for 25 cycles. Many of the fixtures that are suitable for 60 cycle operation are not best for 25 cycles.
Fig. 8 shows a typical lighting plan of a classroom. It will be noted that the circuits are so arranged that the inner and outer rows of fixtures and the chalkboard lighting may be used independently of each other. There are also two plug receptacles indicated, one at the front and the other at the rear, for the use of picture projectors, radios or other electrical appliances.

SPECIAL CLASSES

The visual tasks of ordinary classrooms are to a considerable extent standardized. The pupils in sight-saving classes have the same work as those in ordinary classes. Their abnormal vision requires considerably higher intensities, approximately twice as much as ordinary classes and the lighting should be as accurate as possible. Drafting or stenography call for high intensities. The former involves working out fine details (thread points, etc.). In stenography the eyes are not used to guide the hands but they must follow the material to be transcribed. Speed and accuracy are essential and these are obtainable only with good lighting as there must be no hesitation in reading notes accurately.

Sewing, especially on dark goods, demands high intensity of lighting. Each branch of manual training requires the same kind of lighting as is used for the trades that are taught.

Each of such special classes is an individual problem.

MAINTENANCE

No lighting system, however good it may be initially, will retain its efficiency without some attention. Dust will collect on fixtures and lamps, particularly where hot air heating systems are used. Lamps will become aged. Fluorescent lamps may become erratic in operation and unless attended to promptly will rapidly depreciate. Therefore, regular maintenance of the lighting equipment is necessary, the frequency of cleaning will depend upon the type of fixture and local conditions.

Fixtures may be grouped into three general types with respect to maintenance.

1. Those in which the lamps are enclosed within the fixture. They may be either tungsten or fluorescent. Most of these direct the light predominantly downward. Therefore, the loss of illumination resulting from a layer of dust on the fixture is relatively small. Usually they are reasonably dust-tight and easily cleaned.

2. Indirect and semi-indirect. These project most of the light on the ceiling from which it is distributed throughout the room. Considerable layers of dust on the fixture will absorb light, thereby causing a serious loss of illumination. Any form of open indirect reflector or diffuser will collect dust. The light from the lamp must penetrate the layer of dust to reach the reflecting or diffusing surface and then penetrate it again to escape to the ceiling. There is thus a double absorption of light. (See Fig. 9.)

There is a type of indirect unit designed for the use of silver-bowl lamps which has a definite advantage. (See Fig. 10.) The actual reflecting surface is deposited upon the interior of the lower part of the bulb where it is protected from dust. The upper part of the bulb slopes at a steep angle which counteracts the tendency of dust to settle upon it. These lamps are used in pan-shaped fixtures, the purpose of which is to shield the upper part of the bulb which would be glaring if exposed to view and to present a pleasing appearance. The pan has very little effect as a reflector. These lamps with their fixtures are particularly suitable where maintenance is uncertain and the ceilings are low.

3. Open top and bottom. Some fluorescent lamp fixtures are open at both the top and the bottom. There is nothing to collect dust except the upper surface of the lamps. Consequently, there is little loss of illumination from dust.

CHALKBOARDS (Blackboards)

The chalkboard is a very important item in classroom instruction. If the pupils cannot see clearly what is written on it they cannot profit by the instruction that is given through its use. Mention has previously been made of some of the difficulties associated with its use.

The common material of which they are made is slate which acquires a semi-polish or sheen which in turn causes glare, which viewed from certain directions obscures the letters that have been written on it. The glare may be reflected on its surface of the sky or bright outdoor surfaces. Fig. 11 shows a typical glare zone in a classroom. The light that causes the glare enters through one or two windows near the end of the chalkboard. (See Fig. 12.) The only practical means of preventing it is to shade the windows through which it enters. As this will seriously reduce the illumination of the room, supplementary lighting will be required to improve the visibility. This may be supplied by the room lights, but much better results will be produced by special supplementary lighting installed for the purpose. The intensity of the supplementary lighting should be at least as high as the general room lighting. They must be of a type that will be free from all glare when viewed from the pupils' seats. The choice between recessed units and those mounted on the ceiling depends upon the value placed upon the room appearance. Recessed units result in a more finished appearance than those mounted upon the surface of the ceiling. Figs. 13 and 14 illustrate both types in use.
There is a growing tendency to depart from the use of black slate boards and to select boards of lighter tone and more pleasing colors such as green and ivory. Green boards are used with white or yellow chalk and the ivory ones with dark blue. The dark boards have an advantage of aiding visual acuity and the ivory boards may be more comfortable visually. Any one of them will be satisfactory if the illumination is good and free from glare.

CHALK

Chalk may appear to be an unimportant detail of school supplies but it plays an important part in the legibility of work written on the chalkboard. The greatest visual acuity results from the highest contrast between a letter and its background, that is the contrast between white and black. Hard white chalk makes narrow, gray lines that contrast poorly with the chalkboard whereas soft chalk makes broader, white lines of strong contrast with the board. The same applies to coloured chalk—hard grades reduce the legibility of the written characters and soft grades increase it.

This is another example of a condition that may not adversely affect pupils with normal sight seated in favourable locations but may add to other difficulties of children labouring under adverse conditions such as poor sight or unfavourable location. In well lighted classrooms of normal length hard chalk, which is preferred by teachers, may be generally satisfactory.

WINDOW SHADES

Daylight will be beneficial if it assists vision and detrimental if it causes glare or interferes with vision in other ways. Therefore, it must be controlled in order to make the most effective use of it.

Unobstructed sunlight on white paper is intolerably bright which necessitates shading the windows. The sky exposed to view without direct sunlight may also be glaring when the eyes are exposed to it for appreciable lengths of time, although it may not appear so at a casual
Because of this children sitting in one place may face severe glare which the teacher may not be aware of. In such cases, if the room is provided with adequate artificial lighting it may be advantageous to shade the sky by the window shades and turn on the artificial lighting. However, if shading the windows would rob pupils at the inner desks of much needed light, the lesser of the two evils would be to not shade the windows.

As intimated previously, the pupils at the inner rows of desks (farthest from the windows) suffer most from the vagaries of daylight and its improper control. By reference to Fig. 15 it will be seen that the upper part of windows is the most valuable source of illumination for desks near the center of the window row. Most light comes by the upper half whereas only 37% of the light on the desks near the windows is furnished from the upper half of the windows. Therefore, any unnecessary shading of the upper half causes a very serious reduction of the lighting on the dark side where it is usually insufficient at best. Fig. 16 shows two examples of a common practice of covering the upper half of the windows on the dark side of the room under unfavorable sky conditions. If this data is studied with relation to Fig. 2 (daylight distribution) which shows actual intensities of daylight in rooms with unshaded windows the seriousness of the reduction of daylight illumination by shading the upper halves of the windows will be apparent. It is thus obvious that a single blind does not provide sufficient flexibility for use to provide for conditions that change during the day and through the seasons. Fig. 17 shows a method of mounting two roller blinds, one between the top and the bottom of the window, one to be drawn up over the upper half of the windows and the other to be pulled down over the lower half. This arrangement provides flexibility for variations in conditions through the day and season.

The correct operation of window shades is important. Glare must be eliminated and if this requires the shading of the windows artificial lighting should be brought into use. Each teacher should study the conditions in his or her room. Sky glare may be troublesome in one room of a school and absent in another.

Window blinds play an important part in the achievement of good seeing conditions in classrooms. The commonly used heavily coated opaque materials are not suitable for classroom use. A medium green of such material absorbs all of the light that strikes it. None goes through. Light cream and white of the same type would allow about 8% of the light to pass through. These blinds waste energy and should be used. There is a material known as Scotolightblind which is a medium white bleached cotton impregnated with translucent filler and stiffening that allows about one-third of the light to pass through. The density of this material is sufficient to prevent glare from direct sunlight or sky. The light that it transmits is softly diffused throughout the room and although it is relatively low in intensity it produces a pleasantly bright environment with the light that is totally wasted with opaque blinds.
Venetian blinds possess some advantages but they require considerable care in their operation to use them most effectively. Under some conditions of wind, when the windows are open, the vibration of the slats makes an intolerable noise.

All window shades or blinds should be as rugged and positive in their operation as possible to withstand the use that they get in classrooms.

GLARE

There are many forms of glare, all of which are detrimental in one way or another. One of the most common forms in classrooms is the high brightness of fixtures or parts of them. This applies more particularly to diffusing enclosing tungsten units and to unshielded fluorescent lamps. A different form of glare is that caused by windows visible beyond the chalkboard, usually in a cloak-room. Fig. 16 shows examples of this, also Fig. 18 (blackboard glare). Such windows should be permanently darkened by paint or other means. It is characteristic of human nature that people will recall from danger of the sudden death variety, but complacently tolerate the slow but sure kind. It is the same with glare. Blinding glare is remedied because it is intolerable, but mild insidious glare is allowed to exact its toll of eye strain and fatigue which in the end may be more injurious than more obvious glare.

The effect of glare is to nullify a proportion of the useful light. This effect is most pronounced when the source of glare is close to the line of vision. The following table illustrates this:

| Glare source* | Percentage of light wasted |
|---------------|---------------------------|
| 5° from the line of vision | 83% |
| 10° from the line of vision | 73% |
| 20° from the line of vision | 60% |
| 40° from the line of vision | 48% |

It is for this reason that lighting fixtures should be free from bright spots and if they exist the fixtures should be mounted as high as practicable.

Chalkboard glare and sky glare are referred to in other sections. A little thought will convince one that these forms of glare can be entirely eliminated by the co-ordination of artificial lighting and window shades.

The teacher's desk should not be near windows because when he or she stands near the window to address the pupils they will probably have to face the windows and thus be confronted with sky glare. Furthermore, being close to the windows the teacher will be less conscious of the fading of daylight.

AUTOMATIC CONTROL OF LIGHTING

The best artificial lighting is worthless unless it is used. Ordinarily in late afternoon the intensity of daylight decreases so gradually that the eyes can easily accommodate themselves to the slow change. Under such conditions a point is reached at which the intensity is too low for the normal use of the eyes.

It is easy for the teacher to fail to notice this with the result that the pupils would not have the benefit of the artificial lighting when it was most needed.

The use of photo-electric automatic control of the lighting system will prevent such a condition. It can be set to turn on the lights when the daylight falls to a selected value and to turn them off when it increases to a predetermined value.

Usually the inner rows of lamps should be lighted all day. These can be turned on at the beginning of the session by the teacher. The outer rows of lamps may be operated automatically. Each school has its own set of conditions that will determine the method of use. It is a simple matter to make provision in the wiring for automatic control if it is desirable to postpone its purchase to a future time.

ROOM FINISHES

No lighting plan for classrooms is complete without reference to the finish of the ceiling, walls, floor, desk tops and furniture generally. Light ceiling (matte white) and moderately light upper walls (light gray, ivory or green) are necessary to obtain an efficient lighting system. Contrast in brightness should be avoided wherever possible. White paper on a dark stained desk top would result in a brightness ratio of about 10 to 1 which is too high for comfort. The same paper may present a brightness ratio of only 2 or 3 to 1 on a natural unstained desk top which would be quite comfortable. Similarly, light finished floors will be much more comfortable as a background for books and paper than dark ones. As the eyes roam from bright surfaces to dark and vice versa they must adjust themselves to each change in brightness. When the brightness contrasts are high the eye adjustments are severe which naturally results in fatigue. Low brightness contrasts reduce slight muscular strain and are therefore conducive to eye comfort and avoidance of strain and fatigue. Light finishes, room equipment and furniture make their contributions to a comfortable and cheerful environment.

SUMMARY

The adverse factors discussed in the foregoing are common in classrooms, although not necessarily all of them in all rooms. Every step tending to reduce these factors will be a contribution to better vision and easier seeing. On the other hand, if they are ignored they will continue as retarding factors. Good lighting is the basic factor in the achievement of good seeing conditions but it alone cannot completely accomplish the desired result. The combination of good lighting, light toned paint and other room equipment produced by suitable paint and varnish, elimination of glare, intelligent use of window shades and elimination of strong brightness contrasts, will minimize the inequalities that exist in classrooms and produce conditions that are conducive to the most rapid advancement with the least eye strain; least physical ills resulting from it and the least effort.

Eighty-five per cent of our knowledge is gained through the sense of sight; in other words through seeing and hence seeing is directly based upon lighting it naturally follows that adequate and correct lighting plays a vitally important part in a child's progress in school. Artificial lighting can supply the deficiencies of daylight and can be controlled to suit any condition.

The teachers should know from personal observation what the seeing conditions are in the different locations in their rooms. Handicaps can be removed or overcome by readily available means. Children with defective sight should be given the benefit of the most favorable conditions.

If two individuals are given identical loads to carry for the same distance, one over smooth level road, the other over rough, uneven ground; the one who travels the rough road will either take longer time or be more tired, or both. Similarly, children working in school under good conditions will perform their tasks with little fatigue whereas others in the same classroom will have to work slower and harder and consequently become more fatigued. The eyes cannot work as fast and with as little expenditure of energy under poor as under good lighting.

All of the pupils as well as the teachers will benefit by good lighting, but those with defective vision will derive more benefit than those with normal vision. Children with defective vision are handicapped for life. Therefore, the employment of any means of preventing the development of eye defects or of assisting those already afflicted is the responsibility of every person entrusted with the equipment of our schools.

OTTAWA, May 12, 1949.

Director

Federal Projects Statistics

Col. B. F. Neary and the undersigned attended a meeting on this date called by Mr. Skelton, Department of Trade and Commerce, to clarify various aspects of Form #280.

During the meeting the following points were cleared by the Chairman.

(a) Grouping

So far as Indian Affairs is concerned, a number of small projects such as Housing Units, Schools, etc., may be grouped by Provinces rather than as individual units or more localized areas.

(b) Band Funds

Construction and/or projects financed from Band Funds are NOT to be included.

(c) Fur Development

All Fur development projects are to be covered even where only labour, planning or direction is involved.

(d) Proposals under Preliminary Examination

The widest possible interpretation is given to this classification under 3-lll and 4-lll. It was referred to as the "idea stage" and not a "state of planning". While some policy guidance might be employed in providing amounts under this heading it was stressed that no policy decision was involved.

(e) "Shelf" Projects

Clarification was requested of 3-l which reads "of which now registered on shelf". The Chairman interpreted this to mean all projects now fully planned, but not yet provided for in estimates.

(f) Signing Authority

The "signature of Authorized Officer", so far as this survey is concerned, includes the Director and/or the Superintendents of the Services or Divisions concerned.

(g) Channels

Completed Forms are to be forwarded through the office of the Deputy-Minister, Mines and Resources. (Mr. Odell).
(h) Publicity

The Chairman stated that it was not the intention to release information to the public on any one or group of projects included in this survey. Only total probable expenditures would be publicized.

The Chairman summarized the purpose of the survey as being to indicate the Government's intention of meeting unemployment by means of public investment.

The foregoing is passed for your information, please.

Admin. Officer.

Appendix

The following lighting recommendation has been prepared from information which you forwarded to us.

The lighting, if installed according to this plan and specifications, will fulfill the requirements of the Department of Education.

Classroom Lighting

The blueprint shows the necessary locations of the fixtures to produce uniform lighting. The various types are described in the attached Appendix.

Fluorescent lighting possesses some advantages over incandescent lighting and is recommended as first choice. Its first cost is higher but its power consumption is much less than incandescent lighting.

Of the two incandescent types indirect lighting is recommended in preference to semi-direct because of its freedom from glare and its soft distribution, provided that the fixtures and lamps will be kept clean and the ceiling will not be allowed to become dirty or discoloured.

It is particularly suited in this case also because of the lower than average ceiling height. The glare from enclosing globes would be excessive.

FLUORESCENT - illustrated on Plate 3 in group 2.
Lamps to be shielded by louvres, lens plates or diffusing glass or plastic.
Lamps per fixture: 4
Colour of lamps: ordinary white
Height: close to ceiling
Place the fixtures so that they are parallel to the line of vision of pupils.

INDIRECT - illustrated on Plate 2, group 1, No. 2
Height: suspended 20 to 28 inches from ceiling
Hydro lamp: 500 watt bowl-silvered inside-frosted
Note: Units of this type are less affected by accumulated dust than any other form of indirect lighting.
May 17, 1949

Blackboard Lighting

The blackboard lighting indicated on the drawing is according to Method No. 3 illustrated on Plate 7. If PAH-58 lamps should not be available R-40 flood lamps may be substituted.

Other types of equipment, which may be either exposed or recessed into the ceiling as desired, are manufactured by the following firms:
- Curtis Lighting of Canada Limited
- Chadwick-Carroll Brass & Fixtures Limited
- Ellis & Howard Limited
- Holophane Company Limited

This equipment must be installed according to the manufacturer's printed or written instructions.

Vestibules

Installation of enclosing glass is optional.
Hydro lamps: 60 - 100 watts, inside-frosted
Height: 3 - 10 ft. above floor

Entrance

Enclosing glass, type not important.
Hydro lamp: 100 or 150 watts.

Residence

Kitchen - 12 inch ceiling globe with 150 watt lamp.
Living Room and Bed Room - select from suitable styles in manufacturer's catalog.

Painting

The results for which these classroom lighting recommendations are planned will require white ceiling and light tinted upper walls.

Electric Wiring

All wiring must conform to the regulations of the Electrical Inspection Dept. of the H.E.P.C.

The service entrance may be located wherever convenient. Conductors: 3 No. 8 wires in one inch conduit. Service Switch: 60 A., enclosed safety switch fused at 35 A., or a 35 A. air circuit breaker. Panel: 6 oct. D.F. type.

Branch circuits may be concealed or exposed conduit, concealed cable, or surface raceway. For wire sizes see instruction on the drawing. Wall switches for classroom general lighting should be 20 A. T-rated.
May 17, 1949

Comments

If indirect lighting is selected the fixtures and lamps must be wiped free of dust once a month and thoroughly washed three times a year. Also the ceiling must be repainted with matte white when it becomes discoloured or dull in tone.

Windows at either the right or the rear of pupils are more of a hindrance than a help. Therefore, they should be shaded with white Scotch-holland window shades.

Respectfully submitted,

[Signature]

APPENDIX TO SCHOOL LIGHTING REPORT

This appendix forms an essential part of the lighting recommendation

GENERAL CONSIDERATIONS

Benefits of Adequate Lighting

The necessity of adequate lighting in classrooms has been thoroughly established by scientific research and by actual experience. The cost of installing a good lighting system is small compared to the benefits accruing from it. Some of these benefits are: minimized eye strain, clear seeing from all parts of the room, increased efficiency of teacher, independence of variations in daylight; better progress and fewer examination failures, greater benefits to pupils with subnormal eyes, better discipline, and more cheerful surroundings.

Requirements of the System

The principal requirements of classroom lighting are that it shall provide evenly distributed illumination of adequate intensity for all desks, with sharp shadows minimized and with the least possible glare.

Types of Lighting

There are three types of lighting that may be used for classrooms. The selection will be influenced chiefly by the cost of the fixtures, the provision for cleaning them regularly, and the maintenance of the ceiling in good reflecting condition.

Indirect Tungsten Lighting, See Plate 2, groups 1 and 2

This is produced by projecting light to the ceiling from which it is distributed throughout the room. Consequently the ceiling MUST be maintained in a highly reflective condition: white or near white.

If the fixtures are of the OPEN type, units 1, 3, 4 and 5 of group 1, Plate 2, or those of group 2, they will collect considerable dust which will necessitate frequent cleaning. Unit No. 2, group 1 uses a BOWL-SILVERED lamp in which the reflector is deposited upon the inside of the bulb where dust cannot collect. Therefore, a reasonable accumulation of dust will not seriously reduce their efficiency. This is a decided advantage.

The quality of properly designed and installed indirect lighting is excellent - softly diffused light that is beneficial to the eyes.
Semi-direct Tungsten Lighting. See Plate 2, group 4.

This lighting is produced by enclosing-glass units; No. 1, group 4 is of prismatic glass; units 2 to 5 are of white or milk glass. White glass units to comply with these recommendations must be greater in diameter than in depth.

Semi-direct fixtures are satisfactory if they are of the specified size and shape, and suspended at the specified height.

The lighting is somewhat less refined in quality than indirect, but does not depreciate quite as rapidly from the accumulation of dust or discoloration of the ceiling.

Fluorescent Lighting.

This is much more efficient than tungsten and will produce twice or more as much light for the same amount of power. It has advantages for high intensity lighting. Fixtures with bare lamps fully exposed are not suitable for classrooms.

In school the pupils spend a considerable amount of time looking straight ahead at the blackboard or the teacher. If bare lamps are exposed to view the glare may be objectionable.

When fluorescent lighting is to be used on 25 cycle power, the utmost care is needed in the selection of fixtures that will minimize the flicker that is caused by the 25 cycle power.

Relative Cost.

Fluorescent lighting is higher in first cost than tungsten lighting, particularly in 25 cycle districts. Indirect tungsten is next, and semi-direct tungsten the lowest.

Blackboard Lighting.

It is most important that all the pupils be able to see distinctly the work that is written on the blackboards. Most blackboards reflect glaring light that prevents clear seeing.

The most effective way of overcoming this is to shade the windows that admit the glaring light and illuminate the blackboards by supplementary units installed especially for the purpose.

Maintenance.

All lighting fixtures collect dust, particularly indirect open type fixtures of any kind. Dust absorbs and wastes light. This wasted light is paid for but not received. Cleaning of lighting equipment is just as necessary to a lighting system as lubrication to an automobile.
Maintenance (Cont'd)

Do not let the ceiling become dull with age. Dark ceilings increase glare and reduce the efficiency of the lighting.

Allowance for Depreciation.

In the preparation of this recommendation an allowance has been made for natural depreciation of the lamps and the accumulation of dust on the lighting equipment between cleaning periods. The lighting will therefore appear higher in intensity when the system is new than it will after a few months' use.

Wiring.

The importance of adequate wiring is evident from the fact that a 10% voltage loss, due to inadequate current-carrying capacity, will cause a light loss of approximately 24%. The minimum wire size is noted on the drawing. This size is based on a maximum voltage loss of 2%, which is in accordance with good wiring practice. (In no case should wire smaller than No. 12 B & S Gauge be used for branch circuits).

Window Shades.

Attention is directed to the proper use of window shades. They are installed particularly to shield the desks near the windows from direct sunlight.

It is only under the MOST favourable conditions that the desks farthest from the windows receive fair daylight illumination. When the window shades are drawn over the upper half of the windows, the illumination on desks farthest from the windows may be decreased 60% or more, depending upon the local conditions.

Conclusion.

This plan has been carefully prepared for this particular school. Emphasis is placed on the importance of providing lighting in accordance with present-day standards. REDUCTION OF THE NUMBER OF FIXTURES, OR THE SUBSTITUTION OF SMALLER LAMPS OR INFERIOR LIGHTING EQUIPMENT WILL RESULT IN INFERIOR LIGHTING THAT WILL NOT PRODUCE THE DESIRED RESULTS. The following steps are necessary in order to take full advantage of the benefits of better lighting.

1. Install the lighting outlets as indicated.
2. Insist on adequate wiring with wire sizes shown on the drawing.
3. Install only mogul-socket fixtures for classroom lighting (for tungsten lamps).
4. Select the type and size of fixture specified.
5. All electrical work must be approved by your District Electrical Inspector.

Supervising Lighting Engineer.

Memorandum:

COLONEL AGLAND,

Please find attached the three main types of contracts used by the Education Division in handling repairs and construction contracts:

(1) Cost Plus Contract.

This is for projects on which we are unable to get firm tenders but must be satisfied with cost plus bid. To date this year, we have not accepted any cost plus tenders and will do everything possible to avoid entering into such contracts.

(2) Firm Price Contracts.

This is the standard contract form used and is based on the one designed by the Lands and Development Services Branch of this Department.

(3) Day Labour and Labour Contract.

In many instances we can save considerable sums of money by purchasing all the materials necessary for the construction of a school, through the Departmental Purchasing Agent. These are then shipped to the site and arrangements are made to have the building erected according to our plans and specifications, by either day labour or a flat labour fee. This form is used on such projects therefore, where only labour is hired and the Department furnishes all necessary materials.

Enc.

STANDARD EQUIPMENT FOR POWER UNITS

The equipment and accessories considered standard for Cummins “Dependable” Diesel Multiple Engine Units are as follows:

**DRIVE**

Power is taken from each engine through individual industrial clutches to a common output shaft, through heavy duty silent chain drives. The chain is completely enclosed and force-feed lubricated. The output shaft is rigidly held by heavy duty anti-friction pillow blocks. Outboard bearings are used on clutch shaft extensions where required.

In the case of Triple Engine Units, the centre engine is direct connected to the output shaft through a suitable heavy duty clutch and gear unit.

Foursome Units consists of two Duals, one placed ahead of the other, and with the output shafts connected by means of a special flexible coupling. In all cases, a single shaft is provided from which the total power of the Multiple Engine Unit is taken.

Standard direction of rotation is counter clockwise when viewed from the drive end.

**BASE**

Each Dual and Triple Engine Unit has an individual fabricated steel base, on which are mounted all components, to form a packaged power unit.

Foursome Units consist of two Dual Units, each having its own steel base.

Assuming a load factor of from 70 to 75%, which I consider to be conservative we could assume that a 5 kilowatt diesel generating set would be satisfactory.

Assuming that my assumptions are correct, there are still a few points in connection with Mr. Jeffries' request which I would like to discuss.

The standard conventional 5 K.W. diesel generating set is equipped with electric starting, which is accomplished by means of a push-button. To start up the engine all that need be done is to depress the starter button and screw the throttle control knob in to the stop. As this is being done the engine comes up to speed and everything then is under control. This operation however can be performed only right at the engine.

There is another form of starting which we call remote manual starting, and consists merely of having the engine starting push-button located at some point distant from the engine itself. In order that there will be no air lock in the fuel system when the engine is shut down from a remote point, the Sheppard Engine Company have found it advisable to use a hydraulic throttle for this type of service, which adds slightly to the cost. This scheme however to my way of thinking would be the best compromise between a fully automatic set and one which would have to be started at the engine every time power were required.

The third method of starting is what we call load demand control. This is a completely automatic starting equipment which causes the engine to start up whenever any light switch or other power demand is turned on. The engine runs continuously until the last light switch is turned off, at which time the engine automatically shuts down. This would be a very lovely arrangement for the schools, but frankly it involves some rather tricky electrical relay circuits etc., and we feel here that we should not advise its use in such a remote point, where knowledge of electrical circuits etc., should not be expected.

As far as the location of the generating set is concerned, I would strongly suggest that it be installed on a concrete block in the basement store-room. This site is chosen in preference to the boiler room merely because the latter is directly under the teacher's living room, and since there is of necessity some noise while the set is operating we thought it would be better to get it away from the living quarters.

A TOY BECOMES A TOOL

Nearly 100 years before automobiles began to appear on streets and highways in the United States, European inventors were experimenting with a mechanical toy to transport men and materials over land. A few expensive models were built for the amusement of wealthy Europeans who could buy them, but transportation by motor vehicle remained out of reach of the masses until several ingenious American mechanics turned their attention toward the European toys.

These pioneers visualized the day when motor vehicles would become a common tool for all men, and toward that end they worked to build a better, cheaper car using special machinery and more efficient methods of manufacture. Soon the toy of wealthy Europeans became the tool of working Americans.

That, according to the Automobile Manufacturers Association is how it happened that this year the United States completed the building of its 100 millionth motor vehicle. During the same period the rest of the world combined has produced only 24 million; so today our country has one passenger car for every five persons while the rest of the world has one for every 231 persons.

What are the reasons for America's superiority in motor transportation? Perhaps the best single answer is—freedom. Freedom to plan, invest, buy, and invent has enabled each manufacturer to compete with other manufacturers for a fair share of the mass market. Frequent advertising and sell has made it possible to create that market in the minds of free men. Last, but perhaps the most important reason, is our system of free roads.

THE NEED FOR MODERN HIGHWAYS

The first census of American roads was taken in 1904, several years before automobiles began to appear in any numbers. It revealed that there were then 2,151,570 miles of rural highways in the United States, but only 141 miles were paved. This was not the kind of road system needed to encourage motor transportation, but it did, at least, provide a point from which to start working.

Throughout the period from 1904, highway development has lagged behind that of motor vehicles. When automobiles were first made available, roads were little more than crooked, dusty or mud-choked trails totally unsuited for motor transportation. Public demand for passenger cars created a strong demand for surfaced, all-weather roads, which were built as fast as funds could be made available. However, the urgent need for lifting rural roads out of the mud, left little time in which to consider future needs, so that shortly after highways were completed, they became outmoded because of new vehicle developments.

Today, as in the past, vehicle manufacturers are far ahead of road builders. Cars have been made to travel faster even though steep hills, sharp curves, and narrow pavements still exist on our highways. The design of new and better trucks is limited by narrow, weak bridges, unstable pavements, and steep grades.

Efforts are being made in every state to advance highway construction to standards comparable with motor vehicle developments. Even more important, engineers are attempting to anticipate highway needs ten or twenty years from now so that roads built today will still be adequate then. This is a difficult, expensive task, but it is the only way to keep vehicle manufacturers from saying to the public, "We could give you better cars if our roads were capable of handling them."
Olympic National Park

A unique blend of nature's objects and processes combined with an unusual climate

by Gunnar Fagerlund

In 1788, while sailing near the coast of northern Washington, John Meares, the English navigator, saw a dominating, glacier-clad peak and was so impressed with its beauty that he named it Mount Olympus after the mythical abode of the Greek Gods in Macedonia. The Olympic Peninsula and the Olympic Mountains derive their names from the mountain.

The Olympic Mountains remained a land of mystery for more than a hundred years after Meares saw them. Even today many areas have not been trod by the foot of man.

When in 1938 Congress established Olympic National Park, conservationists the country over realized the fruits of 34 years of struggle to preserve a superb forest and mountain wilderness. They had fought in vain with a bill in Congress to establish the Elk National Park. It failed to pass, but in 1909 President Theodore Roosevelt set aside 600,000 acres of the Olympic wilderness as Mount Olympus National Monument. From 1912 to 1929 half of this area was withdrawn and returned to commercial use. The 1938 Act provided for a national park of 898,000 acres, which has since been reduced to about 850,000 acres. At present only Yellowstone, Mount McKinley, and Glacier National Parks are larger than Olympic.

Congress had three reasons for establishing this park: (1) preservation of a substantial area of virgin coniferous "rain forest," (2) protection and preservation of interesting fauna, notably the Roosevelt Elk, (3) protection of some of the finest scenic wilderness areas in the nation. As a national park the values inherent in this wilderness are preserved for the inspirational and educational benefit of all the people of this and future generations.

Olympic National Park's outstanding features are mainly a result of the wet climate. The wettest climate in the continental United States prevails on the west side of the park where yearly precipitation exceeds 140 inches. In contrast the east slope of the park is the driest on the west coast, outside of southern California.

Through the centuries an extraordinary forest growth has developed on the western slopes of the Olympics. The predominant forest: Sitka spruce, Douglas fir, red cedar and western hemlock. They attain heights that exceed 200 feet and diameters greater than 10 feet. Here are found the largest Douglas fir and the largest red cedar on record. They are 17 feet 8 inches and 20 feet in diameter, respectively.

The rain forest offers more than big trees. It is a fairyland of plant life, not dark and gloomy, but luminous with a misty green light. Mosses are everywhere, forming a soft carpet underfoot and creating draperies to decorate the whole forest. Even the sphagnum or peat moss grows here, not in bogs but on the ground and on trees. Epiphytic ferns (air plants) venture nearly to the tops of some trees.

As mountains go, the Olympics are not high. Olympus, the highest of the peaks, fails to reach 8,000 feet, but this mountain mass has its base at sea level. Many peaks in Olympic National Park are over 7,000 feet high.

Nobody knows exactly how much snow falls in the high country around Mount Olympus, but from the amount of water that flows back to the ocean in streams, it has been calculated that precipitation must be close to 250 inches every year. The summers are not long enough nor warm enough to melt all the snow, and under such conditions glaciers are born and grow. The glaciers have not all been counted, but there are probably more than a hundred in Olympic National Park. Most of these are small, but a few exceed two miles in length.

All the Olympic mountain glaciers combined cover 30 square miles or more. But the high country is not all snow and ice. By the first of July the snow has melted away from most of it, and on the heels of the melting drifts comes a kaleidoscope of alpine flower gardens in which the pattern of species changes from spring to fall.

With the melting of the snow, animal life, too, springs quickly into action in the high country to take full advantage of the few summer months. The Roosevelt Elk, numbering nearly 5,000, move upward, the cows to rear their calves and the bulls to grow their antlers on the abundant, mineral-rich forage. During this important business the cows and bulls remain separated. As autumn approaches antlers are matured, the females harden and the polygamous bulls rejoin the herds of cows. Each bull strives to secure as large a harem of cows as he can and many are left without followers.
But these bachelors don't give up hope. Their bugling challenges often lead to fights in their attempts to take over a herd. One of the most stirring sounds in nature is the bugling of the bull elk during the mating season.

Of animal species, no matter how interesting and magnificent, does not make a complete national park wildlife picture. Plant eaters and flesh eaters, animals that prey and those that are preyed upon are equally important. It is the assemblage of all the native animals living undisturbed in their natural home that the National Park Service believes is important. The Olympic wildlife picture includes deer, cougar, black bear, marmot, beaver, otter, mink, skunk, weasel, raccoon and many other mammals.

Up to now there are few roads, and the bulk of this wilderness park probably will never be penetrated by a road. Nevertheless, it is possible for the visitor to see a considerable part of the park from an automobile. Roads extend up some of the river valleys a short distance into the park. Coniferous rain forests can be seen in the valleys of the Hoh, Queets, or Quinault Rivers, and during the winter, elk will likely be seen there also. Two winding mountain roads rise to elevations of 6,000 feet where Mount Olympus and much of the interior Olympics may be viewed. The Cascades, a hundred miles away to the east, are visible, and to the north the Strait of Juan de Fuca and Vancouver Island can be seen. But to fully appreciate and enjoy the park's attractions, visitors should venture onto the trails either on horseback or on foot.

Olympic National Park is easily reached from Seattle, Tacoma, Olympia, Bremerton or Aberdeen, Washington, and from Vancouver or Victoria, British Columbia. Ferry boats cross Puget Sound on regular schedules from Seattle and Edmonds.

Lodges, hotels, and cabin camps are available in and outside the park along the Olympic Loop Highway, U. S. 101. This highway may be entered from Olympia without needing to ferry.

If you prefer to camp, the National Park Service maintains campgrounds along the spur roads that penetrate the park and on Highway 101 at Lake Crescent.

Five-million dollar rehabilitation program on 20 miles of dual highway between Baltimore and Philadelphia places burden on the stabilizing effect of subdrainage pipe

by W. H. Spindler

Editor, The Highway Magazine

About a decade ago the Maryland State Roads Commission built a modern, high-type dual divided-lane highway to replace the obsolete, U. S. Route 40 between Baltimore, Maryland, and Wilmington, Delaware. Alignment, grading and sight distances were excellent. The 26-foot concrete lanes were constructed with a low lip curb on the inside and were divided by a crowned, grassed parkway area.

Most of the pavement was laid on a pervious subbase, but in some instances without adequate drainage. Conditions proved more severe than anticipated. Traffic was and is extremely dense, with a high concentration of heavy, through trucks. During the war years, the Edgewood Arsenal, the Aberdeen Proving Grounds, the Martin bomber plant and other war industries contributed heavily to the traffic on this highway.

To make things worse, long sections of U. S. 40 cross low, tidal marsh areas where it was difficult to secure a stable foundation for the pavement, thus there was severe cracking and settlement. Experience has since proved to the Maryland State Roads Commission that adequate subdrainage in the cut sections would have lowered the water table and prevented subsurface water from rendering the pavement foundation unstable.

Drastic action was necessary to salvage this comparatively new highway. Engineers and officials of the Maryland State Roads Commission faced the issue courageously and took a "stitch in time" by ordering an extensive resurfacing and drainage program. Early in 1948 four contracts were let for repaving 20.465 miles of U. S. Route 40 between Baltimore and Aberdeen. These contracts were sixty per cent completed as of November 1, 1948.
