Mapping from the sky

Aerial photography aids in preliminary design and location work on the eastern extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike

by Norman Shigon

The largest aerial mapping project ever conducted for a highway in the United States was recently completed in connection with the 100-mile extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike, from Middlesex to King of Prussia. Over half a million dollars and two years' time were saved by aerial topographic mapping for the highway's design and location.

Aerial mapping proved to have several advantages over conventional ground surveying methods on this big project. Aerial maps can be produced faster, and inaccuracies are reduced to a minimum. But perhaps the most important advantage in these days of high costs is the economy of aerial mapping. The design and location engineers for the turnpike extension estimated that the aerial mapping was accomplished at one-fifth the cost of ground surveys. Moreover, the aerial method made possible the gathering of necessary data without divulging the proposed location at an early date to land speculators.

The route of the extension was flown and photographed in comparatively few days, without the help of ground surveyors. The newspapers of Pennsylvania, which joined in the wide general guessing regarding the probable route, failed to name any point within 5 miles of the actual route, and the highway's location remained secret until the governor of Pennsylvania formally announced the route.

The location studies for the new 100-mile extension, which will be a two-lane divided expressway linking Harrisburg and Philadelphia, were carried out by Gannett, Fleming, Corddry, and Carpenter, Inc., design and location engineers of Harrisburg, Pennsylvania. They hired Aero Service Corporation...
of Philadelphia to perform the aerial mapping. Aero Service completed the topographic mapping in the record time of 145 days. The first map sheets were delivered within 45 days after the work began, and partial deliveries were made at 30-day intervals thereafter until the final group was completed.

For the final design and location data it was necessary to have a large number of field men on the job. However, the use of aerial photography reduced the staff which would have been needed for the surveying, had ground methods been used for the entire project. This work was done during a period when there was an acute shortage of engineering personnel, and aerial surveys made it possible to carry out the project without serious delays.

A proposal is now under consideration that final location be based on aerial topographic maps made on a larger scale with smaller contour intervals. The accuracy of the aerial mapping for the preliminary location indicates that this is entirely practical. Aero Service has mapped 2-foot contour intervals in other fields, and the application of this technique to highway work is being studied.

While aerial mapping at the smaller contour intervals is necessarily more expensive, it is felt that the increase in cost will still be less than the cost of ground surveys necessary.

The cost of the photogrammetric work on the eastern extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike was less than $1.00 per acre. The men engaged in designing this highway maintain that engineering involved in the location work will probably be the only operation to cost less than similar work on the original 160-mile strip.

Since aerial mapping must be done when foliage is off the trees, those involved in planning the project concentrated only on general route studies during the summer months of 1947. An outline of the through course of flight was made from maps of the United States Geodetic Survey, Army Map Service, and the Pennsylvania Department of Highways. The photogrammetric work was done in the autumn of 1947, and the Aero Service Corporation, which has over 2,000,000 square miles of mapping experience, carried on this work at the rate of about one square mile of finished topography per day.

April • 1949
pilot and photographer used a single-engine light plane with good range and stability to map the proposed route. They flew at a height of more than a mile above the area, using a Brock camera to photograph the ground on glass plate negatives. The photographer exposed the plates at approximately 20-second intervals.

These glass plate negatives were flown to the aerial surveyor's laboratories in Philadelphia daily. Prints were made, and sets were returned each day to field surveyors who established the necessary horizontal and vertical control data. These crews used new precision theodolites, combining traverse and bench leveling.

Radio communication was also used to speed ground survey work. Field parties used short-wave radio receiving and broadcasting units, powered by self-contained battery units, to coordinate basic control.

With the field survey data at hand, topographic maps were compiled from the aerial surveys. The individual photographs were exposed so that full stereoscopic coverage was obtained for each area. This method employs basically the same principles as the old parlor stereopticon, but modern aerial photographs are made by means of precision cameras and lenses and are therefore more accurate. Each photographic plate has a forward overlap of 55 per cent as well as considerable overlap on the sides. These photographs were taken about a half mile apart at an altitude of more than a mile, giving greater accuracy and increased stereoscopic depth in the view.

After field surveys established control points and the plates were rectified for tilt, contouring began. The mapping equipment operates on a principle similar to a military range finder. A stereometer operator measured the exact ground elevations from the views. He was then able to draw contours on the photograph to within one-half the contour interval. Planimetric detail appearing on the aerial photos was then added to the topographic maps.

Collateral photographic information, to increase the usefulness of the maps, required intensive preparation. This included photo-mosaics with a scale of 1 inch to 400 feet and boundaries corresponding to the topographic maps; a set of contact prints from the mapping negatives at a scale of 1 inch to 1,000 feet; a set of enlargements at a scale of 1 inch to 400 feet; an assembled photo index for all photography completed; and a tabulation describing the elevations and coordinates of the aerial mapping control points.

The savings in time and costs through aerial mapping on the eastern extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike recommend its use on other highway projects. Many states have already employed this method in highway projects, and some cities, notably Cleveland and Cincinnati, Ohio, are using aerial methods for their city mapping. In any project requiring the mapping of large areas, rapidly and economically, aerial mapping can be an important surveying tool for the modern engineer.

Man-made rain

Economy, efficiency, and better crops result from sprinkler irrigation

by W. A. Groom

President, Colorado Association of Soil Conservation Districts

In the early days of irrigation, water was plentiful, the land was fertile and cheap, labor costs were low, and very little thought was paid to fertilization and conservation of the soil and water. Now that production costs are continuously increasing and a large amount of the rich top soil has been washed away, farmers in general, and orchard men in particular, are becoming more interested in better ways of applying water.

In choosing an irrigation system, these points should be kept in mind: cost of applying water, even distribution, proper penetration, soil fertility, soil erosion and water supply.

With the old method of flooding or furrow irrigation it required the constant attention of a man to see that the water was evenly distributed and running where it was wanted. This is expensive at the present rate of labor, and it is almost impossible to get all the land uniformly wet as there are always high and low spots. The high spots remain dry and the low spots drown out unless careful and expensive leveling has been done and care is taken from year to year to keep the surface of the land uniform.

Proper penetration of water and uniform depth of penetration is very essential in plant growth as it is necessary to get the water to the depth the plants feed. If more water than necessary is used, soil fertility is carried below the roots and wasted. In order to get the desired penetration and also get the surface soil wet at the lower end of the field, with the old method a great deal more water had to be applied at the upper end than was needed, which resulted in a waste of water and the loss of fertility.

Watering a field of pole beans. Notice that the sprinkler line has been run across the top of the poles.

—Grooms et al., authors.

In the early days of irrigation, very little thought was given to the slope of the land so long as water would run. This caused an enormous amount of erosion on some lands and a waste of water.

The sprinkler system, since the use of light-weight pipe has been adopted, takes...
care of nearly all these features. The cost of operation is small, depth of penetration can be controlled, and an even application of water to the topsoil can be secured. By controlling the amount of water applied and penetration, soluble mineral elements are retained in the root zone area and leaching of this valuable material prevented. Since there is no runoff from use of sprinklers, there is no erosion and loss of valuable topsoil. There is no need for expensive leveling as the pipe can be run over most uneven land. Irrigation engineers claim sprinklers save only 10 to 40 per cent as much water as the old method. This is a very vital advantage, as it is becoming more and more necessary to use our water to its greatest efficiency over more acreage in order to feed the ever increasing population of the world.

It has been found that the main feeder roots of trees, as well as all other crops, are close to the surface of the soil, and that this is where the fertility, both mineral and organic, should be put. Orchard men are turning to cover crops to supply organic matter. Under the old method of irrigation a great deal more water was needed to germinate these small seeds than was good for the trees. With sprinklers the surface can be kept moist enough for a good growth of a cover crop without adding to the free water table in the subsoil.

The use of commercial fertilizers is becoming more common in the growing of all crops. How to get this fertility into the soil so it will be uniformly available to all the feeder roots has always been a problem. The sprinklers, together with liquid fertilizer, will solve this as the desired amount of fertilizer can be run through the sprinklers and then enough water put on the land to get this material down to the proper depth so the feeder roots can pick it up and make use of it.

Sprinklers are like every other method of irrigation in that the farmer must study his land, his application of water, and see that his system is working properly at all times. The time has not yet arrived when we can rely by the pushbutton method. But by proper use and care, sprinklers should conserve both the topsoil and water, and produce better crops at a substantially lower cost. It will eliminate the high dry spots and the low wet spots. Moreover, in a great many cases the cost of a sprinkler system will be less than the cost of leveling the land for an old style system of irrigation.

WANTED—A FOURTH "E"

In the February 1949 issue of The Highway Magazine, we published an editorial on "Built-In Highway Safety." The editorial pointed out that the death rate on the nation's highways can be reduced by applying the "three E's," education, enforcement, and engineering, to the problem of traffic mishaps.

Following the editorial, we received a letter from one of our readers, Mrs. J. N. Olson of Galveston, Texas, with the suggestion that we add a fourth "E" to the other three.

"The three great factors, education, enforcement, and engineering, are its (The National Safety Council) foundation stones, but as a woman I see another element I feel should be added, and that is Economy... I have always felt that we need to inject into the highway, in addition to these three 'E's', a fourth one. It would put new life and attention, a new vigor into the already-stereotyped three."

Mrs. Olson's letter went on to point out that there are a number of practical methods by which the fourth "E" can be applied. She suggests that magazines can show photographic examples of safe driving practices.

Perhaps a better suggestion is that all drivers, and pedestrians, too, conduct themselves so that they are good examples to others at all times.

NATIONAL PARKS ATTRACT MOTORISTS

If past records can be used to predict future happenings, it is safe to say that nearly 30 million persons will visit our national parks during the current vacation season. Furthermore, the records indicate that 98 per cent of those tourists will travel to the park of their choice by motor vehicles, and the average distance traveled to the great parks of the West will be close to 900 miles.

These figures show that in addition to threading the tremendous traffic load on the roads within the parks, vacationing motorists will also place an extra burden of some size on our federal and state highway systems. This load will come at a time when spring repairs and summer construction are at their height, possibly causing delays for the contractors and probably causing inconvenience for the travelers. However, the figures demonstrate what an important part our highways play in serving vacation-minded America.

Despite the heavy concentration of traffic on park roads, only six accident fatalities were reported by the National Park Service for 1948. This was only half the number reported for 1947 and reflects the highway safety program being stressed by all park staffs.

In order to keep down driving hazards, the Park Service is spending $2 million annually on maintenance of its road system. These funds will be spent for education of the motoring public, enforcement of the park regulations, and engineering of better marked, safer highways.

Carlsbad Caverns National Park

The world's greatest underground wonderland

by Donald S. Libbey

Superintendent, Carlsbad Caverns National Park

Carlsbad Caverns National Park is located in southeastern New Mexico approximately 27 miles from the city of Carlsbad. Although the park area is in the rugged foothills of the Guadalupe Mountains, the region consists of picturesque semi-desert country. Its cactus vegetation is as strange as the vast network of subterranean passageways, and its vaulted chambers are draped with myriad dripstone and flowstone formations. The ceilings hang stalactites and helictites of fantastic shapes and color designs and from the floors of the many rooms extend stalagmites of tremendous size.

All that is known of the first man to see the entrance of Carlsbad Caverns is that he was an Indian. Evidences of prehistoric inhabitation are the circular rock mescal or cooking pits and the grinding bowls found on the surface, in addition to the paintings, or photographs, found on the walls of the entrance. It is doubtful, however, that the Indians ventured far into the caverns.

Early pioneer trails passed near the caverns' entrance. The Spanish conquistadors are believed to have come into the Guadalupe Mountains near the caverns, and the historic old Butterfield Express Trail, the first express trail across the West, crossed the route of the Spaniards at this point.

Closely following the wayfarers of the Butterfield Trail came the cattlemen and the first permanent settlers. They knew of the caverns, referring to them as the Bat Cave, and may have explored portions of them. Their interest, however, was not caused by their natural beauty but by the discovery of valuable deposits of bat guano. Mining operations to remove this nitrate-rich fertilizer began at the turn of the century, and the guano miners made extended explorations of the underground chambers and passageways.

Among these early miners was a local youth, Jim White. He was impressed by the wonders he saw beneath the surface and took every opportunity of visiting the caverns and encouraged others to visit them. Later, Jim White became an unofficial guide for the caverns, and when the area was included within the national park system, he was made a park ranger and subsequently, chief ranger.

As more settlers came to the region the fame of the caverns grew, and in 1923 Robert Holley, of the General Land Office, United States Department of the Interior, surveyed the cave to determine whether it should be included in the areas making up the national park system. His report stressed the magnificence of the caverns, and on October 25, 1923, President Coolidge proclaimed the area the Carlsbad Cave National Monument. Also in 1923, and again in 1924, Dr. Willis T. Lee, of the Geological Survey, made comprehensive explorations, and the publishing of his findings in the National Geographic Magazine gave the caverns national publicity. An act of Congress, approved May 14, 1930, changed the status of the area to the Carlsbad Caverns National Park.

The underground caverns are extensive with over 23 miles of explored passageways, some rich in cave formations and others of archeological interest. The park area itself covers an area of 49,608 acres.

An understanding of the manner in which these vast subsurface caverns have been formed is no less interesting than the thrill of visiting them. The study of this underground wonderland and the rock structure in the area of the Guadalupe range makes it evident that two great geological processes were active in the creation of the caverns. The first process accomplished the hollowing-out of an extensive network of subterranean chambers and passageways in the once-solid rock; the second produced the spectacular decorative array of travertine, drapestone formations that embellish the walls, ceilings and even the floors.

Visitors to Carlsbad Caverns explore three miles of well lighted trails leading through...
the most spectacular portion of the caverns. All who are physically capable of the cavern visit are urged to make the complete tours which require about four hours and involve walking down several flights of stairs, entrance on ramp-like trails and stair steps through what is termed the Main Corridor on the top of the ancient rubble heap of rock fragments that developed during the first stage in the formative process.

The true cavern floor is reached in the first of four scenic rooms. The Green Lake Room, which is 829 feet below the surface, is a chamber of breathtaking beauty with draperies, dazzling white columns, and literally thousands of stalactites. Formed by a constant drip from the ceiling, the blue-green water of the Green Lake is mirror-clear. Any visitor can be seen a "Frozen Waterfall" of glistening flowstone, which for all the world resembles a raging torrent of "white water" frozen in place with all the rapids and cataracts preserved.

Superlatives, however, should be saved for the next room, the King's Palace. This is generally considered the most beautiful room in the caverns. It is circular in form with a profusion of fantastic stalactites and draperies hanging from the ceiling. The forms range in architectural style from ornate Gothic through the most florid Baroque to intricate filigree traceries in stone that suggest Moorish embellishments.

The "key-hole" separates the King's Palace from the Queen's Chamber. This opening is through delicate sheets of translucent, gleaming onyx that swirl like vast theatrical curtains. The Queen's Chamber, though smaller in size, excels even the Palace in intricacy of design and magnitude of the draperies.

After passing through the smallest of the scenic rooms, the Papoose Room, the path leads into the King's Palace and then climbs "appetite hill" some eighty feet to the level of the underground lunch room. A stop of 40 minutes is made 754 feet below the surface in this natural lunch room, a space so large than one thousand people can dine at the same time.

The first part of the tour from the natural entrance down the main corridor and through the four scenic rooms involves the steep descent and a walk of 1¾ miles in order to reach the lunch room.

After luncheon visitors are escorted around the edge of the Big Room, which is shaped like a gigantic cross two thousand feet in length and eleven hundred feet in width. Its grandiose size, the high vaulted ceilings, and the massive, even monumental, formations defy description. The ceiling rises 285 feet above the trail and a stalagmite towers 62 feet in height. The wings of an angel, painted grottoes, a "Bottomless Pit," the huge unsupported natural arch, totem poles, intricate varicolored chandeliers, a "Fairyland," and the "Hall of Giants" combine to create the most impressive and inspiring mass of natural formations to be found in any underground wonderland.

The bat spectacle is one of the great attractions of Carlsbad Caverns National Park. Each evening about sundown a great number of bats come forth from Bat Cave during the frost-free months. Flying out through the entrance arch in a spiral, they stream off over the rim in a southerly direction, later to separate into flocks which disappear in the distance for a night's foraging. When night-flying insects such as moths and beetles are numerous literally millions of bats join the flight, but as the insect food supply wanes so does the number of bats, and during the winter months most of them migrate to warmer regions.

Bats return from their nocturnal insect feeding just before dawn. They dive into the entrance at amazingly high speed and fly directly to the Bat Cave, where they spend the daylight hours at rest. Bats at roost hang by their hind legs, head downward, in dense clusters from the ceiling of their particular part of the caverns.

A talk on the bats is given by a national park service naturalist each summer evening at the cavern's entrance just before the flight begins.

Carlsbad Caverns is a year-around park. Four complete cavern tours occur each day, starting at 9, 10, 11 A.M., and 12:15 P.M. It requires from 4 to 4½ hours to complete a tour and return to the surface. All visitors have the opportunity to return to the surface by elevator service, although after the completion of the 10 and 11 A.M. tours, those who desire have the opportunity to return to the surface by the cavern trails.

Each day a special photographic tour starts from the cavern lunch room and those with flash bulbs and tripods are given an opportunity to photograph many of the formations. Only snapshots are permitted on regular tours, but they are not encouraged since the cavern lighting is not adequate for such exposures.

Carlsbad Caverns National Park is served by the Santa Fe Railroad on the north through the city of Carlsbad. Train passengers can reach the park by auto, bus or taxi-cab. The park is also served by the Texas and Pacific, Rock Island, and Southern Pacific Railroads by way of El Paso. Daily airplane service is provided to the Carlsbad airport. By automobile the park can be reached over U.S. Highway No. 62, U.S. Highway No. 285, and from U.S. Highway No. 80.

All visitors are conducted through the caverns by national park rangers who explain the caverns story and are glad to impart authentic information.
Metal forms for concrete piers

At Riverton, Cherokee County, Kansas, the Long Construction Company of Kansas City, Missouri, devised a unique and economical system of driving forms for deep concrete foundation piers. The piers were poured for a boiler and turbine plant erected as part of a new 30,000 KW generating unit for the Empire District Electric Company.

Test borings indicated that it would be necessary to excavate 70 feet deep for most of the piers to reach a solid foundation. A 4-foot diameter was specified for 12 of them while the remaining twenty were 6 feet 7 inches in diameter. All piers consisted of reinforced concrete.

While the first few feet of earth was being excavated for each pier, workmen made up 12-foot sections of cylindrical forms on top of the ground. One of these was lowered into the hole as soon as it was deep enough. The sections were made up by placing pieces of 10 gage ARMCO Flange-type Sheeting around circular bands of angle-iron. Because of the light weight and flexibility of this sheeting, it was easily formed around the small circles. The flanges of adjacent sheets were overlapped to provide tighter joints and assure straighter driving.

After a section of the forms had been lowered into the hole for the pier, excavation proceeded to a depth 3 or 4 feet below the bottom of the sheeting. The digging was performed by hand with a bucket hole being used to remove the dirt from the hole. Each piece of sheeting in the form was then driven individually by an air hammer to the bottom of the excavation. Additional circular angle-iron bands were installed every 6 feet and separated by metal bars. This procedure continued until the 12-foot lengths of sheeting in the first section of forms had been driven almost entirely into the ground.

At this point, an additional piece of sheeting was welded to the top of each piece in the first section, and driving continued in the manner outlined above. Before welding on additional sheets, it was necessary to trim a few inches of metal from the driven end of each sheet to secure a neat, strong connecting weld.

When the proper depth of excavation was reached, cylinders of reinforcing steel, previously assembled on top of the ground, were lowered into the hole. The concrete was then poured in approximately 12-foot lifts. Before this concrete received its initial set, the length of sheeting was pulled up to the connecting weld, burned off, and reclaimed for future use. The device used for pulling the sheeting consisted of a pair of metal tongs connected to an air hammer and suspended from the cable of a crane.

By using ARMCO Steel Sheeting to make up the forms, the contractor was able to reclaim the material in the forms and use it again and again with very little loss of metal. Its light weight made it convenient to handle, and its durability and strength enabled it to resist damage in driving and pulling.

Floyd Gibbons was superintendent of the project for the Long Construction Company. Earl J. Newellow is superintendent of the Empire District Electric Company. Black & Ventesh of Kansas City were the design engineers of the new plant, and S. S. Wardrup served as resident engineer.

How firm a foundation

by Virginia Reetz

Who would believe that the success of a $4,000,000 road project could depend on a few blades of grass?

Texans, who have always been known for doing things in a big way and doing them well, are now involved in completing an interregional highway between Dallas and Rockwell. In order to prevent erosion of the bare slope along the right-of-way, which might ultimately undermine the road itself, grass has already been planted.

Under the supervision of T. E. Huffman, Dallas urban expressways engineer for the state highway department, a new method has been used to hold the loose soil on side slopes until the grass has had a chance to grow and grip the ground beneath it with its tenacious roots.

The operation is simple and efficient. First the ground on the slopes is thoroughly pulverized, and then if necessary, it is raked by hand to remove all large roots, clods and rocks. Following that, the area to be treated is carefully sprayed with water. When the ground has dried sufficiently to be worked on, workers broadcast Bermuda Grass seed over the soil. This seed is raked and rolled into the earth and covered with a layer of asphalt. The asphalt is easily sprayed on by hand or by mechanical sprayers mounted on tank trucks.

This layer of asphalt is nothing more than a thin membrane which covers the soil. It is adherent enough to hold the earth, thereby preventing erosion, and yet it is thin and delicate enough that the growing grass is able to push its slender blades through the surface and develop to maturity. This asphaltic mixture is necessarily non-toxic to grass plants. As it has proved an economical method of mulching, it is favored by engineers and taxpayers alike.

Mr. Huffman, pleased with the results, says "In about ten days the grass has germinated and is sticking its green shoots through the black asphalt. We expect that Texans will see more and more of this type of seeding work along our highways because it has proved successful in preserving top soil along our rights-of-way."

Tiny tunnel for a miniature railroad

Located in the city of Northampton, Massachusetts, home of Smith College and heart of the Pioneer Valley, Frank Newhall Look Memorial Park is visited by over a quarter million people every year. Opened to the public on July 4, 1930, the park was a gift to the city from Mrs. Look in honor of her husband.

Within its 160 acres, Look Park contains many entertainment facilities including a swimming pool, locker building, play fields and baseball diamonds, picnic areas, a public store, and the Pines Outdoor Theater, which is large enough to seat 4,500 people. In addition there are many scenic attractions such as the Swan Pond and the Lily Pools.

Under the management of M. Foss Narum, Look Park is constantly being improved for the enjoyment of children and adults alike. During 1948, a miniature streamlined train, believed to be the first of its kind ever owned and operated by a municipal park, was added to the park.

The tiny railroad operates over 4,800 feet of 16-inch gauge track and has rolling stock of the most modern design. The locomotive is a model, built on a scale of 1 to 5, of General Motors' newest locomotive, the FP3. Powered by a 4-cylinder, air-cooled 4V motor, its 16 driving wheels give it a drawbar pull of 800 pounds. Details are exact in every respect for the locomotive and cars alike, even to the spacing of the rivets and knobs on the sand box door.

The track is laid through open fields, where a large expanse of the park is open to view, and through a wooded area bordering an enclosure where many deer are kept. To make the miniature railroad more like its big brothers, a 90-foot tunnel was constructed on the line. This tunnel also serves as a "round house" when the train is not in operation.

Designed by E. J. Dunn and A. J. Runnals of the New England Metal Culvert Company, the tunnel consists of a 10 gage ARMCO MULTI-PLATE Arch with a base width of 6 feet 10 inches and a clear height of 6 feet 4 inches. The two top plates of the arch have a 36-inch radius of curvature while the other two plates are curved on a 200-inch radius.

The structure is set on metal channels anchored to concrete abutments. Because of subsurface water encountered during excavation, several hundred feet of HEL-COR Perforated Pipe was installed along the sides of the tunnel. In addition, it is expected that portal entrances made of field stone will be added to the arch this summer to more nearly simulate a tunnel on a "big" railroad.

The miniature line operated only a few weeks in 1948, but Narum estimates that during 1949 it will carry close to 100,000 riders.

Cabrillo Freeway Serves San Diego

by Mark McMillin

Constructed at a cost of $3,500,000, the recently-completed Cabrillo Freeway in California extends 7.1 miles from San Diego to connect with U.S. Highway 395, and is regarded by highway engineers as a model of freeway construction. The new road is a four-lane divided highway, having a width from 150 to 200 feet. Wherever possible, the right of way is fenced.

Originally planned in 1938, the project was shelved temporarily because of the war. In the meantime, however, other highway units and structures in the vicinity, which have since been completed, were planned as an integral part of the Cabrillo Freeway.

Ultimately, the northern terminus, Highway 395, will also be modernized for a distance of approximately 120 miles northeast. This project is now under construction.

In planning and building the new freeway, highway engineers overcame many difficult problems. It was necessary to acquire approximately 200 separate parcels of land for the right-of-way, and to move several residences to new locations. However, it was not necessary to resort to a single contractor. Twelve contractors were involved in the work, each of them having several different structures under way at the same time. A total of two bridges and 13 grade separations were constructed. Two and one-half miles of city sewer and water mains were relocated and reconstructed, and six miles of culverts and storm drains were installed. Because the freeway bisects Balboa Park, it was also necessary to transplant many shrubs and trees which were in the path of the project.

Approximately 6,000,000 cubic yards of earth was moved because of the hilly nature of the terrain along the entire length of the freeway. All suitable top soil was salvaged as part of the grading operations, and this soil was later spread on the embankment slopes to a depth from 6 to 8 inches. These slopes were then covered with straw and planted with grass to prevent erosion. Within the city proper, the slopes have been planted with shrubs and trees to harmonize with the landscaping of Balboa Park, one of the most beautiful in the world. Approximately half a million plants, in 28 varieties, were used on this phase of the project.

One interesting feature of the new freeway is the traffic interchange at the Mission Valley Highway. It is the first of its particular type to be placed in service in California. This unit provides for the free flow of traffic in all directions with a minimum of interference.

The freeway cuts through the heart of the business district in San Diego, but since it has seven times the traffic capacity of any of the downtown streets on which parking is permitted, no serious traffic problems are likely to develop from its use. In fact, the new freeway is expected to reduce the accident rate per million vehicle miles by 40 per cent.

Traces of the past

by Betty H. Huntress

In the Northwest, as in many parts of the country, our modern highways often follow quite closely the old pioneer wagon roads, which in their time followed the earlier Indian trails through the same mountain passes, along the same rivers, and across the same dry stretches of scrub brush. Many of our highway bridges, too, span streams and rivers at ancient crossings.

Nowadays few real signs of the past remain along the more traveled highways, but the history-conscious motorist can still find authentic traces of days gone by if he ventures off the beaten track. Among these are old buildings, often scenes of violence in the early days, and here and there even the ruts of the old immigrant roads, always deeper cut on the uphill pulls where the oxen strained against their loads.

One such stretch of the Old Oregon Trail can still be found just south of Vale, almost at the mid-point on the Oregon-Idaho border, beside a county road leading to the famed Owyhee Dam. A downhill grade, it is not so deeply rutted as some, but is plainly visible, taking a more direct route through the ravine than does the modern road. One can almost reconstruct the thoughts of the pioneers as they approached this particular stretch, for there were much anticipated hot springs just ahead. For the men this meant a warm bath, for the women a bath and a chance to do the family washing after the heat and dust of the trail. Today there's a modern laundry on that spot, just across the river from the town of Vale.

Owyhee Dam, a few miles farther south, draws visitors by the hundreds during the summer, though the road is not yet in the best condition. At the time of its completion, in 1932, the dam was the second highest in the world, raising 405 feet above bedrock and extending 175 feet below. The reservoir formed by the dam extends back some 40 miles in the Owyhee Canyon, one of the wildest and most remote parts of Oregon. This area has long been famous for spectacular scenes and wild horse roundups. The name Owyhee, incidentally, is an early day corruption of Hawaii, and was named for two Hawaiians who were killed by the Snake Indians near there in 1819.

Another historic spot of interest is Laurel Hill, in the foothills just below Mt. Hood on Oregon State Highway 56. This was a place to strike fear, even despair, into the hearts of the pioneers traversing the old Barlow toll road around the mountain and down toward the Willamette Valley, fertile goal of their months-long journey. The wide paved curves of the highway today carry thousands of skiers from Portland and vicinity up toward Government Camp and Timberline Lodge every winter. Most of them are so intent on the sport above that they fail to consider the contrast of a hundred years ago on that very hill where pioneers eased their loaded wagons down the steep grade from level to level by ropes tied around the trees. It is said that the marks of the ropes can still be seen in a few places.

Sherar's bridge across the Deschutes River extracted tolls from travelers in stagecoach days, but all that remains of a once thriving community is the old barn in the background.

if you know where to look for them. "We went down Laurel Hill like shot off of a shovel," wrote William Barkow, son of the road builder.

This historic hill has its tales of gold, too, both mined and buried by man. Prospect holes bear witness to the former, while loot, said to have been buried by a highwayman who killed his partner and only confessed on his deathbed, has long been sought there in vain.

One would think the descent of Laurel Hill would have been difficult enough for the weary immigrants, now almost in sight of the "promised land," but a few miles farther down the road they faced another kind of barrier—the toll gate where the charge was $1.00 a head for stock and from $2.50 to $5.00 (accounts differ) for a wagon. Widows, with a touch of generosity, were allowed to go through free, and if a man reaching that point was quite destitute, he could pay by promissory note.
Over on the Deschutes River, famous fishing stream of central Oregon, there's a bridge that marks a crossing with more than its share of exciting history. Sherar's Bridge is still its name, though the actual bridge there now is simply another familiar white-fenced highway bridge, and the real Sherar's Bridge is long gone. A few miles below Tygh Valley, it stands on the route of the old stagecoach road from the mines on the Columbia River to the John Day mines. This is the road that was so dangerous it had to be guarded by U.S. cavalry for many years to protect travelers against holdups by Indians and outlaw whites.

At the site of an ancient Indian crossing, the first bridge was built in 1860. Swept away by a flood the next year, it was rebuilt in 1862, and nine years later was bought for $7,040 by Joseph Sherar, a native of Vermont who had mined in California and freighted in southern Oregon. He spent about $75,000 improving the roads that led to his bridge, charged a high toll for crossing, and built an inn there that became the nucleus of a small settlement. Nothing is left now except the original barn and the water pipes that led to the inn.

There's a thrill in finding these evidences of the past for yourself that you can't get any other way. It's one thing to stop and read a neat, precise bronze historical marker placed beside the road for your edification as you travel—so many Indians killed here, so many white men massacred there—but it's much more adventurous and satisfying to read your history of the region, study old maps or follow a tip from an old-timer, and then go out on the backroads and pick up the trail yourself.

"Typhoid Mary" Starts her day

Just forty years ago, "Typhoid Mary" was caught by the New York Health Department. Her real name was Mary Mallon. She never had typhoid herself, and she never dreamed she was harming anyone. But in her body "Typhoid Mary" carried typhoid germs... millions of them. As a cook, she infected at least fifty-three persons. Some of them died.

All around us today are Typhoid Marys—and Typhoid Toms. They are spreading germs far more deadly than typhoid—germs that infect the mind. You can't see these germs; you hear them: Nasty words about a race or religion.

Every innocent words can be infected by a tone of voice: "Catholics"... "Jews"... "Negroes"... "Protestants."

Typhoid Marys "never dream they are harming anyone" by spreading racial and religious hatreds. But weren't such hatreds behind Hitler's concentration camps? Behind our own lynchings and race riots?

Let's stop the Typhoid Marys—today—for our own sake, for America's sake, by doing these three things:

1. Accept—or reject—people on their individual worth.

2. Don't listen to, or spread, rumors against a race, or a religion.

3. Speak up wherever we are, at home, in business, in our school, labor, church or social groups, against prejudice, for understanding.

Selkirk (Sveinson Patent) INSULATED CHIMNEY
here's what happens INSIDE YOUR CHIMNEY

Today's brick chimney is substantially the same inefficient smoke ejector as used since men first began building houses.

When coal, oil or wood is burned in your stove or furnace, the smoke that is created contains a great deal of tar. This sticky material is inflammable, and when the smoke is cooled, will deposit itself on the handiest object, where it is ready to burst into flame. In the brick chimney, the cold walls cool the smoke rapidly as it passes through, causing tar and gum to be deposited on the porous brick. The brick becomes saturated with this sticky, inflammable deposit, and when the chimney becomes overheated in severe weather, a very dangerous fire hazard is created.

A brick chimney costs more — is less efficient

A brick chimney requires a concrete foundation to support its weight — plus the cost of brick, cement, flue lining, flashing and labor. A brick chimney takes a good deal of time and trouble to construct, and when built is subject to deterioration and constant repair.

Brick chimneys are by far the greatest cause of fires which, if not extinguished promptly, cause complete loss of property and often lives. For instance, of 2,089 fires in Winnipeg in 1947, 676, or more than 32%, were caused by fires in the chimney. Is YOUR house likely to be next?

It's a NEW PRINCIPLE in Chimneys

Two things are necessary to make a chimney efficient. First, the flue must be so constructed as to present a smooth, hard surface that the smoke and tar cannot cling to. Second, some method must be devised whereby the smoke and gases will not be cooled until they reach the open air. Keeping the waste smoke hot increases draft, making the furnace or stove work more efficiently, and in addition, eliminates tar deposits which cause chimney fires.

Selkirk Chimneys are doubly insulated to keep waste smoke and gases hot — first with a 2½ inch fireproof insulation — second with a ½ inch sealed air space surrounding the flue. The flue itself, of heavily galvanized iron, provides a round, hard, smooth, even surface free of corners, cracks and crevices.
BE SAFER - SAVE MONEY -
GET MORE HEAT FROM FUEL -

with a Selkirk INSULATED CHIMNEY

Selkirk Chimneys are designed and built to do the job right. Waste gases are conducted efficiently, economically, and safely to the outside air. Tar cannot form on the smooth, hard, round inner flue. In addition, Selkirk Chimneys cost less than old-fashioned brick chimneys—give far more for your money.

SAFETY
No danger of chimney fires, when tar and gum deposits are eliminated. Many brick chimneys, when old, deteriorate and crack, leaking dangerously into confined spaces inside the house. This can't happen with the Selkirk as gases cannot escape through 3 walls of iron pipe and insulation. All seams heavily riveted. Selkirk's weight will not affect the Selkirk, as it is suspended on roof and floor flanges and thus moves up or down with house.

LIGHT WEIGHT
The Selkirk weighs only 19 pounds per linear foot, compared to 135 pounds per linear foot for a comparable brick chimney. This saves the trouble, space and expense of a foundation, and saves labor because of the ease of installation.

LOW COST - LONG LIFE
You save labor and building materials with a Selkirk—it comes as a complete unit and ready to install. It neither needs cleaning nor maintenance—inside surfaces of flue stays clean at all times. No chimney fires have been reported in 15 years.

APPEARANCE
Cap presents a neat appearance from the outside—may be painted to match color of roof or house. In ordinary roof construction, cap emerges 2 feet above highest point of roof ridge.

PERFORMANCE
The patented design of the Selkirk Chimney consists of three sleeves of heavily galvanized iron, one inside the other. The two outer sleeves contain 2½ inches of fireproof insulation, which keep the waste gases hot until they reach the outer air. The 1½ inch sealed air space surrounding the inner flue gives additional insulation. This provides greatly increased draft and better burning of fuel—and ensures that the flue itself keeps clean and free from tar deposits. Designed to operate efficiently no matter what fuel—coal, wood, or oil—is burned.

INSTALLATION
Being light in weight, the Selkirk is relatively easy to install. No special foundation is needed. The chimney comes complete with special flange made to fit the house; this rests on the roof, where most of the weight is supported. In addition, a sleeve which fits in the crown provides rigidity and supports the bulk of the weight. Two men can easily install the Selkirk in a single afternoon, without hard labor.

TO ALL PRINCIPALS:

Re: Equipment and Plumbing Facilities

When a Principal writes Head Office concerning a breakdown of equipment or non-function of heating, plumbing or lighting units we do our best to have matters remedied as soon as possible by consulting Indian Affairs Ottawa Office. Many times however government engineers in reporting back to Indian Affairs state that evidence shows the equipment has been abused, neglected or not kept clean. Particularly is this found in wash room and toilet facilities. From personal observation, while visiting some schools, I have found the engineers' statements to be correct.

I would strongly urge that, in the case of toilets, wash basins, showers, etc., the supervisors be made especially responsible for keeping the equipment clean and free from foreign matter. Washrooms, toilets, boiler and engine rooms ought to be regularly and carefully inspected by the Principal and any slackness on the part of staff workers brought to their attention. We cannot expect full co-operation from government if we neglect to give equipment it supplies the same care and attention as we give to like facilities in our own homes.

This matter is important and I ask your hearty cooperation.

Yours faithfully,

Henry G. Cook,
Superintendent.

MEMORANDUM FOR THE MINISTER

DEPARTMENTAL ACTIVITIES

The election is over and it would appear that the Government can be expected to remain firmly in power for the next four or five years. This would seem to be an appropriate occasion to review the basic policies upon which the activities of the Department are predicated.

It would, of course, be possible to go on from session to session dealing in the traditional manner with such problems as may arise in the course of our routine activities. This would be an easy and, perhaps, an adequate way of meeting our responsibilities.

On the other hand, we might create a sensation and perhaps do some good by working up two or three big projects and making each of them the subject of a spectacular campaign.

Intermediate between these two courses lies a third and, in my opinion, a more satisfactory alternative. Under this programme we would work out a vigorous, positive and progressive policy in connection with each of the developmental activities that fall within the range of departmental responsibility. To some extent have been doing this over the last two or three years. Much of our time during that period, however, has been taken up with revising the Departmental organization and obtaining personnel for services which were seriously depleted during or prior to the war. As matters now stand, our organization is in reasonably good shape (except for the fantastic difficulties caused by the present physical distribution of our establishment in the city of Ottawa). The personnel position is more satisfactory than it has been for many years and is steadily improving. The Government has displayed a willingness to provide funds for most of the projects that we have recommended.
Given these conditions, I suggest that we should now undertake a review of the activities of each of the Branches and decide in the light of discussions with the Directors on the objectives that we should accept as being desirable and possible of attainment within the next five years. This may lead to the formulation of a general and over-all programme for the development of our natural resources. On the other hand we may decide to confine ourselves to a series of more limited and less ambitious objectives. At least we shall have the satisfaction of knowing all our decisions are the result of a careful and integrated study.

If you think well of this suggestion, I should like to ask each Director to prepare a memorandum on this subject to be used as the basis for a discussion with you and myself. I would suggest that such discussions might be timed to take place during the months of October and November and that they should be sufficiently far advanced by the end of that time to enable us to take whatever consequent steps seem appropriate in the preparation of our final estimates for 1950-51.

I shall be glad to have an indication of your views as to the desirability of the proposed procedure.

(Signed) H.L. Keenleyside,
Deputy Minister.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR,

Five Year Plan - Indian Education.

I feel that this program can best be defined under the following categories:

1. Indian Residential Schools,
2. Indian Day Schools,
3. Joint Schools,
4. Secondary Education,
5. Adult Education and Extension Work,
6. Administration.

I will now treat with each of the above categories and outline what I feel should be the basic policies in each field during the next five years:

1. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOLS

I feel that no residential schools should either be promised or planned in any way until a thorough educational survey has been carried out by a committee of competent educators. In order that we may have a proper perspective, it is most essential that a representative of the Department of Education of
the province concerned be appointed to this committee.

Only in this way can a systematic program of residential school construction be carried out where such schools are specifically required.

In the past the various denominations have taken the initiative with regard to the establishment of residential schools and have pressed the Department into making decisions with regard to their construction. I feel that a new policy must be instituted in which the Department decides on the basis of professional surveys and reports, as to the necessity of erecting this type of school.

We have now 17 requests on hand for the construction of these schools and I am convinced that several of them are not required. However, it is not possible to arrive at such a decision unless a thorough inspection is made of the reserves concerned and a proper picture presented as to the type of educational facilities which should be provided.

I would estimate that some 12 new residential schools will be required during the period 1950 to 1953, both in new districts and as replacements for present schools.

To clarify this situation, therefore, I feel we should make it known to the denominations that in future the Indian residential school will be mainly for the following categories of Indian pupils:

(a) those who are orphans or who come from homes in which competent welfare workers decide that institutional care is needed,

(b) those whose parents earned their living through occupations which demand their absence from reserves or villages during long periods of the standard academic year,

(c) those pupils coming from reserves on which the number of Indian children of school age are either too few or whose homes are too scattered to permit the operation of Indian day schools,
(d) those who are ready for high school education and for whom residential schools can provide board and lodging while they attend nearby provincial high schools.

2. INDIAN DAY SCHOOLS

I feel that the main emphasis in our five year plan should be the erection of Indian day schools on all reserves upon which our inspectors report that conditions will permit the erection of such schools.

We have made a good start during the past three years towards the elimination of reserves upon which no educational facilities whatsoever were provided. The number of Indian children in our schools increased last year by 2,000 and we hope for a similar increase this year.

With this emphasis on the provision of day schools, we must also be prepared to provide good salaries and securities for teachers of such schools. We cannot compete with provincial schools in the field of social activity, amenities of living such as hygiene, running water and similar facilities, but we must be prepared to outbid provincial schools in such matters as salaries, leave to attend universities, and better living conditions in the schools and teacherages.

I have already reported on the great shortage of teachers which exists now in Canada and which will continue to exist. Therefore a basic feature of our five year program will be the attraction to our day schools of a better qualified and experienced teacher.

3. JOINT SCHOOLS

As you are aware, the Parliamentary Committee made the following recommendation with regard to joint schools:

"Your committee recommends the revision of those sections of the Act which pertain to education, in order to prepare Indian children to take their place as citizens.

... "Your
Your Committee, therefore, recommends that wherever and whenever possible Indian children should be educated in association with other children.

With this in mind, we should not build Indian day or residential schools on or near reserves on which the Indian children can be educated in white schools. In order to have our children admitted to these schools, we must be prepared to pay a proportionate share of the capital cost of additional schools or classrooms which might be required because Indian children are admitted.

We will never get local school authorities to educate Indian children unless we are prepared therefore to do the following:

(a) to pay adequate tuition fees based on the annual cost of education per pupil in the school concerned;

(b) where necessary to contribute to the capital cost of additional buildings or classrooms required for Indian children.

We have made a good start in having Indian children admitted to white schools and last year there were 925 children enrolled in joint and in provincial schools.

4. SECONDARY EDUCATION

This is becoming an increasing item in our educational estimates. With the improvements in our school system, there are naturally more pupils who are reaching the upper grades.

Our policy is of course that these children be educated in provincial high schools. This often makes it necessary to have the Indian children commuted back in the communities in which the schools are located. Due to present high living conditions, this is a very expensive item and we are becoming increasingly careful in the selection of students.
I feel that certain of our residential schools could well be expanded for caring for some of these Indian children during the time they are attending local high schools. While not too many of these residential schools are located near towns, we do have those which could be used for this purpose. This would not preclude their being used for younger children but would mean dormitory alterations to accommodate high school pupils and to give them adequate study space, etc. Insofar as university education is concerned, it is recommended that there be more rigorous in checking the reports submitted upon all students who are suggested for such courses. The education of one of these pupils for one year can otherwise amount to fifty per cent of the cost of operating a small one-room day school with possibly twenty children in attendance.

I would also recommend that care be taken in assessing the progress made by these pupils and that aptitude tests be given, particularly to those intending to go through for Law, Medicine and other costly professions.

5. ADULT EDUCATION and EXTENSION WORK.

I feel that a great deal can be done towards the promotion of good attendance at our Indian day schools by the establishment of Home and School or Parent-Teacher Clubs. One of the weaknesses of our day school system up to the present time has been the insatisfactory attendance of the pupils. We are attempting to overcome this by better schools, better teachers and better equipment. However, these efforts on our part will do little if we fail to achieve the co-operation of the Indian parents. We must make our schools "community centres" and have the teachers reach out to the parents, not only through the medium of home and school clubs but also by means of concerts, sports events and social evenings.

When a Supervisor of Physical Education and Recreation has been appointed, I feel that he should be given the opportunity of preparing a five year program in this regard, covering such features as the following:
(a) The Indian Day School as a part of Indian reserve life;

(b) Adult education in health, general welfare and educational subjects through the use of films, lectures and classes;

(c) The promotion of sports and athletics on Indian reserves and in Indian schools;

(d) The institution of a program of health education and corrective physical education.

6. ADMINISTRATION:

I feel that another feature of our five-year policy should be the continued decentralization of our educational system. It is impossible now, with the number of schools concerned, to make proper decisions on all matters here in Ottawa. I have recommended before and I again recommend most strongly the establishment of positions to be entitled "Regional Administrator of Indian Education." This position would combine the duties of School Inspector with supervision of buildings and equipment, the selection of teachers and the general administration of the schools in his region.

Many other changes have been made within the last three years and on a recent inspection trip, many teachers commented on the improvements which had been made. One point in particular is with regard to the provision of school text-books. I feel that the improvements which have recently resulted are well worth all the time and effort which it took on our part to negotiate with the King's Printer and others concerned. The school supply situation is much better than it has ever been and we will endeavour to keep it thus.

We are also endeavouring to speed up the answering of correspondence but find this very difficult in many cases, due to lack of professional advice from the field. I feel that many
questions are referred here now which could be entirely settled in the field without any need for correspondence with the Department. For example, in British Columbia, many professional matters are settled by Inspector Davey and the number of problems raised in letters from the Indian Commissioner for British Columbia is relatively much fewer than from the Regional Supervisors in other provinces.

Bernard J. Murray,
Superintendent of Education.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Hartley Bay, Kinsolitb and Lakalap Indian Day Schools.

Included in our Main Estimates for 1949-50 is the sum of $30,000.00 each for the erection of two-room schools and teacherages on each of the above reserves, in the Skeena River Agency, near Prince Rupert, British Columbia.

Whereas our day school building program has met with considerable success in the other provinces, we have encountered many difficulties in British Columbia. At Valuliet, we advertised for tenders for the erection of a two-room school and attached teachers' residence and the lowest tender for standard construction was $42,612.00. This same school, we are having built in Saskatchewan for $29,000.00. As you are aware, we finally decided to erect a cement school at Valuliet.

At Cape Mudge, we advertised for a one-room school with attached teacher's residence complete with electricity, plumbing, etc. We are having two such schools erected in Ontario for about $17,000.00. The one and only tender received for the erection of the Cape Mudge School was $29,744.75.

At Fort Nelson, we advertised for tenders for the erection of a two-room Indian day school and teacherage but received one tender only, in the amount of $67,392.00.

Therefore, due to the scarcity of contractors bidding on our projects and the high prices tendered by them, our officials in British Columbia have come to the decision that prefabricated
schools should be erected on each of the above three reserves. Their decision in this regard has been aided by the satisfaction obtained from the company which erected the two-room school and teachersage at Pemberton Meadows in the New Westminster Agency and the one-room school at Metlakatla in the Skeena River Agency.

This company is Prefabricated Structures, Limited, Post Office Box 489, Vancouver, B.C., and I attach both the previous Order-in-Council covering the provision of the Pemberton Meadows School and photographs taken by Inspector Davey of the completed building.

Our officials are perfectly satisfied with these buildings and Mr. Indian Superintendent Anfield, who knows how to supervise the erection of this type of school from his experience at Metlakatla, makes the following statement:

"I am satisfied that it will wear well, operate economically and that the type of construction is suitable and most adaptable for the type of country in the Skeena Agency. The school has been viewed with considerable approval by the Provincial School Inspector, Mr. J. Shell, at Prince Rupert. It is recommended that two-classroom schools of this type, with teachersages attached, be constructed at Hartley Bay, Greenville and Kincolith, with the least possible delay."

With regard to advertising for tenders, not only have we our previous disappointments as a guide, but Mr. Anfield makes the following statement:

"I have approached Messrs. Mitchell and Currie, Green and Bridgen, both contracting firms of Prince Rupert and they refuse to bid on the construction of new schools at these three points, giving isolation of location and risk re transportation as the main reasons. These and other contractors in Prince Rupert have so much other work on hand that they are just not interested."

Mr. Indian Commissioner Ament concurs in these recommendations and points out that these buildings can be erected at a cost to the Department considerably less than we could get a quotation from a contractor. In this regard he makes the following statement:
"You will note Mr. Amfield's reference to the need for employment at these Indian villages. Erection of these schools will provide some of that much-needed employment and in addition will assure most urgently required classroom accommodation and, as previously pointed out, at a saving of several thousand dollars in each case."

The only other company in British Columbia producing schools of this type is Precision Housing Company, which produces pre-cut schools. These are much more difficult to erect with the type of semi-skilled Indian labour we will have available and are not recommended by our field officials.

Therefore, I have no hesitation in recommending to you for presentation to the Minister, the attached submission to Council covering the purchase of three prefabricated schools from Prefabricated Structures, Limited, Post Office Box 489, Vancouver, B.C., for erection on these three reserves in the Skeena River Agency. We have foremen-carpenters in mind and can employ the Indians who are fairly competent mechanics and carpenters, under white supervision, for the erection of these prefabricated buildings.

Director.

That it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1948-49 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to provide a two-room Indian day school with attached teachers' residence on the Pemberton Indian Reserve, in the New Westminster Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia;

That it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Pemberton Indian Reserve;

That Section 36 of The Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C. 1927, provides in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest..........."

That, due to the very isolated situation of this reserve, there are no builders or contractors in the area nor are outside contractors interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that authority be granted to enter into a contract with Prefabricated Structures, Limited, for the provision of this building as outlined above, this being the only arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried to completion in order that the building will be available for use by the time the Christmas school term commences.
