Memorandum:

DIRECTOR,

Five Year Plan - Indian Education.

As I have previously discussed with you, I feel that our policies for the next five years can best be defined under the following categories:

1. Indian Residential Schools,
2. Indian Day Schools,
3. Joint Schools,
4. Secondary Education,
5. Adult and Vocational Education and Extension Work,
6. Administration.

In the following paragraphs I will deal with each of the above categories and outline what I feel should be the basic policies and the construction required during the next five years.

1. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOLS

(a) Policy -

I feel that no residential schools should either be provided or planned in any way until a thorough educational survey has been carried out by a committee of competent educators. In order that we may have a proper perspective, it is most essential that a representative of the Department of Education of the province concerned be appointed to this committee.
Only in this way can a systematic program of residential school construction be carried out where such schools are specifically required.

In the past the various denominations have taken the initiative with regard to the establishment of residential schools and have pressed the Department into making decisions with regard to their construction. I feel that a new policy must be instituted in which the Department decides on the basis of professional surveys and reports, as to the necessity of erecting this type of school.

We have now 17 requests on hand for the construction of these schools and I am convinced that several of them are not required. However, it is not possible to arrive at such a decision unless a thorough inspection is made of the reserves concerned and a proper picture presented as to the type of educational facilities which should be provided.

I would estimate that some 12 new residential schools will be required during the period 1930 to 1935, both in new districts and as replacements for present schools.

To clarify this situation, therefore, I feel we should make it known to the denominations that in future the Indian residential school will be mainly for the following categories of Indian pupils:

(I) those who are orphans or who come from homes in which competent welfare workers decide that institutional care is needed,

(II) those whose parents earned their living through occupations which demand their absence from reserves or villages during long periods of the standard academic year,

(III) those pupils coming from reserves on which the number of Indian children of school age are either too few or whose homes are too scattered to permit the operation of Indian day schools,

(IV) those who are ready for high school education and for whom residential schools can provide board and lodging while they attend nearby provincial high schools.
(b) Construction Required.

In view of the policy outlined above, it will be appreciated that we cannot clearly define the exact number of residential schools required during this five year period. An estimate, however, would be that between six and ten such schools will be required. In some cases these will only be hostels and the Department will operate the classrooms or arrange with provincial school boards to operate them.

2. INDIAN DAY SCHOOLS

(a) Policy.

I feel that the main emphasis in our five year plan should be the erection of Indian day schools on all reserves upon which our inspectors report that conditions will permit the erection of such schools.

We have made a good start during the past three years towards the elimination of reserves upon which no educational facilities whatsoever were provided. The number of Indian children in our schools increased last year by 2,000 and we hope for a similar increase this year.

With this emphasis on the provision of day schools, we must also be prepared to provide good salaries and securities for teachers of such schools. We cannot compete with provincial schools in the field of social activity, amenities of living such as hydro, running water and similar facilities, so we must be prepared to outbid provincial schools in such matters as salaries, leave to attend universities, and better living conditions in the schools and teacherages.

I have already reported on the great shortage of teachers which exists now in Canada and which will continue to exist. Therefore a basic feature of our five year program will be the attraction to our day schools of a better qualified and experienced teacher.

(b) Construction Required.

It is estimated that 450 day school classrooms at least will be required and possibly 500 by 1955. Of the
460 used as a minimum figure about 350 will be one-room schools, 30 will be two-room schools and some 40 classrooms will have to be provided in three, four and six-room schools.

3. JOINT SCHOOLS

(a) Policy

As you are aware, the Parliamentary Committee made the following recommendation with regard to joint schools:

"Your committee recommends the revision of those sections of the Act which pertain to education, in order to prepare Indian children to take their place as citizens.

"Your Committee, therefore, recommends that wherever and whenever possible Indian children should be educated in association with other children."

With this in mind, we should not build Indian day or residential schools on or near reserves on which the Indian children can be educated in white schools. In order to have our children admitted to these schools, we must be prepared to pay a proportionate share of the capital cost of additional schools or classrooms which might be required because Indian children are admitted.

We will never get local school authorities to educate Indian children unless we are prepared therefore to do the following:

I. To pay adequate tuition fees based on the annual cost of education per pupil in the school concerned;

II. Where necessary to contribute to the capital cost of additional buildings or classrooms required for Indian children.

We have made a good start in having Indian children admitted to white schools and last year there were 925 children enrolled in joint and in provincial schools.
3. JOINT SCHOOLS (cont'd.)

(b) Construction required

We are not in a position to calculate the amounts which will be required as contributions to the erection of joint schools or as assistance in the addition of extra classrooms in provincial schools. In item No. 6 I am recommending the establishment of positions to be entitled "Regional Administrator of Indian Schools". When these officials are appointed we will no doubt have many requests from local school boards as they are contacted and made acquainted with our new policy with regard to joint education. I would estimate that approximately $500,000.00 will be required in such joint projects over the next five years.

4. SECONDARY EDUCATION

(a) Policy

This is becoming an increasing item in our educational estimates. With the improvements in our school system, there are naturally more pupils who are reaching the upper grades.

Our policy is of course that these children be educated in provincial high schools. This often makes it necessary to have the Indian children commuted board in the communities in which the schools are located. Due to present high living conditions, this is a very expensive item and we are becoming increasingly careful in the selection of students.

I feel that certain of our residential schools could well be earmarked for caring for some of these Indian children during the time they are attending local high schools. While not too many of these residential schools are located near towns, we do have those which could be used for this purpose. This would not preclude their being used for younger children but could mean dormitory alterations to accommodate high school pupils and to give them adequate study space, etc. Insofar as university education is concerned, it is recommended that we be most scrupulous in checking the reports submitted upon all students who are suggested
for such courses. The education of one of these pupils for one year can otherwise amount to fifty per cent of the cost of operating a small one-room day school with possibly twenty children in attendance.

I would also recommend that care be taken in assessing the progress made by these pupils and that aptitude tests be given, particularly to those intending to go through for Law, Medicine and other costly professions.

(b) Construction Required

We might possibly be requested occasionally to contribute a small amount towards the addition of extra classrooms at local white high schools. I do not feel that this should cost more than $50,000.00 over the next five years.

5. ADULT AND VOCATIONAL EDUCATION AND EXTENSION WORK.

(a) Policy

I feel that a great deal can be done towards the promotion of good attendance at our Indian day schools by the establishment of Home and School or Parent-Teacher Clubs. One of the weaknesses of our day school system up to the present time has been the lack of parental attendance of the pupils. We are attempting to overcome this by better schools, better teachers, and better equipment. However, these efforts on our part will do little if we fail to achieve the cooperation of the Indian parents. We must make our schools "community-conscious" and have the teachers reach out to the parents, not only through the medium of home and school clubs but also by means of concerts, sports events and social evenings.

When a Supervisor of Physical Education and Recreation has been appointed, I feel that he should be given the opportunity of preparing a five year programme in this regard, covering such features as the following:

(i) The Indian Day School as a part of Indian reserve life;

(ii) Adult education in health, general welfare and educational subjects through the use of films, lectures and classes;
(iii) The promotion of sports and athletics on Indian reserves and in Indian schools;

(iv) The institution of a program of health education and corrective physical education.

(b) Construction required

At the present time we do not intend to inaugurate a very heavy program of construction of recreation halls and gymnasia. When our construction of day schools begins to catch up with the demand, then some consideration can be given to such projects. In the meantime, we are confining these items to contributions towards recreation halls at residential schools which have inadequate facilities in this regard.

6. ADMINISTRATION

(a) Policy

I feel that another feature of our five-year policy should be the continued decentralization of our educational system. It is impossible now, with the number of schools concerned, to make proper decisions on all matters here in Ottawa. I have recommended before, and I again recommend most strongly, the establishment of positions to be entitled "Regional Administrator of Schools" or "Regional Inspectors of Indian Schools". This position would combine the duties of School Inspector with supervision of buildings and equipment, the selection of teachers and the general administration of the schools in his region.

Many other changes have been made within the last three years and on a recent inspection trip, many teachers commented on the improvements which had been made. One point in particular is with regard to the provision of school text-books. I feel that the improvements which have recently resulted are well worth all the time and effort which it took on our part to negotiate with the King's Printer and others concerned. The school supply situation is much better than it has ever been and we will endeavour to keep it thus.
We are also endeavouring to speed up the answering of correspondence but find this very difficult in many cases, due to lack of professional advice from the field. I feel that many questions are referred here now which could be entirely settled in the field without any need for correspondence with the Department. For example, in British Columbia, many professional matters are settled by Inspector Davy and the number of problems raised in letters from the Indian Commissioner for British Columbia is relatively much fewer than from the Regional Supervisors in other provinces.

(b) Construction required

Other than the provision of offices for the regional administrators or regional school inspectors, I do not think that any funds will be required under this heading.

SUBJECT:

The basis of our preparation of this five-year plan is the immediate need for some 450 classrooms to provide educational facilities for Indian children who have none whatsoever. A minimum of 70 additional classrooms will be required by the end of 1955 to provide replacements for completely dilapidated buildings and to allow for natural increase in school population, based on census figures. Twenty-five (25) joint schools will be a minimum requirement.

It is felt that this need can best be provided by the erection of the following classrooms with estimated costs as shown:

(a) Day Schools . . . 460 . . . $8,440,000.

(b) Residential Schools 60 . . . 1,280,000.

This means the erection of about 350 one-room schools, 30 two-room schools and 40 classrooms in three, four and six room day schools. It provides for the minimum of six residential schools at the most needed sites as recommended by educational survey committees.
The total contribution towards joint elementary and secondary schools will amount to approximately $550,000.00.

It is impossible to calculate how many of our day schools can be considered as joint schools until field officials are appointed who can work with educational committees, provincial inspectors and local school boards in determining where and to what extent such joint educational plans are possible. Many of our one-room schools may thus become joint schools and more of our children handled by provincial educational authorities.

The grand total estimated required for the erection or as contributions towards the erection of these schools will amount to $10,270,000.00.

I have prepared a chart attached hereto, to indicate the breakdown of these schools by type and by provinces.

MEMORANDUM TO

THE DIRECTOR, LANDS AND DEVELOPMENT SERVICES BRANCH,

NEW STANDARD PLANS REQUIRED FOR

EDUCATION DIVISION BUILDING PROGRAM, 1950-1951.

As a result of our last three years' work in carrying out an extensive day school building program, it has been decided that further modifications are required in the standard plans now being used for the erection of one, two and four room day schools. We would, therefore, request that the following plans and specifications be prepared to be available by the 15th of March, 1950:

You will note that specific suggestions are given in each case so that this deadline date can be met.

(a) ONE-ROOM SCHOOLS:

At present we are building in accordance with your plan 826 and attached specifications. This building has proven to be quite satisfactory but modifications are required especially in providing a sub-basement with a gravity-feed or blower type furnace (depending on the availability of hydro). We do not wish full basements for this type of school and a sub-basement is all that we require.

(i) Without Teachers' Room:

This plan can be based almost directly on that prepared by the Ontario Association of Architects. We feel that little improvement can be made in this plan and that
it will meet our requirements entirely. It is suggested, however, instead of the two plans, one with electricity and toilets and the other without electricity and toilets, being prepared, that one plan only need be prepared. This would provide for electricity and toilets but would indicate how these can be omitted in districts where hydro is not available. In other words, the space shown for the toilets could be used as storage space and could be converted to its proper use at a later date if and when hydro becomes available on the reserve.

(ii) High Teacherage:

This could be based on the plan outlined above by the provision of the same type and size of teacherage as now provided in plan 688.

(b) TWO-ROOM SCHOOLS:

(i) Without Teacherage:

Under separate cover, we are sending a photostatic copy of a two-room school of the type we require. You will note that a full basement is not required. The manual training and domestic science activities are carried out in small rooms separated by glass partitions from the main classrooms. A sub-basement is provided permitting the installation of a gravity hot air furnace and allowing for storage space.

As for the one-room school, it is felt that toilet and hydro services should be planned for but indication should be given that other use can be made of this space if hydro is not available.

(ii) With Teacherage:

A small "T" can be extended to provide the usual two bedrooms, living room and kitchen, all on the one floor.
(c) FOUR-ROOM SCHOOLS:

This can be redesigned to provide all classrooms on the one floor with a small glassed-in manual training and domestic science room at the end of the classrooms, as provided for in the two-room schools.

A sub-basement and storage room only need be provided.

It is the considered opinion of the school inspectors and officials of the Department of Education in Ontario that basements can well be eliminated in view of the heavy costs of excavation and pouring of concrete. You will note that most small schools are now being planned as indicated above and our Superintendent of Education reports most favorably on a two-room school without basement, seen recently in one of his inspection trips. This was completed for just over $30,000.00 and even provided hot water heating.

All schools should have insulated floors and the exterior should be covered with cedar siding. Now that this is available, we intend to drop the use of Insul Brick and Asbestos Shingles.

It is suggested that a meeting be held in the near future with your Architects, Engineers and our Education Officials so that work on these plans can be commenced. We are particularly anxious to have the one-room school plans prepared as we hope to begin advertising for tenders early this year. This type of school should be given priority and we would like it ready by February 1. It is felt this should be possible as it is based on a prepared set of plans.

SCHOOL CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS

An examination of the building requirements at day schools indicates that roughly half of our existing plants are wholly inadequate—at least three of them are in imminent danger of falling down, fourteen are hopelessly over-crowded, and fifteen are buildings designed for some totally different purpose but which have been used as schools presumably for a temporary period which has lasted in some cases over twenty years, as for example at Kincolith and Rocher Deboile.

I have arranged the attached list indicating the requirements in the order that I believe priority should be given to the projects. You will note that I have commented after each of the first fifteen. The picture of some of the other buildings will indicate that many of the remaining projects also require the very earliest possible attention. It will also be noted that nine of the first 15 were to have been undertaken in the current year. No reference is made to the need at the Cariboo Residential School as it is believed the Department is fully aware of the condition there. It will also be noted that the Cape Mudge School has been left off the list, which I hope will be undertaken before the end of the fiscal year.

1. Bella Bella - 4 rooms required with teacherage for two)

A review of our files indicates that this school has been over-crowded since before the resignation of my predecessor, Captain Barry, in 1942. Indeed even as far back as that date children below the age of seven and over the age of fourteen were denied admission because of the lack of accommodation. In 1946 Mr. J.A. Findlay, then acting agent at the Bella Coola Agency, made a survey of the school-age population on this reserve, including only those children from seven to fifteen years of age. This showed a school age population of 157. Of these, 35 were enrolled in Residential schools, and six were in hospital, leaving 116 on the reserve to attend the two room day school capable of handling not more than seventy. At the present time
there are 181 children of school age (6 to 16) of whom probably
20 should be either in a hospital or residential school,
leaving 161 for enrolment in the day school. It is only because
this reserve is removed from a white community that the
deplorable conditions have not received unwelcome publicity.
There appears to be no reason why this requirement should not
receive immediate attention, at least to prepare for building
next year. Certainly the need has existed longer and is greater
than at Fort St. James.

2. Lakalsap (Greenville) - see attached pictures - 2 rooms with
teacherage.

I am surprised that the one class-room school building
at this point survived the 1948-49 winter. The accompanying
pictures indicate to some extent the alarming bulge in the end
wall but do not show how the teacherage section, apparently
added some time after the main portion of the building was
constructed, is separating from the remainder of the building.
I was able, on the occasion of my visit in the spring of 1948
to stand in the kitchen of the teacherage and see the sky
through the ceiling. Not only is the building falling down but
the one class-room is quite inadequate for the school population
of over 50, after deducting those who should be enrolled in a
residential school.

3. Fort Babine (see attached pictures) - 2 rooms with teacherage.

The above school is an old Hudson Bay building long
abandoned by the company. The teacherage which appears in the
picture to be in reasonably good condition is also an abandoned
Hudson Bay Company log house.

4. Hartley Bay (see attached pictures) - 2 rooms with teacherage.

In this case I can speak from an experience of two years
of service as teacher from 1933 to 1935. At that time the
school was too small and the lighting quite inadequate. This
year for the first time two class-rooms have been established
to accommodate over 50 pupils. This has been made possible by the utilization of an old Indian hall and the continued use of the building shown in the picture. I might add that the hall had been abandoned by the Indians who have constructed a new one.

5. Alert Bay - six class-rooms

It has been proposed that the pupils from the Residential School attend the Indian Day School. This latter is a four-room building constructed from the former army camp huts at Port Hardy. The Residential school is now using two class-rooms in the main building and two rooms in a condemned building known locally as the "Old Girls Home". This fire trap is in such poor condition that classes have had to be discontinued temporarily because of the amount of water which leaks through the roof during heavy rainstorms. The authorized enrolment of the Residential school is 210 which with the 120 pupils in the day school, indicates a need for a total of nine rooms immediately and a tenth to provide for the rapidly growing day school population. I have previously recommended the construction of six rooms on the day school site, leaving the two habitable rooms in the Residential School for the badly needed recreational space for the Residential School pupils. This was to be done by the construction of a four room class-room block and the utilization of an army hut to provide for the other two rooms.

6. Kincolith (see attached picture) - 2 class-rooms with teacherage

The attached picture taken in 1940 indicates the type of accommodation provided for over fifty pupils, crowded into one class-room. It was with great difficulty that the Superintendent of this Agency persuaded the teacher to return, and I believe that this was only accomplished through his assurance that work would be begun on a new school this year.

7. Shalalth - addition for teacherage

The teacher of this school is at present sleeping in
a small room at the end of the building originally planned for a small library room. This teacher was also given to understand that the Department expected to provide better accommodation next year.

8. Fort St. James - 2 class-rooms and teacherage required

The initial planning for construction at this point is already under way.

9. Chehalis - 2 class-rooms required

It was originally planned to construct a one room addition this year. However, a more detailed examination of the existing building indicated that the foundation and framing were in such poor condition that a two room unit should be constructed. The anticipated enrolment for this year is over 45.

10. Alberni - 3 rooms required

The Alberni Residential school has a four room block to provide for its authorized enrolment of 225. Temporary accommodation is provided in a section of the basement of the block and by a "make-shift" partitioning of a section of the girls' recreation room. The shortage of proper class-room facilities has existed since the construction of the school in 1940.

11. Ahousaht (see attached picture) - 2 class-rooms with teacherage required

This tiny chapel now used for a school is totally unsuited in every respect.* It housed a maximum enrolment of thirty-nine last year. Some indication of the class-room lighting may be gathered from the windows shown in the picture. These are the chief source of light for the class-room.

12. Moricetown (see attached picture) - 2 class-rooms with teacherage

This old building can provide only one class-room for the 40 children of school age on this reserve. The lighting is extremely poor, in fact it is one of the most depressing class-rooms I have ever been in. The building is rented from an Indian.
13. **Rocher Deboule** (see attached picture) one room with teacherage required

This building is also rented from an Indian and is one of the poorest on a reserve reputed to have had the worst housing conditions of any in B.C. The picture would certainly tend to confirm this. The Superintendent of the Babine Agency is making considerable progress towards the improvement of the housing problem and it is unfortunate that the school building should be such a poor example.

14. **Kitwancool** (see attached picture)—one room with teacherage

This is another building rented from an Indian. It is totally unsuited for school purposes, and I find it remarkable that teachers have been secured in the last few years.

15. **Village Island** (Mamalilikulla) —one room with teacherage

The school was apparently held in the church building in the years preceding the war and the teacher in those days occupied a building presumably owned by the church. This latter building has now fallen into such a poor state of repair that it is uninhabitable. A teacher was secured for the current academic year but when plans for the rental of an Indian home as a teacherage fell through he accepted a position at the Alberni Residential School. Anticipated enrolment in this school is 20.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR,

Five Year Plan - Indian Education.

As I have previously discussed with you, I feel that our policies for the next five years can best be defined under the following categories:

1. Indian Residential Schools,
2. Indian Day Schools,
3. Joint Schools,
4. Secondary Education,
5. Adult and Vocational Education and Extension Work,
6. Administration.

In the following paragraphs I will deal with each of the above categories and outline what I feel should be the basic policies and the construction required during the next five years.

1. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOLS

(a) Policy -

I feel that no residential schools should either be promised or planned in any way until a thorough educational survey has been carried out by a committee of competent educators. In order that we may have a proper perspective, it is most essential that a representative of the Department of Education of the province concerned be appointed to this committee.
Only in this way can a systematic program of residential school construction be carried out where such schools are specifically required.

In the past the various denominations have taken the initiative with regard to the establishment of residential schools and have pressed the Department into making decisions with regard to their construction. I feel that a new policy must be instituted in which the Department decides on the basis of professional surveys and reports, as to the necessity of erecting this type of school.

We have now 17 requests on hand for the construction of these schools and I am convinced that several of them are not required. However, it is not possible to arrive at such a decision unless a thorough inspection is made of the reserves concerned and a proper picture presented as to the type of educational facilities which should be provided.

I would estimate that some 12 new residential schools will be built during the period 1950 to 1955, both in new districts and as replacements for present schools.

To clarify this situation, therefore, I feel we should make it known to the denominations that in future the Indian residential school will be mainly for the following categories of Indian pupils:

(I) those who are orphans or who come from homes in which competent welfare workers decide that institutional care is needed,

(II) those whose parents earned their living through occupations which demand their absence from reserves or villages during long periods of the standard academic year,

(III) those pupils coming from reserves on which the number of Indian children of school age are either too few or whose homes are too scattered to permit the operation of Indian day schools,

(IV) those who are ready for high school education and for whom residential schools can provide board and lodging while they attend nearby provincial high schools.
(b) Construction Required.

In view of the policy outlined above, it will be appreciated that we cannot clearly define the exact number of residential schools required during this five year period. An estimate, however, would be that between six and ten such schools will be required. In some cases these will only be hostels and the Department will operate the classrooms or arrange with provincial school boards to operate them.

2. INDIAN DAY SCHOOLS

(a) Policy

I feel that the main emphasis in our five year plan should be the erection of Indian day schools on all reserves upon which our inspectors report that conditions will permit the erection of such schools.

We have made a good start during the past three years towards the elimination of reserves upon which no educational facilities whatsoever were provided. The number of Indian children in our schools increased last year by 2,000 and we hope for a similar increase this year.

With this emphasis on the provision of day schools, we must also be prepared to provide good salaries and securities for teachers of such schools. We cannot compete with provincial schools in the field of social activity, amenities of living such as hydro, running water and similar facilities, so we must be prepared to outbid provincial schools in such matters as salaries, leave to attend universities, and better living conditions in the schools and teacherages.

I have already reported on the great shortage of teachers which exists now in Canada and which will continue to exist. Therefore a basic feature of our five year program will be the attraction to our day schools of a better qualified and experienced teacher.

(b) Construction Required.

It is estimated that 460 day school classrooms at least will be required and possibly 500 by 1955. Of the
460 used as a minimum figure about 350 will be one-room schools, 30 will be two-room schools and some 40 classrooms will have to be provided in three, four and six room schools.

3. JOINT SCHOOLS

(a) Policy

As you are aware, the Parliamentary Committee made the following recommendation with regard to joint schools:

"Your committee recommends the revision of those sections of the Act which pertain to education, in order to prepare Indian children to take their place as citizens.

"Your Committee, therefore, recommends that wherever and whenever possible Indian children should be educated in association with other children."

With this in mind, we should not build Indian day or residential schools on or near reserves on which the Indian children can be educated in white schools. In order to have our children admitted to these schools, we must be prepared to pay a proportionate share of the capital cost of additional schools or classrooms which might be required because Indian children are admitted.

We will never get local school authorities to educate Indian children unless we are prepared therefore to do the following:

(i) to pay adequate tuition fees based on the annual cost of education per pupil in the school concerned;

(ii) where necessary to contribute to the capital cost of additional buildings or classrooms required for Indian children.

We have made a good start in having Indian children admitted to white schools and last year there were 925 children enrolled in joint and in provincial schools.
3. JOINT SCHOOLS (cont'd.)

(b) Construction required.

We are not in a position to calculate the amounts which will be required as contributions to the erection of joint schools or as assistance in the addition of extra classrooms in provincial schools. In Item No. 6 I am considering the establishment of positions to be entitled "Regional Administrator of Indian Schools". When these officials are appointed we will no doubt have many requests from local school boards as they are contacted and made acquainted with our new policy with regard to joint education. I would estimate that approximately $500,000.00 will be required in such joint projects over the next five years.

4. SECONDARY EDUCATION

(a) Policy

This is becoming an increasing item in our educational estimates. With the improvements in our school system, there are naturally more pupils who are reaching the upper grades.

Our policy is of course that these children be educated in provincial high schools. This often makes it necessary to have the Indian children concerned board in the communities in which the schools are located. Due to present high living conditions, this is a very expensive item and we are becoming increasingly careful in the selection of students.

I feel that certain of our residential schools could well be earmarked for caring for some of these Indian children during the time they are attending local high schools. While not too many of these residential schools are located near towns, we do have those which could be used for this purpose. This would not preclude their being used for younger children but would mean temporary alterations to accommodate high school pupils and to give them adequate study space, etc. Insofar as university education is concerned, it is recommended that we be most scrupulous in checking the reports submitted upon all students who are suggested
for such courses. The education of one of these pupils for one year can otherwise amount to fifty per cent of the cost of operating a small one-room day school with possibly twenty children in attendance.

I would also recommend that care be taken in assessing the progress made by these pupils and that aptitude tests be given, particularly to those intending to go through for Law, Medicine and other costly professions.

(b) Construction Required

We might possibly be requested occasionally to contribute a small amount towards the addition of extra classrooms at local white high schools. I do not feel that this should cost more than $50,000.00 over the next five years.

5. ADULT AND VOCATIONAL EDUCATION AND EXTENSION WORK

(a) Policy

I feel that a great deal can be done towards the promotion of good attendance at our Indian day schools by the establishment of Home and School or Parent-Teacher Clubs. One of the weaknesses of our day school system up to the present time has been the lack of additional attendance of the pupils. We are attempting to overcome this by better schools, better teachers, and better equipment. However, these efforts on our part will do little if we fail to achieve the co-operation of the Indians' parents. We must make our schools "community-conscious" and have the teachers reach out to the parents, not only through the medium of home and school clubs but also by means of concerts, sports events and social evenings.

When a Supervisor of Physical Education and Recreation has been appointed, I feel that he should be given the opportunity of preparing a five year programme in this regard, covering such features as the following:

(i) The Indian Day School as a part of Indian reserve life;

(ii) Adult education in health, general welfare and educational subjects through the use of films, lectures and classes;
(iii) The promotion of sports and athletics on Indian reserves and in Indian schools;

(iv) The institution of a program of health education and corrective physical education.

(b) Construction required

At the present time we do not intend to inaugurate a very heavy program of construction of recreation halls and gymnasiums. When our construction of day schools begins to catch up with the demand, then some consideration can be given to such projects. In the meantime, we are confining these items to contributions towards recreation halls at residential schools which have inadequate facilities in this regard.

6. ADMINISTRATION

(a) Policy

I feel that another feature of our five-year policy should be the continued decentralization of our educational system. It is impossible now, with the number of schools concerned, to make proper decisions on all matters here in Ottawa. I have recommended before, and I again recommend most strongly, the establishment of positions to be entitled "Regional Administrator of Schools" or "Regional Inspectors of Indian Schools". This position would combine the duties of School Inspector with supervision of buildings and equipment, the selection of teachers and the general administration of the schools in his region.

Many other changes have been made within the last three years and on a recent inspection trip, many teachers commented on the improvements which had been made. One point in particular is with regard to the provision of school text-books. I feel that the improvements which have recently resulted are well worth all the time and effort which it took on our part to negotiate with the King's Printer and others concerned. The school supply situation is much better than it has ever been and we will endeavour to keep it thus.
We are also endeavouring to speed up the answering of correspondence but find this very difficult in many cases, due to lack of professional advice from the field. I feel that many questions are referred here now which could be entirely settled in the field without any need for correspondence with the Department. For example, in British Columbia, many professional matters are settled by Inspector Davy and the number of problems raised in letters from the Indian Commissioner for British Columbia is relatively much fewer than from the Regional Supervisors in other provinces.

(b) Construction required

Other than the provision of offices for the regional administrators or regional school inspectors, I do not think that any funds will be required under this heading.

SUMMARY:

The basis of our preparation of this five-year plan is the immediate need for some 450 classrooms to provide educational facilities for Indian children who have none whatsoever. A minimum of 70 additional classrooms will be required by the end of 1955 to provide replacements for completely dilapidated buildings and to allow for natural increase in school population, based on census figures. Twenty-five (25) joint schools will be a minimum requirement.

It is felt that this need can best be provided by the erection of the following classrooms with estimated costs as shown:

(a) Day Schools ... 460 ... $8,440,000.

(b) Residential Schools 60 ... 1,280,000.

This means the erection of about 350 one-room schools, 30 two-room schools and 40 classrooms in three, four and six room day schools. It provides for the minimum of six residential schools at the most needed sites as recommended by educational survey committees.
The total contribution towards joint elementary and secondary schools will amount to approximately $550,000.00.

It is impossible to calculate how many of our day schools can be considered as joint schools until field officials are appointed who can work with educational committees, provincial inspectors and local school boards in determining where and to what extent such joint educational plans are possible. Many of our one-room schools may thus become joint schools and more of our children handled by provincial educational authorities.

The grand total estimated required for the erection or as contributions towards the erection of these schools will amount to $10,270,000.00.

SASKATOON, Sask., Dec. 14 (Spec. via) - The annual meeting of the Saskatchewan Federation of Teachers was held in the Prince Albert School recently. In a speech before the delegates, Mr. E. Spiegle, director of the division of education, said that the surplus heat should not be wasted.

There may be implications for us particularly in regard to two-room schools, or future classrooms are added at residential centres.

Memorandum

MR. C. BICK
LANDS & DEVELOPMENT SERVICES BRANCH

One and Two-room Indian Day Schools

Further to our conversation of recent date, I am pleased to confirm the following in writing:

(1) Exterior - Cedar siding and not insul brick or asbestos shingles.

(2) Windows - To have top and bottom opening sections with a central fixed window.

(3) Basement - A partial basement can be installed for the furnace and storage room but we do not wish a basement under the entire building.

(4) Heating - By gravity feed furnace in most schools but the plan should also provide for a forced draft system of hot air for schools where electricity is available.

(5) Plumbing - Where electricity is not available, we would recommend the installation of a hygienic septic toilet and I left you the bulletin concerning this toilet. This would call for the following:

(a) Two toilets for the boys and one wall type urinal.
(b) Two toilets for the girls.
(c) A single toilet for the teacher.

I wrote to the Company concerning a cement septic
tank and have now received a reply from them reading as follows:

"We note that you are interested in a set-up whereby a cement septic tank could be used instead of the steel tank. Our experience in this connection and the writer has been in this type of business for twenty-eight years, has not been a favourable substitution for the following reasons. In the first instance, cement is very difficult to make water tight and in over a period of time the walls of the tank become saturated with sewage and a condition is created that is obnoxious and unhealthy. Furthermore sometimes we find that these schools are closed down due to weather conditions on reservations and also during the holiday seasons and if these happen to occur when the winter is extremely cold there is the possibility of the septic tank freezing, and if the tank is cement it will crack and be destroyed whereas steel or iron will expand and will not crack and is water-proof. Furthermore these tanks are designed specifically for this purpose and have long years of experience behind these designs and we confidently believe you will get the maximum amount of satisfaction from equipment supplied as illustrated in our leaflet."

Where hydro is available, then naturally we would request the installation of running water with the same facilities as outlined above.

(6) Water - Wash basins will be provided in the boys and girls' toilet rooms and in the teacher's kitchen. Where electricity is not available, pumps should be provided for these three places. Where electricity is available, a shower and a wash basin should be installed in the teacher's toilet.

(7) Roof - We are prepared to accept a flat roof but would like to raise the point where it will be difficult to obtain a boned roof in the Northern sections of the provinces where the schools are built by day labour.

(8) Interior finish - Classroom walls should have plywood to the level of the lower edge of the blackboards..."
with ten-test pin board from the lower edge of the blackboard to at least 15" above the top of the blackboards.

(9) Floors - We are having some difficulty with hardwood floors as they are proving difficult to keep clean and waxed especially when a lot of mud is tracked into the building. Provincial schools are using Grade AA linoleum cemented down to a stained fir floor 1" by 3" or fir plywood. This is laid over a sub-floor and the Battleship linoleum should be easier to keep clean.

(10) Blackboards - The blackboard at the back of the room should be a foot lower than the normal level. This will permit the smaller students to write on the blackboards without difficulty. This should only apply to the blackboard at the rear of the room.

(11) Cupboards - There should be one cupboard in the classroom, made with plywood and with plenty of shelves.

(12) Library Shelf - This should extend the length of the room at the bottom of the windows. There should be one or two shelves of similar width under this to provide storage space for library books, plasticine, scissors, crayons, etc.

(13) Cloakroom - This shall have coat hooks installed and a 1 x 12 shelf (for the storing of lunches). The wall under this shelf should be lined with plywood.

Cost of Building - It is hoped to keep the cost of erection of this school under $14,500.00. Plan 555 has been costing about $12,000.00. I attach the preliminary drawing prepared by Precision Housing Limited for a one-room school indicating the type of window glass now being used in provincial schools and in a prefabricated school which we bought from this Company.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.
January 17, 1950.

BY FORCED SPRAYING, RECIRCULATION

All Jackson Dishwashers function on a principle of hydraulic force applied through a designated area. This is not a random force, as built up in the regular 'splash' method of mechanical dishwashing, but is carefully calculated and directed to cover every bit of exposed dish surface. Spray arms of Jackson machines are strategically located to facilitate the downward and upward through the basket-container area, from the orbits through which they revolve both clockwise and counter-clockwise (to cover both front and back areas). Although the Jackson Method features a constant play of solution and water over every inch inside and outside the machine, yet it does not consume any more than the modest amount of water used during the 10 second rinsing operation. This is due to the water's being recirculated through the machine, which not only assures thermal stability, but permits use of a minimum amount of dish cleanser compound. Wash water may be recirculated through a Jackson machine without becoming contaminated due to the fact that the greasy water is carried out automatically. You see, the Jackson combination strainer-overflow-drain plug segregates all particles of food and residue. A basket of greasy dirty dishes or a basket of broken dishes and yet they will come out sparkling clean. Hot water should be held at not less than 140 degrees for washing. Rinse water should be not less than 180 degrees. Temperature drop of approximately 40 degrees occurs in its passage from wash reservoir to through the machine's circulatory system, so that no other thermal control is needed. The heavy one piece casting once heated helps to maintain the proper temperature in both the wash and rinse reservoirs.

Dear Mr. Neary:

Re: Labour saving devices in Indian Residential Schools

We are interested to hear that you are purchasing more labour-saving equipment for the Indian Residential Schools. They will save time and effort in doing routine work on the part of both the staff and children and will do a better job.

With regard to the dishwashing machine described in the folder attached to your letter of January 13th, we cannot say we have had any experience with such machines. This particular type is usually installed in very small operations such as hospital ward kitchens or small soda fountains. The wash tank capacity is extremely small, actually holding not more than a good size dishpan. Following are the pros and cons for the machine as we see it:

Points For

1. Small space required for installation but sufficient drain tables necessary.
2. Metal racks lighter than wooden ones. Metal racks may increase breakage though.
3. Price of this machine much less than most machines.
4. Water supply limited in the Muscowequan School.

Points Against

1. Doors, for children, harder to open than curtains. The reach may be too great for the children.
2. Round rack harder to fill than square ones.
3. Metal racks may increase breakage.
4. 3 gallons of wash water very small quantity—consideration should be given to the quantity of detergent which would be used (rapid change of water in tank).
5. Machine may have to be emptied and cleaned of garbage residue during washing because of the small quantity of water to pro-
Points Against (Cont'd)

portion of garbage residue which may collect.

6. Better for smaller operation, e.g., hospital ward kitchen.
7. More and better supervision required when rinse not automatic.
8. ½ h.p. pump is not as efficient as a more powerful one.

Whereas the rate capacity of this machine is stated at 1200 dishes per hour, it is doubtful if the children would be able to fill the rack quickly enough to operate the machine efficiently. It is doubtful whether the machine would operate for an hour without draining the tank and cleaning it.

We would recommend a machine with:

(1) ½ h.p. motor
(2) An automatic rinse (it is too easy to put dishes through the machine without rinsing it if a hand switch is used).
(3) A machine with curtains rather than doors as it is difficult for children to manipulate doors.

A machine with the above mentioned specifications will cost considerably more but no doubt will give more efficient and longer service.

I hope this information will be of some assistance to you in making your selection.

Yours sincerely,

L. B. Pett, Ph.D., M.D.,
Chief, Nutrition Division.

Mr. Weir

On the 11th instant the Reverend J. O. Plourde called on us to discuss the erection of a residential school at Chesterfield Inlet. He suggested that if this Administration would supply materials delivered at Churchill, Manitoba, his organization would be prepared to transport them to Chesterfield and erect the building.

In order that we might have some idea of the amount of money involved, I sent Mr. J. G. Wright and Father Plourde to discuss the matter with Mr. Buck. Father Plourde outlined to Mr. Buck the general specifications for the proposed school which should be designed to accommodate 50 resident pupils. The general specifications for the building were as follows:

- 2 dormitories housing 25 pupils each.
- 7 individual rooms for 7 teaching sisters.
- 1 dining hall for 50 pupils.
- 1 dining room for teaching sisters.
- 1 dining room for 4 male teachers.
- 1 recreation room.
- 1 kitchen.
- 1 bakery.
- 1 laundry.
- Cold storage quarters with 1 low-temperature compartment for meat and 1 compartment for foods which must not be frozen.

Father Plourde was emphatic that the building should be designed with maximum insulation to provide economy in heating. He felt it should be heated with coal as they have found oil too expensive. It would be impossible to have a basement but a suitable central heating plant should be provided. Provision will also have to be made for requisite electric power for lighting and the operation of equipment.

In order that we may have some idea of what the cost of the materials would be for such a building, I should be glad if Mr. Buck would prepare a sketch design and let me have an estimate of the cost of materials. It will not be necessary at this stage to prepare elaborate plans or itemized details of the materials required.

MEMORANDUM FOR DEPARTMENTS

PLANNING AND EXECUTION OF PUBLIC PROJECTS

1. In the economic review the Minister of Finance gave in presenting the budget on October 29th, he referred to recent currency changes and to economic conditions in the United States, and mentioned the possibility of developments which might affect Canadian trade and the level of economic activity in Canada. The Minister added:

"It is with these possibilities in mind that the government is actively reviewing measures to counteract any serious downturn that might develop in our export markets and in the level of economic activity at home. As hon. members know, we have already taken steps to give still greater encouragement to housing construction, and we are in the midst of discussions with the provinces regarding both the magnitude and the timing of extensive work on the trans-Canada highway. Other development projects are also under review, so that they may be undertaken at the appropriate time. We have also been considering measures to deal with any special situations or difficulties which have already emerged or which may emerge even though general economic activity remains high."

The matters to which the Minister of Finance referred are of interest to most, if not all departments of the government.

2. It is expected that it may be possible to proceed in the next twelve months with useful projects of a national character with less strain upon available supplies of labour and material than would have been the case until now. It is also expected that the effect of any change in the rate of economic activity may affect different parts of the country unevenly. In the circumstances it is of importance that departments of government should be in a position to proceed at an early date with projects which are already included in their estimates and which relate to areas that may be particularly affected. Similarly, departments should bring forward additional proposals which they may have for expenditures in such areas.

3. Since 1945, an attempt has been made to build up a "shelf" of fully-planned public projects which might be carried forward at short notice when desired. The Cabinet has now directed that the basis of the shelf should be altered. It is to be replaced by a capital investment programme of construction, industrial and resource development projects in more general form, which may be planned in detail as the time approaches for implementation. The programme is to include projects solely under federal jurisdiction, and also projects shared with provincial or municipal governments and with private industry. It is to be kept approximately five years ahead at all times and to include projects in the three planning categories used in the recent survey -
(a) those fully planned,
(b) those in various stages of planning, and
(c) those under preliminary consideration.

To expedite plans in relation to such projects the attention of departments is drawn to the Reconstruction Vote, which may be used for the employment of consultants, and to the engineering assistance available for specific assignments in the Department of Reconstruction and Supply. Any enquiries with regard to this matter should be directed to the Deputy Minister of Reconstruction and Supply.

4. The Cabinet has also directed that a further survey of the stage of planning in relation to projects of the character referred to above should be made by the Economic Research and Development Branch of the Department of Trade and Commerce, in conjunction with the Department of Reconstruction and Supply, on March 31st, 1950. You may wish to have this in mind in order that plans may be advanced as far as possible by that date.

N. A. Robertson,
Secretary to the Cabinet.

Privy Council Office,
October 25, 1949.

MEMORANDUM TO MR. MACKAY

The following is an extract from a memorandum to the Minister from the Secretary to the Cabinet:

"At the meeting of Cabinet on Thursday, October 20th, the Minister of Trade and Commerce made a report from the Cabinet Committee on Economic Policy on the economic outlook for 1950 and on the handling of Federal construction and development projects.

"The following recommendations were made:

(a) useful projects of a national character, such as those connected with housing, Trans-Canada Highway and resources development, be examined with a view to early implementation;

(b) a committee under the chairmanship of the Deputy Minister of Fisheries, and including officials from Trade and Commerce, Finance, Agriculture, Mines and Resources and Labour, be established and directed to make a special study of regional problems in the Maritime Provinces (including Newfoundland);

(c) departments place themselves in a position to proceed as soon as possible with projects in areas showing high unemployment;

(d) the concept of a "shelf" of fully planned projects be replaced by a capital investment programme including construction, industrial and resources development projects. In this connection, departments should advance their planning as far as possible and a further survey should be made as of March 31st, 1950."
"The Cabinet noted the report of the Cabinet Committee on Economic Policy and approved the recommendations made therein concerning the economic outlook for 1950 and action to be taken with regard to Federal construction and development projects."

The Deputy Minister has asked me to bring this to your attention for consideration and to request you to give him a report in so far as your Branch is concerned.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR,

Five Year Plan - Indian Education.

As I have previously discussed with you, I feel that our policies for the next five years can best be defined under the following categories:

1. Indian Residential Schools,
2. Indian Day Schools,
3. Joint Schools,
4. Secondary Education,
5. Adult and Vocational Education and Extension Work,
6. Administration.

In the following paragraphs I will deal with each of the above categories and outline what I feel should be the basic policies and the construction required during the next five years.

1. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOLS

(a) Policy -

I feel that no residential schools should either be promised or planned in any way until a thorough educational survey has been carried out by a committee of competent educators. In order that we may have a proper perspective, it is most essential that a representative of the Department of Education of the province concerned be appointed to this committee.
Only in this way can a systematic program of residential school construction be carried out where such schools are specifically required.

In the past the various denominations have taken the initiative with regard to the establishment of residential schools and have pressed the Department into making decisions with regard to their construction. I feel that a new policy must be instituted in which the Department decides on the basis of professional surveys and reports, as to the necessity of erecting this type of school.

We have now 17 requests on hand for the construction of these schools and I am convinced that several of them are not required. However, it is not possible to arrive at such a decision unless a thorough inspection is made of the reserves concerned and a proper picture presented as to the type of educational facilities which should be provided.

I would estimate that some 12 new residential schools will be required during the period 1950 to 1955, both in new districts and as replacements for present schools.

To clarify this situation, therefore, I feel we should make it known to the denominations that in future the Indian residential school will be mainly for the following categories of Indian pupils:

(I) those who are orphans or who come from homes in which competent welfare workers decide that institutional care is needed,

(II) those whose parents earned their living through occupations which demand their absence from reserves or villages during long periods of the standard academic year,

(III) those pupils coming from reserves on which the number of Indian children of school age are either too few or whose homes are too scattered to permit the operation of Indian day schools,

(IV) those who are ready for high school education and for whom residential schools can provide board and lodging while they attend nearby provincial high schools.
(b) Construction Required.

In view of the policy outlined above, it will be appreciated that we cannot clearly define the exact number of residential schools required during this five year period. An estimate, however, would be that between six and ten such schools will be required. In some cases these will only be hostels and the Department will operate the classrooms or arrange with provincial school boards to operate them.

2. INDIAN DAY SCHOOLS

(a) Policy

I feel that the main emphasis in our five year plan should be the erection of Indian day schools on all reserves upon which our inspectors report that conditions will permit the erection of such schools.

We have made a good start during the past three years towards the elimination of reserves upon which no educational facilities whatsoever were provided. The number of Indian children in our schools increased last year by 2,000 and we hope for a similar increase this year.

With this emphasis on the provision of day schools, we must also be prepared to provide good salaries and securities for teachers of such schools. We cannot compete with provincial schools in the field of social activity, amenities of living such as hydro, running water and similar facilities, so we must be prepared to outbid provincial schools in such matters as salaries, leaves to attend universities, and better living conditions in the schools and teacherages.

I have already reported on the great shortage of teachers which exists now in Canada and which will continue to exist. Therefore a basic feature of our five year program will be the attraction to our day schools of a better qualified and experienced teacher.

(b) Construction required.

It is estimated that 460 day school classrooms at least will be required and possibly 500 by 1955. Of the
460 used as a minimum figure about 350 will be one-room schools; 30 will be two-room schools and some 40 classrooms will have to be provided in three, four and six room schools.

3. JOINT SCHOOLS

(a) Policy

As you are aware, the Parliamentary Committee made the following recommendation with regard to joint schools:

"Your committee recommends the revision of those sections of the Act which pertain to education, in order to prepare Indian children to take their place as citizens.

"Your Committee, therefore, recommends that wherever and whenever possible Indian children should be educated in association with other children."

With this in mind, we should not build Indian day or residential schools on or near reserves on which the Indian children can be educated in white schools. In order to have our children admitted to these schools, we must be prepared to pay a proportionate share of the capital cost of additional schools or classrooms which might be required because Indian children are admitted.

We will never get local school authorities to educate Indian children unless we are prepared therefore to do the following:

(i) to pay adequate tuition fees based on the annual cost of education per pupil in the school concerned;

(ii) where necessary to contribute to the capital cost of additional buildings or classrooms required for Indian children.

We have made a good start in having Indian children admitted to white schools and last year there were 925 children enrolled in joint and in provincial schools.
3. JOINT SCHOOLS (cont'd.)

(b) Construction required

We are not in a position to calculate the amounts which will be required as contributions to the erection of joint schools or as assistance in the addition of extra classrooms in provincial schools. In item No. 6 I am recommending the establishment of positions to be entitled "Regional Administrator of Indian Schools". When these officials are appointed we will no doubt have many requests from local school boards as they are contacted and made acquainted with our new policy with regard to joint education. I would estimate that approximately $500,000.00 will be required in such joint projects over the next five years.

4. SECONDARY EDUCATION

(a) Policy

This is becoming an increasing item in our educational estimates. With the improvements in our school system, there are naturally more pupils who are reaching the upper grades.

Our policy is of course that these children be educated in provincial high schools. This often makes it necessary to have the Indian children concerned board in the communities in which the schools are located. Due to present high living conditions, this is a very expensive item and we are becoming increasingly careful in the selection of students.

I feel that certain of our residential schools could well be earmarked for saving for some of these Indian children during the time they are attending local high schools. While not too many of these residential schools are located near towns, we do have those which could be used for this purpose. This would help provide their being used for younger children but would mean dormitory alterations to accommodate high school pupils and to give them adequate study space, etc. Insofar as university education is concerned, it is recommended that we be most scrupulous in checking the reports submitted upon all students who are suggested
for such courses. The education of one of these pupils for one year can otherwise amount to fifty per cent of the cost of operating a small one-room day school with possibly twenty children in attendance.

I would also recommend that care be taken in assessing the progress made by these pupils and that aptitude tests be given, particularly to those intending to go through for Law, Medicine and other costly professions.

(b) Construction Required

We might possibly be requested occasionally to contribute a small amount towards the addition of extra classrooms at local white high schools. I do not feel that this should cost more than $50,000.00 over the next five years.

5. ADULT AND VOCATIONAL EDUCATION AND EXTENSION WORK

(a) Policy

I feel that a great deal can be done towards the promotion of good attendance at our Indian day schools by the establishment of Home and School or Parent-Teacher Clubs. One of the weaknesses of our day school system up to the present time has been the lack of parental attendance of the pupils. We are attempting to overcome this by better schools, better teachers, and better equipment. However, these efforts on our part will do little if we fail to achieve the co-operation of the Indian parents. We must make our schools "community-conscious" and have the teachers reach out to the parents, not only through the medium of home and school clubs but also by means of concerts, sports events and social evenings.

When a Supervisor of Physical Education and Recreation has been appointed, I feel that he should be given the opportunity of preparing a five year programme in this regard, covering such features as the following:

(i) The Indian Day School as a part of Indian reserve life;

(ii) Adult education in health, general welfare and educational subjects through the use of films, lectures and classes;
(iii) The promotion of sports and athletics on Indian reserves and in Indian schools;

(iv) The institution of a program of health education and corrective physical education.

(b) Construction required

At the present time we do not intend to inaugurate a very heavy program of construction of recreation halls and gymnasiums. When our construction of day schools begins to catch up with the demand, then some consideration can be given to such projects. In the meantime, we are confining these items to contributions towards recreation halls at residential schools which have inadequate facilities in this regard.

6. ADMINISTRATION

(a) Policy

I feel that another feature of our five-year policy should be the continued decentralization of our educational system. It is impossible now, with the number of schools concerned, to make proper decisions on all matters here in Ottawa. I have recommended before, and I again recommend most strongly, the establishment of positions to be entitled "Regional Administrator of Schools" or "Regional Inspectors of Indian Schools". This position would combine the duties of School Inspector with supervision of buildings and equipment, the selection of teachers and the general administration of the schools in his region.

Many other changes have been made within the last three years and on a recent inspection trip, many teachers commented on the improvements which had been made. One point in particular is with regard to the provision of school text-books. I feel that the improvements which have recently resulted are well worth all the time and effort which it took on our part to negotiate with the King's Printer and others concerned. The school supply situation is much better than it has ever been and we will endeavour to keep it thus.
We are also endeavouring to speed up the answering of correspondence but find this very difficult in many cases, due to lack of professional advice from the field. I feel that many questions are referred here now which could be entirely settled in the field without any need for correspondence with the Department. For example, in British Columbia, many professional matters are settled by Inspector Davey and the number of problems raised in letters from the Indian Commissioner for British Columbia is relatively much fewer than from the Regional Supervisors in other provinces.

(b) Construction required

Other than the provision of offices for the regional administrators or regional school inspectors, I do not think that any funds will be required under this heading.

SUMMARY:

The basis of our preparation of this five-year plan is the immediate need for some 450 classrooms to provide educational facilities for Indian children who have none whatsoever. A minimum of 70 additional classrooms will be required by the end of 1955 to provide replacements for completely dilapidated buildings and to allow for natural increase in school population, based on census figures. Twenty-five (25) joint schools will be a minimum requirement.

It is felt that this need can best be provided by the erection of the following classrooms with estimated costs as shown:

(a) Day Schools ... 460 ... $8,440,000.
(b) Residential Schools 60 ... 1,280,000.

This means the erection of about 350 one-room schools, 30 two-room schools and 40 classrooms in three, four and six room day schools. It provides for the minimum of six residential schools at the most needed sites as recommended by educational survey committees.
The total contribution towards joint elementary and secondary schools will amount to approximately $550,000.00.

It is impossible to calculate how many of our day schools can be considered as joint schools until field officials are appointed who can work with educational committees, provincial inspectors and local school boards in determining where and to what extent such joint educational plans are possible. Many of our one-room schools may thus become joint schools and more of our children handled by provincial educational authorities.

The grand total estimated required for the erection or as contributions towards the erection of these schools will amount to $10,270,000.00.

Labour Saving Devices - Dishwashers

As I advised you in our letter of January 13 dealing with the dishwasher requested for the Muscowequan Residential School, we have sought advice from the Nutrition Division of the Department of National Health and Welfare. While we will not be able to provide dishwashers for any but our larger schools, the following will help both you and the other Supervisors in considering such requests.

You will recall that the machine in question was the Jackson Dishwasher Model 1-A. We sent the folder describing this machine to the Nutrition Division and their report reads as follows:

"This particular type is usually installed in very small operations such as hospital ward kitchens or small soda fountains. The wash tank capacity is extremely small, actually holding not more than a good size dishpan. Following are the pros and cons for the machine as we see it."

Points For Points Against

1. Small space required for installation but sufficient drain tables necessary.
2. Metal racks lighter than wooden ones. Metal racks may increase breakage though.

1. Doors, for children, harder to open than curtains. The reach may be too great for the children.
2. Round rack harder to fill than square ones...
Points For

1. Price of this machine much less than most machines.
2. Water supply limited in the Muscowequan School.

Points Against

1. Metal racks may increase breakage.
2. 3 gallons of wash water very small quantity—consideration should be given to the quantity of detergent which would be used (rapid change of water in tank).
3. Machine may have to be emptied and cleaned of garbage residue during washing because of the small quantity of water to prevent overflow of garbage residue which may collect.
4. Better for smaller operation, e.g., hospital ward kitchen.
5. More and better supervision required when rinse not automatic.
6. 1 h.p. pump is not as efficient as a more powerful one.

Whereas the rate capacity of this machine is stated at 1000 dishes per hour, it is doubtful if the children would be able to fill the rack quickly enough to operate the machine efficiently. It is doubtful whether the machine would operate for an hour without draining the tank and cleaning it.

We would recommend a machine with:

(1) ½ h.p. motor
(2) An automatic rinse (it is too easy to put dishes through the machine without rinsing it if a hand wash is used).
(3) A machine with curtains rather than doors as it is difficult for children to manipulate doors.
A machine with the above mentioned specifications will cost considerably more but no doubt will give more efficient and longer service."

The recommendations of the Nutrition Division are very clear and it is felt that their specifications should be followed when consideration is being given to the provision of dishwashers. As previously mentioned, it is felt that these can only be provided for our larger schools with a pupilage of at least 300 children.

Dear Bernard:

I am enclosing standard plans which I have received from the Provincial Department of Education. You will notice from the accompanying literature that this type of construction is more expensive than that which we have been using in our schools to date. However, although the initial cost is high I believe that in the long run it would be cheaper as the plans are more flexible and permit additions to be readily added. I also believe that teachers could easily be attached.

You will note that provision is made for open play space along the lines I described to you when I was in Ottawa. One change I would make is the placing of a partition at one end to separate the cloakroom from the classroom. You will note that the classrooms, including cloakrooms, are approximately 40' in length and a partition running all or part way across the width of the room to provide enclosed cloakroom space would still leave ample room for classroom purposes.

Adequate forecasting of the pupilage on our reserves for periods up to five years is so difficult that I believe our schools should be as flexible as possible. In any case I feel you will find these plans interesting.

My understanding with the Provincial Department was that these plans are not to be used without permission from that Department as their agreement with the architect calls
for payment of $75.00 for the working plans. I understand they also made a lump sum contribution to the architect for the preparation of these. If you have any school where you would like to use them you may secure the working plans from Mr. R.C. Grant, Executive Assistant to the Deputy Minister, Victoria, presumably on payment of the required $75.00.

I shall be writing today concerning the Saanich Schools and I think it would pay us to use these plans at that point, but I shall outline my suggestions and those of Mr. Frederickson in greater detail in that letter.

I have also secured from Mr. Frederickson a copy of the periodical "Architectural Forum", issued for October 1949, which is devoted entirely to school plans. I found it most interesting but the majority of articles and sketch plans included are more elaborate set-ups than we normally have on our reserves.

We are still experiencing the Arctic weather and are quite green with envy when we read about the rain and high temperatures in the East. With very best regards.

Sincerely,
