Indian Superintendents:

REPAIRS AND MAINTENANCE TO INDIAN DAY SCHOOLS

GENERAL POLICY

Each Indian Superintendent is regarded as the official School Trustee for the Indian Day Schools in his Agency. Therefore, it is his direct responsibility to ensure that the principals and teachers of these schools maintain the building and that premises are clean and neat at all times. Each principal or teacher of an Indian day school has more responsibility than the corresponding principal or teacher of a provincial school. They have no Board of School Trustees immediately available and must therefore exercise greater supervision and control over the Indian school concerned.

Regional Supervisors are naturally expected to inspect the classrooms and teacherages in the course of their routine visits.

MAINTENANCE

(a) CARETAKING

In the small one-room school this is usually done either by (a) hiring a part-time janitor or by (b) paying the teacher for janitor services. A small amount per classroom is usually allowed in return for sweeping and fuelling. Many of the small chores SHOULD be done by the school children, on a monitor basis, as is done in nearly all well conducted public schools. The Department is paying all the school operating expenses and surely the older Indian children can do some of the cleaning work.

Many teachers might use the last hour of the school week on Friday afternoon for a thorough schoolroom cleaning. The older pupils set to and each, with his or her own task, scrub the floor, the desks, wash the windows, dust and generally freshen up the schoolroom. This takes some organization ahead of time by the teacher, by dividing the class into working gangs, having the hot water and janitor supplies ready, etc. Under (b) compensation for those who perform truly janitorial duties should be made from the "janitor allowance".

If this is laid down as a definite part of the weekly programme, many of the caretaking worries can be eliminated. In some schools we have more correspondence on the files about caretaking than about teaching the pupils or any other topic.

Indian Superintendents must therefore impress upon teachers the need for a little energy on their part in solving this cleaning problem. It will not do for them to merely sit back and blame the Indian janitor if things are not clean. They must co-operate by training the children to accept the responsibility for housekeeping activities which will lighten the burden on janitors.
When school closes each day, the various monitors should proceed with the cleaning of the blackboards, the checking of the toilets, the filling of the water cooler, etc. This must be done in an organized way with a list of monitors for each duty posted weekly. Where the teacher is paid for janitor services, some teachers might wish to reward these children. The cleanliness of the floor can easily be ensured by having each child responsible for the space under or near his or her own desk. No children should NEVER be dismissed at recess, noon or the close of the day without a check being made of the floor near their desks. In fact, a row should not be dismissed until the floor near their desks are clean. If children know they are being held responsible for keeping the floor clear from paper, peelings, etc., they will see to it that they put such scraps in the waste paper basket.

An article on this will appear in the next issue of the School Bulletin. When it appears, Indian Superintendents should regularly check on their monthly visits into this matter of classroom, toilet and playground cleanliness. No excuses should be accepted for carelessness in this matter. We are paying our teachers good salaries and expect that they will help in this way. Furthermore, this will do a great deal towards impressing upon Indian children the need for cleanliness in their persons and in their surroundings.

(b) PAINTING

This is a major item each year in our schools. We can effect a great saving by buying the paint needed through the Departmental Purchasing Agent. This may take longer but if there is an intelligent anticipation of your requirements, we can get the paint to you in time for the school holiday period. Each year the Education Division is literally swamped with requisitions for paint, brushes, etc. This reaches its climax in August when some Superintendents suddenly realize that the summer holidays are half over and that their school or schools have not yet been painted. Then they sit back and wonder why it takes so long for the paint to arrive. If they could only see us in Ottawa during those two months with our desks piled high with requisitions for paint, etc., from many other Superintendents, they would realize why delays occur. This is not fair to the Education Division and just when we are trying to locate new teachers, to get on with the building of new schools, and other immediate business, we get requisitions for paint and requests for accountable advances, etc., from Indian Superintendents who have forgotten to forward such requests during the spring months.

APRIL is the month during which all Superintendents should forward their requests for items needed to keep their day schools in good condition. All officials needing paint for their schools can requisition NOW for the supplies which they will require. An example as to the savings which can be made by buying our paint through the Purchasing Agent and then arranging for an Indian or a painter to apply it is the following:

An Indian Superintendent got local prices from a painter for a school, as follows:

| Item       | Quantity | Price per Gallon | Total Cost |
|------------|----------|------------------|------------|
| Paint      | 93       | $5.75            | $534.75    |
| Undercoat  | 20       | $5.25            | $105.00    |
| Sealer     | 6        | $5.80            | $34.80     |
| Enamel     | 16       | $10.00           | $160.00    |
| Turps      | 7        | $2.00            | $14.00     |

The Departmental Purchasing Agent secured tenders for the same type of paint, as follows:

| Item       | Company A | Company B |
|------------|-----------|-----------|
| Paint      | $2.95     | $274.35   |
| Undercoat  | $4.12     | $82.40    |
| Sealer     | $3.40     | $20.40    |
| Enamel     | $5.20     | $83.20    |
| Turps      | $1.37     | $9.59     |
| Containers |           |           |

Total Cost:
- Company A: $469.74
- Company B: $578.59
It only requires simple arithmetic to note that the Department would have saved $378.81, or nearly 45% by buying the paint from Company A. This company is one of the largest manufacturers of paint in Canada and supplies a product which meets our government specifications. (We could have saved enough money to paint two small schools by buying through the Purchasing Agent).

Each year, we have a large number of schools to paint. From the above illustration you can therefore appreciate the fact that the most economical way of doing the job is by purchasing the paint directly from the manufacturer through the Departmental Purchasing Agent. In this way we can use our money to best advantage and it will enable us to paint more schools each year.

**COLOUR SCHEME:**

While we have no particular interest in the colour scheme as requested by individual teachers for their teacherages, we must insist on pastel colours and light shades in the classrooms. We would recommend the following shades:

(1) Classroom Ceiling  
White or off white

(2) Classroom Upper Walls  
Pale green such as pastel green Arcadian light green.

(3) Lower Walls  
Darker green, equivalent to Milan green or Thistle green.

**NOTE:** Where classrooms have lower walls of plywood, this should be left in light Oak varnish.

**REPAIRS**

In submitting requests for repairs such as replacement of verandahs, etc., there are two methods of procedure:

(a) By purchasing the materials and having the work done by day labour;

(b) By letting a contract.

When submitting a requisition for the materials required in following plan (a), be sure to give specific details of the lumber required and also to advise the name of local suppliers who could be contacted by the Purchasing Agent.

In following plan (b), try to obtain more than one fixed tender and be sure to give the name and address and to attach a written bid from the firm or firms concerned. If you cannot obtain more than one tender, you must state this in your covering letter.

**SUMMARY**

Submit NOW:
(a) All paint requirements for your day schools, classifying under exterior paint, interior paint, varnishes, etc.;
(b) All requisitions for desks, blackboards, cement, lumber, etc.

Submit LATER:
(a) All labour tenders for painting and repairs;
(b) All tenders for major alterations, etc.

Dear Mr. Gibson:

We are now in a position to advise you concerning the new school building projects and the major repair projects which we would like to have undertaken by your Branch in the fiscal year 1950-51.

I have, therefore, had the Superintendent of Education prepare a list of such projects which have been divided into two parts:

(a) Erection of new Indian day and residential schools.
(b) Repairs to existing Indian day and residential schools.

A. ERECTION OF NEW INDIAN DAY AND RESIDENTIAL SCHOOLS

(1) Plans

We have previously requested from you on December 6th, 1949, the preparation of plans and specifications for the new one, two and four room schools which will be needed by our Education Division by April 1st, 1950. I understand that some progress has already been made in the preparation of these plans, and we hope that they will be finished in the near future.

(2) Buildings

Residential Schools

Seven Islands (Seven Islands Agency) - We understand that this project is already in hand.
Lower Post (Stikine Agency) - This project also is proceeding satisfactorily.

William's Lake (William's Lake Agency) - We are anxious to have tenders called in the near future for the erection of this classroom-dormitory block.

Cowanesse (Crooked Lake Agency) - We have included an amount of $50,000.00 for the erection of a classroom-dormitory block identical to William's Lake. Would you please have one of your engineers do the necessary ground survey and check on heating arrangements. The building will be the same as that planned for William's Lake with the possible exception of the heating arrangements. Your heating engineer may have to report on the possibility of connecting this block with the existing heating facilities in the main building.

Ermineskins (Hobbsena Agency) - While funds are not provided in our main Estimates for this project, we require an inspection by one of your engineers to decide the following points:

(a) The best site for the new building in relation to water, electricity and transportation.

(b) The possibility of using the William's Lake type classroom-dormitory building as the first block in replacing this old school.

The Ermineskins Schools is identical with William's Lake in its need for replacement. They are both very old schools and parts have been standing for 80 or 90 years. They are frame structures and are a great menace to the lives of the pupils now boarding in them.

Your engineer should see Mr. Indian Superintendent Woodsworth concerning this school, as he will be able to explain the requirements at some length.

Morley (Stony-Sarose Agency) - This will be a classroom-dormitory block of the William's Lake prototype. An engineer will have to visit this school to decide whether the present heating facilities will be sufficient to heat the new building, or whether it will have to be self-contained.
Alberni (West Coast Agency) - We have included a sum of $60,000.00 for the erection of a four-classroom block. It is quite likely that provision will have to be made in 1952 for a hostel at this school to be used in accommodating the increasing number of high school pupils who are living there while attending high school in Alberni.

Inspector Davey has recommended the provision of a small frame building to accommodate 30 pupils and a staff of 2.

Mr. Indian Commissioner Arneil has suggested that the heating system installed in the new classroom block be sufficiently large to take care of the heating requirements of this hostel when it is built.

This classroom block is to be identical with the one previously erected at the school by your Department.

Alert Bay (Kwawkewlth Agency)

This is another four-classroom block and will not be the same as the Alberni classroom block, but will be based on the new plans and specifications which you are now preparing for a four-room school.

Day Schools

Moose Fort (James Bay Agency) - This is to be a four-room school based on the new design being prepared by your architects.

Norway House (Norway House Agency) - We will advise you later concerning our requirements at this project.

Dear Mr. Gibson:

We are now in a position to advise you concerning the new school building projects and the major repair projects which we would like to have undertaken by your Branch in the fiscal year 1950-51.

I have, therefore, had the Superintendent of Education prepare a list of such projects which have been divided into two parts:

(a) Erection of new Indian day and residential schools.
(b) Repairs to existing Indian day and residential schools.

A. ERECTION OF NEW INDIAN DAY AND RESIDENTIAL SCHOOLS

(1) Plans

We have previously requested from you on December 6th, 1949, the preparation of plans and specifications for the new one, two and four room schools which will be needed by our Education Division by April 1st, 1950. I understand that some progress has already been made in the preparation of these plans, and we hope that they will be finished in the near future.

(2) Buildings

Residential Schools

Seven Islands (Seven Islands Agency) - We understand that this project is already in hand.
Lower Post (Stikine Agency) - This project also is proceeding satisfactorily.

William's Lake (William's Lake Agency) - We are anxious to have tenders called in the near future for the erection of this classroom-dormitory block.

Cowessess (Crooked Lake Agency) - We have included an amount of $30,000.00 for the erection of a classroom-dormitory block identical to William's Lake. Would you please have one of your engineers do the necessary ground survey and check on heating arrangements. This building will be the same as that planned for William's Lake with the possible exception of the heating arrangement. Your heating engineer may have to report on the possibility of connecting this block with the existing heating facilities in the main building.

Ermineskins (Hobbema Agency) - While funds are not provided in our main Estimates for this project, we require an inspection by one of your engineers to decide the following points:

(a) The best site for the new building in relation to water, electricity and transportation.

(b) The possibility of using the William's Lake type classroom-dormitory building as the first block in replacing this old school.

The Ermineskins Schools is identical with William's Lake in its need for replacement. They are both very old schools and parts have been standing for 80 or 90 years. They are frame structures and are a great menace to the lives of the pupils now boarding in them.

Your engineer should see Mr. Indian Superintendent Woodsworth concerning this school, as he will be able to explain the requirements at some length.

Morley (Stony-Sarcee Agency) - This will be a classroom-dormitory block of the William's Lake prototype. An engineer will have to visit this school to decide whether the present heating facilities will be sufficient to heat the new building, or whether it will have to be self-contained.
Alberni (West Coast Agency) - We have included a sum of $60,000.00 for the erection of a four-classroom block. It is quite likely that provision will have to be made in 1952 for a hostel at this school to be used in accommodating the increasing number of high school pupils who are living there while attending high school in Alberni.

Inspector Davey has recommended the provision of a small frame building to accommodate 30 pupils and a staff of 2.

Mr. Indian Commissioner Arneil has suggested that the heating system installed in the new classroom block be sufficiently large to take care of the heating requirements of this hostel when it is built.

This classroom block is to be identical with the one previously erected at the school by your Department.

Alert Bay (Kwawkewlth Agency)

This is another four-classroom block and will not be the same as the Alberni classroom block, but will be based on the new plans and specifications which you are now preparing for a four-room school.

Day Schools

Moose Port (James Bay Agency) - This is to be a four-room school based on the new design being prepared by your architects.

Norway House (Norway House Agency) - We will advise you later concerning our requirements at this project.

Dear Sir:

Under separate cover I am returning the pamphlet on
stain-proof cleaning processes which I regret keeping so long.

As I previously remarked, I wish I were better equipped
technically to advise the operators of our Indian school
laundries on such points as:

(a) The use and care of machinery.
(b) The most efficient formulas for cleansing
with reference to the water that has to
be used.
(c) Job-analyses and training of workers.
(d) Lay-outs for new installations and for improve-
ment of existing installations.

As you know, some years ago in collaboration with the
soap companies, I tried to work out a formula for a universal
detergent and since then (I wish I may because of that) we
have seen the appearance of Fab, Vel, Dreft, etc., which are
rather too expensive for institutions which have to operate
on a tight budget. Our schools, accordingly, have to fall
back on simpler materials, and some of the workers whom I
have seen on the job very obviously need instruction comprehen-
sible by a person who has not studied the chemistry of washing.
Moreover, there is a considerable turnover of helpers in these laundries and even of the charge-hands and supervisors.

To give you an idea of the variety of water problems which have to be faced I attach a list of our residential schools with addresses showing their wide distribution. I have not visited all these school but I have seen the majority of them. Some like Kamloops, Lebret and Prince Albert have an imposing array of machinery with high pressure steam, and cater to 400 persons; some installations are geared to institutions serving only 50 people.

The job-analysis problem interests me because the helpers are usually Indian girls and laundry work is an aspect of vocational training. There is an increasing number of Indian Health Services sanatoria and hospitals in which competent laundry workers are required, and occasionally an Indian girl has found employment in a commercial laundry.

Thank you again for the advice and suggestions received.

Yours sincerely,

HORN DUOCREX

Floors are the most used and most abused portion of a building. They are often thoughtlessly treated or entirely neglected, and yet careful consideration given them will be repaid many times over.

Proper treatment of a floor by applying Horn Duocrex assures the user not only of a decided improvement in the appearance of the floor, but the wear and replacement cost can be avoided almost entirely. Cleaning and other upkeep expense can be reduced to a minimum.

HORN DUOCREX

Never becomes brittle. Does not dry with a slippery effect. Does not wear away quickly under heavy traffic. Does not require an expert to apply. Does not whiten in spots when wet. HORN DUOCREX

When applied to a concrete floor, Horn Duocrex is thin enough in body to work into the pores of the surface, sealing them so as to make a solid film over the entire surface. This develops a concrete floor that is waterproof (waterproof on the topside but it will not prevent water from coming through) and it serves to minimize the dusting of the concrete.

When Horn Duocrex is used on wood surfaces it accomplishes results similar to those secured with varnish. The fact that Horn Duocrex is thinner in body makes maximum penetration into the wood surface. The first application will disappear into the surface, and in the case of concrete would seal the second. This is not to its disadvantage because herein lies the secret of the success of the product. By penetrating the wood surface, Horn Duocrex fills the minute cells, reinforcing the entire surface and greatly increasing its resistance to wear.

HORN DUOCREX

Horn Duocrex is a perfect preservative, dust eliminator, wear reducer (coating), and waterproofing agent for floors.

Horn Duocrex is neither an oil dressing nor a varnish, but is a chemical compound of gums and preservatives designed after extensive research with the sole idea of producing a perfect dressing for floors.

Horn Duocrex may best be described as a thin bodied coating, having many of the characteristics of varnish and being applied in similar manner.

After Horn Duocrex has dried hard, the resulting surface is one that can be kept clean and attractive by merely dusting off.
SPECIFICATIONS FOR HORN DUOCREX

CONCRETE FLOORS

PREPARATION OF SURFACE
Careful preparation of concrete floors prior to the application of Duocrex is essential. The surface must be perfectly dry and free from oil, grease, wax, polish, and foreign matter. Scrubbing with Hornglaze Cleaner will remove ordinary traffic dirt and wax coatings.

To remove oil and grease, scrub with Hornglaze Cleaner and D-X Cleanser. Several coats may be necessary depending upon condition.

On concrete floors where oil and grease have penetrated too deeply remove with gasoline, naphtha or special grease removers.

APPLICATION
The first coat of Duocrex should be thoroughly brushed into the surface. Use a medium stiff bristle brush applying Duocrex into the pores of the concrete to assure satisfactory depth of penetration. Twenty-four hours should elapse before application of the second coat. Allow the second coat to dry for at least twelve hours before using the floor.

WOOD FLOORS

PREPARATION OF SURFACE
All oil, wax, grease, dirt and dust must be removed and the surface must be perfectly dry. Scrubbing with Hornglaze Cleaner and Horn D-X Cleanser or Maintenex is recommended. Previously varnished and painted floors should be sanded to remove the old finish before applying Duocrex. If flooring is open grain wood such as oak, Horn Paste Wood Finish should be used. On close grained woods on which a penetrant sealer is preferred, apply Horn Florene. Follow with a two-coat application of Duocrex.

APPLICATION
Duocrex is applied in two or three coats depending upon porosity. The first coat is applied by thoroughly brushing Duocrex into the pores. Twenty-four hours should elapse between coats. Treated surfaces may be put to traffic for at least twelve hours. Sixty degrees or above with good ventilation should be maintained in the building while floors are being treated.

Dear Col. Neary,

I received a letter recently from Neale, Stothard & Chapman, Plumbers of Brandon, Manitoba. I had looked forward to seeing you personally, but shall write instead.

It appears that much of the work connected with your Department is now handled from Regina, and they are adopting the cost plus method of remuneration, and that the Regina office has largely gone into the wholesale business themselves, where the procedure used to be that would specify the work required and call for tenders, which we all know is the most businesslike way, and generally most economical way, of having this work done. I think it has been very well shown in recent years that the cost plus method, so far as cheapness is concerned, is a delusion and a snare.

The firm referred to complains that it is very difficult for them to supply labor to do some work that may come upon them unexpectedly or to do it as cheaply as if they had time to tender themselves and get their labor resources arranged accordingly. I can understand very well the awkwardness of the position in which they are liable to be placed. Furthermore, I think you will recall personally that this firm has always cooperated most willingly toward giving good service and in making suggestions wherever in their opinion an economy can be effected by suggesting some minor changes in the original plan. I am sure their record with your Department will justify a large measure of confidence in their ability and their reliability.

Yours sincerely,

TO ALL: Indian Superintendents, Regional Supervisors of Indian Agencies, and the Indian Commissioner for British Columbia.

Information will be going forward within the next few days to the offices of the Regional Supervisors and the Indian Commissioner for B.C., regarding funds provided in the 1950-51 Welfare estimates under Allotments 10 and 18 for the repair of Indian dwellings, construction of Indian dwellings, and other activities involving expenditures chargeable to Allotments 10 and 18.

During the fiscal year 1949-50, the unsatisfactory situation was permitted to develop in several agencies whereby building material required was not requisitioned in sufficient time to permit the Departmental Purchasing Agent to invite competitive tenders and place purchase orders in the approved manner. With a view to avoiding situations of this nature during the coming year, and in order that full advantage may be taken of funds provided in the Welfare Appropriation, it is requested that all superintendents formulate their plans for the fiscal year 1950-51 and submit the same to the office of their Regional supervisors for approval as early as possible.

It is also noted that in many agencies little or no action was taken with respect to construction of Indian homes and repairs to existing dwellings until late in the year. This has necessitated construction during cold weather which is uneconomical and has resulted in delays in placing of orders for material due to congestion in the office of the Departmental Purchasing Agent, and inability of the Welfare Service staff to process requisitions for material and cash advances, tradesmen's accounts, etc., as expeditiously as is desirable. In order that these difficulties may be avoided during 1950-51 it is requested that all concerned give active consideration to the Welfare housing programme immediately.

Just as soon as the programme for the year has been arranged, it is requested that requisitions be prepared listing all building material required, and that the same be submitted through the offices of the Regional Supervisors and the Indian Commissioner for B.C., for approval and further departmental action.

Requests for Accountable Advances to pay labour should be submitted through the offices of the Regional supervisors and the Indian Commissioner for B.C., for approval, and if at all possible, these should be submitted in sufficient time to allow this office ten days from the date of the receipt of the request until the funds are required.

Accountable Advances should not be requested too long before they are required, however, and should not be in excess of requirements. If found in excess of requirements the excess should be refunded immediately under cover of a letter of explanation. If for any reason, an advance has been received which because of a change in plans is not required, it should be refunded immediately; not held until the end of the fiscal year or until the Branch has written numerous letters regarding the matter. Funds provided for a specific purpose must not be diverted to any other purpose.
In accordance with approved Departmental procedure, funds are advanced to pay wages on a day-labour basis only. If work of any nature is contemplated on a contract basis, the following regulations must be observed:

1. Except in emergencies all contracts involving expenditures in excess of $100 should be referred to this office for approval through the office of the Regional supervisor.

2. In emergencies the Regional Supervisor may authorize contracts up to a maximum of $500 provided the circumstances are reported to this office immediately.

3. In the event of contracts up to a maximum of $5,000, with the exceptions noted above, competitive tenders should be obtained and the same should be submitted to this office for approval. All draft contracts covering construction of buildings should be accompanied by plans and specifications in duplicate.

4. In the event of contracts involving expenditures in excess of $5,000 the same should be referred to this office before any other action is taken, as regulations covered by the Public Works Act stipulate that public works involving expenditures in excess of $5,000 must be advertised by public tender and that all tenders submitted must be accompanied by a deposit of 10% of the amount of the tender.

Notwithstanding the foregoing, contracts with Indians involving expenditures in excess of $100, but not exceeding $500, may be authorized by the Regional supervisor as a matter of routine, but all contracts should be numbered consecutively commencing with "No. 1" in each fiscal year, and the circumstances regarding each contract should be reported to this office immediately. If progress payments are made, the voucher or credit voucher covering each progress payment should show the consecutive progress payment number, the consecutive contract number, the total amount of the contract and the voucher covering the final payment should clearly indicate that it is the final payment.

Separate credit vouchers should be submitted covering payment of wages on a day-labour basis and progress payments on contracts.

Departmental regulations stipulate that except in emergencies orders for material or equipment involving expenditures in excess of $100 must be placed by the Departmental Purchasing Agent. In emergencies, Regional supervisors may authorize purchases up to $500 but every invoice covering an emergency purchase in excess of $100 must be submitted to the Departmental Purchasing Agent for a covering purchase order before it may be submitted to Treasury for payment; a detailed explanation of the circumstances is necessary.
Accounts covering material purchased, services rendered (contracts), and credit vouchers covering payment of wages on a day-labour basis should be submitted as promptly as possible. Credit vouchers should be submitted, preferably at the end of each pay period, and under no circumstance should their submission be delayed past the end of the month in which expenditures were incurred, except when unavoidable, accounts for material purchased and accounts covering contracts should be submitted to Head Office for payment.

When the Annual Welfare Estimates are being screened by the Treasury Board of the Privy Council in December each year preparatory to submission to Parliament it is difficult to argue successfully that certain items are necessary for the coming year if there are large unexpended balances in Allotments 10 and 15 at that date. It is imperative, therefore, that the building programme be commenced just as soon as weather conditions permit and that the main portion of it be completed by December 31st.

H. H. Jones,
Superintendent - Welfare Service.

Dear Sir:

Re: Repairs to Schools

I have for acknowledgment your letter of March 14th in which you have raised the fact that certain schools appear to have had repairs done by firms in excess of $5,000.00.

I would like to clarify for you the situation which existed at these various projects.

St. Paul's Residential School

We are not exactly certain what vouchers you used to reach the total mentioned in your letter of $10,061.08. However, we are inclined to feel that this amount included Vouchers 420 and 596, which total $4,900.00. This expenditure of $4,900.00 covered a new roof on the main building of the St. Paul's School.

In the fall of 1948, we secured an airforce building from a nearby air station, and moved it to the site of the St. Paul's School to be used as a classroom block. An endeavour was made to secure competitive bids on converting this building to our purposes, but we were unsuccessful, and as the accommodation was urgently required arrangements were made with Mr. Weston whom we had employed on previous occasions and whose work was always satisfactory.

I may add that Mr. Weston was the only contractor available in the district at that time who would go to the Reserve to work.
Payment of $2,739.00 covered the cost of providing a full basement. It was subsequently found necessary to provide extra windows and erect extra pillars in the building in order to strengthen it.

At first we did not intend to provide a tunnel from the main building to the classroom block, but subsequent investigation by our field officials resulted in a decision to provide this tunnel. This involved an expenditure of $701.81.

Other expenditures in connection with the classroom block followed as a result of endeavouring to convert a building intended for one purpose to an absolutely different purpose, and the actual work was done at different times in spite of the fact that when forwarding certain vouchers, the Indian Superintendent gave the same date on each voucher, although the expenditures had been authorized at different periods.

Sacred Heart Residential School

This school is situated near Brocket, Alberta, and our files do not show that Mr. Weston ever did any work on this building during the fiscal year 1949-50.

R.C.M.P. Building

We have no knowledge of this project, and the matter should be referred to Miss Walton.

U.C. Day School, Caughnawaga

When the new Roman Catholic school was completed during the past summer, it was decided to renovate two buildings which had been used for school purposes (these were known locally as Caughnawaga U.C. School and Caughnawaga Eastern School). There was an increased enrollment at the Caughnawaga U.C. School, and it was found that by renovating the Caughnawaga Eastern School, suitable additional classroom space could be provided.
This necessitated the employment of three teachers and it was decided to convert the former Caughnawaga U.C. School into a residence for the teachers. Both of these were old buildings, and in converting them we experienced the usual difficulties, namely, that when one change is made others are necessitated and could not be foreseen.

We tried to get a contractor to give us a firm bid on the work, but were unsuccessful. We then obtained the services of Mr. Jean Bedard to act as a general contractor in securing the labour and carrying out the work required. We feel that good value has been obtained for the expenditure incurred, and we now have two buildings which will meet the requirements of the teachers and pupils at the Caughnawaga U.C. School for some years to come, at a much lower cost than if we had endeavoured to erect a new building.

Carcross Residential School

The financial situation which arose at this school was due to an inexperienced Indian Superintendent who arranged for a contract without first obtaining proper authority, although lack of communication facilities to Carcross was partially to blame for his error.

For your information, I quote the following extract received from the Superintendent:

"May I first remind you that the Yukon Agency has been more or less dormant for a number of years during which no building has taken place; there was, therefore, no precedent for the sort of project I was asked to undertake. I consulted Part X (Construction and Engineering) of Indian Agent's Reference and Regulations, but apparently did not interpret Para 152 (Financial) right. The Director's letter of June 2nd, 1943, file 166-1-5 (E) stated that funds had been provided for the purchase of a prefabricated house, and I assumed, whether rightly or wrongly, that construction costs had been provided for in the Estimates by Headquarters."
"Robert Campbell of Whitehorse is the Yukon Agent for Prefabricated Structures, the firm supplying the house, and it is only natural that I referred to him for the erection of the Principal's residence. As this was a departure from the usual construction in the Yukon, being the first one erected, Mr. Campbell would not give me a firm estimate. He stated that he would superintend the construction of the building for cost of wages and materials purchased by him, plus 10 per cent. I regret to say, owing to my very frequent absences in the field during the summer months, I did not report this to you, but was under the impression I had done so. This error is the crux of the unfortunate subsequent happenings. There is no written contract with Robert Campbell."

Our Minister is aware of the contents of the above letter.

Yours sincerely,

To: Indian Commissioner for British Columbia; Regional Supervisors, and Indian Superintendents:

REPAIRS and MAINTENANCE TO INDIAN DAY SCHOOLS

GENERAL POLICY

Each Indian Superintendent is regarded as the official School Trustee for the Indian Day Schools in his Agency. Therefore, it is his direct responsibility to ensure that the principals and teachers of these schools maintain the building and that premises are clean and neat at all times. Each principal or teacher of an Indian day school has more responsibility than the corresponding principal or teacher of a provincial school. They have no Board of School Trustees immediately available and must therefore exercise greater supervision and control over the Indian school concerned.

Regional Supervisors are naturally expected to inspect the classrooms and teacherages in the course of their routine visits.

MAINTENANCE

(a) CARETAKING

In the small one-room school this is usually done either by (a) hiring a part-time janitor or by (b) paying the teacher for janitor services. A small amount per classroom is usually allowed in return for sweeping and fuelling. Many of the small chores SHOULD be done by the school children, on a monitor basis, as is done in nearly all well conducted public schools. The Department is paying all the school operating expenses and surely the older Indian children can do some of the cleaning work.

Many teachers might use the last hour of the school week on Friday afternoon for a thorough schoolroom cleaning. The older pupils set to and each, with his or her own task, scrub the floor, the desks, wash the windows, dust and generally freshen up the schoolroom. This takes some organization ahead of time by the teacher, by dividing the class into working gangs, having the hot water and janitor supplies ready, etc. Under (b) compensation for those who perform truly janitorial duties should be made from the "janitor allowance".

If this is laid down as a definite part of the weekly programme, many of the caretaking worries can be eliminated. In some schools we have more correspondence on the files about caretaking than about teaching the pupils or any other topic.

Indian Superintendents must therefore impress upon teachers the need for a little energy on their part in solving this cleaning problem. It will not do for them to merely sit back and blame the Indian janitor if things are not clean. They must co-operate by training the children to accept the responsibility for housekeeping activities which will lighten the burden on janitors.
When school closes each day, the various monitors should proceed with the cleaning of the blackboards, the checking of the toilets, the filling of the water cooler, etc. This must be done in an organized way with a list of monitors for each duty posted weekly. Where the teacher is aided by monitor devices, some teachers might wish to reward these children. The cleanliness of the room can easily be ensured by having each child responsible for the space under or near his or her own desk. The children should NEVER be dismissed at recess, noon or the close of the day without a check being made of the floor near their desks. In fact, a row should not be dismissed until the floors near their desks are clean. If children know they are being held responsible for keeping the floor clear from paper, peelings, etc., they will see to it that they put such scraps in the waste paper basket.

An article on this will appear in the next issue of the School Bulletin. When it appears, Indian Superintendents should regularly check on their monthly visits into this matter of classroom, toilet and playground cleanliness. No excuses should be accepted for carelessness in this matter. We are paying our teachers good salaries and expect that they will help in this way. Furthermore, this will do a great deal towards impressing upon Indian children the need for cleanliness in their persons and in their surroundings.

(b) PAINTING

This is a major item each year in our schools. We can effect a great saving by buying the paint needed through the Departmental Purchasing Agent. This may take longer but if there is an intelligent anticipation of your requirements, we can get the paint to you in time for the school holiday period. Each year the Education Division is literally swamped with requisitions for paint, brushes, etc. This reaches its climax in August when some Superintendents suddenly realize that the summer holidays are half over and that their school or schools have not yet been painted. Then they sit back and wonder why it takes so long for the paint to arrive. If they could only see us in Ottawa during those two months with our desks piled high with requisitions for paint, etc., from many other Superintendents, they would realize why such delays occur. This is not fair to the Education Division and just when we are trying to locate new teachers, to get on with the building of new schools, and other immediate business, we get requisitions for paint and requests for accountable advances, etc., from Indian Superintendents who have forgotten to forward such requests during the spring months.

APRIL is the month during which all Superintendents should forward their requests for items needed to keep their day schools in good condition. All officials needing paint for their schools can requisition NOW for the supplies which they will require. An example as to the savings which can be made by buying our paint through the Purchasing Agent and then arranging for an Indian or a painter to apply it is the following:

An Indian Superintendent got local prices from a painter for a school, as follows:

| Item       | Quantity | Unit Price | Total Price |
|------------|----------|------------|-------------|
| Gallons of paint | 93       | $5.75      | $534.75     |
| Undercoat  | 20       | $5.25      | $105.00     |
| Sealer     | 6        | $5.80      | $34.80      |
| Enamel     | 16       | $10.00     | $160.00     |
| Turps      | 7        | $2.00      | $14.00      |
|            |          |            | $848.55     |

The Departmental Purchasing Agent secured tenders for the same type of paint, as follows:

| Item       | Company A | Company B |
|------------|-----------|-----------|
| Gallons of paint | $2.95    | $274.35   |
| Undercoat  | $4.12     | $4.14     |
| Sealer     | $3.40     | $3.42     |
| Enamel     | $5.20     | $5.04     |
| Turps      | $1.37     | $1.10     |
| Containers |           | $1.91     |
|            | $469.74   | $378.59   |
It only requires simple arithmetic to note that the Department would have saved $378.61, or nearly 45% by buying the paint from Company A. This company is one of the largest manufacturers of paint in Canada and supplies a product which meets our government specifications. (We could have saved enough money to paint two small schools by buying through the Purchasing Agent).

Each year, we have a large number of schools to paint. From the above illustration you can therefore appreciate the fact that the most economical way of doing the job is by purchasing the paint directly from the manufacturer through the Departmental Purchasing Agent. In this way we can use our money to best advantage and it will enable us to paint more schools each year.

COLOUR SCHEME:

While we have no particular interest in the colour scheme as requested by individual teachers for their teacherages, we must insist on pastel colours and light shades in the classrooms. We would recommend the following shades:

(1) Classroom Ceiling White or off white
(2) Classroom Upper Walls Pale green such as pastel green Arcadian light green.
(3) Lower Walls Darker green, equivalent to Milen green or Thistle green.

NOTE:
Where classrooms have lower walls of plywood, this should be left in light Oak varnish.

REPAIRS

In submitting requests for repairs such as replacement of verandahs, etc., there are two methods of procedure:

(a) By purchasing the materials and having the work done by day labour;
(b) By letting a contract.

When submitting a requisition for the materials required in following plan (a), be sure to give specific details of the lumber required and also to advise the name of local suppliers who could be contacted by the Purchasing Agent.

In following plan (b), try to obtain more than one fixed tender and be sure to give the name and address and to attach a written bid from the firm or firms concerned. If you cannot obtain more than one tender, you must state this in your covering letter.

SUMMARY

Submit NOW:
(a) All paint requirements for your day schools, classifying under exterior paint, interior paint, varnishes, etc.;
(b) All requisitions for desks, blackboards, cement, lumber, etc.

Submit LATER:
(a) All labour tenders for painting and repairs;
(b) All tenders for major alterations, etc.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Re: P.C. 56/222 of January 19th, 1950.
Purchase and Maintenance of Equipment,
Repairs and Improvements to Church-Owned Indian Residential Schools

It has been found necessary to amend the above Order-in-Council.

The amounts requested in Section 1 apply to schools owned by the Church of England. At the time the 1949-50 Estimates were prepared, it was expected that arrangements would be made for the purchase of the Fort George C.E. and Wabasca C.E. Indian Residential Schools. It was not possible to carry out this arrangement, but in order to assist the M.S.C.C., it was necessary to expend an amount of $689.36 at Fort George and $439.92 at Wabasca during the fiscal year 1949-50.

We provided in the 1949-50 Estimates an amount of $3,500.00 for expenditures at Carcross C.E. Indian Residential School, but it was found necessary to only expend part of this amount.

The amounts requested in Section 2 for Joussard R.C. and Christie R.C. Indian Residential Schools, represent small amounts for the purchase of materials over and above the amounts specifically provided for these two schools. The Squamish R.C. Residential School was in very poor condition, and in order to keep it in operation, it was essential that the amount we expended was much larger than the amount specifically mentioned in the Order in Council.
We were unable to complete all the work at the Cariboo R.C. Residential School that we contemplated when preparing the 1949-50 Estimates.

Director.
Memorandum:

SUPERINTENDENT OF EDUCATION

Proposed Design No. 929

Commendable features are:

(1) Nine feet of cupboard (horizontal measurement). These cupboards should be not less than six feet in height. Eight feet is not too high.

(2) Blackboard at the front and side is adequate. The rear wall should be display board.

(3) The shelves below the window are an advantage. They should be equipped with sliding doors.

Would it be possible to include an exit on the same side of the building as the window-bank? The window nearest the blackboard might be the panic door and thus allow three feet of blackboard on the opposite wall where it would be most convenient. This would avoid a hole in what is presumed to become the west wall.

The lavatories are shown as having only one type of fixture. The design should allow for tables on which to stand wash basins with mirrors above. The lavatory next to the bedroom is reserved for the teachers. No wash stand or bath-tub is shown. Because of the roundabout way to the kitchen a hot bath is likely to involve a good deal of inconvenience. Perhaps the linen closet between the halls could be abandoned and a door inserted there. Otherwise the living-room must be traversed at all times.
In the bedrooms windows are shown in one wall only. Most people would, in a corner bedroom, prefer windows on both walls.

It is noted that the classroom windows face the east. I suppose we could turn the building a little toward the south-east in northern latitudes.

C.A.F. Clark,
Educational Survey Officer.
Ottawa, 19 April, 1950.

Re: One Room Day School, Plan 888

With reference to your 205-6-1-2 of January 27th regarding suggestions to improvement of plan number 888, I beg to report as follows:

1. I consider the lack of a full basement a great handicap. The installation of a furnace is the major expense which is evidently to be provided for in the next basement. It was our considered opinion in the construction of the Louis Bull Day School that a full basement would have cost no more than the existing foundation construction. In conversation with Mr. B. F. Neary, Superintendent of Education, the added cost was considered in likely installations such as furnace and water system. The advantage of a full basement in the Hobbema Day School is quite evident. In this building, the children are able to use the basement as a play room and cloak room which is utilized fully during the cold winter months, which make up the bulk of the school term. A workshop could also be installed.

2. The Hobbema Day School has yeast toilets which are installed in the basement and are very efficient. Mr. F.F. Neary has asked me to supply the name of the company installing this efficient, sanitary arrangement.

3. The addition of another room to the teacherage should be provided for. It is my opinion that our best teachers, especially in isolated day schools, will be married men with families.

4. There is a great lack of cupboard and storage space in plan number 888. It is quite evident in the Louis Bull Day School that the school supplies, janitor supplies and numerous other items utilized in a day school set up, will have to be stored under lock and key. No such storage space is provided and certainly will have to be. Mr. Neary verbally authorized me to provide such space under the windows or in the halls. Whatever arrangements are made now should certainly be included in a plan.

5. The preparation and supplying of the noon hot drink and biscuit involves the use of facilities of what we expect to be an over-crowded classroom. Again, the use of a common room in the basement would be of great advantage. I have noted that when the lunch is furnished in the class room, efficiency and cleanliness are involved.

DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE, CANADA

OTTAWA April 23, 1949.

PLEASE ADDRESS
THE DEPUTY MINISTER OF JUSTICE
OTTAWA

Re: Orders in Council authorizing the Purchase of Land or Payment of Compensation for Expropriated Land

Dear Sir:

Orders in Council authorizing the acquisition of land almost invariably require that a good title, free from all encumbrances, be acquired as a condition precedent to payment of the purchase moneys. It frequently appears, upon title to land being searched by agents of the Minister of Justice, that the vendor's title is subject to a reservation in respect of mines or minerals or to easements or encroachments which do not affect the use of the land for which it is being acquired. In such cases, it has, in the past, been necessary to have the Order in Council amended to permit the purchase price to be paid for the land subject to the reservation, encumbrance or encroachment.

To avoid delays and inconvenience, I suggest, for your consideration, that when authority is being sought from the Governor in Council for such transactions, the Report to Council should be so framed as to seek authority to pay the purchase money upon obtaining a good title free from all encumbrances, reservations or encroachments other than such encumbrances, reservations or encroachments as, in the opinion of your Minister, do not affect the use of the land for the purpose for which it is being acquired.

Yours truly,

(sgd) W. R. Jackett

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Septic Toilets

In our new one-room day school (plan 933) it is our intention to install septic toilet combinations. At present under plan 886 it costs over $1,000 to provide a combination toilet and storage shed.

In our new plan No. 933, copies of which I attach, you will note that the toilet and storage shed has been completely eliminated. Instead, septic toilet combinations are called for. These are provided where no running water or electricity is available and shall be installed by lowering pipes down the unit. You will note in the plans that two toilet bowls are provided for boys, two toilet bowls for girls, and one for the teacher. This means that a five bowl system is required with correspondingly sized septic tank, ventilator, vent pipes, etc.

As we will be needing a number of these units for these new schools, I have recommended that they be purchased through your office rather than through the contractor. In this way we will ensure that a proper septic tank is provided and also that the piping is of good quality. Otherwise, contractors can obtain cheaper units with narrow gauge septic tanks, galvanized piping, etc., which while suitable for homes and churches, would not be satisfactory for school use.

INSTALLATION:

In securing tenders, you should obtain two types:

(a) for installation in Ontario - for schools of this type which we will be erecting in this province;

(b) f.s.o.b. Toronto - for shipping to Western and Northern Canada where installation will have to be made by local contractors in accordance with instructions to be issued by the company concerned.
There are only two companies to my knowledge which manufacture this equipment:

(1) Rural Sewage Disposal Equipment, 2067 Dundas St. W., Toronto,
(2) Caustic Sanitation Limited, 21 Ridley Blvd., Toronto.

I attach copies of advertising folders. I would be pleased to have Mr. Simard drop over and discuss with me the attached specification or to provide any information which you might require.

New One-room Bay School Plan

Please find herein the plan for the one-room Bay school with attached teacher's residence which is to replace SSE.

In accordance with recommendations made previously by Regional Supervisors we have made three major changes:

(1) A basement has been provided under the main school building. This will provide ample storage space for fuel, etc.

(2) The outside toilet unit has been eliminated entirely and attached to one end of the school is a septic toilet system. These are the septic toilets in wide use now in schools in Ontario and to some lesser extent in Western Canada. They provide for a disposal system which should eliminate many of the caretaking worries in our rural one-room schools. I am attaching descriptive folders as prepared by one company and will shortly send you similar folders prepared by another company.

These units operate similarly to a septic tank although only require the addition of one pail of water per day. The steel in the septic tank unit is provided by the company with all fixtures. When a school is being erected by contract, the Department will provide these units. There are certain specifications clearly laid down for the same.
of steel to be provided for the school service tanks and we wish to ensure that an inferior product is not substituted.

You will note that these toilets are placed on the teaching end of the building so that the teacher would have access to her toilet without leaving the building.

This will mean that only one building will be provided so that the entire school plant is under one roof.

(3) The stoves used in heating the school have been eliminated and a hot air furnace is substituted. This is also in accordance with your recommendations and not only eliminates two stoves but also provides a larger classroom space.

You will note that the drawings call for artificial brick siding. Asbestos shingles or cedar siding can be substituted for this at the discretion of the Regional Supervisors.

You will notice minor points of improvement such as the elimination of one chimney; plywood dadoes below blackboards and in corridors; double shelving under the window ledges and large cupboards; and ventilators for the attics.

Memorandum:

SUPERINTENDENT OF EDUCATION

Proposed Day School at Witchesan Reserve

During my most recent conversation with Mr. Regional Supervisor Ostrander (in January) he told me that he wished to postpone any construction at this point so that construction might proceed on one of his reserves where prospects for a successful school seem brighter.

The present potential school population is only 22 and of this number we may assume that some are already enrolled at residential schools. It seems to me that the most convenient way of disposing of the language problem would be to arrange for some children, during the next year, to attend residential school so that when a day school is built and the teacher appointed, the teacher will not face an entirely primitive situation. It is too difficult to find teachers who are able to face and to control successfully such situations. A lowering of the population in the manner of James Bay and Abitibi areas appears to be indicated before we embark on a full-fledged, full-scale school.

ALL FUELS

All fuels may be used with the insulated, acid proof Van-Packer chimney. High temperatures incidental to most fires, badly adjusted heaters or flue defects are not a problem with Van-Packer chimneys. LOW COST

It can be easily installed by the average workman even after the house is built, thus eliminating very laborious and overhead due to delays in construction. It is shipped complete, packaged and ready for immediate installation.

LIGHT-WEIGHT

Many times lighter than brick (+10 lbs. against 220 lbs.), the lightweight Van-Packer chimney is suspended between the ceiling joists when used with a floor furnace or basement furnace. It is suspended between the ceiling joists when a utility room below is used. Supported over the heater it requires no floor space, eliminates the need of a foundation.

JOINTS

The average brick chimney has about 5000 joints which are loosely made with various mortars. Weather and corrosive flue gases eat holes in the mortar joints, resulting in low draft, poor heater operation and fire hazard.

The Van-Packer chimney has an average of only five joints, made in the simplest and most effective way. Set in acid proof cement, they form perfect flames, and permanently bonded with acid proof cement. To prevent expansion and shrinkage, the sections are clamped together with joint bands, thus assuring perfect alignment and permanent sealing of joints. These joints are not affected by building settlement.

Tests prove that the Van-Packer joint is not affected by extreme temperature, boiling acid solutions, freezing and thawing, heat shock or harsh treatment during construction. This joint construction results in a continuous chimney wall which is permanently leakproof.

INSTALLATION

Easy to install. The Van-Packer chimney is packaged and shipped complete—ready for quick and easy assembly and installation. Requires no special tools.

1. Cut holes in floor, ceiling and roof.
2. Nest chimney support in place and set first section with joint cement provided.
3. Set second section with joint cement and lock joint with joint bands provided. Repeat until all sections are installed.
4. Set roof housing in place and flash to roof.
5. Set cap on top section with joint cement and fasten to housing with sheet-metal screws.

Heating plant performance depends on chimney draft. The hotter the gas in the chimney the better the draft. After gases enter the chimney they should be kept as hot as possible to preserve draft. The Van-Packer insulated chimney wall does this.

Masonry chimneys not being insulated, cool the flue gases quickly. This cooling produces much less draft than the Van-Packer chimney produces because of its insulated wall.

The 3" Van-Packer chimney wall has an insulating value equal to a 2½" brick chimney wall or 50° concrete chimney wall. The Van-Packer chimney produces adequate and better draft, for safer and more efficient operation of the heating equipment.

All materials used have a long record of field performance with proven quality and permanence. The best of these materials have been combined and molded into the safer and more efficient Van-Packer chimney.

Acids produced in the combustion of all fuels do not affect and eat masonry in the Van-Packer chimney, gases contact only fire clay tile which is impervious to acids, heat shock, freezing and thawing. This tile lining is easily cast into the light weight refractory concrete wall.

The Van-Packer chimney is built to last as long as the house it serves.

APPEARANCE

The decorative roof housing of the Van-Packer chimney is furnished in conventional chimney designs which harmonize with most roofs. They may be painted on the job in any color preferred. They are designed in pleasing proportions to replace conventional square chimney lines and are available in a variety of dimensions to suit requirements.

SAFETY

Comparative Performance Tests
on Van-Packer Chimney and Standard Code Chimney

This report covers comparative performance of a 17 foot Van-Packer chimney and a 17 foot Standard Code brick chimney on an intermittent firing test and on a maximum fuel burning rate test. Those tests were performed at Buda, Illinois on chimneys erected by the Van-Packer Corporation.

Test Conditions:

The chimneys used in this test were erected next to each other to a height of 17' 12" above the grate. The code chimney consisted of one course of 4" brick around a standard 8" x 12" flue liner. The inside dimensions of the flue liner were 10.02" x 6.17" with an area of 61.8 square inches.

The Van-Packer chimney consisted of seven 2 foot lengths supported on a stand to bring the tops of the chimneys to the same height. The inside diameter of the Van-Packer flue was 7.25 inches with a flue area of 41.30 square inches.

Conclusions:

1. The Van-Packer chimney develops 34% more draft than a code chimney under identical firing conditions when burning Southern Illinois bituminous coal.
2. The Van-Packer chimney shows considerably less heat loss than the code chimney.
3. The Van-Packer chimney is far less subject to condensation than the code chimney since during a four minute interval from zero fire it had an average exit flue gas temperature of 470°F compared to an average of 304°F on the code chimney during the same interval.
4. The Van-Packer chimney is more suitable for intermittent firing with either coal or oil because it develops maximum draft in less than one-half the time required by the code chimney.
5. The Van-Packer chimney has a maximum coal burning rate equal to 1.9 times the burning rate of a code chimney.
6. The Van-Packer flue has a venting capacity far in excess of the code flue as is shown by the coal burning rate test.

Dear Sir,

In further reply to your favor of the 17th inst., relating to inspection of Indian Schools, I have to submit for the information of His Honor the Lieutenant Governor, the following explanations received from Mr. McCallum, Inspector of Schools, for the District of Pictou and South Colchester.

Mr. McCallum reports that on his visit to the locality of the Indian School during the latter part of the Summer term of 1883, he found the school closed, though it had been in session during the earlier part of the term. During the whole of the succeeding term (Nov 1st 1883 - April 31st 1884) the school remained closed. It was the Inspector's intention to inspect the school last term (May 1st 1884 - Oct 31st 1884) but his plans were interrupted by reasons which no doubt the Department of Indian Affairs would accept as good as sufficient.

I may add that Mr. McCallum who is a most conscientious and pains-taking official expects to visit the school within the ensuing three weeks and that his report will be promptly forwarded.

I beg to enclose for transmission, Inspector Gunn's account for inspection, accidentally omitted from my last.

I am your obedient Servant,

(Signed) Daniel Allison

Sir,

Your letter in reference to Indian Schools has been lying on my desk so long unanswered that I owe you an apology and an explanation.

A good many years ago, I used to visit those schools till I found that I had little or no influence over them or control over their teachers; so I ceased to inspect them. In recent years, I was under the impression that Mr. Boyd, the Superintendent of Agencies, was doing the necessary inspection.

There being no Trustees or other local control, over these schools, I should like to be informed as to:

(a) What are supposed to be the relations between the teacher and the inspector,

(b) How far is the former responsible to the latter for the management of the school, and

(c) On whose recommendation is a teacher to be appointed or liable to be dismissed?

I may state that I have just been informed that the teacher of the Salmon River school, this County, Miss Devereaux, has been dismissed to make room for a young man having neither license...
experience nor professional training; whereas the deposed teacher is an experienced and capable one, having a Normal College Diploma—a young lady of irreproachable character in every respect, and (tho, I presume, this does not count) an orphan—fatherless and motherless. Is it too much to ask the reason for this change and at whose instance it was made? Because if it is as is commonly reported, I would like to say that I should much prefer to have nothing to do with these schools if they are to be controlled by political influence. The schools of Nova Scotia are not managed on those principles.

I was informed by Mr. Boyd, some weeks ago, that the school at Malagawatch, Inverness County, was closed, not to be re-opened till some time in January. Hence I should not have been able to visit that one, i.e., any case, before now, so I decided to visit neither till I heard from you.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient Servant,

Inspector of Schools.

Sir,

Under the agreement entered into with the Government of the Province of Nova Scotia for the securing to the Indian schools in that province the same system of inspection at the hands of the government officers as the public schools there enjoy, and which agreement is still in existence and working satisfactorily, the fee allowed to each inspector was at the rate of $5.00 per class-room inspected, together with actual travelling expenses from the nearest point on the inspector's regular route of inspection.

As the fees allowed have remained at the same rate during the past thirty-five years, it is considered that the time has arrived when an increase should be granted for the work performed by the inspectors, which has been invariably satisfactory. I have, therefore, to inform you that, from January 1st, next, the fee allowed will be at the rate of $7.50 for the inspection of each class-room, as well as the payment of the actual travelling expenses of the inspectors from the nearest point on their regular route, schools to be inspected semi-annually as in the past; such fees and expenses to be paid, as in the past, upon receipt of accounts for the amount due at the above rate.

I shall be pleased if you will inform your inspectors in whose districts Indian schools are located of the increase in the fees allowed and that they should render their accounts accordingly.

Your obedient servant,

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE

About 1885 an arrangement was made with the Ontario Department of Education for the inspection of the Indian schools. It was agreed that the remuneration paid to the inspectors would be at the rate of $6.00 per room, plus the actual travelling expenses from the nearest point on their regular route. This arrangement obtains today. Inspections are made semi-annually.

In Quebec and the Maritime Provinces an arrangement was made in 1886 with the Departments of Education on similar lines as for Ontario. The rate of remuneration was $5.00 per room plus expenses. Since January 1, 1921, in Quebec and the Maritime Provinces the inspectors have received $7.50 per room plus expenses. Inspections are made semi-annually.

Arrangements have been concluded this year with the Prairie Provinces. In Manitoba we have agreed to pay the inspectors at the rate of $15.00 per classroom plus expenses. In Saskatchewan and Alberta a flat rate of $20.00 per school is being charged for one inspection per year. In the case of the last two provinces, no allowances are made in connection with expenses.

Dear Sir:

In further reply to your communication of June 27 in reference to the inspection of the Indian Day Schools at Whyconagh and Middle River, I beg to say in continuation of my note of July 3 that Mr. James MacKinnon, Inspector of Schools at Baddeck, N.S., has written me in reply to your correspondence as follows:

"After repeated visits to these schools, followed by continued disregard for the recommendations made by me in connection with them, I came to the conclusion that nobody was telling us seriously the matter of the education of the Indians in this part of the country, and I did not want to continue to be party to what appeared to me to be nothing but a farce.

The Department of Indian Affairs has my reports covering several years and by comparison of them with the conditions they can now find in the schools referred to they can see just what I mean in the rather strong statement in the foregoing paragraph.

I may say however, that if the Department wishes me to give it another trial, I shall do so, but I cannot promise to continue from year to year, reporting the same old deficiencies and inefficiencies, with no hope of improvement.

You will see that Inspector MacKinnon takes an interest in the schools and has been desirous of making improvements. He evidently considers the equipment of these schools to be insufficient and not creditable to the inspecting official who would continue to supervise them without being able to bring them into a creditable condition. You cannot do better than to co-operate with an honest and competent Inspector. I presume your difficulty will be of the same class as our own -- the lack of sufficient funds provided by Parliament.

I am,

Yours very truly,

- In inspecting -
In inspecting Indian schools, you should pay particular attention to the academic qualifications of the teacher; the progress of the pupils and offer recommendations concerning buildings or equipment with a view to making the instruction more attractive and efficient. It should be remembered that the teacher of an Indian day school is not directly responsible to the public school inspector, as Indian day schools are controlled and managed solely by this Department.

However, a teacher is expected to carry out the instructions of the inspector in regard to the work and the general management of the school. You should feel at liberty to report to this Department any failure on the part of the teacher to carry out any reasonable suggestions made by you.

The appointment and dismissal of teachers rests solely with the Department of Indian Affairs. Recommendations from you in this connection, however, will receive consideration. The course of study prescribed by the Nova Scotia Department of Education should be followed as far as possible.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.
